otherData.headline: Best Face Masks To Keep You Safe And Warm In The Winter During COVID-19
otherData.short_description: Here's what to look for and what to avoid in the cold weather to protect you during the pandemic.

articleContent: Three seasons have passed since COVID-19 first broke out, and now the Northern Hemisphere is facing a long, masked winter. Weâ€™ll need to adapt our current face mask-wearing practices for the realities of living in a colder environment.

The good news (if anything related to this pandemic can be called good news) is that you wonâ€™t have to change anything youâ€™re doing â€” as long as youâ€™re already following WHO recommendations to wear a three-layered nonmedical mask, one with an absorbent inner layer near the mouth, a middle filtration layer and an outer layer. But do you need to bulk up and wear a woolen mask, or will that only put you more at risk? Experts gave us answers.
Your best bet: cotton masks with baby wipe filters

Everyone seems to have an opinion about face masks, even if itâ€™s just about what type of fabric they should be made from. In the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, two professors at the University of British Columbia tested 41 different mask and filter materials to find out how well they blocked particles out while still remaining breathable.

The study they published in August showed that a mask with two layers of quilting cotton was the best bet for effectiveness and wearability. They found that a dried-out baby wipe filter was almost as breathable as a commercial nonsurgical mask but still effective at blocking particles. In fact, the wipes filtered out up to 80% of three-micron particles and more than 90% of 10-micron particles. (The COVID-19 particle is around 0.1 micron in size, but it always attaches to something larger, like the droplets produced by breathing, talking and coughing, which are typically larger than five microns.)
How cold weather affects face masks
Winter mask-wearing provides some upsides for people who are perennially chilly all season long.

â€œOne of the most commonly reported negative side effects is warmth and overheating,â€ said Jaimie Meyer, a physician specializing in infectious diseases at Yale Medicine and an associate professor at Yale School of Medicine. â€œSo if your environment is colder or youâ€™re just one of those people who are always cold in winter, then a mask might feel more comfortable now.â€

Colder weather can create condensation from breathing, which wets the layers of the mask. Bring a spare mask if youâ€™re going to be out for a while, and switch it out when your mask feels damp. And if your glasses fog up while youâ€™re wearing the mask, Meyer suggested washing the glasses with soap and water, then rinsing and drying them before you head outdoors.
â€œEnough soap particles will remain on the lenses to prevent them from fogging up,â€ she said.
Donâ€™t knit yourself a woolen mask this winter
If youâ€™ve become a dedicated quarantine crafter, you might be thinking that knitting your very own mask is a brilliant, homespun idea. The quick answer: Stop yourself.

â€œThere are two problems with this idea. The first reason is that hand-knitted items will have large holes in them and thatâ€™s the opposite of what you want, since the tighter the weave, the more effective the fabric with filtration,â€ said Jing Wang, one of the professors who carried out the University of British Columbia study. â€Secondly, thereâ€™s the issue of comfort. We tested fleece and wool fabrics and found that theyâ€™re poorly tolerated due to overheating and moisture buildup. In other words, that knitted mask could cause overheating.â€
Instead, she referred back to the results of her study that showed double-knit cotton was the most effective common fabric for filtering out particles while still allowing for breathability.
Two masks arenâ€™t always better than one
As COVID-19 cases continue to rise, some people are wondering if wearing two masks at a time might be better than wearing just one. Again, not so fast.

â€œSometimes in a patient room, Iâ€™ll wear an N95 mask with another mask over it in an attempt to protect that precious personal protective equipment,â€ Meyer said. â€œItâ€™s very uncomfortable, and I canâ€™t talk for more than a few minutes, so I wouldnâ€™t recommend that people try it as part of their everyday activities.â€

â€œWearing two masks might help in terms of offering more protection, but it also might make it harder for you to breathe,â€ Wang added. â€œWhatever youâ€™re doing, you need to strike a balance between whatâ€™s safe and what you can comfortably tolerate.â€
What to look for in a winter mask
In addition to making sure your mask is made of the right material, you also want to be aware of its design.
â€œIt should have a good piece of wire or aluminum around the nose, and the straps should fit snugly around the ears or around the head,â€ Wang said.
When it comes to the fit, itâ€™s important to keep the mask over your nose and entirely over your chin.

â€œThe mask should be slightly lifted off your face, not stuck to your mouth and nose,â€ she said. â€œA small space there allows for the exchange of air across the entire surface of the mask. Just be sure you donâ€™t have a gigantic dome far in front of your face. That creates dead space for CO2 to be retained, and your breathing can become compromised. If you notice that youâ€™re breathing faster or deeper when wearing a certain mask, that can be whatâ€™s happening.â€
And if you find it difficult to wear face masks that loop around your ears, there are alternatives.
â€œIâ€™ve seen masks that tie above the neck and above the head, which can help you avoid tying something behind the back of your ears and feeling uncomfortable,â€ Meyer said.
How to test whether your mask fits properly
Wang offered a quick tip for testing whether or not a mask is properly â€œsealedâ€ around your face.
â€œAdjust the mask and take a deep breath through your mouth. If the mask suctions inward and then re-expands when you exhale, youâ€™ve got a relatively good seal,â€ she said.
And what about those â€œneck gaiterâ€ masks that cover both your face and neck?

â€œThey donâ€™t give you that tight fight you need,â€ Meyer said. â€œMy two very athletic sons keep telling me how comfortable they are to wear, and I get that. But when one of them told me how he loved being able to drink water right through his gaiter, I explained that being porous is the exact opposite quality you want in a face mask. If you hold up a mask to the light and see light shining through, itâ€™s not a good mask.â€
What to avoid in a winter face mask
You should consider the size of your head and face when choosing a mask.

â€œI see people all the time who are wearing masks that are too small for them, so they basically become chin straps,â€ Meyer said. â€œAnd Iâ€™ve seen people wearing their masks upside down, so take a look at the picture on the package to figure out which end is up.â€
And some masks should be avoided altogether.
â€œIf you see that a mask is obviously poorly constructed or if it smells of chemicals, I wouldnâ€™t wear it,â€ Wang said.
Winter face masks to wear right now
Note: None of the face masks listed below are a replacement for medical-grade PPE, and theyâ€™re not intended to replace other recommended measures to stop the spread of COVID-19.
Coordinate with your winter coat

â€œWe were one of the first fashion brands to get into the nonmedical mask market,â€ said Aaron Luo, CEO of Caraa, a sport bag and accessory brand based in New York City. â€œThe exterior of this mask is lined with a 185-gram cotton twill to provide that extra warmth factor, and weâ€™re offering a range of winter colors that complement outerwear.â€
5 masks for $25 from Caraa Sport
Organic masks
Thicker cotton canvas makes these a warmer option, according to Jessica Hann, vice president of brand marketing for Avocado Green Mattress, an eco-conscious mattress and bedding company.
â€œWe make some of the only Global Organic Textile Standard organic-certified masks on the market, which we feel is pretty important for something thatâ€™s covering your mouth,â€ Hann told HuffPost.
Organic cotton face mask, 4 for $30 from Avocado Green Mattress
Hope for glasses wearers
Mask brand Lekko was founded in WrocÅ‚aw, Poland, one of the most polluted cities in Europe.

â€œWe started to look for protective equipment, but none of it was good enough to convince us to use it, so we started our own company,â€ founder Adam MuszyÅ„ski told HuffPost. â€œOur masks are airtight in the nose area, which helps to reduce foggy glasses.â€
Antipollution scarf/face mask, $59.90 from Lekko
Designer knitwear from St. John
A wool circular scarf is built right into this lightweight, luxurious mask.
â€œWe use the highest-quality Italian yarns, woven by special knitting techniques that our artisans have perfected,â€ Eran Cohen, CEO of the luxury fashion brand St. John, told HuffPost.
Artisanal scarf mask, $150 from St. John
A mask made with merino wool

â€œWe use merino wool in these masks, which is naturally moisture-wicking, breathable, temperature-regulating and odor-resistant,â€ said Charles Moodispaw, growth marketing associate at Huckberry, an outdoor gear company. The mask features three layers: a merino wool outer layer, cotton inner layer and merino wool lining layer.
Merino wool face mask, $15 from Huckberry
Buy one, give one

â€œFor every mask purchased, we donate another to a frontline worker, health care professional or other impacted organization,â€ Aviv Gattenuo, senior marketing manager at the culinary brand Hedley & Bennett, told HuffPost. â€œWeâ€™ve already donated more than 350,000 masks.â€
Wake Up and Fight face mask, 3 for $45 from Hedley & Bennett
A mask thatâ€™s like a scarf for your face

â€œThese ribbed knit masks are super soft, like a scarf for your face,â€ Lisa BÃ¼hler, founder and CEO of the fashion retailer Lisa Says Gah, told HuffPost. For every mask purchase, the organization donates $1 to the San Francisco-Marin Food Bank, enough for two meals.
Blue knit mask, $18 from Lisa Says Gah
Masks with a superpower

â€œMasks worn in the winter have a hidden superpower â€” they keep your face protected from the wind,â€ said Kim McGee, senior director of product and marketing at American Blanket Company. â€œThese fleece masks are thick, dense and comfortable.â€
5 masks for $29 from American Blanket Company
Kona quilterâ€™s cotton

â€œQuilterâ€™s cotton means itâ€™s a great fabric thatâ€™s thick enough to serve the functionality of a safe mask,â€ said Hannah Gordon, marketing associate at Baggu, a reusable bag company. â€œOur masks use high-thread count, heavyweight cotton, all in the same bright colors and fun patterns weâ€™re known for.â€
Fabric mask set (three masks per set), $32 from Baggu
A great winter mask from a Black-owned business

â€œOur Lumberjack masks are top sellers to customers in Northern states,â€ said Rashima Sonson, founder of SONSON, a Black-owned accessory business based in Oakland, California. â€œThey give you that dressed-up look without feeling weighed down, and theyâ€™re perfect to pair with a sports coat or a denim jacket.â€
Lumberjack face mask, $15 from SONSON
HuffPost may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Prices and availability subject to change.

otherData.headline: Meghan Markle Is Now A Startup Investor And Oprah Sends Her Full Support
otherData.short_description: The Duchess of Sussex's first public investment is a very trendy one.

articleContent: Meghan Markle has a new title to add to her already extensive resume: startup investor.

The Duchess of Sussex revealed in a Fortune article published on Monday that she personally invested in Clevr Blends, which makes ubertrendy instant oat milk lattes. It is Meghanâ€™s first public investment.

â€œThis investment is in support of a passionate female entrepreneur who prioritizes building community alongside her business,â€ the former â€œSuitsâ€ actor said in a statement also shared with HuffPost, endorsing Clevr Blends co-founder and CEO Hannah Mendoza.

â€œIâ€™m proud to invest in Hannahâ€™s commitment to sourcing ethical ingredients,â€ Meghan added, â€œand creating a product that I personally love and has a holistic approach to wellness. I believe in her and I believe in her company.â€

Mendoza acknowledged the duchess in her own statement. â€œEntrepreneurs need funding, but they also need advisors who care deeply about what they are building,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m grateful to have found both in The Duchess of Sussex â€” her passion for what weâ€™re creating is palpable, and I couldnâ€™t imagine a more aligned partnership.â€
Fortune reported that Meghan reached out to the company, based in Santa Barbara, California, after trying its products.
In addition to Meghan, a megawatt leader on a global stage, Mendoza has garnered a dream endorsement from none other than Oprah Winfrey.

â€œOn the first day of Christmas my neighbor â€˜Mâ€™ sent to me...a basket of deliciousness! (Yes that MğŸ‘‘),â€ Oprah wrote Monday on Instagram, alongside a video of her showing off the goods and making an instant latte, which she called â€œMy new drink of choice for the morning and night.â€
The media mogul, who lives near Meghan and Prince Harry in Montecito, California, attended the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex and has regularly spoken in support of the couple.
Oprah and Prince Harry announced last year that they were teaming up for a â€œdynamic multi-part documentary series that will focus on both mental illness and mental wellnessâ€ for Apple TV Plus.
The couple also recently inked a major, multiyear deal with Netflix, which will see them producing films, scripted series, documentaries, features and childrenâ€™s programming.
Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: We Need A National Day Of Mourning For COVID-19 Victims
otherData.short_description: Over 300,000 people have died of the coronavirus in the U.S. And as thousands more die each day, Americans have not had the chance to collectively mourn.

articleContent: We need a national day of mourning for the coronavirus.
As the first vaccinations began in the U.S. on Monday, bringing with them a ray of hope, the nation hit a grim milestone: more than 300,000 people dead from the virus so far.

â€œWeâ€™ve been struggling,â€ said Douglas Yankton, chairman of the Spirit Lake Tribe in North Dakota. Native Americans have been disproportionately infected, hospitalized and killed by the virus. Yankton lost four family members â€” an uncle and three cousins â€” in the span of a week.
â€œItâ€™s a burden not only on the families but on the community when we keep having to bury our people,â€ he said.

Scott Davis, a member of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe, who lost two cousins and a friend to COVID-19, said that thereâ€™s been â€œno closureâ€ as coronavirus protocols have prevented people from visiting hospitalized loved ones or gathering for funerals.

â€œThey go to the hospital, you canâ€™t see them, you canâ€™t be around them, and all of a sudden it happens, and then the families are left struggling to have closure,â€ he said. â€œYou gotta mourn.â€

With an average now of 2,400 people dying each day of the coronavirus, Black and Latinx people have also been disproportionately affected â€” not only by the deaths but also by the economic fallout from the pandemic, including high rates of joblessness.
Grief coach Breeshia Wade said that a national day of observance for the coronavirus losses would be important for â€œaccountability and acknowledging the massive failure in how this played out.â€

â€œItâ€™s not just the death toll. Thereâ€™s the loss of a way of life, of American identity and what it means to be a cohesive country that comes together to protect its citizens,â€ Wade said. â€œThereâ€™s a loss of trust with our neighbors, with some wearing a mask and some who arenâ€™t.â€
â€œWe need something to bring us together to honor what has been lost if weâ€™re going to have any hope of healing,â€ she added.

National days of observance are typically enacted by Congress, after which the president issues a proclamation on that day each year and local governments may also hold dedicated ceremonies or events. Existing ones include Veterans Day and Hispanic Heritage Month.
Rep. Donald Payne Jr. (D-N.J.) introduced a resolution in the House last month calling for a day of mourning for coronavirus victims in January, to provide â€œa national opportunity to grieve.â€

The legislation, which specifically calls out the disproportionate infection rates and deaths among communities of color, is sitting in the House Oversight Committee. Payne, whose best friend lost his mother to COVID-19, plans to ask other lawmakers to support the resolution once the more immediate concern of passing another economic stimulus package has been resolved.

â€œEvery elected official in Washington has lost a constituent to the virus,â€ Payne said, noting that heâ€™s hopeful he can get it passed. â€œI would hope it could be handled in a bipartisan manner.â€

Activists have been calling for such a day for months. In May, several progressive groups, including the Center for American Progress, Indivisible and the National Domestic Workers Alliance, organized a â€œday of mourningâ€ protest by dumping body bags outside the White House to call out the mounting death toll, which had then reached nearly 100,000.

NDWAâ€™s Black Organizing Director AimÃ©e-Josiane Twagirumukiza said that any acknowledgment of the death toll should also come with a commitment to â€œuse this pain, this grief to create something better.â€

Twagirumukiza specifically urged more relief funding from Congress, particularly for essential workers, including child care and home care providers, who have â€œkept the country going in a time like this.â€

Similarly, Jim Bunn, the co-creator of World AIDS Day, said that at this stage, a simple day of remembrance would not be â€œenough.â€ When he helped found the HIV/AIDS awareness day in 1987, the public health challenge at the time was overcoming the stigma around the disease. With this virus, one of the main challenges he sees is convincing everyone to get vaccinated.

â€œLetâ€™s use it to perhaps bring more purpose to the day â€” and to the suffering those families are experiencing â€” so that itâ€™s leveraged in order for there to be fewer families who have suffered these losses,â€ Bunn said of the need to get a large majority of people to take the vaccine to significantly slow the spread of the virus. â€œWe need to get needles in arms.â€

Amy DeGurian, a grief expert and faculty lecturer at the University of Pittsburghâ€™s school of social work, noted how a national day of mourning would be important given how â€œso much of the grief that has occurred has been isolated.â€ As traditional funerals are replaced with Zoom memorials or drive-thru services, â€œwe have not been able to tend to others in their time of need,â€ she said.

Since the coronavirus pandemic is ongoing, organizers would have to think of a meaningful way to mark this day while staying safe and distanced. DeGurian suggested that everyone across the country could light a candle in their window or outside their home, or a banner of each of the names of the dead could scroll at the same time on national television. Whatâ€™s key is for people to not feel alone in their grief.

â€œYou are more likely to have complicated grief when you grieve alone, more likely to have prolonged grief when you donâ€™t have support, more likely to have lingering issues when you donâ€™t have intervention,â€ DeGurian said. â€œWe need each other.â€

Historian Diana Appelbaum, who wrote recently on the politics behind the creation of American holidays, noted that there are currently dozens of days of observance, most of which the vast majority of Americans pay zero attention to â€” such as Aviation Day or Safe Boating Week.

Whether a national day of mourning for coronavirus carries significance in the future depends largely on how many people are still affected. Memorial Day, for instance, was a solemn day for decades, as many Americans who fought in World War II were still alive. Today, most people mark it as a day off to barbecue or rent a beach house, as Appelbaum put it.

â€œWhen this [pandemic] started and people said, â€˜That horrible flu epidemic of 1918,â€™ was it even on your radar? Was it in your high school history book?â€ Appelbaum said, referring to the deadly Spanish influenza outbreak that began in 1918. â€œThatâ€™s what this will be â€” unless it marks the start of a series of such pandemics.â€

The latter scenario is certainly possible. Last month, Dr. Robert Redfield, director of the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, warned that, when it comes to the pandemic, â€œthere will be a next time.â€

But for those living through this moment, Appelbaum had no doubt about the value of dedicating a day to mourning coronavirus victims: â€œItâ€™s important for people who are living now to do this. I think it will be tremendously meaningful.â€

A HuffPost Guide To Coronavirus
Which airlines are blocking out middle seats for holiday travel?
How does the coronavirus spread differently than the flu?
Can you close your COVID â€œbubbleâ€ without losing friends forever?
Is it safe to see grandparents over the holidays?
How can you help a friend with anxiety when youâ€™re also struggling?

As COVID-19 cases rise, itâ€™s more important than ever to remain connected and informed. Join the HuffPost community today. (Itâ€™s free!)

otherData.headline: How Progressives Failed A Key Test In The Heartland
otherData.short_description: Nebraska Democrat Kara Eastmanâ€™s loss in a competitive House race offers lessons for the left.

articleContent: Kara Eastman was supposed to win this year. The polling looked good, she had come so close to winning the Omaha congressional seat in 2018, and this time, the national party was all in for her. Progressive activists were eager to show that their ideas could win outside heavily blue areas. And Nebraskaâ€™s 2nd Congressional District, which includes metropolitan Omaha and a more rural area around a military base, was as good a place as any.

But the vindication progressives had hoped for never materialized. Eastman lost last month to Rep. Don Bacon (R-Neb.) by more than she had in 2018 (4.5 percentage points compared to 2 points two years ago). President-elect Joe Bidenâ€™s 6.5-point win in the district, four years after President Donald Trump won there, made Eastmanâ€™s defeat that much more frustrating.

Eastmanâ€™s loss was a blow to Democrats hoping to expand their majority in the House. But it was an especially painful loss for the partyâ€™s progressive wing, which wanted to show it could do more than just oust incumbent Democrats in ultra-liberal seats. It wanted to demonstrate the viability of its preferred policies in the swing seats and states that determine control of Congress. The left touted Eastmanâ€™s race as a marquee opportunity to show that progressive policies designed to excite the party base are assets, rather than liabilities.

The party tried to do things differently than it had in 2018. After Eastman defeated former Rep. Brad Ashford (D) in the 2018 primary, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee was late to endorse her and provided her relatively modest financial support. Baconâ€™s campaign heavily outspent Eastman until the final weeks. Eastmanâ€™s supporters believed an extra push from the party establishment would have pushed her over the finish line.

This cycle, the DCCC tried to correct its mistake, endorsing Eastman from the moment she won her primary and spending $3.5 million to try to elect her with more modest support from progressive groups.

Many of the forces that sank Eastman were out of her control. She received nearly 34,000 more votes than she had in 2018, but a surge in Republican turnout limited the impact of those gains. Ashford, the man Eastman defeated in the 2018 primary, worked against her. Eastman also defeated Ashfordâ€™s wife, Ann, in the 2020 primary, and Ashford endorsed Bacon, providing the GOP congressman with a valuable talking point. And plenty of Republicans who voted for Biden out of their disdain for Trump probably would not have elected a Democrat to Congress regardless of their positions or background.

â€œRepublicans just came out like crazy and voted for Biden and Bacon,â€ Eastman told HuffPost in an interview. â€œI personally donâ€™t think it would have mattered who was running in my seat. I think the Democrat would have lost.â€

But Eastmanâ€™s race also offers some lessons for progressives eager to win seats like hers in the future. Republicans succeeded in casting Eastman as a radical left-wing figure partly because of her support for Medicare for All, her positive comments about Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and her affiliation with grassroots groups and causes associated with the movement to â€œdefund the police.â€

Whatâ€™s more, the progressive groups that had once been the foundation of Eastmanâ€™s support did little to offset the damage inflicted by Bacon and his allies, spreading small amounts of money between multiple TV ads in contravention of traditional campaign strategy.

â€œBy the 2020 election cycle, she already had a definition and they spent several million dollars reinforcing that definition and making it even worse,â€ said Paul Landow, a political science professor at the University of Nebraska, Omaha, who previously served as a top aide to a Democratic mayor of Omaha and a Democratic member of Congress from Nebraska. â€œWhen thereâ€™s that kind of money floating around, youâ€™ve got a pretty good chance of making it happen. And they did.â€
The Creation Of â€˜Comradeâ€™ Kara

Itâ€™s not hard to see what progressives saw in Eastman. As a social worker and the founder of the lead safety nonprofit Omaha Healthy Kids Alliance, Eastman boasts deep community roots in the districtâ€™s biggest population center. And she spoke movingly about how her motherâ€™s struggle paying medical bills associated with cancer informed her commitment to providing health care as a right to all Americans.

Although she did not vote for Sanders in the 2016 presidential primary, she told Politico she was a â€œbig Bernie Sanders fanâ€ and shared that her daughter had canvassed for him. Eastmanâ€™s platform reflected her affinity for the Vermont senator. In that first congressional run, in particular, Eastman ran as an unabashed proponent of a Medicare for All, single-payer health care system, a $15 minimum wage and free tuition at public colleges. And unlike the national party, Eastmanâ€™s campaign embraced the activist leftâ€™s belief that turning out infrequent, liberal-leaning voters made catering to moderate Republicans unnecessary.

Since Eastman nearly unseated Bacon with little help from the national party during her first run, the plan seems to have worked. But in fact, the circumstances of the 2018 midterm elections were uniquely favorable for the left and did not necessarily provide a roadmap to victory in elections where the electorate would be less lopsided toward highly educated Democrats.
â€œ2018 was a Democratic wave year,â€ said David Shor, a data scientist who consults for Democratic candidates and campaigns.
â€œIn midterms, voters are much more educated. There are fewer working-class voters,â€ he added. â€œThat creates a more fertile ground for highly ideological candidates.â€

Instead of serving as a template for an even stronger performance during a presidential election year, Eastmanâ€™s freewheeling remarks during the 2018 campaign provided fodder for Republican attacks in what would turn out to be a more favorable environment for the GOP in 2020.

The National Republican Congressional Committee, which is House Republicansâ€™ campaign arm, used these comments to characterize Eastman, whom they nicknamed â€œComrade Kara,â€ as a socialist in the Sanders mold, rather than a Biden-style Democrat of the kind suburbanites and military families could stomach. One NRCC spot that aired more than 300 times beginning in early October featured a clip of Eastman telling a left-wing host in 2018, â€œFull disclosure: I love Bernie Sanders,â€ according to Kantar Media/CMAG. (All references to TV ads in this story rely on data from Kantar Media/CMAG.)

Republicans also dishonestly pulled a clip of Eastman mocking how Republicans say of her, â€œIâ€™m a radical socialist.â€ One TV ad from the GOP super PAC Defending Main Street that aired more than 100 times replayed the clip of her without clarifying that she reiterated it to laugh at how preposterous the characterization was.

â€œWhat this really came down to was that Don Bacon is a moderate, commonsense Republican who is in line with the district, and Kara Eastman is a socialist who is far to the left of the district,â€ said NRCC spokesperson Bob Salera.

Another advantage for Republicans this election cycle was that Biden, who was expected to perform well in Omahaâ€™s highly educated, Republican-leaning suburbs, was on record condemning Medicare for All in the strongest of terms.

The NRCC funded at least two TV ads using Bidenâ€™s words condemning Medicare for All to attack Eastman. The ads, which aired more than 600 times beginning in September, quoted Biden lamenting that Medicare for All would cost â€œ$30 trillionâ€ and would mean â€œWashington dictating to you, â€˜You cannot keep the plan you have.â€™â€ Another NRCC spot that aired more than 300 times in October contrasted Eastmanâ€™s support for a Green New Deal with Bidenâ€™s opposition to it, deeming Eastman â€œtoo extreme for Joe Biden.â€
â€œIf you just look at how Biden performed versus Kara, Kara did not fit the district,â€ said Nebraska Democratic Party Chairwoman Jane Kleeb.
Struggling To Push Back

Eastman and Democrats hammered Bacon, in turn, for his vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act. As a freshman lawmaker in March 2017, Bacon said prior to voting for the repeal bill that would have allowed states to opt out of federal protections for people with preexisting conditions that he was changing his vote from â€œâ€˜yesâ€™ to â€˜hell, yes.â€™â€ The phrase came up again and again in Democratic ads, albeit without the video evidence that gave Republican attacks against Eastman extra punch.

Campaigns and outside groups generally try to concentrate as much money as possible in individual ads to maximize the likelihood that voters will see a particular message. And the DCCC highlights the themes it wants those outside groups to amplify on an opposition research page â€• or â€œred boxâ€ â€• designed to circumvent campaign finance rules against coordinating with outside groups. In its red box on Eastmanâ€™s race, the DCCC said â€œvoters in Omaha should seeâ€ that Bacon voted â€œhell yesâ€ to repealing the ACA and for defunding Planned Parenthood.
Some of Eastmanâ€™s progressive allies, such as the Congressional Progressive Caucus PAC, amplified the red box message with six-figure digital ad buys.
But other groups spread their resources thinly over a greater number of ads with differing themes â€• a tactical mistake, according to several veteran campaign operatives.

Justice Democratsâ€™ pro-Eastman blitz â€• funded jointly with MoveOn, the Sunrise Movement and the Working Families Party â€• spent $60,000 on a TV ad hitting Bacon for voting against funding to clean up drinking water. The spot aired just 34 times, though it echoed themes in an ad funded by the End Citizens United PAC that aired more than 125 times.

The progressive coalition spent another $167,000 on a TV ad that aired nearly 130 times emphasizing Baconâ€™s ACA repeal vote. A separate TV ad funded by the Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Rebellion PACâ€™s super PAC focusing on Baconâ€™s resistance to COVID-19 relief â€• and a secondary mention of Baconâ€™s ACA repeal vote â€• aired just 36 times. (The super PAC spent a total of $200,000 on Eastmanâ€™s behalf, including on cable TV ads not counted by Kantar Media/CMAG.)

Asked why Justice Democrats had decided to do a smaller ad buy about clean water, a Justice Democrats spokesperson said, â€œWe had interest from the Working Families Party and other partners on that message.â€ The spokesperson noted that the ad expanded on the spot run by End Citizens United.

Justice Democrats did not join forces with the PCCC on a single, unified ad campaign because they were already in the process of producing their own ads when the groups approached one another about cooperating, according to the Justice Democrats spokesperson. The PCCC declined to comment for this story.
Landow, the veteran Nebraska Democrat and politics expert, blames the national party as well as progressive groups for a â€œbungled responseâ€ that failed to adequately shape the narrative.
â€œIt was too little, too late and didnâ€™t come close to hitting the nail on the head,â€ he said.

For his part, Bacon simply lied about the implications of his vote, co-opting the â€œhell yesâ€ phrase as a description for his commitment to protecting people with preexisting conditions. He likely benefited from a national environment where Democratic attacks on the ACA repeal vote did not resonate as strongly as they had in 2018.

Bacon, who is a retired general, also took pains to cast himself as the more moderate and bipartisan candidate in the race. For example, he funded an ad that featured a Black woman who said Bacon was the first Republican she was voting for.

â€œIt was a referendum at the federal level on Trump and we couldnâ€™t make the case that Bacon was a madman,â€ Crystal Rhoades, who sits on the Nebraska Public Service Commission and is a former chair of the Douglas County Democratic Party, told HuffPost. â€œWe didnâ€™t do enough to tie them together.â€
Eastman tried her own version of bipartisan jiujitsu with a TV spot that featured the endorsement of Republican state Sen. John McCollister.

But she never settled on a clear response to attacks on her support for Medicare for All. She defended the policy on the merits during an October debate with Bacon. Yet in a campaign ad, she sought to skirt the issue by highlighting Bidenâ€™s endorsement of her bid and their shared commitment to lowering prescription drug prices and â€œexpanding health care for all families.â€
â€œWe know that if youâ€™re running a campaign and youâ€™re trying to explain things to people, then youâ€™re losing,â€ Eastman said.
In ads and on the stump, Eastman ran as a crusader against corruption who refused corporate PAC money so voters could be confident that she would â€œput families first, not special interests.â€
â€œI see people talking about, â€˜Well, you just have to run on a strong economic message,â€™â€ Eastman said. â€œWe did run on a strong economic message.â€

Whether elevating validators like McCollister or promoting her plans to reduce prescription drug prices, Eastman found herself frustrated by her inability to cut through the narrative perpetuated by Republicans on the airwaves. She told HuffPost that she had greater success dispelling misconceptions in one-on-one conversations with voters.

But Eastmanâ€™s campaign paused its door-knocking program in March due to the COVID-19 pandemic and resumed literature drops in September in lieu of face-to-face conversations. The DCCCâ€™s opposition to canvassing also prompted the state party to shelve its plans to canvass with heavy health precautions, according to Kleeb.
â€œI donâ€™t think they ever came out and said, â€˜If candidates door-knock, you will lose funding.â€™ But they said, â€˜They cannot door-knock,â€™â€ she said. â€œThat hurt Democrats everywhere.â€
The Don Kleine Debacle

In congressional races, Republicans ran 216 advertisements on broadcast television attacking Democrats for being anti-police and pro-riots. Out of that total, 157 ads that aired 103,000 times specifically blasted Democrats for their association with the slogan â€œdefund the police.â€

Republicans ran at least three such TV spots that aired more than 900 times against Eastman. One Bacon campaign spot featured two Omaha policewomen warning that Eastman would throw cops under the bus â€œfor her radical friends in New Yorkâ€ as an image of Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) appeared on-screen. Another Bacon ad tying Eastman to riots in Portland, Oregon; Kenosha, Wisconsin; and Omaha featured Tony Conner, the Black president of Omahaâ€™s police union, declaring that Bacon would stand against â€œradicals who want to defund the police.â€

Unlike some Democrats who faced down policing-related attacks by marshaling law enforcement officers of their own to affirm their pro-police credentials in TV ads, Eastman and her allies did not use TV ads to rebut claims that she was beholden to radical, anti-police forces.

But in public appearances, Eastman made clear that she does not support â€œdefundingâ€ the police. And unlike with some of Eastmanâ€™s other missteps, Republicans did not have footage of her saying anything that could be construed that way.

What they had instead was Eastmanâ€™s reaction to white bar owner Jake Gardnerâ€™s killing of James Scurlock, a young Black man, in downtown Omaha on May 30. Omaha, like other areas of the country, was swept up in a wave of protests against police brutality over the summer, some of which spilled into vandalism and looting. Scurlock was allegedly part of a group of people who broke the glass of Gardnerâ€™s bar and got into a fight with Gardnerâ€™s aging father. Video appeared to show him engaged in a physical scuffle with Gardner and his father, who were trying to guard their store, when Gardner shot him to death with his handgun.
The following morning, Eastman denounced the killing on Twitter as a â€œcold-blooded murder.â€

But Don Kleine, a Democrat serving as Douglas Countyâ€™s prosecutor since 2006, announced two days after the killing that after a review of grainy video of the incident, he was declining to press charges against Gardner. Scurlock had pinned Gardner to the ground and held his head in a headlock, according to Kleine. In his press conference announcing the decision, Kleine also blasted Eastman without naming her, arguing that her characterization of the killing was â€œrecklessâ€ and â€œdangerous to our community.â€ Republicans would end up using those comments in attack ads against Eastman.

The progression of the judicial process brought new headaches for Eastman. Scurlockâ€™s family, Omahaâ€™s Black community and progressive Nebraskans were outraged by Kleineâ€™s initial decision not to prosecute, which they condemned as a rush to judgment. A neighboring bar owner said that Gardner and his father had â€œinstigatedâ€ the fight with racists comments, including the elder Gardnerâ€™s use of the â€œn-word.â€

Under pressure, Kleine reversed his decision, convening a grand jury and appointing a special counsel to determine whether to bring charges. The grand jury indicted Gardner in September, for manslaughter, â€œterroristic threatsâ€ and other charges. Shortly before he was to turn himself in, he died by suicide in Oregon.

The indictment and the suicide sparked another round of recriminations in Omaha as Kleine held a press conference to dispute characterizations of Gardner as a Trump-loving vigilante who provoked an altercation with Scurlock, instead claiming that Scurlock was the one involved in â€œterrorizingâ€ other people.

Kleineâ€™s remarks angered Scurlockâ€™s family and many Democrats. The Nebraska Democratic Party responded by passing a harshly worded resolution stating that Kleineâ€™s handling of the Scurlock case â€œperpetuated white supremacy.â€

The move pushed Kleine to leave the Democratic Party and register as a Republican. Top Republicans in the state held a rally welcoming him to the Republican Party in early October with early voting underway. At the event, Kleine revealed that he had already cast his ballot for Trump, crediting Trump for being a â€œlaw-and-order guy.â€

Many Nebraska Democrats fault Kleeb for passing a resolution that effectively drove a ranking elected official out of the party and heightening the apparent gulf between the stateâ€™s old guard of moderate and conservative Democrats and progressives like Eastman.
â€œThat should have never happened,â€ said Ben Gray, the only Black member of the Omaha city council.
Kleeb, however, insists the resolution helped all Democrats on the ballot by showing people of color, young people and progressives that the party had their back.
â€œThey saw us standing up to someone who was disparaging an African-American man who was shot by a racist bar owner,â€ she said.

Gray sees the Scurlock killing as a complicated one. He believes that Gardner should not have been taking the defense of his own stores into his hands and put himself in a situation where he would be confronting looters, but that once Gardner was accosted, he shot Scurlock in an effort to defend himself.
As a supporter of Eastmanâ€™s, Gray wishes that the Democratic congressional candidate had reserved judgment before calling the killing a â€œcold-blooded murder.â€
â€œIf I had my choice and I had been running the campaign, I wouldnâ€™t have had her say anything,â€ Gray said. â€œI never say anything about an event until I know all the facts about an event.â€
Yet despite her loss, Eastman has no regrets about her stand on behalf of Scurlock.
â€œCalling that murder to me doesnâ€™t seem very bold,â€ she said. â€œIt just seems commonsensical.â€

otherData.headline: Former Cuomo Aide Accuses N.Y. Governor Of Sexual Harassment
otherData.short_description: Lindsey Boylan, who is running for Manhattan borough president, claims Cuomo harassed her "for years" when she worked in his administration.

articleContent: A former adviser to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo accused him of sexually harassing her â€œfor yearsâ€ while she worked in his administration.
Lindsey Boylan, who is running for Manhattan borough president, made her allegations on Twitter Sunday morning and claimed that she wasnâ€™t the only woman to have been victimized.

â€œMany saw it, and watched,â€ she said in a Twitter thread. â€œI could never anticipate what to expect: would I be grilled on my work (which was very good) or harassed about my looks. Or would it be both in the same conversation?â€
Cuomoâ€™s press secretary, Caitlin Girouard, denied the allegations against the governor in a statement to HuffPost on Sunday. â€œThere is simply no truth to these claims,â€ she said.

Boylan worked for the Cuomo administration from March 2015 to October 2018. She served as deputy secretary with the stateâ€™s economic development agency, Empire State Development, and then as a special adviser to the governor, according to her LinkedIn profile.

Boylan, who did not immediately provide any corroborating evidence on the sexual harassment allegations against Cuomo, said in comments posted to Twitter that she has no interest in speaking with journalists about her allegations. She did not respond to requests for comment from HuffPost or reportedly from several other news outlets.
â€œI am about validating the experience of countless women and making sure abuse stops,â€ she said.
Boylanâ€™s allegations came after she tweeted last week that working for Cuomo was the â€œmost toxic team environmentâ€ and that people were â€œdeathly afraid of him.â€

â€œIâ€™ve had many jobs. Waitressing at Friendlyâ€™s as a teenager was an infinitely more respectful environment. Even when I had bad customers who tipped poorly,â€ she tweeted. â€œIf people werenâ€™t deathly afraid of him, theyâ€™d be saying the same thing and youâ€™d already know the stories.â€

Internal documents obtained by HuffPost, also reported by the Associated Press, indicate that Boylan resigned from her position with Empire State Development in 2018 after several co-workers accused her of abusive behavior. Complaints to Human Resources against her alleged bullying, yelling and treating staff â€œlike children.â€ Two employees asked to file their complaints anonymously due to â€œa significant fear of retaliation,â€ the report states.

Boylan offered to resign during an â€œemployment counselingâ€ session at which the complaints were raised, according to an internal memo. Several days later, during a phone conversation with administration lawyer Alphonso David, Boylan admitted to having made mistakes but asked if she could rescind her resignation, according to a memorandum of the call.

A former worker at Empire State Development, who spoke with HuffPost on the condition of anonymity, said she personally witnessed Boylan yelling at staff and threatening to fire workers. â€œSome of the words she used were just not acceptable, and it could be heard throughout the whole entire floor,â€ the source said. â€œI donâ€™t think she has any footing to speak about toxicity or any kind of harassment when that is what she did to many people.â€

Boylan turned to the campaign trail the year after leaving the Cuomo administration, with an unsuccessful run against U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler in the spring of 2019. She announced her campaign for Manhattan Borough President this fall.

otherData.headline: Americaâ€™s Eviction Crisis Is A Public Health Disaster Waiting To Happen
otherData.short_description: Pushing millions of people out of their homes could prolong the coronavirus pandemic and trigger a wave of long-term impacts.

articleContent: America is on the verge of an unprecedented eviction crisis. On Dec. 31, the Centers for Disease Control and Preventionâ€™s nationwide eviction moratorium will expire. According to the National Low Income Housing Coalition, somewhere between 12 million and 17 million households â€” up to 40 million people â€” have little or no confidence that they can pay their rent and avoid eviction if they donâ€™t get relief.
â€œWeâ€™re looking at the very real possibility of tens of millions of people losing their homes this winter during a spike in COVID-19,â€ said NLIHC President Diane Yentel.

The looming eviction crisis is not only a moral failing and a financial catastrophe, but an unprecedented public health disaster. A large body of evidence has found links between evictions and health outcomes ranging from homelessness to domestic violence to chronic stress.

â€œIf we get a wave of mass evictions in the new year, weâ€™re going to see a huge range of long-term effects,â€ said Kathryn Leifheit, a UCLA researcher who studies the effect of housing disruptions on health.

Children often have to transfer schools after an eviction, she said, which can affect their cognitive skills. Due to the difficulty of securing an apartment with an eviction on their record, adults often end up moving to more distant and lower-quality housing. Even being threatened with eviction can spike blood pressure, exacerbate mental illness, and provoke chronic stress.

And, in a darkly ironic twist, evictions may even end up prolonging the pandemic that triggered them in the first place. Before the CDC enacted its nationwide eviction moratorium in early September, the agency left it up to states to decide what to do about tenants who fell behind on their rent. During the spring, 44 states enacted short-term moratoriums. In the summer, 33 of them lifted the bans.

Leifheit and her co-authors published a study last month that found states that lifted their eviction bans had double the cases and five times more deaths compared to states that left their eviction bans in place. North Carolina, for example, banned evictions in April. When the state lifted the ban June 20, renters were left unprotected until the CDC moratorium went into effect on Sept. 4. Authorities carried out an estimated 18,000 evictions in those three months. Leifheitâ€™s study found this resulted in 15,690 extra coronavirus cases and 304 deaths.

Across the U.S., evictions led to 434,000 COVID-19 cases and nearly 11,000 deaths. But only a small portion of those deaths likely occurred among people who were evicted themselves, Leifheit said. The vast majority were second- and third-degree infections caused by evicted tenants coming in contact with other people through their households or jobs.

â€œWe tend to think about the link between evictions and COVID-19 as an individual process â€” someone gets evicted, they get COVID-19 and then, in the worst-case scenario, they die,â€ Leiftheit said. â€œBut a wave of evictions ends up increasing the risk for everyone.â€
An urgent problem

Even before the pandemic, Americaâ€™s renters were in crisis. In 2018, nearly half of tenant households were spending over one-third of their income on rent. Black people, Latinos and families with children made up the bulk of Americaâ€™s 3.6 million evictions every year.

The pandemic has put that crisis on steroids. Since the start of the year, roughly 46 million Americans â€” roughly one-quarter of the workforce â€” have filed for unemployment benefits. The Urban Institute, a think tank, estimated in June that 20% of renter households included at least one person who had lost their job in the first two months of the pandemic.

So far, the economic effects of the pandemic have hit renters disproportionately hard. The sectors most severely impacted â€” retail, restaurants, bars and tourism â€” employ large numbers of low-wage workers. In October, the NLIHC found that 26% of Black renters and 18% of Latino renters were behind on rent, compared to just 10% of white renters. Those who could pay were increasingly relying on credit cards, selling possessions and borrowing money from family and friends.

â€œWeâ€™re seeing a different population facing eviction than weâ€™ve ever had before,â€ said Pam Bridge, the director of advocacy for Community Legal Services, a Phoenix-based legal aid nonprofit that helps tenants avoid eviction. Over the last four months, Bridge has started to see clients from a wider range of the income scale. She used to mostly see unemployed and hourly workers. Now she gets office workers and Uber drivers.

â€œThe people being evicted arenâ€™t necessarily low-income anymore,â€ she said. â€œWeâ€™ve got a lot more people dealing with evictions who have never been through one before and have no idea how the process works.â€

So far, COVID-19 hasnâ€™t resulted in an avalanche of evictions, mostly due to the CDCâ€™s soon-to-expire nationwide eviction moratorium. (The CDC declined to comment for this story.) The moratorium order, however, contains two significant loopholes: Tenants have to prove that the pandemic directly caused their failure to pay rent, and it only stops the evictions â€• not all the legal processes and fees that come along with them.

These provisions mean that a significant number of evictions are still trickling through the courts. Bridge said in many cases she deals with, the court has issued a judgment saying the tenant needs to vacate their apartment, but sheriffs wonâ€™t enforce it until after the CDC lifts the moratorium.

Thatâ€™s good news compared to being put out on the streets. But Bridge said renters often canâ€™t find new apartments with an eviction judgment on their record. Plus, the court process can cost up to $200 in administrative fees â€” a tall order for workers already behind on rent.
â€œOur COVID-19 numbers are the worst theyâ€™ve ever been, weâ€™re in the middle of a pandemic, and weâ€™re three weeks away from people having nowhere to go,â€ Bridge said.
How an eviction crisis becomes a public health crisis

While evictions do indeed spike homelessness rates, Bridge said most people donâ€™t end up sleeping on the streets. Most of them end up moving in with family and friends while they sort out their finances and look for a new apartment.

Under normal circumstances, this post-eviction â€œdoubling upâ€ would be a tragedy. During the coronavirus pandemic, it has become a significant health risk. According to a modeling study published in November, members of households that moved in together due to an eviction had a 40% higher risk of contracting COVID-19. Low-income workers already live in smaller homes than wealthy workers; each extra person moving into a crowded household makes it harder to maintain social distance and avoid respiratory droplets.
These arrangements are also often a step along the path into homelessness, another significant risk factor for contracting COVID-19.
â€œOnce someone ends up in the shelter system, it gets a lot harder to socially distance and quarantine,â€ Yentel said.

Even with the moratorium in place, this spiral is already playing out for low-income Americans. One of Bridgeâ€™s clients is a restaurant server who couldnâ€™t handle the stress of being threatened with eviction and decided to move herself and her children into her sisterâ€™s home. Others have had to miss work to take care of older family members with COVID-19 â€” a situation that threatens their income and their health alike.
Contact tracing studies earlier in the pandemic found that roughly 45% of new infections came from people living in the same household.

And these impacts donâ€™t just affect renters. Poor tenants are more likely to be essential workers, take public transportation and rely on food banks. These activities put them in contact with other people and risk extending the chain of coronavirus infection â€” and fueling even more evictions.
â€œWeâ€™re starting to understand the relationship between evictions and health as cyclical,â€ Leifheit said. â€œEvictions lead to poor health, but poor health also leads to evictions.â€
Rent relief is a no-brainer
The only good news about the eviction crisis is that it can be prevented with a relatively straightforward fix: rental assistance.

â€œItâ€™s kind of maddening because of how simple it is,â€ Yentel said. In June, the Urban Institute estimated the cost of providing relief to every rent-burdened household in America at $15.5 billion per month. The latest bipartisan stimulus proposal includes $25 billion in rental assistance â€” â€œItâ€™s not enough but itâ€™s a step in the right direction,â€ Yentel said â€” but the fate of the proposal remains unclear.

Rent relief is a rare political no-brainer. Tenants (who want to pay their rents) and landlords (who want rental income) alike support it. Itâ€™s also a bargain: An eviction-driven homelessness crisis could cost up to $129 billion in extra spending for emergency shelters, medical care and other services, far more than the price tag for preventing it in the first place, according to an NLIHC analysis. And even that astronomical figure doesnâ€™t include the second- and third-order effects of cities across the country experiencing a crash in home and rental prices as vacancy rates explode.
â€œItâ€™s extraordinarily shortsighted and cruel to allow this many evictions to occur,â€ Yentel said. â€œThis was entirely predictable. And the solutions are simple even if theyâ€™re not easy.â€

otherData.headline: Alex Jones Vows Biden 'Will Be Removed One Way Or Another' At Pro-Trump Rally
otherData.short_description: "Joe Biden is a globalist, and Joe Biden will be removed, one way or another!" the conspiracy theorist said to cheers.

articleContent: Conspiracy theorist Alex Jones denounced President-elect Joe Bidenâ€™s White House victory before a crowd of Donald Trump supporters on Saturday, declaring that â€œwe will never recognizeâ€ Biden and that he â€œwill be removed one way or another.â€

â€œWe will never back down to the satanic pedophile globalist new world order and their walking-dead reanimated corpse Joe Biden. And we will never recognize him,â€ the far-right radio host shouted from a stage at the second so-called Million MAGA March in Washington. He added: â€œSo I donâ€™t know whoâ€™s going to the White House in 38 days, but I sure know this: Joe Biden is a globalist, and Joe Biden will be removed one way or another.â€

Jonesâ€™ comments appeared to echo the far-right conspiracy theory QAnon, which alleges without evidence that Satan-worshipping pedophiles are plotting against Trump. His use of the word â€œglobalistâ€ also raised concerns about anti-Semitism, as the term has been increasingly used in xenophobic and anti-Semitic contexts.

David Weissman, who is involved with the anti-Trump Republican group The Lincoln Project, was among those highlighting Jonesâ€™ choice of language and warning that his speech appeared to be a call for violence.
â€œThis antisemitic trope should also be considered a threat, and Alex Jones should be arrested for incitement,â€ Weissman tweeted, echoing similar tweets that tagged the FBI.
Trump still refuses to concede the election, claiming without evidence that the election was stolen from him.
â€œWeâ€™re going to continue to go forward,â€ he said of his unsuccessful attempts to reverse the electionâ€™s result in an interview with â€œFox & Friendsâ€ that aired Sunday morning.
Trumpâ€™s remarks followed the Friday action by the Supreme Court, which became the latest court to dismiss a lawsuit by his campaign alleging widespread voter fraud.

otherData.headline: Biden Transition Team Wonâ€™t Commit To Asian American Cabinet Secretary
otherData.short_description: Not having an Asian American secretary nominee would be â€œunacceptable,â€ lawmakers said.

articleContent: President-elect Joe Bidenâ€™s transition team would not commit to nominating an Asian American for a Cabinet secretary position on Friday, shortly after Asian American lawmakers said failing to do so would be â€œunacceptable.â€
When asked about the nomination request during a press conference Friday, two top transition officials reiterated Bidenâ€™s pledge to build a historically diverse Cabinet.

â€œWeâ€™re already on track to have the most diverse cabinet in American history,â€ transition spokesperson Jen Psaki said. â€œThat is a value that will continue to be important to the president-elect, the vice president-elect and the entire team as further decisions are made.â€

Yohannes Abraham, the transition teamâ€™s executive director, noted Bidenâ€™s plans to nominate Neera Tanden to be director of the Office of Management and Budget and Katherine Tai to be U.S. trade representative. Both are Asian American.

In a statement earlier Friday, the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus applauded the selections of Tanden and Tai, but said nominating Asian Americans or Pacific Islanders for the higher-profile secretary positions was still necessary.

â€œFor the first time in over two decades, we are facing the possibility that there might not be a single AAPI Cabinet Secretary in a presidential administration,â€ members of the caucus said in a statement. â€œLet us be clear: that outcome is unacceptable.â€

The group pointed out that every president since Bill Clinton in the 1990s has had at least one Asian American Cabinet secretary. President Barack Obama in particular had three Asian American cabinet members.

â€œTo not include an AAPI official as a Cabinet Secretary overseeing a federal department would send the wrong message that AAPIs do not need to be included,â€ the caucus said. â€œWe already see the exclusion of AAPIs in critical policy conversations regarding the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on communities of color, immigration and racial justice that often overlook our community due to the harmful â€˜model minorityâ€™ stereotype that paints AAPIs as a monolithic group.â€

In a separate letter, Hawaii Sen. Mazie Hirono â€” one of the Senateâ€™s three Asian American members â€” specifically pushed Biden to nominate California Labor Secretary Julie Su for the same position at the federal level.

The transition team declined to comment on who is or isnâ€™t under consideration for the labor secretary job, though speculation has centered on Su, Boston Mayor Marty Walsh and Michigan Rep. Andy Levin. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders has also pushed for the job, but Biden has been reluctant to select members of the Senate for key positions so far.

Asian Americans are the nationâ€™s fastest-growing racial group, and overwhelmingly supported Biden over incumbent GOP President Donald Trump and were key to his victories in the swing states of Nevada and Georgia.

Bidenâ€™s pledge to build the most diverse Cabinet in American history, in addition to pressure from Black, Latinx and Asian American lawmakers, has helped shape the transition process and Bidenâ€™s picks for top jobs.

Black lawmakers, including South Carolina Rep. James Clyburn, a close Biden ally, pushed for the nominations of retired Gen. Lloyd Austin as secretary of defense and of Rep. Marcia Fudge as head of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Of Bidenâ€™s 14 Cabinet-level nominations so far, seven have gone to women and nine have gone to people of color.

otherData.headline: The Grocery Trends To Look Forward To In 2021
otherData.short_description: Instacart released its "New Year, New Cart" forecast of food-buying trends and attitudes.

articleContent: The year 2020 saw big changes to the grocery shopping experience â€• from the bread-baking craze to the pandemic panic buying rush. Looking ahead to 2021, Instacart is forecasting the grocery trends expected to take hold next year in the U.S.

The online grocery platform released its first â€œNew Year, New Cartâ€ 2021 report with at-home food trends, shopping habits and attitudes to look out for. It seems after indulging in comfort foods and booze to cope in 2020, consumers will be shifting to lower-alcohol cocktails, keto snacks and bolder spices, among other trends.

The Instacart report combines a in-depth analysis of Instacart search and purchase activity and a new online survey conducted by The Harris Poll. The folks at Instacart compared searches and sales from Jan. 1, 2019, through Nov. 1, 2019, to activity from the same period in 2020 to identify trending products and categories. Meanwhile, the survey took place from Nov. 5-9 and reached 2,050 U.S. adults ages 18 and older.
Without further ado, here are the five grocery trends to look forward to in 2021.
Flavorful Spices And Condiments

Although many turned to their favorite comfort foods this year, Instacartâ€™s data suggests people may be trying to spice things up more in 2021. The report identified five spices and condiments that got a big boost in year-over-year sales: piri piri sauce (up 725%), Lao Gan Ma (up 227%), zaâ€™atar (up 39%), turmeric (up 18%) and gojuchang (up 17%).

â€œ2021 is shaping up to be a flavorful year. Consumers are looking for quick and easy ways to spice up the meals theyâ€™ve been making at home, and weâ€™re seeing a lot of interest in handcrafted shelf-stable sauces and spice blends on the Instacart marketplace,â€œ said Instacart trends expert and senior product manager Laurentia Romaniuk.
Keto, Keto, Keto

According to Instacartâ€™s survey, 28% of those who tried a diet in 2020 opted for the high-fat, low-carb keto diet. Sales trends were consistent with the survey, as products with â€œketoâ€ in the name saw a 72% increase in the Instacart marketplace.

The cities that had the most keto product orders this year were Austin, San Francisco, San Diego, Sacramento, Houston, Los Angeles, San Antonio, Denver, Chicago and Tampa. Additionally, Instacart found that keto treats in particular were in demand for adherents to the diet. The platform identified the 10 most popular keto products in the marketplace:

KetoPint Salt and Caramel Keto Bar

Think! Keto Protein Bar â€• Chocolate Peanut Butter Pie flavored

Birch Benders Keto Pancake and Waffle Mix

Sundae Shoppe Keto Peanut Butter Fudge Ice Cream

Sundae Shoppe Keto Cookie Dough Ice Cream

Lenny and Larryâ€™s Keto Gluten Free Chocolate Chip Cookie

Sundae Shoppe Keto Mint Chip Ice Cream

Epic Chicken Sriracha Protein Bar

Ratio Keto Friendly Strawberry Dairy Snack

Ratio Keto Friendly Vanilla Dairy Snack
Less Potent Alcohol

â€œHomemade craft cocktails have been popular this year with the work-from-home crowd,â€ Romaniuk said. â€œWeâ€™ve seen sales for trendy alcohol-free spirits boom, increasing by 195% year-over-year. Perhaps consumers are looking to turn over a new leaf in 2021 with tasty, guilt-free libations.â€

In addition to booze-free spirits, consumers have also indicated rising interest in low-calorie alcohol beverages and alcoholic versions of healthy drinks. Hard kombucha rose 320% in Instacart searches, with the most purchases coming from Seattle, San Diego, Sacramento, Los Angeles and San Francisco.
While White Claw continues to dominate, searches for brands across the hard seltzer category rose 519% compared to 2019, and sales spiked in Orlando, Chicago, St. Louis, Tampa and Washington, D.C.
Brand Mindfulness
The year 2020 brought a racial reckoning that raised awareness for many brands owned by people of color. The economic crisis also highlighted the importance of supporting small, locally owned brands.

About 23% of the Instacart survey respondents have researched brands that are locally run or owned in 2020, and 14% said theyâ€™ve researched brands run or owned by women and by BIPOC. The grocery platform predicts consumers will continue to be selective about the stores and brands they support in 2021.
Instacart also put together a list of five women and BIPOC-owned brands to look out for in 2021, based on high-performers that have seen search traffic increases this year:

Partake Foods â€• Allergen-free cookies

Pipcorn â€• Heirloom corn snacks

Pitmaster LTâ€™s â€• Kansas City-style BBQ products

Glory Foods â€• Seasoned vegetables

Uncle Nearest â€• Premium whiskey
Weekday Warriors

With the work-from-home flexibility of 2020, Instacart unsurprisingly saw changes to the grocery shopping schedules people follow. The number of orders placed between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. during the work week rose by 32%.

Twenty-two percent of survey respondents said they shifted from weekend to weekday grocery shopping runs this year, and the number of Instacart orders placed on weekdays increased by 8%. The report predicts that this evolution from the â€œSunday Shopâ€ to the â€œMonday Missionâ€ or the â€œTuesday Tripâ€ may continue into the following year.

otherData.headline: The 17 Best New Shows Of 2020
otherData.short_description: The scripted and unscripted series that got us through this year's ups and downs.

articleContent: There are many words frequently used to describe the year that is 2020: â€œunprecedented,â€ â€œtumultuous,â€ â€œhellish.â€ Itâ€™s been an unrivaled few months filled with loss, lockdowns, hand-washing, social distancing, working from home, homeschooling, takeout. Not to mention, hurricanes and wildfires, police violence and racial injustice and seemingly never-ending election results.
Thankfully, we had a sidekick who was there to get us through it all.

Viewers turned to television as an escape, a way to ease anxieties and silence those racing midnight thoughts. We became obsessed with the world of big cat ownership. We went on culinary journeys. We questioned a career in chess. We even found ourselves relating to a Gen Z crew of babysitters. Although release dates were pushed back and productions delayed, 2020 gifted us with a few scripted and unscripted shows that helped us relax for a while.
Below, the HuffPost Culture team shares their picks for the best new series, limited series, reality series and docu-series of Quarantimes. This list is in no particular order.

otherData.headline: Tom Brady And Ivanka Trump Could Be Neighbors After His $17 Million Property Buy
otherData.short_description: The quarterback and Gisele BÃ¼ndchen bought on Miami's Indian Creek Island, where Ivanka and Jared Kushner also have land, per media reports.

articleContent: Quarterback Tom Brady and model Gisele BÃ¼ndchen bought property on the same Miami island where Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner just purchased land, according to media reports.

The six-time Super Bowl winner and the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue veteran paid $17 million for land on Indian Creek Island and plan to tear down the house thatâ€™s there and rebuild, the New York Post reported.
The coupleâ€™s property is close to the lot that Trump and Kushner, who will lose their jobs as White House advisers on Jan. 20, purchased for over $30 million, The Real Deal noted.
Billionaire Jeff Soffer, a friend of Brady and BÃ¼ndchen, lives on the island as well, the South Florida real estate outlet added.
The island, also known as â€œBillionaire Bunker,â€ is Donald Trump country, with 79% of its 53 presidential votes going to the losing incumbent, according to the Miami Herald.
Brady calls the president a friend but declined to appear at the 2016 Republican National Convention when Trump was nominated the first time.

â€œPolitical support is totally different than the support of a friend,â€ he told Howard Stern earlier this year. â€œThereâ€™s zero win in anything in regards to that. Itâ€™s politics.â€

Brady â€• who is renting former New York Yankee Derek Jeterâ€™s mansion in Tampa, Florida, while he spends his first season with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers after 20 with the New England Patriots â€• is busy on the real estate front. People magazine reported that he and his wife are eyeing new digs in Los Angeles after selling a Manhattan apartment for $40 million.

Reps for Brady and BÃ¼ndchen did not immediately respond to a HuffPost request for comment. HuffPost also reached out to Indian Creek Village manager Jennifer Medina but did not immediately hear back.

otherData.headline: Laura Benanti Celebrates Joe Biden With 2020 Twist On A Holiday Classic
otherData.short_description: The Tony-winning actor and singer known for her Melania Trump impersonations offers her Christmas wish for a "man with a plan" in the White House.

articleContent: With her years of parodying Melania Trump coming to a close, Laura Benanti is ready to usher in a new era with a forward-thinking take on a holiday classic.

The Tony-winning actor and singer on Friday unveiled a new single, â€œ(Everybodyâ€™s Waitinâ€™ for) The Man with a Plan,â€ a politically tinged send-up of 1950â€™s â€œ(Everybodyâ€™s Waitinâ€™ for) The Man with the Bag.â€

Viewable above, the music video finds Benanti and a troupe of dancers executing Rockettes-style choreography as images of the White House and, of course, Melaniaâ€™s infamous Christmas decorations appear behind them. Unlike the original, â€œ(Everybodyâ€™s Waitinâ€™ for) The Man with a Planâ€ swaps out Santa Claus for President-elect Joe Biden, who Benanti hopes will make America â€œfeel normal again.â€

In an interview with HuffPost, Benanti said she found inspiration for the new song by watching classic holiday movies like â€œWhite Christmas.â€ She revised the lyrics in collaboration with comedian Randy Rainbow, who is known for skewering President Donald Trump and other members of the current administration with his musical YouTube series.

â€œRandyâ€™s brand of satire is my cup of tea and he was the first person I thought of for a holiday parody like this,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ve been wanting to collaborate with him for a while, and this was the perfect opportunity!â€

â€œ(Everybodyâ€™s Waitinâ€™ for) The Man with a Planâ€ wraps up a busy year for Benanti, who won a Tony Award in 2008 for â€œGypsyâ€ and is beloved by Broadway fans for her performances in â€œShe Loves Meâ€ and â€œMy Fair Lady,â€ among other musicals.
And though she also boasts a number of screen credits, sheâ€™s perhaps best known to television audiences for her impersonations of the first lady on â€œThe Late Show with Stephen Colbert.â€

As well-received as her version of Melania has been, Benanti is ready to move on, and in October, she unveiled her self-titled solo album. Before COVID-19 was declared a pandemic, sheâ€™d planned to launch the record, which features versions of classic songs as well as pop tunes made famous by Selena Gomez and Rufus Wainwright, with a residency-style series of concerts in New York.
Instead, Benanti wound up spending most of 2020 hunkered down with family in New Jersey, and sadly, lost a grandmother to the coronavirus.

But 2021, as well as the waning weeks of 2020, are looking up. Sheâ€™s the executive producer of â€œHomeschool Musical: Class of 2020,â€ a documentary-style special featuring performances by high school students whose school productions were canceled by the pandemic and slated to debut on HBO Max next week. And sheâ€™s currently filming roles on â€œYoungerâ€ and the much-anticipated â€œGossip Girlâ€ reboot.

As for the incoming White House administration, sheâ€™s hopeful Bidenâ€™s plans for COVID-19 will include stipulations for the performing arts, the future of which remains uncertain amid the ongoing pandemic.
But until then, she hopes viewers find some solace in â€œ(Everybodyâ€™s Waitinâ€™ for) The Man with a Plan.â€

â€œHonestly, I just want to make people laugh, and give them some holiday cheer,â€ she said. â€œIf Iâ€™ve learned anything during the four years Iâ€™ve portrayed Melania Trump ... itâ€™s that the crazier things are, the more we need to laugh, and 2020 has been crazy as hell.â€

otherData.headline: Republicans Back Trumpâ€™s Election Lies To Please Their Base
otherData.short_description: And to protect their political future.

articleContent: Hundreds of elected and appointed Republicans around the country are backing President Donald Trumpâ€™s false claims he won the 2020 presidential election, a widespread embrace that is likely to empower Trumpâ€™s grip over the GOP even after he leaves office and turn belief in Trumpâ€™s falsehoods into a litmus test for a significant segment of Republican voters.

The Republicans embracing Trumpâ€™s cause, and the nonsensical conspiracy theories used to justify it, come from every level of government. They include prominent senators like Texasâ€™ Ted Cruz, ambitious attorneys general, well-known conservative bombthrowers and little-known state legislators. They are egged on by a vocal portion of GOP voters who refuse to accept President-elect Joe Bidenâ€™s victory, and are unlikely to change their minds anytime soon.

â€œThis is going to be a long-term litmus test for some Republicans. Even though Trumpâ€™s leaving office, heâ€™s not going to let go of the reins of the party,â€ said Ryan Williams, a GOP operative who was a top spokesman for Mitt Romneyâ€™s 2012 presidential campaign. He contrasted Trump with former Republican President George W. Bush: â€œHeâ€™s not going to go back to Crawford, Texas, to paint portraits of dogs and foreign leaders.â€

The efforts have zero chance of actually overthrowing the election. Almost every Republican with the power to somehow impact the result has declined to indulge Trumpâ€™s delusions, and many have subsequently faced vociferous criticism from other members of their party.

â€œI make the distinction between whatâ€™s professional wrestling and whatâ€™s a serious attempt to undermine democracy,â€ said Pennsylvania Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, a Democrat who has repeatedly worked to shoot down conspiracy theories about Bidenâ€™s narrow win in the state. He noted GOP leaders in Pennsylvaniaâ€™s state Legislature â€œhave never made an actual move to overthrow the election result.â€

The most recent evidence of the GOPâ€™s decision to back Trumpâ€™s claims came on Wednesday afternoon, when 17 state attorneys general submitted an amicus brief to the Supreme Court backing a spurious lawsuit from Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton seeking to throw out the election results in four states won by Biden: Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan and Georgia.
Trump, meanwhile, is actively asking congressional Republicans to sign on to a similar amicus brief, written by Louisiana GOP Rep. Mike Johnson, backing the Texas lawsuit.

â€œPresident Trump called me this morning to express his great appreciation for our effort to file an amicus brief in the Texas case on behalf of concerned members of Congress,â€ Johnson wrote in an email to his fellow House Republicans, which was first obtained by CNN. â€œHe specifically asked me to contact all Republican members of the House and Senate today and request that all join on to our brief. He said he will be anxiously awaiting the final list to review.â€
One hundred and five House Republicans, more than half of the party caucus, signed on to Johnsonâ€™s brief, which was filed Thursday afternoon.

Paxtonâ€™s suit illustrates the self-interested game many elected Republicans are playing. Paxton, who is facing a federal investigation for securities fraud, is thought to be lobbying for a pardon from Trump before the president leaves office.

Wisconsin Sen. Ron Johnson also announced Wednesday that he would hold a Senate Homeland Security Committee hearing on â€œirregularities in the 2020 electionâ€ next week, though itâ€™s unclear who the witnesses will be.

After being pressured by Trump to overturn Bidenâ€™s win in Pennsylvania, 64 elected state legislators there sent a letter to their congressional delegation urging them to reject the stateâ€™s Biden electors in January. State Senate Majority Leader Kim Ward, a Republican, did not see the letter in time to sign it, according to The New York Times, but suggested pressure from the base made it impossible for her to say if she would not have signed it.
â€œIf I would say to you, â€˜I donâ€™t want to do it,â€™â€ Ward told the Times, â€œIâ€™d get my house bombed tonight.â€

Republican lawmakers in Arizona, Michigan and Pennsylvania felt the need to hold special hearings to allow the presidentâ€™s lawyers Rudy Giuliani and Jenna Ellis to air false conspiracy theories about supposed election fraud. The hearings ultimately forced the closure of the Arizona and Michigan legislatures after Giuliani and Ellis tested positive for the coronavirus after spreading it to legislators in both states.

One of the lawsuits promoted by Giuliani and Ellis was filed by Republican Rep. Mike Kelly (Penn.) and failed congressional candidate Sean Parnell. After the suit failed at every level before reaching the U.S. Supreme Court, Cruz suggested, at Trumpâ€™s request, that he would offer his services to argue the case if the court took it up. The court refused to take the case on Tuesday with no dissent.

Meanwhile, in Washington, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) and Senate Rules Committee Chairman Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) voted to block the congressional inauguration committee from recognizing Biden as the president-elect.

A slew of public surveys indicate a majority of Republican voters believe Trumpâ€™s unsupported claims about widespread election fraud. An NPR/PBS Newshour/Marist College poll released Wednesday morning found just 24% of Republicans trust the results, compared to 61% of Americans overall and 67% of independent voters. (An overwhelming 95% of Democrats said they trusted the results.)

Backing the overturning of the election result and the end of American democracy is just the latest in the Republican Partyâ€™s long history of litmus tests imposed by the furthest right flank of the party. This dynamic was introduced into the party by the New Right political movement in the middle of the 20th century and became a routine feature after the movement took over the party after Ronald Reaganâ€™s 1980 White House win.
Since then, elected Republicans have been consistently pressured from the right to take increasingly extreme positions in order to fend off primary challengers from their conservative movement base.
