This played out when Rep. Tom DeLay (R-Texas) pressured House Republicans to impeach President Bill Clinton after the party lost seats in the 1998 midterm elections. â€œBesides, the DeLay camp says, a vote to impeach the President is the perfect inoculation for moderate Republicans under assault from conservatives in their districts,â€ CNN reported at the time.

After President Barack Obamaâ€™s election, Republicans had to meet the litmus test of not supporting Obama â€” or even hugging him, as then-Republican Florida Gov. Charlie Crist learned. Appearing at an event to promote stimulus spending in his state, Crist hugged Obama â€” leading to a primary loss to Marco Rubio in the 2010 Senate race. Crist is now a Democratic House member.

These litmus tests also often ran along ideological lines related to contemporary positions on immigration or gun rights or free market economics. But Trumpâ€™s election has mostly swept away these concerns and made the sole GOP litmus test fealty to Trump. There are a handful of elected Republicans who are willing to publicly cross Trump. And many of those who did hold office, like Sens. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) and Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) and Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wisc.), retired. Rep. Justin Amash (I-Mich.) left the party before retiring. And some, like former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty, lost party primaries because they werenâ€™t pro-Trump enough.

â€œThe Republican Party has shifted,â€ Pawlenty said after losing his stateâ€™s Republican Party gubernatorial primary to a Trump supporter in 2018. â€œIt is the era of Trump and Iâ€™m just not a Trump-like politician.â€

The partyâ€™s kneel-before-Trump litmus test also means that party members must either support the presidentâ€™s worst actions or pretend not to see them. Members who dared attack Trump after the release of the Access Hollywood tape where he jokingly boasted of sexually assaulting women were savaged by pro-Trump opponents, and many lost primary elections. (More than two dozen women have accused Trump of sexual assault.) Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) was the only congressional Republican to vote to impeach Trump after the president tried to pressure Ukraine to interfere in the 2020 election on his behalf.

And so now the Republican Party must defend Trumpâ€™s effort to steal the 2020 election and install himself as ruler to protect themselves from primary challenges. Whether or not the defense is sincere is irrelevant. By feeding their conservative baseâ€™s desire to believe that the election was stolen, elected Republicans are verifying those beliefs.

Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp and Arizona Gov. Doug Ducey, both Republicans, are already facing Trumpâ€™s wrath after they both certified Bidenâ€™s wins in their respective states. Trump tweeted that the two Republican governors â€œfight harder against us than do the Radical Left Dems.â€ He suggested that retiring Rep. Doug Collins (R-Ga.) primary Kemp in 2022.

And while the midterm elections are a long way away, attacks on Kemp and Ducey could hurt GOP chances in key races in 2022. Democratic rising star Stacey Abrams, whose organizing has been credited with helping secure Bidenâ€™s victory in Georgia, plans to run for governor again. Sheâ€™d almost certainly rather face the arch-conservative Collins than Kemp, an incumbent.

Ducey is term-limited, but Senate Republicans are likely to try to persuade him to challenge Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly, who will be running for a full term after winning a special election last month. Trumpâ€™s antagonism toward Ducey could encourage other Republicans to run for the partyâ€™s nomination.

In Pennsylvania, meanwhile, Fetterman â€• who is openly considering his own bid for Senate â€• predicted almost every Republican running for office in the Keystone State would need to embrace Trumpâ€™s conspiracies.

â€œThere isnâ€™t going to be a Republican thatâ€™s going to run on the platform that Joe Biden won the election fair and square,â€ he said. â€œIf you represent a series of counties that voted 80% for Donald Trump and he says â€˜X,â€™ and you donâ€™t toe that line, you might as well look for a new line of work. Thereâ€™s always going to be someone willing to primary you on that.â€

otherData.headline: Video Shows How Much Face Shields Protect Against A 'Sneeze Vortex'
otherData.short_description: Sneezes produce a fluid phenomenon known as "vortex rings." Here's what that looks like and how well your face covering stops it.

articleContent: A video showing a simulation of someone sneezing near another person wearing a face shield has revealed exactly how much protection such face covers can offer â€• and the answer is, not much.
Researchers at Fukuoka University in Japan wanted to better understand what happens to the airflow around a face shield when someone nearby sneezes.

They were particularly interested in sneezes because they produce a fluid phenomenon known as â€œvortex rings,â€ which lead researcher Fujio Akagi says is â€œa donut-shaped vortex that is generated by an instantaneous ejection of fluid from a circular orificeâ€ â€• a bit like bubble rings made by dolphins.

Researchers found when a face shield wearer is exposed to a sneeze from an infected person standing about 3 feet away, the vortex rings generated by the sneeze capture microscopic droplets and transport them to the top and bottom edges of the face shield.
They concluded that face shields alone are not â€œhighly effectiveâ€ to prevent COVID-19 infection, as aerosols can still be inhaled through the nose and mouth.

On their own, face shields can help protect the wearer from the bulk of larger droplets caused by a cough or sneeze a short distance away, but studies have found smaller aerosols can travel up and underneath the shield.

A study of healthcare workers found wearing a face shield reduced exposure to flu by 96% in the period immediately after a cough â€“ from 18 inches away. But in the context of a smaller aerosol, the face shield was less effective, blocking only 68% of the cough.

In the half an hour period after a cough, during which the aerosol had dispersed throughout the room and larger particles had settled, the face shield was less effective, the study found â€• with researchers concluding that people wearing face shields can still inhale infectious airborne particles.

â€œThey cannot be used as a substitute for respiratory protection when it is needed,â€ researchers said of face shields.

Fujio Akagi tells HuffPost UK that people who want to prevent COVID-19 infection should wear a face mask under a face shield. Health experts agree â€• and have continued to do so throughout the pandemic â€• that doubling up offers the best protection.

David Strain, a clinician at the Royal Devon and Exeter Hospital in the UK, previously told HuffPost UK that face shields on their own are not protective and should be worn in addition to a face mask, rather than as a replacement. And Julian Tang, honorary associate professor in respiratory sciences at the University of Leicester, previously said face shields are â€œbetter than nothing,â€ but recommended wearing a shield and face mask together for â€œadded protection.â€

One of the benefits of wearing a shield is that it can protect the eyes from potential droplet exposure, whereas a face mask alone cannot. They are also washable and re-useable, and less claustrophobic than masks.

â€œHowever, as our research shows, small droplets and aerosolized COVID-19 can enter the shield and can be inhaled,â€ Akagi says. â€œSo wearing a face mask and a face shield reinforces the weaknesses of both and is a much more effective preventive measure.â€

â€œWe are currently developing and demonstrating several improved shields,â€ Akagi continues. â€œWe want to contribute to keeping people safe from infection, and believe that one day in the near future, medical workers will be able to prevent infection using only a face shield and a regular mask or, ideally, with only a face shield.â€
This story originally appeared in HuffPost UK.

Experts are still learning about COVID-19. The information in this story is what was known or available as of publication, but guidance can change as scientists discover more about the virus. Please check the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the most updated recommendations.

otherData.headline: Eggnog Taste Test: The Best And Worst Nogs For Your Buck
otherData.short_description: We tried 11 nationally available eggnogs (three of them nondairy) and found a clear winner.

articleContent: Move over, PSL, itâ€™s eggnogâ€™s time to shine. For those of us who associate The Holidaysâ„¢ with a glass of the custard-like beverage, the sight of bottles and cartons of nog snuggled against the usual dairy offerings at the grocery store is a welcome sight.
But itâ€™s also overwhelming! Which one do you choose? The generic grocery store brand, or the expensive organic stuff?

While homemade eggnog is the best, itâ€™s easier to grab a bottle at the store and live off of it for a week â€” put it in your coffee, turn it into a nightcap with bourbon, drink it from the bottle while standing at the fridge ... there are no more rules.

Proper eggnog should have a golden color, but shouldnâ€™t actually taste like eggs. It should be laced with nutmeg and maybe cinnamon. And when buying it at the store, there are obviously a lot of additives to be wary of, but sometimes you just have to do your best.

To help make your holiday season more festive, HuffPost enlisted the help of Kelly Cornett, an Atlanta-based wine educator and host of the podcast â€A Cork in the Road.â€ We taste tested 11 nationally available eggnogs (three of them are nondairy) and there was definitely a clear winner. Here are the picks, from best to worst.
Dairy Options
1. Mayfield

When Santaâ€™s face is blown up and plastered on the bottle, itâ€™s a sign of good things. Mayfieldâ€™s eggnog hit the right notes all the way around. It was a visual treat in the glass with a deep golden hue and plenty of flecks of spices, and had the flavor and texture to support it. â€œIâ€™m so down with this,â€ Cornett said. â€œThe texture is decadent. This is like dessert.â€
2. 365 Everyday Value

The Whole Foods brand eggnog is not for the calorie-conscious â€” it packs a whopping 210 calories per half cup â€” but at least itâ€™s incredibly delicious. Cornettâ€™s first observation was how aromatic it was. â€œIt kind of reminds me of when Cinnamon Toast Crunch sits in your cereal too long,â€ she said. Warming, and not too sweet with almost the right texture moved it up to No. 2 on our list. Bonus points for mostly pronounceable ingredients.
3. Market Pantry

The first thing you notice about the Target brand eggnog is how much it resembles melted ice cream. Itâ€™s slightly eggy, but has a strong vanilla and ginger flavor (ginger is great, but nutmeg is a defining spice of eggnog). While it wasnâ€™t a beverage that we wanted to sit around and drink by the fire, the thinner consistency did seem like it would lend itself nicely to cooking (letâ€™s say, French toast) and could be properly spiced in the process.
4. Lactaid

Lactaid is lactose-free (meaning itâ€™s had an enzyme called lactase added to it), but that didnâ€™t stop it from ranking moderately high on our list. It had a nice vanilla flavor with a hint of spice, making it delicious to sip, even if not as â€œnoggyâ€ as we would have liked.
5. Southern Comfort

The liqueur brand makes a booze-free eggnog and itâ€™s â€• fine. The color is so yellow it â€œresembles beaten eggs,â€ Cornett said, and it was almost cloyingly sweet. But we wouldnâ€™t be offended if someone served us this, and maybe if you added some SoCo it would make a nice sipper.
6. Promised Land Dairy

Things were off to a â€” ahem â€” promising start with Promised Land and its old fashioned-looking bottle. The nogâ€™s golden hue was inviting, but was too sweet and lacked depth. â€œThatâ€™s more like condensed milk kind of sweetness. Not a warm spice sweetness,â€ Cornett said. It was like drinking sugary liquid yogurt.
7. Trader Joeâ€™s

We had high hopes for the Trader Joeâ€™s brand of eggnog, but it thudded harder than Santaâ€™s fall off the roof in â€The Santa Clause.â€ It had a thin consistency, and the turmeric in the beverage overtook the flavor. â€œThis is just kind of a basic milk beverage. It doesnâ€™t really float in one way or the other,â€ Cornett said.
8. Horizon Low Fat

Horizon, an organic brand, appears to only sell low-fat eggnog. It had a runny consistency and tasted synthetically sweet, which was surprising, considering the listed ingredients all were real. Sadly, it moved straight to the top of our naughty list.
Dairy-free options
1. 356 Everyday Value Almond Nog

Almond milk will never be that thick, but 365â€™s almond nog did a pretty good job replicating the real deal. Although cinnamon isnâ€™t listed in the ingredients (it contains nutmeg and ginger), it had a warm cinnamon scent that made up for the lack of dairy and eggs. If you donâ€™t drink dairy or you want a lower calorie option, this would be a great one.
2. Silk
Soy milk isnâ€™t without its problems, but Silkâ€™s dairy-free nog was the best of the three we tried. It was almost rich and had a nice hint of spice.
3. Califia Farms

The almond milk brandâ€™s nog bottle certainly sets a festive tone, but unfortunately, it had a watery consistency and was way too sweet. Weâ€™re not saying youâ€™d have to be a cotton-headed ninny muggins to drink this one, but you can do better.

otherData.headline: Here's Where The Term 'Lame Duck' Comes From
otherData.short_description: The history of the "lame duck" descriptor dates back to the London Stock Exchange.

articleContent: Following the election of former Vice President Joe Biden, President Donald Trump is in the â€œlame duckâ€ period of his one-term presidency. This new era has spawned many cartoons and even merchandise featuring Trump illustrated as a duck.
But why is an outgoing president called a lame duck, anyway? It turns out the term dates back centuries.
The earliest reported reference to the term comes in a December 1761 letter written by British historian and politician Horace Walpole to Sir Horace Mann.

â€œDo you know what a Bull, and a Bear, and a Lame Duck are?â€ he asked, alluding to a phrase used in the Exchange Alley, or â€œChange Alley,â€ coffeehouses that evolved into the London Stock Exchange.

â€œLame duckâ€ described a person who defaulted on his debt. The idea was that this trader would be powerless and vulnerable to predators, like a duck unable to keep up with its flock. Unable to pay up, the defaulter has to â€œwaddleâ€ off.
In 1771, playwright David Garrick wrote, â€œChange-Alley bankrupts waddle out lame ducks!â€ in the prologue to Samuel Footeâ€™s play â€œThe Maid of Bath.â€

The term remained in use into the 19th century and eventually reached the U.S. financial markets and other areas of culture. â€œLame duckâ€ reportedly appeared in naval contexts to refer to an â€œold, slow shipâ€ as well.
In 1869, writer George W. Bungay used the phrase in reference to supporters of the temperance movement who faltered in their commitment over time.

â€œIn Wall Street, New York, we have a class of men known as â€˜lame ducksâ€™: they have met with financial disasters, and can not keep pace with their more successful competitors,â€ he wrote. â€œWe have lame ducks in our temperance associations, and I will briefly classify some of the men and women who do not and who will not keep up with our progressive organization. The lame ducks were once out-and-out friends of â€˜the cause.â€™ ... When they have attempted to swim in whisky, they have become â€˜dead ducks.â€™â€

The political application of the term appeared around the same time. In 1844, a writer for the Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, newspaper The Compiler opined about presidential candidates: â€œHenry Clay is acknowledged to be first rate at the game of brag, but [James K.] Polk will make a lame duck of him.â€ President Abraham Lincoln reportedly once said, â€[A] senator or representative out of business is a sort of lame duck. He has to be provided for,â€ per the Online Etymology Dictionary.

And according to a January 1863 issue of The Congressional Globe (a record of the official proceedings of the U.S. Congress in the mid-1800s), Sen. Lazarus W. Powell of Kentucky stated, â€œIn no event, either as originally organized or as now organized, could [the Court of Claims] be justly obnoxious to the charge of being a receptacle of â€˜lame ducksâ€™ or broken down politicians.â€

In the early 20th century, â€œlame duckâ€ began to refer more specifically to politicians who had lost their recent elections but hadnâ€™t yet left office. The New York Evening Post in 1910 alluded to â€œLame Duck Alley ... a screened-off corridor in the White House offices, where statesmen who went down in the recent electoral combat may meet.â€ In 1922, The New York Times mentioned a plan â€œto have the convening of Congress moved up to avoid lame-duck Congresses.â€

As for the executive branch, Republican Calvin Coolidge was the subject of a 1926 editorial from the Grand Rapids Press called â€œMaking A Lame Duck of Coolidgeâ€ about the possibility of a Democratic Senate majority during the final two years of the presidentâ€™s term.

â€œLame duckâ€ informally made its way into constitutional discussions with the adoption of the 20th Amendment in 1933. Nicknamed the â€œLame Duck Amendment,â€ it moved the dates for the inauguration of the president and the start of the new Congress.

People still use â€œlame duckâ€ to refer to outgoing presidents and members of Congress in the period before newly elected officials take office. Itâ€™s also used to describe congressional sessions during that time.
The term has faced criticism, however, for being ableist and mischaracterizing the role presidents can play at the end of their terms.
In 2015, Atlantic writer Megan Garber described â€œlame duckâ€ as â€œa terrible term.â€

â€œIt is jargon-y. It is partisan. It is poorly descriptive. It is offensive to both humans and, we can reasonably assume, the entire waterfowl community,â€ she wrote. â€œMore than anything, though, â€˜lame duckâ€™ is often simply inaccurate: The golden years of a presidency can be, for better or for worse, intensely productive ones â€” not just despite a presidentâ€™s ability to extricate himself from standard political pageantries, but because of it.â€
For now, â€œlame duckâ€ remains the descriptor many are using for the period after the 2020 election. Still, as one Twitter user posited, perhaps â€œpresident-ejectâ€ would be a better alternative.

otherData.headline: What Are Your COVID-19 Vaccine Questions? Ask Our Experts
otherData.short_description: What do the new coronavirus vaccinations mean for your heath and safety? Our experts will answer your questions about this next stage of the pandemic.

articleContent: Thank you for joining our Q&A with our health experts on December 17. You can view their responses here. If you did not get to leave a question or your question wasnâ€™t answered, you can email coronavirus.questions@huffpost.com. Our reporters may answer them in a future story.

As we enter the 10th month of the coronavirus pandemic in the U.S. and COVID-19 cases continue to surge, weâ€™ve finally received some positive news: One vaccine has been granted emergency authorization use by the Food and Drug Administration, people have started to receive the first doses and other vaccine candidates are showing promise.

What questions do you have about the vaccine as we enter this next phase of the pandemic? Are you wondering when will they be available, or how will they be distributed? What groups will get the vaccine first? Are there any side effects? Exactly how effective will they be? Will life return to normal as more people are vaccinated?

Leave your questions in the comments here, and HuffPost medical contributor Dr. Kavita Patel and senior wellness editor Lindsay Holmes will respond to as many as they can. Check back on Dec. 17 between 1:30 and 3 p.m. ET for their answers. (If youâ€™re using a HuffPost mobile app, click on the quote icon at the bottom of your screen to see the comments.)

Note: Please avoid sharing personally identifiable health information about yourself or others in this thread, as these comments are public. And please be aware that any general advice provided here is no substitute for consulting your doctor or health care professional.

Dr. Kavita Patel is a practicing internal medicine physician in D.C. and senior scholar at the Brookings Institution working on health policy. She is also an adviser to New Enterprise Associates, one of the worldâ€™s largest venture capital funds. She has worked on disaster preparedness, first in Los Angeles County, then in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, in the White House on swine flu and now on COVID-19.

Lindsay Holmes is the senior wellness editor at HuffPost, where she oversees the health content for HuffPost Life and writes about mental health. She was selected for a National Press Foundation mental health fellowship in 2016 and has participated in multiple panels on how mental health is covered in the media. She graduated with a degree in journalism from the University of Central Florida and lives in New York.

otherData.headline: Getting Through ... With Mominatu
otherData.short_description: At just 26 years old, this free spirit moved to Dakar, Senegal, to open up her first yoga studio.

articleContent: At just 26 years old, Mominatu has lived many lives. Sheâ€™s traveled the world â€” Puerto Rico, Portugal, India, Tanzania and Ecuador â€” and through it all, she has cultivated a deep yoga practice that has allowed her to stay grounded no matter where she is. This year, the model-turned-yoga instructor embarked on her biggest adventure yet: moving to Dakar, Senegal, to open her first yoga studio.

Of course, she couldnâ€™t have anticipated the emergence of COVID-19, but rather than throw a complete wrench in her business venture, the past several months have created opportunities for Mominatu to learn how to adapt and grow. Nine months after moving to Dakar, sheâ€™s birthed a beautiful community of mostly Black women, teaching virtual and socially distanced yoga classes to local clients who are discovering a new way of finding peace amid mayhem.
In this interview for â€œGetting Through,â€ Mominatu discusses finding community, the key to mastering meditation and, after years of jet-setting, what sheâ€™s learned about the power of being still.
OK, first: How are you, really?

I think weâ€™ve all been quietly going through it. As a Black woman in a patriarchal world, youâ€™re always quietly going through it â€” on top of a pandemic, on top of racism, on top of the world sliding, falling apart. On top of people not honoring Black bodies. Itâ€™s like everyone is walking around with this weight on their backs. And any single person who is saying they are â€œOKâ€ and that â€œeverything is fineâ€ has either not tapped into themselves â€” spiritually, emotionally or mentally â€” or are too privileged to acknowledge anything because it doesnâ€™t affect them.

On your Instagram, youâ€™ve talked a lot about how yoga has helped center you during the hardest times. Right now you are in your studio in Dakar, getting ready to lead your first yoga class for the day. How did you find your way to Senegal, and how did you find your way to starting this yoga practice?

Well, for some background, Iâ€™m Liberian and Senegalese. I went to school in America for broadcast journalism and a minor in fashion business. And then I was like, â€œMmm, this ainâ€™t it for me.â€ I decided I wanted to start traveling the world. I moved to Puerto Rico from Chicago with my best friend. I just followed my intuition and have been blessed along the way. I was doing marketing in Puerto Rico, and then I got signed to a major modeling agency. It was always my dream to model, so I did that. Then from Puerto Rico, I was like, â€œAll right, Iâ€™ve made it here. Iâ€™ve done billboards here. Iâ€™ve done commercial campaigns. Maybe Iâ€™ll go to New York and see what thatâ€™s about.â€ This was after watching this movie, â€œBegin Again.â€ I was like, â€œThese motherfuckers are on the rooftops and shit, following their dreams!â€ Iâ€™m like, â€œWhat am I doing sitting in Puerto Rico? I want to go to New York.â€ [Laughs] So I went to New York, and I got signed with this management team and started modeling there. But throughout it all, for the past 11 years, I was always practicing yoga. I got a yoga teacher training certification when I was 18.

I always had the intention of deepening my own practice because it was something that I needed. I never called it anxiety because Iâ€™m African and â€œwe donâ€™t have depression and anxiety,â€ right? [Laughs] Thatâ€™s a white people thing, right? But I never, ever felt good. There was always this underlying trauma. I always needed yoga, and I always needed meditation or working out to find an equilibrium. And whenever I fell out of my practice, I found that I was not OK. It has always been a medicine for me, and Iâ€™m sure maybe it would have been better for me had I found, like, actual medicine, but that was the holistic approach [that] has worked for me and has allowed me to not only heal myself, but to use this practice to heal others. And thatâ€™s what brought me to Africa this year. I have decided to come back to Senegal, which is where my mom is from, and to bring yoga from a Black woman to the Senegalese people.
And how has that experience been for you? What has the response been from the people who take your classes?

Iâ€™ve been here for nine months now. Iâ€™ve been teaching the community classes for about five months, and people are loving it. Senegalese people are loving it. They wanted it. They wanted it! I had a class on the beach just the other day. Let me tell you: My first-ever class, I was scared shitless. I had my friends â€” who are social media influencers and theyâ€™re very powerful people â€” and they came, theyâ€™re like, â€œBitch, if you donâ€™t teach this mothafuckinâ€™ class...â€ [Laughs] And theyâ€™re like, â€œWeâ€™re just gonna sit in class and weâ€™re going to put you on the stories. Teach a class.â€ And so Iâ€™m there and my class was full, and it was all Black women. It was all Senegalese women, Senegalese diaspora, Africans.

And when one of the girls left the beach, a guy came up to her. Heâ€™s like, â€œYou know, I have never, ever, ever seen Black people doing this. Itâ€™s always the white girls that come from America.â€ And that was so powerful for me. And now, fast forward, all my classes are Black. I mean, of course I have Lebanese clients and my private clients, but my group classes are African. They are Senegalese. And even African men are taking my classes. These men are coming in and stretching, and theyâ€™re not here for the fine girls. [Laughs] Theyâ€™re here to find their peace.
What are your self-care rituals? Not just yoga, but other things that you do to stay grounded and centered?

I wake up in the morning at like 5 a.m., and I use a tongue scraper. Are you familiar with those Ayurvedic tongue scrapers, to get out all of the bacteria? And then I do oil pulling with coconut oil for 20 minutes. I just walk around the house. It changes everything. Everything. And then once Iâ€™m done with the oil pulling, I love herbs, so Iâ€™ll do an herbal tea to warm up. And then I do this specific massage called Abhyanga, and thatâ€™s an Ayurvedic self-massage. I love Ayurvedic science, and I treat my body on those philosophies. But the idea, basically, is pouring love into yourself. You take hot oil and you rub â€” itâ€™s almost like lymphatic drainage. You rub the oil going down in strokes and then circling around the joints to [do] lymphatic drainage, but also as a self-love ritual. As you massage yourself, taking the time to really moisturize is an act of love. Itâ€™s like cleaning your temple. So I do that. And then I will go to the gym or train my first client that day. But those are things that, truly, no bullshit, Iâ€™m not the same person if I donâ€™t start my day with those things. And then, of course, meditation.
How has yoga, meditation and all these practices changed your outlook on your life, and specifically during this time, how have they aided you in dealing with the chaos of 2020?

So for me, I like to say that yoga and meditation is very selfish, right? It allows you to deal with your own shit, but it doesnâ€™t really show you how to deal with the world around you. So meditation allowed me to realize I wasnâ€™t OK. And in that awareness, I could say, â€œAll right, so what am I going to do about not feeling good right now?â€ ... We got a pandemic. We got to stay in the house. We canâ€™t go anywhere. All right. Thatâ€™s that. Now you got Black Lives Matter, the racism. All right. Then what? Itâ€™s just like, youâ€™re constantly just â€” [takes three pronounced gasps] â€” taking in all these gulps until youâ€™re like, â€œI. Canâ€™t. Breathe. Anymore.â€ You know?

So I think having the awareness of what was going on allowed me to feel it. I know that sounds really weird, but I think the knowing and the grieving and being able to know what I was crying about [helped a lot], whereas a lot of my friends were just like, â€œI donâ€™t know why Iâ€™m so upset.â€ Itâ€™s like, â€œBabes, open your eyes.â€
You canâ€™t solve a problem if you canâ€™t name it.

Exactly. And thatâ€™s what meditation did for me. It allows me the space to have stillness, to understand whatâ€™s going on and how I respond and react to that. And to find a little bit of peace under pressure.
What was the worst thing that happened this year, so far?

The worst thing? [Laughs] Iâ€™ll be deadass. I was messing around with this one dude who was just devil dick. Weâ€™re all quarantining. We had a curfew here, so you couldnâ€™t leave the house past 7 p.m. You couldnâ€™t be on the streets. In Senegal, they were beating people [for breaking curfew]. So, you know, you had your little quarantine bae. Just that loneliness of having to be home all the time, youâ€™re sort of blind. There was this heartbreak from having this nigga over all the time and realizing that I was just his nice little house to chill at, you know what I mean? So that, for me, was the worst thing that happened â€” but also the best thing that happened, because it propelled me to focus on my yoga and go into super-drive for work. But the quarantine bae situation, I got played. [Laughs]
And then on the flip side, what would you say is the best thing thatâ€™s happened this year so far?

Launching my business and being able to ground in a space. I think corona has been a blessing because Iâ€™m always on the move, and thatâ€™s something that I learned in my meditation â€” that when shit got difficult, I booked a flight. I was like, â€œYou know what, let me just go to Bali for a little bit.â€ You know what I mean? â€œLet me like find my zen.â€ But it was like, what the fuck is that? Like, if you canâ€™t find zen within the space youâ€™re at, you donâ€™t really have zen. Youâ€™re just escaping. Because home is within you. You take you everywhere. So if at any point you get a little uncomfortable, youâ€™re jumping and running â€” youâ€™ve got nothing concrete.

What would be your advice to anyone whoâ€™s struggling? And when I say struggling, I mean, struggling to cope with everything thatâ€™s coming their way, struggling with their mental health, struggling to be happy and content in this really chaotic time.

I would say, donâ€™t fake it. Acknowledge where youâ€™re at and donâ€™t let anyone tell you how youâ€™re supposed to feel. But most importantly, community and finding people to just talk to and listen. It could be a therapist or it could be someone thatâ€™s one step ahead of you. Someone that genuinely wants to listen. â€™Cause oftentimes, people â€” especially yoga instructors â€” say, â€œWell, do some meditation, do some yoga, eat some good food.â€ Like, â€œBitch, itâ€™s serotonin. Itâ€™s not kale.â€ Sometimes, it really does require Lexapro, you know what I mean? There are other tools.

But I think the first step is acknowledging where you are and not faking it, because youâ€™re living in your own prison because you have no integrity to your soul. Youâ€™re showing everyone this nice and pretty version of you when, inside, youâ€™re crying and dying and no one can see your pain. So the only way that someone can help you or that you can get out of your situation is by one, acknowledging where you are, and two, understanding that you donâ€™t do this life alone, so ask for help. And after asking for help, saying, â€œAll right, so what are some tools that I can take to get to where I need to be?â€ It can be professional help or could even just be a friend. But I think the biggest thing with people suffering right now is that it seems like itâ€™s a collective thing, [yet] no one wants to place their burden on someone else. When in reality, through us being able to discuss suffering, weâ€™re able to be like, â€œOh, itâ€™s you, too? Oh, OK.â€ And that collectiveness, that â€” [takes deep, intentional sigh] â€” that collective sigh is enough. So I think thatâ€™s what I would recommend: finding a community.

Yeah. I think that dovetails with this other idea Iâ€™ve been thinking a lot about over the past several months, which is that it feels like the world is ending in a lot of ways, but not in a bad way. It feels like a lot of institutions, systems, structures that have oppressed us are crumbling or have the potential to crumble. And that is inviting the possibility for imagination and imagining a new world. Iâ€™m curious to know what world, what portals are you imagining, what are you manifesting for the rest of the year and the years to come?
Radical self-thought. In a way, Iâ€™m very, very thankful for Donald Trump because he showed us we werenâ€™t bullshitting. We werenâ€™t lying. Racism was real.

Iâ€™d like to see more authenticity. More people just standing [up against injustice], but I also just want the whole fucking thing to deconstruct. I would like to see everything flipped upside down. I just want the whole cup to be poured over. I want to see the world tap into itself in a way that is not what we want to see necessarily, but what it is. And I think that itâ€™s going to get so much more ugly before it gets good, but thatâ€™s how we build. Thatâ€™s how we grow.
Itâ€™s necessary, yeah.

Suffering can be ugly, but it isnâ€™t necessarily bad. Iâ€™m sure when you were in school and you were like, â€œIâ€™m not trying to do this motherfuckinâ€™ journalism class. This is hell on Earth!â€ [Laughs] You know what I mean? It was suffering for you at that time. But maybe you look back on that now and itâ€™s like, â€œWow, Iâ€™m so thankful for that because thatâ€™s what made me who I am. These situations, this trauma, this whatever put me into the space that I needed to be.â€ So I think itâ€™s just shifting the narrative and shifting our perception.
Finally, what are the books, movies and music that have fed you, that have centered you during this time?

Wow. Thatâ€™s a beautiful question. I love that. â€œPurple Hibiscusâ€ was a treat in lockdown. I listened to a lot of Ethiopian jazz, so Dexter Story, the â€œBahirâ€ album. Florence and the Machine, her latest album. A lot of Osho â€” I love Osho. I know heâ€™s so controversial, but I love Oshoâ€™s books. I love his talks.
This interview has been edited for clarity and length.
More recommendations from Mominatu
Books: â€œThe Wind-Up Bird Chronicleâ€ by Haruki Murakami, â€œThe Picture of Dorian Grayâ€ by Oscar Wilde, â€œA Course in Miraclesâ€ by Helen Schucman
Movies: â€œPonyo,â€ â€œTableau Ferraille,â€ â€œTouki Boukiâ€
TV shows: â€³Ethosâ€, The Crown Season 4, â€œThe Queenâ€™s Gambitâ€
Music: â€œBlack Rainâ€ by Rhye, â€œDearest Alfredâ€ by Khruangbin, â€œCome Overâ€ by Jorja Smith, â€œTime Fliesâ€ by Burna Boy, â€œChamber of Reflectionâ€ by Mac DeMarco

â€œGetting Throughâ€¦â€ explores the ways in which people from all backgrounds and walks of life â€” artists, scientists, entertainers, healers, activists, entrepreneurs and â€œeverydayâ€ folks â€” are processing, connecting and taking care of themselves and others during these wild times. Hopefully, these conversations will serve as a record and a guide for anyone who reads them. Read the first installment with author Fariha RÃ³isÃ­n.

otherData.headline: Tribes Want Deb Haaland For Interior Secretary. Some Biden Advisers Are Trying To Thwart Her.
otherData.short_description: Anonymous Biden allies are telling news outlets the Indigenous congresswoman is not qualified. "Of course it's offensive," said Rep. Raul Grijalva (D-Ariz.).

articleContent: For weeks, leaders of Native American tribes all over the country have been urging President-elect Joe Biden to pick Rep. Deb Haaland (D-N.M.) to be his interior secretary. So have dozens of members of Congress, including Republicans.

But for some reason, some of Bidenâ€™s advisers have begun anonymously planting the idea in news stories that the Native American congresswoman, who chairs a House subcommittee with oversight of the Interior Department, is not qualified. Whatâ€™s also puzzling is that these sources say a better candidate is a lesser-known man who is also Native, Michael Connor, despite dozens of tribal leaders telling Biden, publicly and privately, that they back Haaland.

â€œBut her lack of policy experience worries some Biden advisers, who have suggested another Native American candidate: Michael L. Connor, a deputy interior secretary in the Obama administration, whose experience is unquestioned,â€ reads a New York Times piece in late November.
â€œBut many of Mr. Bidenâ€™s advisers fear that she lacks the experience to manage the sprawling complex agency,â€ reads a second New York Times piece on Thursday.

Another anonymous â€œconservation sourceâ€ told The Hill on Wednesday that Haalandâ€™s support by progressive groups could complicate her Senate confirmation. This person suggested Haalandâ€™s support for the Green New Deal, a legislative plan aimed at addressing climate change and economic inequality, could cause problems.
But Biden himself has called the proposal a â€œcrucial framework,â€ and another top candidate for Interior, Sen. Tom Udall (D-N.M.), supports the plan, too.

The anonymous slights against Haaland havenâ€™t gone unnoticed by her supporters, who say they are angry and confused to see her being belittled by people in Bidenâ€™s orbit. Some prominent Native women have noted the sexism of the anonymous comments, per reporter Julian Brave Noisecat. Some of Haalandâ€™s supporters made similar suggestions to HuffPost privately; others were willing to go public with their frustrations.
â€œOf course itâ€™s offensive to say sheâ€™s not qualified,â€ said Rep. Raul Grijalva (D-Ariz.), chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee.

Not only is Haaland equipped for the job, he said, but she embodies the kind of diversity and representation in government that Biden says he wants. It would be a seismic shift to put a Native American woman at the helm of the federal agency that oversees public lands â€• the same lands from which Indigenous people were previously forcibly removed by the U.S. government.
It would also be historic: The U.S. has never had any Indigenous Cabinet secretaries.

â€œI think those individuals being anonymous should think that through for themselves, because by going after this person, youâ€™re standing in the way of history,â€ Grijalva said. â€œWeâ€™re not going to get it again. Sheâ€™s real. Sheâ€™s authentic. Sheâ€™s legitimate. And she should have it.â€
He added, â€œAnything less than that, I think, is really going to create some blowback.â€

Shannon Holsey, president of the Stockbridge-Munsee Band of Mohican tribe in Wisconsin, lamented the â€œshroud of elusivenessâ€ over the anonymous sources criticizing Haaland and floating Connorâ€™s name instead. Whatâ€™s odd about Connor suddenly being pushed, she said, is that so many tribal leaders are united behind Haaland while Connorâ€™s name hasnâ€™t even come up.

â€œIf there are truly concerns, in the spirit of transparency, they should put them forward. I donâ€™t know what the issues would be,â€ she said. â€œWeâ€™ve lived the past four years in this kind of shroud. Why would you start a new transition that way?â€
Holsey is one of 150 tribal leaders who privately wrote to Biden last week in support of Haaland for interior secretary. HuffPost obtained a copy of the letter and agreed to only excerpt from it.

â€œRep. Haaland has championed the environment, helped lead efforts to address climate change, and worked to improve the nation-to-nation relationship between our Tribes and the United States â€“ all issues within the Department of the Interiorâ€™s responsibilities,â€ reads the letter. â€œAt every turn, she has been a leading voice against the Trump Administrationâ€™s work to roll back environmental protections ... She has also fought the Trump Administrationâ€™s efforts to cut programs that benefit tribal communities.â€

It concludes, â€œAs the leaders of sovereign tribal nations, we believe it is long past time that a Native American person serve as Secretary of the Interior. Further, we believe that Congresswoman Deb Haaland is ready to serve as Secretary.â€

Adding to the confusion over the anonymous attacks on Haaland, Biden last week offered the interior secretary job to New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, who has relatively little experience with the public lands and energy issues the Interior Department focuses on. Grisham turned down the offer, which already made no sense but also would have pitted her against Haaland and Udall, both colleagues from New Mexico.

One source who works closely with tribal leaders on federal strategy speculated there are people on Bidenâ€™s transition team who have worked with Connor in the past, and they are trying to push â€œa message of there being an alternative Native Americanâ€ in an effort to help their former colleague get the Interior post.

â€œThis is not the will of the tribes who have thrown their weight heavily behind Deb Haaland, who is highly qualified,â€ said this source, who requested anonymity to speak freely. â€œThis is an age-old classic of divide and conquer where you are supposedly working with tribes but, at the end of the day, you do the thing you want to do.â€

A spokesperson for Bidenâ€™s transition team said he could not confirm or deny that Haaland is under consideration for the Interior post (she is, but they have to say this), but whoever is anonymously criticizing Haaland is not someone authorized to speak for Bidenâ€™s team.
â€œNo one is trying to discount Deb Haaland,â€ he said.
A Haaland spokesperson declined comment.
Connor, who currently works for the international law firm WilmerHale, did not respond to a request for comment.

Another member of Bidenâ€™s transition team emphasized that the team has already been meeting with dozens of tribal leaders, councils and organizations representing Indian Country, and will continue to do so in the coming weeks to strengthen government-to-government relations. The team also recently added a Native American doctor, Dr. Jim Jill, to its COVID-19 advisory board.

Regardless of who Biden picks for the post, the surge of momentum behind Haaland for interior secretary â€• not the most flashy job â€• is remarkable. Republican and Democratic lawmakers have thrown their support behind her. Data for Progress, a progressive think tank, is circulating a petition urging Biden to pick Haaland for the post. Indigenous-led organizations like NDN Collective and Indigenous Environmental Network have been trying to get the hashtag #DebForInterior trending on Twitter.
Some have come up with hilarious memes to go with it.
Some Indigenous women angrily defended Haaland on social media and to HuffPost shortly after this story was published.
Melanie Benjamin, chief executive of the Mille Lacs Band of Ojibwe in Minnesota, said Biden promised that his administration would have gender parity and diversity unlike any previous administration.

â€œHe promised he would listen to Indian Country,â€ said Benjamin. â€œCongresswoman Haalandâ€™s accomplishments are already historic and her qualifications are not in question ... The opportunity for the Biden/Harris team to make this inspired choice is golden. It should not be overtaken by anonymous voices that insult both women and Indian Country.â€

â€œIt is offensive that Congresswoman Deb Haaland is being subjected to a sexist whisper campaign that is attempting to undermine her experience,â€ said Crystal Echo Hawk, executive director of Illuminative, a nonprofit aimed at increasing the visibility of Native people.

â€œItâ€™s yet another example of how Native women, and women of color, despite having excellent qualifications and broad support, have to continuously fight against sexist narratives that could disqualify them from positions they deserve,â€ she said. â€œPresident-Elect Biden said he would strengthen the nation-to-nation relationship between tribes and his administration. Tribal leaders are endorsing Haaland and are telling the administration she is the best, most qualified candidate for the position. Is the president-elect listening?â€

Meanwhile, groups in New Mexico are still sending letters to Biden backing Haaland. On Saturday, 50 Indigenous, environmental and social justice organizations in the state wrote to Biden saying Haaland is â€œuniquely qualifiedâ€ to be interior secretary. This was a day after the All Pueblo Council of Governors formally urged Biden to nominate Haaland, and two weeks after the Eight Northern Indian Pueblos Council wrote a similar letter.
In the mix of those New Mexico tribes backing Haaland?
Taos Pueblo, Connorâ€™s tribe.

otherData.headline: Trump Presses Own Election Grievances At Rally For Georgia Senators
otherData.short_description: Trump rallied thousands of largely maskless supporters in Valdosta for Sens. Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue, but focused much attention on his own election.
otherData.authors: Aamer Madhani, Ben Nadler and Zeke Miller, AP

articleContent: VALDOSTA, Georgia (AP) â€” President Donald Trump is pressing his grievances over losing the presidential election, using a weekend rally to spread baseless allegations of misconduct in last monthâ€™s voting in Georgia and beyond even as he pushed supporters to turn out for a pair of Republican Senate candidates in a runoff election in January.
â€œLet them steal Georgia again, youâ€™ll never be able to look yourself in the mirror,â€ Trump told rallygoers.

Trumpâ€™s 100-minute rally before thousands of largely maskless supporters came not long after he was rebuffed by Georgiaâ€™s Republican governor in his astounding call for a special legislative session to give him the stateâ€™s electoral votes, even though President-elect Joe Biden won more votes than any other candidate.

The Jan. 5 Senate runoffs in Georgia will determine the balance of power in Washington after Biden takes office. Republicans in the state are worried that Trump is stoking so much suspicion about Georgia elections that voters will think the system is rigged and decide to sit out the two races.

The latest futile attempt to subvert the presidential election results continued Trumpâ€™s unprecedented campaign to undermine confidence in the democratic process, but overshadowed his stated purpose in traveling to Georgia â€” boosting Sens. David Perdue and Kelly Loeffler.

Republicans need one victory to maintain their Senate majority. Democrats need a Georgia sweep to force a 50-50 Senate and position Vice President-elect Kamala Harris as the tiebreaking vote. Party officials had hoped the president would dedicate his energy to imploring supporters to vote in the runoff, when Perdue and Loeffler try to hold off Democrats Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock, respectively.
Trump did echo Republican rhetoric that the races amounted to â€œthe most important congressional runoff, probably in American history.â€ That is only true because he lost.

But after Air Force One landed, it quickly became apparent that Trump was intent on airing his own complaints and stoking baseless doubts about the conduct of last monthâ€™s vote, rather than boosting his party.

â€œI want to stay on presidential,â€ Trumps said minutes into his speech. â€œBut I got to get to these two.â€ He praised the GOP lawmakers, Perdue for his support for military spending and Loeffler for pushing for early coronavirus relief spending. But he quickly pivoted back to his own defeat.

Trump pulled out a piece of paper and read a list of his electoral achievements, including falsely asserting he won Georgia and the White House. Biden carried the state by 12,670 votes and won a record 81 million votes nationally. Trump continued to reiterate his unsubstantiated claims of fraud, despite his own administration assessing the election to have been conducted without any major issues.
Chants of â€œFight for Trumpâ€ drowned out the two senators as they briefly spoke to the crowd.

Hours before the event, Trump asked Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp in a phone call to order the legislative session; the governor refused, according to a senior government official in Georgia with knowledge of the call who was not authorized to discuss the private conversation and spoke on the condition of anonymity. A person close to the White House who was briefed on the matter verified that account of the call.

Kemp, in a tweet, said Trump also asked him to order an audit of signatures on absentee ballot envelopes in his state, a step Kemp is not empowered to take because he has no authority to interfere in the electoral process on Trumpâ€™s behalf.
Trump, though, vented his frustrations with Kemp on Twitter and at the rally.

â€œYour people are refusing to do what you ask,â€ he complained in a tweet, as if speaking with Kemp. â€œWhat are they hiding? At least immediately ask for a Special Session of the Legislature. That you can easily, and immediately, do.â€
At the rally, he took aim once again at Kemp, saying he could assure him victory â€œif he knew what the hell he was doing.â€

Trumpâ€™s personal contact with the governor demonstrated he is intent on amplifying his conspiratorial and debunked theories of electoral fraud even as Georgia Republicans want him to turn his focus to the runoff and encourage their supporters to get out and vote.

In his tweet, Kemp said: â€œAs I told the President this morning, Iâ€™ve publicly called for a signature audit three times (11/20, 11/24, 12/3) to restore confidence in our election process and to ensure that only legal votes are counted in Georgia.â€

While the governor does not have the authority to order a signature audit, an audit was initiated by Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger and it triggered a full hand recount that confirmed Bidenâ€™s victory in Georgia. The race has been certified for Biden and affirmed by the stateâ€™s Republican election officials as a fairly conducted and counted vote, with none of the systemic errors Trump alleges.

But after two pro-Trump lawyers this past week questioned whether voting again is even worth it â€” in echoes of the presidentâ€™s baseless accusations of widespread voter fraud â€” even Vice President Mike Pence betrayed concerns that the Republican coalition could crack under the force of Trumpâ€™s grievances.

â€œI know weâ€™ve all got our doubts about the last election, and I hear some of you saying, â€˜Just donâ€™t vote,â€™â€ Pence said Friday while campaigning with Perdue in Savannah. â€œIf you donâ€™t vote, they win.â€

Few Republicans in Washington or Georgia believe wide swaths of the electorate in this newfound battleground would opt out of voting because of Trumpâ€™s false claims or his denigration of the Georgia governor and secretary of state for certifying Bidenâ€™s victory in the state.

The risk for the GOP is that it wouldnâ€™t take much of a drop-off to matter if the runoffs are as close as the presidential contest: Biden won Georgia by about 12,500 votes out of 5 million cast. Thereâ€™s enough noise to explain why Pence felt the need to confront the matter head on after two Trump loyalists floated the idea of the presidentâ€™s supporters bailing on Perdue and Loeffler.

Trumpâ€™s false claims have resonated with voters such as Barry Mann, a 61-year-old business owner who came to hear Pence in Savannah. Mann hasnâ€™t decided whether heâ€™ll vote for his senators a second time.

â€œI think thereâ€™s some issues with our election and more investigation needs to be done,â€ Mann said, adding that he doesnâ€™t think Perdue and Loeffler have done enough to support Trumpâ€™s efforts to overturn the results. â€œI want to see what happens between now and January,â€ Mann said.

otherData.headline: This Is How Trumpâ€™s Executions Are Spreading The Coronavirus
otherData.short_description: The government admitted in a buried footnote of a court filing that "some" key staffers contracted COVID-19 after the last execution.

articleContent: In late November, as health officials urged the public to avoid travel amid a new wave of coronavirus cases, dozens of people traveled to a federal prison complex in Terre Haute, Indiana, for the execution of Orlando Hall. At the time, around 75 incarcerated people and staff at the complex had active cases of COVID-19.

A few days later, Hallâ€™s spiritual adviser Yusuf Ahmed Nur, who performed last rites for Hall while next to two unmasked executioners, tested positive. Since then, cases have spiked at Federal Correctional Complex, Terre Haute, where all federal executions take place. As of Monday, over 200 incarcerated people and 21 staff are sick with the virus. Now, the Department of Justice has admitted that eight members of the approximately 40-person execution team also tested positive after the execution.

The latest disclosure came in response to a lawsuit brought by two men incarcerated at FCC Terre Haute. They are suing the government to halt executions until the pandemic is under control in order to protect their health.

The government initially said that â€œsomeâ€ members of the execution team had tested positive â€” but the admission was buried in a footnote of a court filing and did not specify how many people had gotten sick. In a subsequent court filing, Bureau of Prisons lawyer Richard Winter said that six members tested positive about a week after returning home and an additional two tested positive more than a week after going home. That at least 20% of the execution team contracted COVID-19 after the most recent execution is evidence of what public health experts and lawyers who represent people on death row have been warning for months: Carrying out executions during a pandemic puts people who live and work in and around the prison at increased risk of contracting a potentially fatal disease.

Lawyers for the two men wrote that the government disclosure offered â€œcompelling evidence of the significant risk that conducting the scheduled executions will spread COVID-19 within FCC Terre Haute (and beyond).â€
In the meantime, the Trump administration is pushing forward with the killings.

On Thursday, the government plans to execute Brandon Bernard, a man who was sentenced to death for acting as an accomplice to a crime that occurred when he was 18 years old. Five of the nine surviving jurors who sentenced Bernard to death now believe he should live, citing information that came out after his trial.

Prisons are some of the most dangerous places to be during the pandemic, as those living within them cannot socially distance themselves from others and often lack access to protective gear and cleaning supplies. Prisons also tend to be crowded and poorly ventilated. Since the pandemic began, many of the largest outbreaks have been linked to correctional facilities.
There is no compelling reason these executions need to be carried out now.

Until recently, there had not been a federal execution in 17 years. When the pandemic hit the U.S., most states paused executions in an effort to contain the spread of the virus. But in July, the Trump administration resumed federal executions, against the advice of public health experts. Since then, the government has rushed to put to death eight people, with five more scheduled to die before President-elect Joe Biden, who opposes the death penalty, takes office on Jan. 20. This is the first time since 1889 that an outgoing administration has carried out a federal execution after losing an election.

Since resuming the killings in July, coronavirus cases have spiked at FCC Terre Haute, as well as in Vigo County, where the prison is located. (The government has argued in court filings that there is no evidence the spikes were definitively caused by the executions.)

The consequences of the governmentâ€™s rush to execute go far beyond health concerns. Criminal justice leaders have warned that death-row prisoners are being denied access to effective legal representation during the pandemic, and travel restrictions are jeopardizing clemency efforts.
Still, there are serious public health risks involved with carrying out executions in the midst of a pandemic.

â€œAt the risk of sounding like a broken record, there is simply no doubt that these executions spread COVID-19,â€ said Cassandra Stubbs, director of the American Civil Liberties Unionâ€™s Capital Punishment Project, in a statement. â€œThe spread of disease that will occur if the wave of five scheduled executions â€” starting Thursday and scheduled until just before inauguration day â€” are allowed to take place will have been totally predictable and preventable. The courts must step in to stop them, protect the people incarcerated at Terre Haute who have no control over the risk the government is subjecting them, and slow the senseless suffering of the American people.â€
Part of the reason federal executions pose such a high risk of COVID-19 transmission is the number of people involved in the operation.

Each one requires the involvement of an â€œexecution teamâ€ sourced from Bureau of Prisons staff, usually from out of state. The roughly 40 people on a team are not required to quarantine once arriving in Indiana or undergo testing for the coronavirus prior to the execution, according to a government filing. Those individuals also work closely with about 200 FCC Terre Haute prison staff, who provide security and support. Testing after working an execution is voluntary; in an affidavit, the prison complex warden said that in the past, only five to seven members of the execution team have elected to be tested prior to returning to their home communities.

Others, including lawyers, media, family and demonstrators also gather for each execution, making such occasions prime candidates for superspreader events. The Bureau of Prisons estimates that approximately 50 to 125 people will travel to the prison for each execution.
The risks of carrying out executions during the pandemic were evident from the beginning.

In July, when federal executions first resumed, the ACLU sued the government on behalf of Buddhist priest Seigen Hartkemeyer, the spiritual adviser to Wesley Purkey, who was scheduled to be executed later that month.

Moving forward with Purkeyâ€™s execution in the middle of the pandemic presented â€œan untenable conflictâ€ for Hartkemeyer by forcing the 68-year-old man with a history of recurring bronchitis and pleurisy to â€œdecide whether to risk his own life in order to exercise his religious obligation to be present for Mr. Purkeyâ€™s execution,â€ the ACLU wrote in its complaint.
Family members of the victims of another man who was scheduled for execution in July joined Hartkemeyer in calling for the executions to be delayed until it would be safe to attend.

About a week after the ACLU filed suit, a BOP staffer who had attended meetings in preparation for three executions, including Purkeyâ€™s, tested positive for COVID-19. The staff member did not always wear a mask, a BOP lawyer acknowledged in a court filing. Asked how many staff and incarcerated individuals he was in contact with in the lead-up to his positive test result, the staff member simply reported, â€œ? Alot.â€
The Trump administration went forward with the scheduled executions: In the week following the BOP staffer testing positive, Purkey and two other men were put to death.
The rush to execute federal prisoners during the pandemic has also put attorneys in danger.

The two lead attorneys for Lisa Montgomery, the only woman on federal death row, both contracted COVID-19 after visiting with her in prison after her execution date was set. Montgomery suffers from mental illness and was a victim of extreme childhood abuse, including incest and sex trafficking by her parents, according to her attorneys.

Both her lawyers reported severe COVID-19 symptoms and were unable to prepare Montgomeryâ€™s clemency petition before the deadline. A judge delayed Montgomeryâ€™s execution until Jan. 12 â€” eight days before Bidenâ€™s inauguration â€” to give her attorneys some time to recover.

Robert Owen, a lawyer who has worked with Bernard for the past 20 years, is not planning to attend his execution on Thursday if it proceeds. Owen is in a high-risk group for COVID-19 and doesnâ€™t feel he can take the chance of contracting the disease. â€œIâ€™m deeply disappointed at that. Iâ€™m angry about it,â€ he said in an interview.

â€œI know that it can be really important to the client to have counsel present close to, or even at the time of the execution, and I would like to be able to offer that comfort to Brandon,â€ Owen said. â€œIâ€™m frustrated that I canâ€™t do it safely.â€
This story has been updated to reflect the governmentâ€™s admission that eight members of a federal execution team tested positive for COVID-19 after returning home from a November execution.

otherData.headline: People Love This Sweet Video Of Prince William Helping Princess Diana With Her Makeup
otherData.short_description: In an extended version of the clip, a young Prince Harry plays away on the piano.

articleContent: As â€œThe Crownâ€ continues to stir up a renewed interest in the British royal family, a recently resurfaced clip of a young Prince William and the late Princess Diana is making the royal rounds.

The behind-the-scenes footage was taken during a family photoshoot with Tim Graham in 1985. It shows the young prince dabbing powder on his motherâ€™s face, as Diana scrunches her face and plays along.
Commenters swooned over the sweet clip:
Additional video footage from the same day shows both William and Prince Harry playing the piano, while Prince Charles tries to get Harryâ€™s attention for the photoshoot.
At one point in the clip, Charles sits Harry on Williamâ€™s little shoulders, while the elder brother delightfully protests.
Toward the end of the longer footage â€• which has been viewed over 2 million times â€• one can see the sweet clip of William powdering Dianaâ€™s face again:
Below are some of the photos Graham was able to capture during the sitting at Kensington Palace:
While â€œThe Crownâ€ has drummed up even more support for the beloved late princess, some critics are up in arms about the Netflix hitâ€™s label as a drama.
Dianaâ€™s brother, Charles Spencer, wants people to remember the series is fictional, and that viewers shouldnâ€™t just accept all that they see as fact.

â€œThe worry for me is that people see a program like that and they forget that it is fiction,â€ the earl said during an interview last month. â€œThey assume. Especially foreigners â€“ I find Americans tell me they watch â€˜The Crownâ€™ as if theyâ€™ve taken a history lesson. Well, they havenâ€™t.â€
â€œIt is very hard,â€ he added. â€œThere is a lot of conjecture and a lot of invention, isnâ€™t there? You can hang it on fact, but the bits in between are not fact.â€
Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: Lou Dobbs Is Now A Hub For Pro-Trump Election Conspiracies
otherData.short_description: The Fox Business host has gone all in on baseless claims of voter fraud.

articleContent: As President Donald Trumpâ€™s attempts to overturn the 2020 presidential election have veered into embarrassing farce, many of Foxâ€™s biggest stars have begun to hedge their support of Trumpâ€™s delusional claims of an election fraud conspiracy. Not Lou Dobbs.

Dobbs, the top-rated host on Fox Business and a fervent Trump ally, has been unwavering in his support of the presidentâ€™s baseless allegations that President-elect Joe Biden and his supporters stole the election. Dobbs has declared that Trump should take â€œdrastic actionâ€ over the vote. Heâ€™s hosted guests making unfounded claims of election fraud, and raged at Republican officials accepting the legitimate results of the election.

This makes Dobbs one of Foxâ€™s last true holdouts denying that Biden won the election. While far-right media outlets have largely detached themselves from reality, many mainstream conservative personalities have been more subtle: raising conspiracy theories, but not fully backing them. The savvier Fox News hosts, such as Tucker Carlson, have carefully walked a line of appealing to pro-Trump audiences while claiming some veneer of independence. Dobbs, whom Fox touts as having the most watched program on business television, has instead gone all in on trying to delegitimize the election.

Dobbs started this week by giving pro-Trump lawyer Sidney Powell free rein to spout groundless allegations of voter fraud while presenting no credible evidence. Powell, who was abruptly kicked off Trumpâ€™s legal team last week, claimed on Monday that the election represented â€œthe most massive and historical, egregious fraud the world has ever seen.â€ Meanwhile, Dobbs called on Trump to take action against â€œthe crimes that have been committed against him and the American people.â€

The next day Dobbs was at it again, suggesting that Attorney General William Barr was â€œcompromisedâ€ and part of the â€œdeep stateâ€ after Barr (belatedly) acknowledged there has been no proof of widespread election fraud. Dobbs attacked Barr, himself a close Trump ally, as â€œa liar or a fool or bothâ€ who â€œjoined in with the radical Dems.â€ Dobbs continued to espouse unfounded allegations and bizarre conspiracy theories throughout the show.
â€œCould it be that antifa was running the election for Democrats in that room?â€ Dobbs asked a guest during a segment about Michigan vote tallying.

On the same episode, Dobbs interviewed Jesse Morgan, a truck driver who claimed to have witnessed massive voter fraud but who has provided dubious evidence for his allegations. Morgan previously claimed in a series of YouTube videos that his family was being haunted by ghosts and that he caught a â€œshadow personâ€ on camera.

On Thursday, Dobbs is slated to host former national security adviser Michael Flynn, who this week tweeted out a call for Trump to declare martial law in order to hold a new election. In addition to his calls to suspend the Constitution, Flynn â€• whom Trump pardoned last week for twice pleading guilty to lying to the FBI â€• has been promoting a groundless conspiracy that China somehow rigged the election for Biden to win.

Itâ€™s been this way for weeks. Throughout November, Dobbs featured guests like Powell on his show while trying to delegitimize the election and call on Republicans to rally around Trumpâ€™s attempts to overturn the vote.
â€œThis is an attempt to take over the country and deny this president what is rightfully his, a second term,â€ Dobbs said in mid-November.

Dobbsâ€™ relentless fealty to Trump, whom he has called â€œarguably the greatest president in our history,â€ has made his show more reminiscent of programming on far-right conspiracy outlets such as One America News Network and Newsmax than most of the other marquee Fox hosts at this point. Although Fox News hosts such as Sean Hannity are still deeply in the tank for Trump, most of the networkâ€™s programming now conveys a sense of inevitability about Bidenâ€™s inauguration in January.

Even informal Trump advisers such as hosts Carlson and Laura Ingraham have started to distance themselves from the presidentâ€™s most egregious falsehoods, and have at times been critical of the lack of evidence for his claims.
But thanks to Dobbs, the Trump campaign still has an immense mainstream platform to promote its wildest election conspiracies to millions of viewers.

otherData.headline: Gifts For Fans Of 'The Queenâ€™s Gambit' That They Wonâ€™t Want To Pawn Off
otherData.short_description: Including stunning chess sets and other chess-inspired gifts that'll be a checkmate for fans of "The Queen's Gambit."

articleContent: HuffPost may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Prices and availability subject to change.

In a year of social distancing, it was television that actually brought us (somewhat) together â€” think of time when we were all watched â€œTiger King,â€ caught up on the latest season of â€œThe Crownâ€ or even, found out what Baby Yodaâ€™s real name is on â€œThe Mandalorian.â€

One of the most popular shows to premiere this year was about *checks notes* chess. Yes, chess. â€œThe Queenâ€™s Gambitâ€ follows the life of (fictional) orphan Beth Harmon as she becomes a chess champion. Itâ€™s based on a novel of the same name published back in the â€™80s.

Chess has been around for awhile but the show has been credited with making chess seem sexy. Thanks to the show, sales for chess sets and books about the game are up and checkerboard prints have made a comeback, too. Oh, and did we mention that â€œThe Queenâ€™s Gambitâ€ is the most watched limited series on Netflix to date?

Chances are you know a friend or family member who really got into the show â€” you know the one who now likes to throw in the word â€œcheckmateâ€ in casual conversations and carries a rook around in their pocket. Okay, maybe not. But you probably know someone who loved the show and wants to get into the game themselves.

For those fans, we picked out the perfect presents that include everything from a glass chess set thatâ€™s crystal clear to a set of bookends in the shape of chess pieces. Below, youâ€™ll find all kinds of gifts for the person who canâ€™t get enough of â€œThe Queenâ€™s Gambit.â€ They wonâ€™t want to pawn these off, we promise.
