The seismic shift of putting a Native American woman in charge of the department with oversight of public lands â€• from which Indigenous people were forcibly removed by the U.S. government â€• is not lost on Haaland.
â€œThe symbolism alone, yes, itâ€™s profound,â€ she said.
Haaland emphasized that while people are advocating for her to get the post, she has not been contacted directly by Bidenâ€™s team about it.

Cameron French, a spokesman for Bidenâ€™s transition team, declined to say whether she was being considered for the Cabinet position. â€œThe Biden-Harris transition team has not made any personnel decisions at this time,â€ said French.
But Haaland said the fact that people are even lobbying on her behalf is a sign of progress in a country where many Native Americans werenâ€™t allowed to vote until 1948.

â€œI tell people Iâ€™m a 35th-generation New Mexican because I am. The Pueblo people migrated to the Rio Grande Valley in the late 1200s, 35 generations ago,â€ she said. â€œI think itâ€™s a time in our world â€• not just in our country, but our entire world â€• to listen to Indigenous people when it comes to climate change, when it comes to our environment.â€
Regardless of whom Biden picks for the job, Haaland said he gets credit for starting off with the most progressive climate and environmental plan of any president.

â€œWhoever becomes secretary has an opportunity to combat climate change, to take this 25% carbon that our public lands are emitting right now and eliminate that,â€ the congresswoman said. â€œI think that what is required is somebody who cares about our public lands.â€
Biden also has pledged to work closely with Indigenous tribes when it comes to preserving natural resources, which is a far cry from President Donald Trumpâ€™s record.

â€œWeâ€™ve had Indian tribes in our committee at hearings talking about this Trump administration blasting apart with dynamite sacred sites so they can build the southern border wall,â€ Haaland said. â€œItâ€™s just atrocious.â€

otherData.headline: Charles Dance On 'The Crown,' 'Game Of Thrones' And Aging In Hollywood
otherData.short_description: The actor, widely known for his role as Tywin Lannister, has a string of projects sure to impress this season, including "Mank."

articleContent: Well before his best-known character Tywin Lannister was shot on the loo at the end of â€œGame of Thronesâ€ Season 4, Charles Dance was contemplating his career. Sure, he was getting older, but the British actor knew there were plenty of substantial roles yet to come his way, despite the film industryâ€™s long-standing focus on youth and beauty.
People may age, Dance told me last week as he sipped tea and snacked on a cinnamon bun, but they donâ€™t â€• or rather shouldnâ€™t â€• age out of Hollywood.
â€œIf actors retire, there would be nobody to play the old, wrinkly people,â€ the 74-year-old said with a chuckle.
Dance applauded the late French actor Simone Signoret, whose 1979 autobiography, â€œNostalgia Isnâ€™t What It Used To Be,â€ featured a closeup photo of her face on the cover.

â€œThere were these wonderful lines around her eyes and around the corner of her mouth. She was puffy. But she looked fantastic. On her face was the story of her life,â€ he recalled. â€œOur faces, if we let them, get more interesting as we get older.â€

In his 60s, Dance was cast as the ruthless head of House Lannister in â€œGame of Thrones,â€ which became HBOâ€™s most-watched series over its eight-season run. The highly respected stage and screen actorâ€™s memorable performance as Tywin made him a household name and was followed by other successful projects, including â€œThe Imitation Gameâ€ (2014), â€œGhostbustersâ€ (2016), â€œGodzilla: King of Monstersâ€ (2019), and most recently â€œThe Crownâ€ and David Fincherâ€™s upcoming buzzed-about film â€œMank.â€

Dance â€• who, I can assure you, is much more charming over the phone than Tywin might be if he were pushing his latest project â€• said, â€œIâ€™m very lucky, especially at the moment when the worldâ€™s turned upside down and people from all walks of life are struggling in one way or another.â€

When Dance and I spoke over the phone, it was a â€œwintery, blusteryâ€ day in London and he and his countrymen were back in quarantine after Prime Minister Boris Johnson issued a second national lockdown amid spikes in COVID-19 cases. Dance is tested frequently for the coronavirus while heâ€™s currently in production on Netflixâ€™s â€œThe Sandman,â€ although he notes that isnâ€™t the case for his fellow citizens.

â€œWe claim to have this world-beating test and trace system in this country. Well, itâ€™s a shambles,â€ he said. â€œPeople maybe have to drive 100 miles to just test and wait for five days before they get a result and itâ€™s chaotic. Whereas, if youâ€™re prepared to pay for it, you can have a rapid test and get your result in an hour. Thatâ€™s how we are able in this industry to keep going.â€

Dance said the Netflix set observes all the rules and regulations, including mask-wearing and social distancing. â€œWe have lunches prepacked and not very nice, usually,â€ he said, laughing. â€œBut the job remains the same. We just have hurdles to jump every day.â€

Dance is an expert hurdler after 50 years in the entertainment business. He began as a member of the Royal Shakespeare Company in the 1970s before getting his big break as Guy Perron in the 1984 television series â€œThe Jewel in the Crown.â€ Although he played James Bond creator Ian Fleming in 1989â€™s â€œGoldeneye,â€ he turned down the opportunity to screen test for Flemingâ€™s famous character years prior. Dance said his agent urged him to stay out of the fold.

â€œIn hindsight, she was probably right because I think I would have blown it,â€ he said. â€œI didnâ€™t have nearly enough experience to go into a franchise like that and suck it up. That would have really killed my career.â€

After bidding adieu to 007, Dance gained additional recognition in miniseries like â€œThe Phantom of the Operaâ€ (1990), â€œRebeccaâ€ (1997) and the BBCâ€™s â€œBleak House,â€ for which he was nominated for an Emmy for Lead Actor in a Limited Series or Movie in 2006. He was never individually nominated for â€œThrones,â€ but received Emmy nods for his narration work on National Geographicâ€™s â€œSavage Kingdom.â€
Of awards, Dance said, â€œWell, you canâ€™t win â€™em all.â€

He is interested, however, to see what accolades come for â€œMank,â€ Fincherâ€™s ambitious new movie in which Dance stars as William Randolph Hearst, newspaper mogul and the real-life inspiration behind â€œCitizen Kane.â€

â€œMankâ€ is a dense black-and-white biopic that reevaluates 1930s Hollywood by detailing the working relationship between â€œCitizen Kaneâ€ actor-director Orson Welles (Tom Burke) and alcoholic screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz (Gary Oldman). Fincherâ€™s late father Jack wrote the script, which was first floated around in 1997 before the father-son duo decided to shelve it. His father died of cancer in 2003, but Fincher eventually found an opening with Netflix â€• which houses his crime series â€œMindhunterâ€ â€• to make the movie the way they envisioned it.

â€œBecause of the opinion I have about Fincher, which is basically I think heâ€™s a genius, I just have this feeling all the time that the end result is going to be a really good movie,â€ Dance said. â€œI did his first film years ago, which is â€˜Alien 3,â€™ and I thought at the time, â€˜Well, this guyâ€™s clever.â€™â€
â€œMankâ€ is only his second project with Fincher, but Dance confirmed the 58-year-old directorâ€™s intense working method hasnâ€™t changed much since 1992.

â€œHe has a reputation for being demanding,â€ Dance said. â€œHe goes through a lot of takes and actors moan a bit about that, but itâ€™s not a very deep moan. With success comes a degree of power, so heâ€™s able to put his foot down and basically tell people to â€˜fuck offâ€™ and â€˜this is what Iâ€™m gonna do and if you donâ€™t like it, tough shit.â€™ Forgive my language.â€
â€œHeâ€™s a film animal from the top of his head to the soles of his feet,â€ the actor added. â€œHe is a perfectionist and he will strive for it, no matter how long it takes.â€

Dance appreciates that mindset, even if itâ€™s hard to keep energy levels up after countless calls of â€œactionâ€ and â€œcut.â€ For a particular party scene in â€œMank,â€ he said he was impressed by Oldmanâ€™s stamina and commitment to his character as Oldman brought new vigor take after take after take.

â€œWe were pretty close to 50 takes,â€ Dance remembered. â€œThat scene is one long monologue with Mankiewicz vomiting halfway through. And David was covering that scene like heâ€™s covered all the scenes, with four cameras.â€

Dance said composition is what the director is focused on. Itâ€™s only after he is satisfied with that element that heâ€™ll turn his attention to the actorsâ€™ performances. Fincher wants his full artistic vision realized, from start to finish, while Netflix, of course, is probably more interested in the economic side of the business and attracting audiences.

â€œAlthough itâ€™s quite a while ago, and Hollywood was a different place, the way the industry was run [during the â€˜Citizen Kaneâ€™ era] is really not that dissimilar to the way itâ€™s being run now, is it?â€ Dance said. â€œItâ€™s this continual trying to please all of the people, all the time, while knowing that we canâ€™t.â€
On the note of pleasing people, how does Dance feel about that polarizing eighth and final season of â€œGame of Thronesâ€?

â€œI have to say, personally, I was underwhelmed,â€ he observed of the showâ€™s lackluster conclusion. â€œIt was decided by committee and I thought, â€˜Oh, no, no, no, no, no.â€™ I wanted it to go out with a bang.â€
â€œAnyway, itâ€™s just nitpicking,â€ Dance quickly added. â€œI wouldnâ€™t have continued to watch it if the show hadnâ€™t been good. It raised the bar when it came to television drama.â€

â€œThronesâ€ surely paved the way for series like Netflixâ€™s royal family saga â€œThe Crown,â€ which, when it launched in 2016, was reportedly â€œthe most expensive TV show ever made.â€ Now, budgets are even bigger as premium content continues to shift from cable networks to streaming platforms. That might explain why Dance has primarily worked with Netflix over the last 18 months.

â€œTelevision, both physically and metaphorically, was something that you looked down to â€• it was this little box that used to sit in the corner of your living room. Film was something that you looked up to, by virtue of the fact that you went into a cinema and there was an enormous screen. Now, of course, the dividing line between television and film has totally blurred,â€ Dance said. â€œPeople can stream a movie into their television, which is as big as the cinema screen, rather than go to the cinema and listen to the noise of others chomping on popcorn. They can watch it in their home whenever they want to see it, rather than the times a distributor says they have to see the film.â€

â€œI think itâ€™s sad, of course, because thereâ€™s a community experience of going to the movies that weâ€™re missing out on,â€ he continued, â€œbut weâ€™re getting close to emulating that [at home].â€

For now, Dance â€• whose brilliant Lord Mountbatten, aka Uncle Dickie, meets his end on Season 4 of â€œThe Crownâ€ â€• is taking advantage of his working relationship with Netflix, which has allowed him the chance to not only make a living but examine his own countryâ€™s monarchy.
â€œI have no idea whether they ever watch it,â€ he said, laughing, of Queen Elizabeth and company, â€œbut I fear probably not.â€

As for the entrance of Diana, Princess of Wales (Emma Corrin) in the new batch of episodes debuting Nov. 15, Dance believes her story gives viewers a glimpse into the never-ending pressure the royals endure.

â€œThere comes a point where I think one has to be kind and leave them alone, you know? Obviously, they have a life of enormous privilege, but I would hate to be a member of that family. Youâ€™re in a goldfish bowl, youâ€™re on show, all the time â€• itâ€™s much worse than being a movie star.â€

Dance gets his fair share of recognition from passersby, although in pandemic times, that in-person attention has certainly waned a bit. For now, heâ€™s focused on his current Netflix project, which he predicts will get people talking, and set to direct his second feature, â€œThe Inn at the Edge of the World,â€ whenever the world picks up its pace again.
In terms of a role he can sink his teeth into, I did mention that Hollywood is still on the hunt for a new James Bond.
â€œIâ€™m too old,â€ he insisted. â€œBond has to be 40 or below.â€
This article has been updated to identify the â€œtop-secret Netflix projectâ€ that Dance is working on.

otherData.headline: Progressive Catholics Hope Joe Biden Will Highlight The Kinder Side Of Faith
otherData.short_description: Biden, who will be America's second Catholic president, is a "Pope Francis Catholic" who chooses to emphasize common-good issues, one ally said.

articleContent: Sixty years after John F. Kennedyâ€™s election, Americans are preparing to welcome a second Roman Catholic politician, President-elect Joe Biden, to the nationâ€™s highest office.

Despite suggestions from some bishops that Catholics canâ€™t be Democrats, early exit poll data suggests Biden won between 49% and 52% of the Catholic vote this year â€• demonstrating the diversity of political views within Americaâ€™s largest single religious institution.

As Biden heads to the White House, some Catholics are hoping his election will highlight a different side of their faith. These are the Catholics whose consciences place them in disagreement with church doctrine on culture war issues. Itâ€™s a segment of the religion that often gets overshadowed by the loud voices from the churchâ€™s staunchly conservative wing.

Biden, an Irish Catholic who carries a rosary in his pocket, spoke often on the campaign trail about how his faith has led him through periods of suffering in his life. Heâ€™s also spoken about how heâ€™s been influenced by Catholic social doctrine, a set of church teachings about how faith should be lived in public life.

John Gehring, Catholic program director at Faith in Public Life Action, said the â€œsincere prideâ€ and â€œquiet humilityâ€ of Bidenâ€™s faith reminded him of how his Irish American grandmother carried her Catholicism.

â€œBidenâ€™s faith is an old-school, lunch-pail, ethnic Catholicism that animated places like Scranton,â€ Gehring said, referring to Bidenâ€™s hometown in Pennsylvania. â€œItâ€™s a faith deeply connected to the dignity of work, respect for unions and a communitarian ethos that values the common good.â€
â€œI imagine there will be more than a few Catholics who come from those places and that particular culture raising a beer in celebration,â€ he told HuffPost.

Although Bidenâ€™s stances on culture war issues have often placed him at odds with official church teachings, his views arenâ€™t too far from those of many fellow U.S. Catholics. Most ignore church teaching on contraception, and a majority say abortion should be legal in all or most cases. Biden has long been more conservative than many Democrats on abortion, but his agenda as a presidential candidate this year included plans to strengthen womenâ€™s access to the procedure.

Biden has also pledged to protect queer Americansâ€™ rights â€• even though the church views queer relationships as sinful and Catholic institutions have fiercely defended their ability to use religious exemptions to discriminate against LGBTQ people. In 2016, Biden served as an officiant at a wedding of a gay couple, reflecting a shift in the pews toward a more accepting view of same-sex marriage. Most Catholics also oppose allowing small business owners to refuse to serve gay or lesbian people for religious reasons.

Sister Simone Campbell, executive director of the Catholic social justice advocacy group Network and a close ally of Bidenâ€™s, said she thinks of the president-elect as a â€œPope Francis Catholic.â€ Francis has cautioned against Catholics becoming â€œobsessedâ€ with issues like abortion, gay marriage and contraception, urging his flock to focus on serving the poor and oppressed.

Biden â€œintegrates [his faith] into his lifelong quest to improve things for people in our nation, and his compassion and caring is for those who are too often left out,â€ Campbell said. â€œHe represents the fullness of our faith.â€

The Republican Party has manipulated Catholics into believing that they must fight for the criminalization of abortion, Campbell said. Bidenâ€™s approach to the issue is to care for the â€œunbornâ€ by caring for pregnant mothers, Campbell said â€• making sure they have health care, good nutrition, stable housing, affordable child care.
In her conversations with the president-elect, Campbell said she got the impression that while Biden personally opposes abortion, he doesnâ€™t think he can force his religious views on others.

Biden has received fierce backlash from some pockets of American Catholicism for his stance on abortion. Last year, Biden was reportedly denied Holy Communion at a South Carolina Catholic church. A Rhode Island bishop suggested over the summer that Biden wasnâ€™t a real Catholic, and a Texas bishop promoted the idea that Catholics canâ€™t vote for Democrats.

But even among the bishops, there is disagreement about whether Catholics owe fealty to the Republican Party because of its opposition to abortion. A handful of American bishops â€• most of whom were appointed by Pope Francis â€• have criticized President Donald Trump and the GOP as being â€œanti-lifeâ€ for failing to care about issues such as racism, workersâ€™ rights, climate change and restoring protections for asylum seekers.

Itâ€™s unclear how the right-wing Catholics who attacked Bidenâ€™s faith will react to a Biden presidency. Gehring said the â€œquasi schismâ€ between Catholic leaders who oppose Pope Francis and those who support him bleeds into fights about who owns the Catholic political narrative.

â€œGiven how much animosity and contempt some showed toward Obama, I expect it will often get ugly,â€ Gehring said. â€œBut my hope is there will be a distinction between reasonable conservative Catholics who will oppose some Biden administration policies without attacking his faith, and the far-right Catholic fringe that has no interest in building bridges or finding common ground.â€
Natalia Imperatori-Lee, a scholar of Catholicism at Manhattan College, said she finds it â€œincredibleâ€ that for both of the Catholic men elected president, the pope was a liability, not an asset.

While campaigning, Kennedy had to defend himself against centuries-old discriminatory notions that Catholics held â€œdual loyaltyâ€â€• that they couldnâ€™t be trusted as citizens because they owed religious loyalty to the pope. According to Kennedyâ€™s presidential library, the first Catholic presidentâ€™s religious identity contributed to election losses in certain states.

Decades later, Catholics â€• particularly white Catholics â€• have attained positions of political power in Congress, as state governors, and on the Supreme Court. They are so far into the mainstream of American society that Pope Francisâ€™s central message of caring for the poor, immigrants and the environment are seen as partisan issues, Imperatori-Lee said. White Catholicsâ€™ alliance with â€œculture-war conservatismâ€ turned some members of the faith against a Catholic candidate who was actually in agreement with many of the churchâ€™s core teachings â€• about the dignity of the human person, the importance of solidarity, and the importance of a fair wage and unionized labor, she said.
â€œAs white Catholics have climbed the socioeconomic ranks, their concerns have turned away from labor issues (once the bread and butter for Catholics) to sexual issues,â€ Imperatori-Lee said.

The mark of a â€œCatholic presidentâ€ is governing â€œwith the most vulnerable in mind,â€ Imperatori-Lee said. Bidenâ€™s win means that the conservative wing of the church has a great deal of soul searching to do on race, sexism, and what freedom of religion means, she said.
The president-elect represents many â€œaverage Catholics who are just trying to do their best,â€ Imperatori-Lee said.

â€œIf many of the more zealous or partisan bishops and priests who were telling their parishioners that you cannot vote for a Democrat and be a good Catholic would get to know their church communities more, I think theyâ€™d find a lot of people like Joe Biden in their pews,â€ she said.

otherData.headline: â€˜A Loss Is A Lossâ€™: Democratic Senators Frustrated After Party Falls Short
otherData.short_description: Democratic senators are pondering how to fix their partyâ€™s electoral strategies after losses in key swing seats.

articleContent: Democratic senators are pushing for significant changes to how the party runs campaigns after its efforts to make major gains in Congressâ€™ upper chamber faltered for the third cycle in a row.
â€œWeâ€™d be fools not to engage in some amount of self-reflection,â€ said Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.).

The party had hopes of winning a dozen Republican-held seats on Election Day after spending hundreds of millions of dollars of both grassroots and big-donor money to put the GOP on defense. Instead, Republicans have swept most of the competitive races, and Democrats have only netted a single seat after losing incumbent Sen. Doug Jones in Alabama and ousting Republicans in Colorado and Arizona.
The party still has a chance at claiming a narrow majority if itâ€™s able to sweep two runoff elections in Georgia set for early January.

Senators interviewed for this story said the party needs to reexamine its message, polling methods and how it spends the tens of millions of dollars it collects from donors every election cycle. Some suggested significant overhauls to the partyâ€™s operations, including reorienting the party to focus more on long-term goals instead of supporting individual candidates.

Hawaii Sen. Brian Schatz, who worked with Murphy to raise hundreds of thousands of dollars for Democratic Senate candidates from online donors, said the party owes â€œthe majority of voters across America who are desperate for a Democratic Senate our very best, most disciplined, and most effective effort.â€

â€œIf you lose a football game, you never say everything went perfectly, even if you did some things well and it was close,â€ Schatz said. â€œA loss is a loss. Every Democratic organization, including the DSCC [Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee], should be looking at what strategies, processes, candidates, consultants and messages were most effective.â€

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, whose tight control of the DSCC is legendary among operatives, was unanimously reelected to another two years in his job on Tuesday. Schumer is known to put in a full day on senatorial work, then work late into the night at the committeeâ€™s offices near the Capitol.

During his weekly press conference on Tuesday, Schumer was focused on the possibility that victories in both Georgia runoff elections could bring Democrats to 50 seats, and to the barest of majorities.

â€œWe are happy. We have won the most important election that weâ€™ve faced,â€ he told reporters. â€œWhen it comes to the Senate, itâ€™s not over at all. Georgia is close. We are working very hard to win Georgia and we believe we have a very good chance of winning.â€

Senators did not vote for a new chair of the DSCC, though two Democratic sources said Ben Ray LujÃ¡n, a newly elected senator from New Mexico and a former chair of House Democratsâ€™ campaign arm, was seen as a front-runner for the job. Other Democratic Senate staffers said there was some desire among some senators for a more experienced member of the caucus to take the job.
In a statement, DSCC spokeswoman Lauren Passalacqua said the committee was constantly examining its own work.

â€œThere are always lessons we can apply to future elections, which is how we flipped two seats in Colorado and Arizona, forced Republicans on defense everywhere and are still in a position to win the majority with the Georgia runoffs,â€ Passalacqua said.

The Senate mapâ€™s bias toward rural voters and states makes it more difficult for Democrats to win control of the chamber, and only two GOP incumbents up for reelection were in states Hillary Clinton won in 2016. But senators were particularly upset by losses in Iowa and Maine, where candidates they saw as strong contenders ended up losing by significant margins.

â€œThereâ€™s just become such a convergence between how presidential candidates do and how Senate candidates do. It doesnâ€™t mean you canâ€™t buck the trend, but it means there has to be something that pulls you over the top when your presidential candidate is losing,â€ said Maryland Sen. Chris Van Hollen, who chaired the DSCC during the 2018 election cycle. â€œI really think itâ€™s important not to jump to conclusions in races like this.â€
Michigan Sen. Debbie Stabenow, a member of Schumerâ€™s leadership team, said she thought Republicans were able to effectively label lesser-known first-time candidates as more leftist than they were.

â€œI think the truth is that even though none of our candidates were supporting defunding the police or socialism, or so on, you still got tagged by it,â€ Stabenow said. â€œSo the question becomes addressing how do you rise above that. People knew President-elect Biden enough and didnâ€™t believe it when they attacked him because people knew him and he had a track record. When you have a new candidate running who people donâ€™t know, itâ€™s easier to make something like that stick.â€

Montana Sen. Jon Tester, who watched Gov. Steve Bullock lose by 10 percentage points in what was supposed to be a close race, was focused on fixing the partyâ€™s internal polls. Tester, who chaired the DSCC in 2016, said the partyâ€™s surveys were off four years ago and were even worse this cycle.

â€œWe need to get some answers on whatâ€™s going on the last few cycles with polling,â€ said Tester. â€œI got on the phone with many a donor and told them Montana was tied or within the margin, and you need to send money. And it wasnâ€™t. Thatâ€™s false advertising. That means weâ€™re putting funds in places that arenâ€™t working.â€

Murphy said he was hoping to refocus small-dollar donor energy and cash toward â€œbuilding permanent political infrastructures in every state rather than just channeling it toward the flavor-of-the-week candidate.â€

â€œWhy does Nevada move into the Democratic column more quickly than other Southwestern states?â€ Murphy asked rhetorically. â€œItâ€™s because Harry Reid built the permanent political organization. Why does Georgia look different than Florida and North Carolina? Because of Stacey Abrams.â€
Igor Bobic and Amanda Terkel contributed reporting
Read live updates on the election below. (Note: An ad blocker may prevent you from seeing the blog, so if youâ€™re using one, please pause or turn it off.)

otherData.headline: Why It Matters That Jill Biden Plans To Teach While Serving As First Lady
otherData.short_description: President-elect Joe Biden's wife has said she wants to continue her work outside her White House role. That would be a first.

articleContent: If everything goes as planned, Jill Biden will become the first first lady with a paying job, as a college professor, outside the White House. Sheâ€™s been talking about this frequently, her spokesperson told HuffPost on Sunday night.

â€œI like working,â€ the 69-year-old Biden explained to Vogue in September. â€œLike so many of your readers, Iâ€™m a working woman. [Teaching is] my passion. Thatâ€™s what I love doing. That has been my career and really a major focus in my life, so I feel like I could handle it and do everything else that first ladies want to do.â€

In one sense, this isnâ€™t much of a surprise. Biden kept teaching at a community college in Northern Virginia when her husband was vice president â€• a decision that an aide recently called â€œinsaneâ€ because of the grueling workload it entailed.
And itâ€™s hardly revolutionary in 2020 that someoneâ€™s wife has a paying job. But in the Upside Down of presidential gender dynamics, itâ€™s a big deal.

A first lady is expected to support her husband and to take on causes of a stereotypically feminine nature â€• perhaps to do with children, maybe food, fighting disease is good. She is judged on how she runs the White House, graciously hosts events, and dresses. Millions of words have been spilled on, say, Melania Trumpâ€™s outfits, Christmas decorations and landscaping decisions.

â€œIâ€™m working ... my ass off on the Christmas stuff, that you know. Who gives a fuck about the Christmas stuff and decorations? But I need to do it, right?â€ the current first lady said in a secretly recorded conversation with one of her advisers, expressing her frustration with the expectations of the role.
Fulfilling the traditional responsibilities of a first lady is definitely a job, demanding hard work with no pay.
But itâ€™s when a first lady steps out of that space â€• particularly if sheâ€™s seen near real policy â€• that she is typically excoriated.

Eleanor Roosevelt took heat from members of her husbandâ€™s Cabinet for her activism. Nancy Reagan was vilified for her involvement in her husbandâ€™s administration. Hillary Clinton was reviled for ... the list is long, but as first lady it was partly for being involved in health care reform (and that one time during the 1992 campaign when she disparaged homemakers).

Even if the first lady stays in her lane, she can get called out. High-profile women walk a tightrope and live in a double bind: Be successful but not ambitious. Beautiful but not showy about it. Well-spoken but not loud. Confident but not arrogant. Michelle Obama faced all of that and more as our first Black first lady, dealing with the pernicious overlay of both racism and sexism.

â€œName a first lady and she has been reprimanded for being too outspoken or too reserved, too controlling or not ambitious enough,â€ author Kate Andersen Brower wrote in The New York Times four years ago, pondering what would happen if a man were in that role. Essentially, the first lady is supposed to embody the perfect woman, she wrote.

These days, the perfect woman typically has a job, in addition to all her other roles. Even conservatives out there touting a womanâ€™s place at home seem to concede this point. Just last month, Republicans fawned over Amy Coney Barrett for having young children and a career. A womanâ€™s place is still in the home, their new line of thinking seems to go, but itâ€™s fine if you can handle that and hold down a paying job, too. (And expect no policy help from us.)

Possibly, the culture has moved a bit since Hillary Clinton was condemned for continuing her work as a lawyer even as her husband was governor of Arkansas. And for justifying it with her infamous quote about baking cookies.

There are also definitely a lot of caveats at play here. If Jill Biden were still the parent of young children, her choice to keep working would likely receive a lot of criticism. Expectations for women with little kids are different.

And if Biden said she was going back to work at a law firm or a widget factory or something more commercial and less recognizably altruistic than teaching, that would almost certainly still be controversial.

Teaching has always been seen as an acceptable job for a woman. It conforms to stereotypical expectations that women are simply better with kids, more caring, more empathetic and more giving. Laura Bush, a former teacher, was widely praised for her focus on education and literacy during her time in the White House.
Teaching also complements the work that Biden wants to do in her role as first lady.

â€œYou wouldnâ€™t want to have a situation where you had a first lady working in a sort of job that was in conflict for ethical reasons,â€ said Betsy Fischer Martin, executive director of the Women & Politics Institute at the American University School of Public Affairs. â€œAnd certainly teaching only enhances the kind of platform I know sheâ€™ll want to advocate for,â€ Fischer Martin said.

Still, Biden keeping her outside job is significant, said Jennifer Lawless, a political science professor at the University of Virginia. â€œIt sends a very strong message to women: No matter how accomplished, powerful, or important your husband, you donâ€™t have to abandon your own career or play second fiddle.â€
The First Second Gentleman

The 2020 campaign was a groundbreaker for gender roles from the start. In the Democratic race, the possibilities for a presidential spouse were wider than ever before. Sen. Elizabeth Warrenâ€™s husband kept his role at Harvard Law School when Warren ran for the nomination. Former Mayor Pete Buttigiegâ€™s husband took time off from his job at a Montessori school during Buttigiegâ€™s campaign for the nomination.
On social media, candidates were able to showcase their personal lives and their supportive spouses.

â€œIn this whole cycle, even during the primary, thereâ€™s been a lot of different examples of what a partner looks like when you think of the fact that there were a couple of potential first gentlemen in the mix for a while,â€ said Amanda Hunter, research and communications director at the Barbara Lee Foundation.
Hunter pointed to another groundbreaking political spouse: Douglas Emhoff, soon to be the nationâ€™s first second gentleman.

Emhoff had taken a leave of absence from the elite law firm DLA Piper to support his wife, Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, during the campaign. He will officially leave the firm by Inauguration Day, a Biden campaign representative said on Tuesday.
Itâ€™ll be fascinating to see what Emhoff does with his new position. â€œItâ€™s nice to have a man as the first for once,â€ said Fischer Martin.
Having Biden and Emhoff in these roles could open up the possibilities for all spouses.

â€œOverall weâ€™ve seen so many stereotypes challenged in the 2020 cycle,â€ Hunter said. â€œThis is one more opportunity for both Doug Emhoff and Dr. Biden to create their own role and not follow the cookie cutter of what previous first and second spouses have done.â€

Crucially, Biden hopes to keep teaching at a moment of educational crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Many kids around the country are going to school virtually or are stuck in some kind of â€œhybridâ€ limbo of both in-person classes and online learning. State and local governments are facing budget shortfalls that could severely undermine public schools. The long-term consequences of this break in regular education could be devastating for children.

So after four years of an administration that did little on education except push for more charter schools, having a first lady with a direct hand in education and a passion for public schools could prove to be no small matter.
â€œIt demonstrates that education will be front and center in a Biden administration, which is a significant departure from the last four years,â€ Lawless suggested.
Other than confirming that Biden plans to return to teaching, her spokesperson Michael LaRosa emphasized her other goals right now.

â€œShe is spending time with her children and grandchildren in Wilmington, Delaware,â€ said LaRosa in an email. â€œDr. Biden is focused on building her team and developing her priorities focused on education, military families and veterans, and cancer.â€

otherData.headline: Just Skip The Senate To Install A Cabinet, Progressives Urge Joe Biden
otherData.short_description: Activists are urging the president-elect to look closely at a 1998 law called the Vacancy Act.

articleContent: President-elect Joe Biden faces the very real possibility of taking office with a Senate controlled by Republicans, ready to block him at every turn. Progressive activists say they have a simple solution, at least when it comes to installing his top officials: Just go around Congress.
The Senate is currently split, with two races still to be called and two others in Georgia to be decided in Jan. 5 runoffs.

Allies of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) told Axios last week that a GOP-controlled Senate would be willing to go along with Bidenâ€™s nominations for his administration, as long as theyâ€™re centrists.

But progressive activists say that path would be unacceptable, and theyâ€™re already putting pressure on the incoming Biden administration to go around the Senate so that McConnell doesnâ€™t get to decide a Democratic Cabinet.

â€œThere are legal tools are available and Biden should be unafraid to use every legal tool available â€” just as McConnell has used to stack the courts,â€ said Jeff Hauser, founder and director of the Revolving Door Project, which scrutinizes executive branch appointees for their ties to corporate interests.

The two main options center around using a law called the Vacancy Act, and appointing officials when the Senate is in recess. Transition officials have so far been unwilling to discuss what sort of strategies theyâ€™re considering.
The first option is a 1998 law that allows a president to temporarily fill vacant executive branch positions that typically require Senate confirmation with â€œactingâ€ secretaries.

â€œThereâ€™s no need to heed to McConnellâ€™s demands to install corporatists,â€ said David Segal, who runs the group Demand Progress and has been leading the progressive effort to influence the Biden transition process. â€œHeâ€™s got to [appoint liberal Cabinet members] If heâ€™s got any chance to attack the crises before us and stave off total democratic collapse in the midterms.â€

Demand Progress and the progressive group Data for Progress ran a survey in September that looked at support for the types of people Biden could install in his administration, which they shared with HuffPost. A majority of likely voters all said that lobbyists, Wall Street executives, executives of large technology companies and oil and gas executives all already have too much influence over government policy.
In other words, these groups argue, picking the types of people who usually have power in Washington â€• and could perhaps get McConnellâ€™s approval â€• will be a bad idea.

Trump has relied heavily on acting secretaries to run the administration, including for high-profile positions like for the Office of Management and Budget director, the director of national intelligence as well as the head of the Department of Homeland Security, which has not had an official head since early 2019.

Installing these temporary picks through the Vacancy Act is limited. They can serve for only 210 days once the position becomes open, although it can be extended if the president nominates someone to be the permanent secretary.

Still, that period would be long enough for Biden to enact the agenda of his first 100 days and to start to address the most pressing crises, including the raging coronavirus pandemic and the struggling economy.
Even aside from appointments, Democrats are hoping that Biden uses his executive authority to get as much done on policy as he can without the Senate.
â€œBidenâ€™s got to use executive orders,â€ Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) said on MSNBC last week.

â€œItâ€™s important to get personnel right so that you can use executive authority robustly, and in this context it will also be important to use executive authority robustly to get personnel right,â€ said a Democratic Senate strategist who requested anonymity to speak freely.
Progressives argue that unless Democrats pick firmly liberal officials for top posts in the new administration, the party will face even more crushing results in the next election cycle.

â€œThe many people who swung back to Democrats relative to Trump need to see that Biden is in a position to actually address the crisis,â€ Segal said. â€œWe need to not repeat 2010 â€” 2010 was not a function of too much response to the crisis, it was a combination of insufficiency and too much largess to corporations.â€
Democrats lost control of the House majority in 2010, fundamentally changing the course of President Barack Obamaâ€™s remaining years in office.

Bidenâ€™s administration could also make appointments when the Senate is in recess, according to Segal. But the Senate has, in the past, blocked the president from making recess appointments by scheduling â€œpro formaâ€ sessions â€• when the Senate meets for a very short time to avoid technically being in recess.

These acting appointments arenâ€™t without drawbacks. Government experts say they donâ€™t have the full authority within their departments of someone who is Senate-confirmed, and their temporary nature makes it harder for them to implement a full agenda.
But supporters of this approach say itâ€™s better than allowing an opposing party hellbent on blocking Bidenâ€™s agenda from controlling the entire process.

Biden has already received backlash for some of his more centrist influences; over the summer his campaign had to distance itself from Larry Summers, a longtime economic adviser who has become a bogeyman on the left for his ties to Wall Street and Silicon Valley and for repeatedly backing bailouts for big financial institutions.

Biden won with a large, ideologically diverse coalition. It includes corporate-friendly moderate Democrats who have long been at the center of power in Washington, and a growing progressive grassroots, advocating for the working class. And people from both sides of the spectrum â€• and even a few Republicans â€• have been discussed as Cabinet secretary choices.

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) told The New York Times that if the administration shuts out progressives and caters to centrists and conservatives, it will be disappointing â€• and will alienate a portion of the country that the Democratic Party needs to win.

â€œThese transition appointments, they send a signal. They tell a story of who the administration credits with this victory,â€ she said. â€œAnd so itâ€™s going be really hard after immigrant youth activists helped potentially deliver Arizona and Nevada. Itâ€™s going to be really hard after Detroit and Rashida Tlaib ran up the numbers in her district. Itâ€™s really hard for us to turn out nonvoters when they feel like nothing changes for them. When they feel like people donâ€™t see them, or even acknowledge their turnout.â€

If the Senate continues to be controlled by McConnell, Biden would have an easy excuse to pick more moderate figures to be part of his administration. But it could also hamper much of his agenda, which is certainly more progressive than any Democratic presidential candidate in recent history.

â€œWeâ€™ve always been worried that Bidenâ€™s not going to have the will or interest in using his authority aggressively,â€ the Democratic Senate strategist said. â€œBut hopefully heâ€™ll see that it will be necessary for his administration to get anything done and ultimately to succeed.â€

â€œThere is a corporate wing of each party and they could definitely make deals together,â€ Hauser said. â€œIâ€™m definitely worried that they might say that the election means we should go to the center.â€
For now outside groups and labor organizers who have also been involved in transition talks â€” at least on the periphery â€” are not giving up hope on Democratsâ€™ chances in the Senate.

Mary Kay Henry, the president of the Service Employees Union International (SEIU), who has a direct line to the Biden campaign, told HuffPost sheâ€™s not yet entertaining the idea of a McConnell-led Senate. Her members are planning on organizing around an outstanding race in North Carolina and the possibility of two runoff elections in Georgia.
Losing the Senate, she said, however, will not be an excuse to lower the partyâ€™s ambitions.

â€œWe just had essential workers turned out in this election and created a record-setting vote in this country,â€ Henry said. â€œWe are not going to reduce our expectations one bit no matter who is in the Senate. They have to understand their political future rests on taking bold and dramatic actions to address the crises of a generation.â€
CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article misstated the date of the Senate runoffs in Georgia; it will be held on January 5, not January 30.

otherData.headline: Carol Kane Never Meant To Become Hollywoodâ€™s Go-To Eccentric
otherData.short_description: Known for her unmistakable voice, the Oscar-nominated actor broke through with "Hester Street" and "Annie Hall." Then she got typecast as the resident loon.

articleContent: Thereâ€™s no mistaking Carol Kaneâ€™s voice. Even if we hadnâ€™t coordinated an exact time for our phone conversation, I would have recognized that throaty warble immediately. Itâ€™s grown more distinctive since she first appeared in â€œCarnal Knowledgeâ€ in 1971 and earned an Oscar nomination for the bittersweet 1975 immigrant romance â€œHester Street.â€ Paired with Kaneâ€™s decadent blond curls, her speech has been a vessel for all sorts of madcap characters, including Simka on the sitcom â€œTaxi,â€ an amateurish witch in â€œThe Princess Bride,â€ a Christmas ghost in â€œScrooged,â€ the aptly named Granny Frump in â€œAddams Family Values,â€ an offbeat landlord on â€œUnbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,â€ a wine-drunk zombie in â€œThe Dead Donâ€™t Dieâ€ and a Nazi combatant on â€œHunters.â€

Kane, 68, didnâ€™t set out to be a comedy maven, and at times she has longed for more opportunities to flex other muscles. But when youâ€™re remembered for one particular mode, it can be hard to convince Hollywood to see you any other way. Even she used to doubt her own talents. During our 80-minute chat last week, she teared up thinking about the roles she turned down in the â€™70s out of intimidation.

Along the way, we talked about being typecast, self-doubt, carrying the influential opening scene of â€œWhen a Stranger Calls,â€ befriending Bette Davis, attending Madonna and Sean Pennâ€™s wedding, Woody Allen and why â€œKimmy Schmidtâ€ changed her life.
David Schweizer, who directed you onstage, once described your signature role as the â€œbreathy-voiced ditz.â€ Why do you think that became your specialty?

I think thatâ€™s kind of diminishing. Iâ€™m surprised that David would say that because I did two very different plays with him. But, you know, each to his own, I guess. It is certainly an aspect of what Iâ€™ve done. Of course, no one likes to be typecast. One does not want to be able to be described in six words after having worked for, luckily and gratefully, a long lifetime. Iâ€™ve been really lucky at my age to go back to doing dramatic characters [like in] â€œHester Streetâ€ or some of the earlier films that I was fortunate to do. Iâ€™ve been lucky enough to do a lot of variety, and certainly some great breathy-voiced ditzes, like maybe the ghost in â€œScrooged.â€
Have there been moments when youâ€™ve felt upset that there wasnâ€™t more dramatic work coming your way?

Well, I donâ€™t want to characterize it as upset because Iâ€™m so grateful for a great deal of the comedy work that Iâ€™ve been privileged to do. Itâ€™s really been a treasure, and Iâ€™ve worked with so many brilliant people. But certainly one wants to play the full scale. For a while, I was mainly being asked to do comedy, and I guess I did wish that maybe there was more dramatic work. But on the other hand, even when I was doing more film or television comedy, like â€œTaxiâ€ or â€œKimmyâ€ or whatever, then some of the stage work has been dramatic.

Youâ€™re right that early in your career, in movies like â€œDog Day Afternoon,â€ â€œThe Worldâ€™s Greatest Loverâ€ and â€œAnnie Hall,â€ you were playing mostly relatable, everyday people. And over time, particularly after â€œTaxiâ€ ended, your most popular movies found you portraying zany, over-the-top loons: â€œThe Princess Bride,â€ â€œScrooged,â€ â€œAddams Family Valuesâ€ or even something like â€œMy Blue Heaven.â€ Did you consistently enjoy working in that more ostentatious mode?

Yeah. Because the movies that youâ€™re describing, I got to work with such great actors and directors and writers, and for me, the writing is just everything. Luckily, in all the work youâ€™re describing, Iâ€™ve been fortunate in that theyâ€™re just wonderfully written.
Youâ€™ve said you felt insecure about your voice, but your voice is the thing youâ€™re most known for. Have you learned to treasure what you can do with it?
I donâ€™t treasure my voice. I am grateful that I can alter it a great deal depending on the role. I enjoy doing that, finding the very specific voice of a character.
Is there a voice that was particularly fun to develop?

Several. I mean, the voice of Gitl in â€œHester Street.â€ The voice in â€œHunters.â€ Certainly the voice in â€œScroogedâ€ was really fun. â€œWhen a Stranger Callsâ€ was a very different voice than â€œScroogedâ€ or whatever, so thereâ€™s a whole bunch of them. I think â€œScroogedâ€ was really fun because it was so crazy, getting to fly around. It was just really great. And then I had a lot of fun when I was doing â€œWicked.â€ Madame Morribleâ€™s voice was very low and very highfalutin and English. I just love the experimentation and alteration that goes along with different characters.
I watched â€œWhen a Stranger Callsâ€ for the first time not too long ago.
I hope you didnâ€™t watch it late at night!
I did turn the lights out. Iâ€™m a big horror fan. You carry the opening scene almost single-handedly, and it inspired the famous opening scene of â€œScream.â€ How did that make you feel?

I know! Iâ€™m tickled by it. And one must give credit to Fred Walton, who wrote and directed â€œWhen a Stranger Calls,â€ who created that incredibly suspenseful scene where you donâ€™t see anything particularly frightening. Itâ€™s just sounds of the refrigerator and the way he built it up. The pacing of it and everything was just so brilliant, and it tickles me that it became slightly iconic.
Iâ€™m guessing youâ€™re not a horror person.
You know what? You are guessing correctly. Iâ€™m such a sucker. Now, how come you guessed that? But youâ€™re right. I canâ€™t watch it. I get really scared.
Well, you just sounded so aghast when I said that I would want to watch â€œWhen a Stranger Callsâ€ with all the lights turned out.
Oh, God! I canâ€™t stand that you did that! Yeah, no, I am totally chicken. I guess I just get carried away with the possibilities of it being real, you know?
You did at least one other horror go-round with â€œOffice Killer,â€ which I only recently learned was directed by Cindy Sherman. Itâ€™s the only movie sheâ€™s made.

I hope it wonâ€™t be the only one, though, because sheâ€™s so brilliant. I love it. Also, her aesthetic is all true to that Cindy Sherman visual aesthetic. I just adore her, and I had a lot of fun with her. She had very specific taste, as you know, but she also encouraged a lot of freedom. For instance, one fun thing for me: I guess you may have noticed that [Kaneâ€™s character] Dorineâ€™s eyebrows were very unique and didnâ€™t match at all. Every day, Cindy painted them on for me. I just said, â€œYou just have to do it yourself,â€ because they were so creative, those eyebrows, and they changed over the course of the film. The left one had nothing to do with the right one. I think only Cindy could do it.
Thereâ€™s a funny joke in â€œKimmy Schmidtâ€ where Lillian says that Cindy Sherman doesnâ€™t really exist and is just a persona she created.

I know! Isnâ€™t that so funny? Tina Fey and Robert Carlock, sometimes they throw in a reference to other work that youâ€™ve been in. I love that Tina does that. I feel like itâ€™s getting a bonbon, if anybody still knows what that word means, to say what it means to me, as opposed to what it means to Lillian. Like a delicious little treat.

You have a small role in â€œIshtar.â€ For a long time, I was more familiar with the lore of â€œIshtarâ€ than the movie itself. At the time, it was called one of the worst movies ever made. It famously went over budget, and Elaine May and Warren Beatty had a falling out. The movie has since been reappraised, but what do you remember about the melodrama that apparently went on behind the scenes?

Well, I remember that I got to go to rehearsal with Elaine May directing and writing. And I got to act with Dustin [Hoffman] and Warren and the great cinematographer [Vittorio Storaro]. I was not aware of behind-the-scenes drama, which Iâ€™m really glad about. And by the way, I have to say, on the movies or even theatre pieces that Iâ€™ve done, where thereâ€™s a great deal of gossip, a lot of it seems to me to be made up. But I also wasnâ€™t there for a long time. I just adore Elaine, and Iâ€™ve gotten to do two other works with her.
Is there a greater achievement than befriending Bette Davis?
I donâ€™t know. Iâ€™m speechless.
Do you have a favorite Bette Davis memory?

This is such a great memory of how I met her, and how I met her assistant, Kathryn Sermak, in the laundry room in the building I moved into in Hollywood. I was on my way to a movie in Sydney, and I was very young and kind of frightened to travel that far, to know no one. And Kathryn told Miss D, as she called her, about me and what was about to happen, and that very same day a beautiful note came under my door: â€œIâ€™ve been to Australia. Maybe I can help. Come for drinks at 6.â€ Signed Bette Davis, whose movies I had watched all my life. I think sheâ€™s just the greatest screen actress in my childhood. Iâ€™d just read her book, and there was this invitation. She was generous like that, very kind towards me. I went to the Emmys one time for â€œTaxi,â€ and she had me in before for drinks and she was just so supportive.
How lovely and how, perhaps, contradictory to the reputation that she earned as this brassy diva.

Well, you know, the thing is, her greatness came along with being a perfectionist. I think many people who are perfectionists, a lot of people donâ€™t understand that that can be the source of what people might think of as distant or tough. But she drove herself the hardest of anybody. I believe, from what I know of her and read that sheâ€™s written about herself, she expected the same kind of standard around her. I mean, I didnâ€™t get to work with her, but as far as our relationship, she was nothing but supportive.
I read that you were the only â€œTaxiâ€ cast member to attend Andy Kaufmanâ€™s funeral. Why was that?

I donâ€™t even remember if thatâ€™s true, to tell you the truth. It could have just been that I was the one that lived on the East Coast. Iâ€™m wondering if Judd [Hirsch] was there, but I really canâ€™t remember.
Around that time, you ended up at Madonna and Sean Pennâ€™s wedding. Was that because you and Sean had made a movie together?

Yes. We made â€œRacing with the Moon,â€ and I met Madonna, was it through Sean? Also I think I met her with [Kaneâ€™s close friend] Diane [Keaton]. I canâ€™t remember why that would be, but I do remember that to be true. I was invited to the wedding. I donâ€™t know how they got through it, to tell you the truth. The amount of helicopters. It was really one of those things that you just read about but canâ€™t relate to because itâ€™s so crazy.
Thatâ€™s why I had to ask you about it, because it sounds so cinematic and almost fantastical.
Well, thatâ€™s a great word for it. It was fantastical.

When you are at an event like that, where there are paparazzi flying overhead and it becomes this storied legacy that will go down in the pop-culture history books, do you feel like itâ€™s a sign that youâ€™ve achieved some sort of celebrity status?

Maybe for a second. I went with my girlfriend, Sheila Jaffe, whoâ€™s also close to Sean. Sheilaâ€™s a casting director that cast â€œThe Sopranosâ€ and most of Mark Wahlbergâ€™s movies, and they were close. I can tell you that we never got the illusion or delusion that any of that attention or craziness has anything to do with you. It was very surreal, you know? Like a Fellini movie. You just get in a car and you drive an hour and suddenly youâ€™re in a totally different world. And then you get back in the car and go home.

I wondered if it was similar to the way people imagine getting an Oscar nomination, which youâ€™ve also experienced. There are these singular things that, for the outsider who doesnâ€™t know what itâ€™s like to be famous, seem like a token of your having â€œmade it.â€

Yeah, I guess so, to the outsider. It comes and goes so fast, and itâ€™s all an illusion. Just to illustrate that, for instance, I can say that when I was out in Los Angeles staying at the Beverly Hills Hotel going to the Academy Awards [in 1976], I was also on unemployment. Those are the types of things to just drive you crazy. How do you balance those two realities? I think you have to be extremely sane and secure to balance.
Was it easy for you to balance the two realities?
Oh, no. I didnâ€™t do well with it.
What do you mean by that?

What I mean is that it really frightened me. I was too young to cope with it, and I definitely turned down work that wouldâ€™ve been very important for me to do because I just was too frightened and I was not sane and secure. I did this tiny little black-and-white movie [â€œHester Streetâ€] for no money. It was shot for no money, we made no money, and suddenly this thing happened. I was not prepared. Iâ€™ve seen, by the way, people that are prepared and are very gracious and can hit that level of success in a much better way than I was able to.
And when you say that you were ill-prepared or frightened, was it the fame aspect that intimidated you?

Yeah. Totally. And the Groucho Marx thing: not wanting to belong to a club that would have me as a member. [Kane briefly tears up.] I really suffered from that intensely, and thatâ€™s why I made some artistic choices that, as you can hear, are very painful to me to this day. But, you know, what can you do? I was 23 years old.
Are you comfortable talking about some of those choices? What was the work that you turned down?

There was a role in a movie playing a true story of an artist. I donâ€™t want to say the name of it because I wouldnâ€™t want to cause anybody involved with it pain. But it was a great, great role and an important true story having to do with the Holocaust. I guess you could say I didnâ€™t allow myself to do it. It was after â€œHester Street,â€ and I was just, to use the horribly overused phrase, too freaked out to accept that it was OK to come my way.
There are so many different nuances to that feeling, and I think a lot of people have what they would call imposter syndrome.
Hey, interesting! Iâ€™ve never heard that phrase, but thatâ€™s an interesting way to describe it. You donâ€™t want to call it the Groucho Marx syndrome?

I think thatâ€™s a far more clever way to frame it, yes. Itâ€™s interesting, though: During that same period weâ€™re talking about, you were getting some really impressive work, including a few movies that are resonant to this day. Did you not feel at the time that that was the case?
Well, I know a movie I love that we havenâ€™t mentioned: â€œThe Last Detail.â€
Of course. And â€œCarnal Knowledge.â€

â€œCarnal Knowledgeâ€ was the beginning of my life as an actress, really. Anyway, I think that I knew that I was fortunate to be in some very great movies and plays, but I also knew that I had gotten rid of some great roles that I should have taken on. More than one. That is not to say that I reject or donâ€™t value or am not endlessly, endlessly grateful for what I have been a part of as an artist.

You are close friends with both Diane Keaton and Mia Farrow, who have very different interpretations of the reputation that Woody Allen currently has. Iâ€™m curious what itâ€™s like to watch someone you worked with assume such a complicated place in your friendsâ€™ lives, and to watch that personâ€™s reputation sour so gravely.

Well, look. I donâ€™t know the truth of what happened. I mean, itâ€™s something that is just ... I have no idea. The truth is, I have no idea. I think that Woody is a great, great director and has given us all the most extraordinary works of art. And I do not sit in judgment at all. I mean, the whole thing is so distressing. The pain on everyoneâ€™s part in the situation is awful. And I think thatâ€™s all I can say.

Sure, you donâ€™t have to answer for his allegations. I was just curious because of the connections you have with those two women who play very different roles in his life and have said very vastly different things about him.
Well, the thing I need to speak to concerning him is that heâ€™s a great artist. I am friends with Mia, but I donâ€™t speak to her frequently or see her, whereas Diane is in my life on a daily basis.
Do you think you might have felt more encouraged about yourself when you were young if youâ€™d come up in the business today, given the attention being paid to elevating women in film and television?

To tell you the truth, I wouldâ€™ve been more encouraged if I had grown up during the â€™30s and â€™40s. Even in silent films, there were so many great female writers and directors and actresses. I donâ€™t have any regret. The late â€™60s and â€™70s were such a rich soil for the work and the birth of independent films. And if it was today, then I wouldnâ€™t have worked with Hal [Ashby], and I wouldnâ€™t have worked with Cindy, and I wouldnâ€™t have worked with John Cassavetes. Or Mike Nichols! But letâ€™s face it. In the â€™30s and â€™40s and even â€™20s, women were just extraordinary. Look at the roles that Bette Davis played. You canâ€™t say things have gotten better than that. Ida Lupino, you know? If you want to talk about the â€™70s, look at the roles created for Gena [Rowlands]. Iâ€™m glad for any enrichment that has happened, but I guess I donâ€™t quite see it that way.

I also think that if you look at European movies â€” English movies, French movies â€” the roles for women of all ages were so rich. America went through a period where, when you turned 40, you had to check with the phone company. It literally felt that way.
Did it feel that way for you?
Yeah. All of a sudden, the scripts that I was getting, [the characters were in their] 50s or 60s. It felt that way for a lot of us. But anyway, like I said, I have no regrets.
When â€œKimmy Schmidtâ€ came along, it put you back in that zany, eccentric mode you were known for. Did you see it that way?

Oh yeah. And I will say that Tina Fey and Robert Carlock and Jeffrey Richmond â€” all the creators of â€œKimmy Schmidtâ€ â€” they changed my life. They put me back to work in a way that I hadnâ€™t been in quite some time on-screen. Iâ€™d been doing a lot of theater, but they really changed my life as an older actress.

That show accentuated â€” and doubled down on accentuating after it became a success â€” the things youâ€™re most known for that might sometimes make you insecure: your voice, your hair, your physicality.

Well, like that line that they wrote about [my hair being] â€œbeautiful spaghetti.â€ Thatâ€™s so great. And I did get to do the kind of physical comedy that I love and havenâ€™t gotten to do on TV since â€œTaxiâ€ and â€œAll Is Forgiven.â€ It was a meal, and it was just served up to me in the most grateful, generous way.
This interview has been condensed and edited for clarity.

otherData.headline: Trump Administration Moves To Freeze Wages For Farmworkers Before Leaving Office
otherData.short_description: The Biden White House could reverse Trump's new regulation for H-2A visas after taking over, but it's likely to be a time-consuming process.

articleContent: The Trump administration is moving ahead with a federal rule that would freeze pay for many agricultural guest workers for the next two years, even as they remain essential personnel during a pandemic.

The new regulation would change the methodology used to determine the prevailing wage rates for workers with H-2A visas. Until now, minimum pay rates for most of these workers were set by a survey the U.S. Department of Agriculture conducts twice a year, asking farms for data on their workersâ€™ hours and earnings. The Trump administration has tried to suspend that survey and intends to base future pay increases on data from the Labor Department starting in 2023.

In the intervening years, the prevailing wage rates, which vary from state to state, would remain at their 2019 levels, leaving workersâ€™ pay stagnant. Once pay increases resumed, experts say they would likely be smaller for most fieldworkers than they would have been under the previous methodology.

Workers on H-2A visas come from Mexico and other countries to work temporarily on U.S. farms, typically picking and processing crops. Worker advocates say the wide use of guest workers means the farm labor market does not function like a free market, since these foreign workers are poorer and more willing than Americans to accept below-market pay.

Under the law, employers have to pay guest workers a minimum prevailing wage â€• known as the Adverse Effect Wage Rate (AEWR) â€• so that their pay isnâ€™t so low that it undercuts that of U.S. workers. In most cases, that prevailing wage comes from the survey that Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue has moved to suspend.

The Labor Department published the new regulation last week. Senior agency officials said on a call with reporters just before Election Day that the change would give employers more stability and predictability when it came to wage increases. They described the current pay rates determined by the agricultural survey as too volatile, making it hard for employers to plan their payrolls each year.

â€œIt is a victory for farmers, agricultural workers, and the American people, who rely on a vibrant agricultural sector to supply food for our families,â€ John Pallasch, the Labor Departmentâ€™s assistant secretary for employment and training, said in a statement.
But as the agencyâ€™s own analysis shows, the rule would undoubtedly bring growers long-term savings on labor costs relative to the status quo.

The text of the rule says it would lead to â€œtransfer paymentsâ€ of an estimated $1.68 billion over 10 years. As a Labor Department chart makes clear, that term is a euphemism: H-2A workers would be transferring $1.68 billion to their employers, in the form of lost wages.
From the Labor Departmentâ€™s rule:
Last year, farmworkers who werenâ€™t supervisors earned $13.99 per hour on average, compared with $23.51 for production workers outside agriculture.
Farmworker Justice, an advocacy group for migrant workers, called the new regulation â€œcruel.â€

â€œThe government has designated farmworkers as essential workers; theyâ€™re expected to work during a pandemic,â€ Bruce Goldstein, the groupâ€™s president, told HuffPost. â€œThe federal government refused to mandate safety standards to protect farmworkers and others against COVID-19. Now the administration is punishing farmworkers by effectively cutting their wage rates. Itâ€™s just cruel and unreasonable.â€
Farmworker Justice estimates that the new rule would directly impact more than 200,000 workers.

Goldstein said the incoming Biden administration could move to reverse the rule, but it would take at least a few months and perhaps longer to do so through the federal rulemaking process. He expects that the wage freeze would apply to the 2021 season at the least. He said the Trump administration was likely moving as quickly as possible with the rule before being forced out of office.
The administration published the rule after the election but before Biden was projected to be the winner. It has been in the works for more than a year.

The United Farm Workers union sued to prevent the farm labor survey from being ended, and a federal judge recently granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction against the Agriculture Department. In his order, the judge said the USDA offered â€œno indication that [it] considered the impact on farmworker wages caused by its decision to eliminateâ€ the survey.
The government must continue the survey for now, but the Trump administration does not have to use the survey to set prevailing wages for workers.

The agriculture industry doesnâ€™t like the survey because itâ€™s typically led to pay rates well above those set by local minimum wage laws. The industry claims the methodology skews the wage rates too high. This year the prevailing wage rates range from $11 to $16 an hour, whereas most state minimum wages are well below that and the federal minimum wage is still just $7.25 an hour.

A lobbyist for the American Farm Bureau Federation wrote earlier this year that the wages determined by the survey make it hard for farms â€œto stay open for business and compete against imports from countries with lower labor costs.â€

Under the Trump administrationâ€™s plan, the prevailing wage rates would freeze until 2023 even as wages in the broader labor market are likely to rise. Then the savings for growers would be locked in, as the rates increased thereafter according to a wage index.

Daniel Costa, an immigration policy expert at the left-leaning Economic Policy Institute, said the index preferred by the Trump administration might produce bigger increases for some higher-skilled workers on farms. But the vast majority of guest workers would see smaller wages than they would have under the current system, hence the â€œtransfer paymentsâ€ going to employers.

In an analysis, Costa found that fieldworkersâ€™ wages rose an average of 3.6% each year between 2010 and 2019 based on the survey; under the index proposed in the new rule, they would have risen at an annual rate of just 2.3%.

Over time, Costa said, the impact could be significant. The fact that guest workers would receive smaller pay hikes could soften wage increases for U.S. workers as well. The change would also allow farms to advertise lower pay than they would have under the survey, making the positions less attractive to U.S. workers.

â€œThis is absolutely a wage cut for migrants who are H-2A farmworkers,â€ he said. â€œH-2A farmworkers will not benefit from any natural wage growth that occurs [until 2023] â€• during what farm owners are saying is a severe labor shortage, which is exactly when you would expect wages to grow in a free market.â€

otherData.headline: Tropical Storm Eta Expected To Strike Florida Keys As A Hurricane
otherData.short_description: The storm has left scores of people dead and over 100 others missing in Mexico and Central America after it made landfall as a category 4 hurricane.

articleContent: HAVANA (AP) â€” A strengthening Tropical Storm Eta sliced across Cuba on Sunday and was aimed at the southern tip of Florida, where officials braced for a storm that could to hit at hurricane force after leaving scores of dead and over 100 missing in Mexico and Central America.

The U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami said declared hurricane and storm surge warnings for the Keys from Ocean Reef to the Dry Tortugas, including Florida Bay, with the storm expected to reach that area by Sunday night or early Monday.

Florida officials closed beaches, ports and COVID testing sites, shut down public transportation and urged residents to stay off the street. Several shelters also opened in Miami and the Florida Keys for residents in mobile homes and low lying areas.
Broward County also shut down in-person schooling Monday and Miami seemed poised to do the same.

Eta had maximum sustained winds of 65 mph (100 kph) at midday Sunday and it was centered north of Cuba, about 145 miles (235 kilometers) southeast of Marathon, Florida, and about 170 miles (275 kilometers) south-southeast of Miami. It was moving toward the north-northwest at 17 mph (28 kph).
The storm swelled rivers and flooded coastal zones in Cuba, where 25,000 had been evacuated. But there were no reports of deaths.

Eta hit Cuba even as searchers in Guatemala were still digging for people believed buried by a massive, rain-fueled landslide. Authorities on Sunday raised the known death toll there to 27 from 15 and said more than 100 were missing in Guatemala, many of them in the landslide in San Cristobal Verapaz.
Some 60,000 people had been evacuated in Guatemala.
At least 20 people also were reported dead in southern Mexico and local officials in Honduras reported 21, though the national disaster agency had confirmed only eight.

Pope Francis on Sunday spoke about the population of Central America, hit â€œby a violent hurricane, which has caused many victims and huge damage, worsened as well by the already difficult situation due to the pandemic.â€ Speaking to faithful gathered in St. Peterâ€™s Square, Francis prayed that â€œthe Lord welcome the deceased, comfort their families and sustain all those so tried, as well as all those who are doing their best to help them.â€

In Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency Saturday for eight counties at the end of the state as Eta approached, urging residents to stock up on supplies. South Florida started emptying ports and a small number of shelters opened in Miami and the Florida Keys for residents in mobile homes and low lying areas.
Miami-Dade County declared a state of emergency Friday night and also warned a flood watch would be in effect through Tuesday night.

Further south in the Keys, officials were monitoring the storm closely, but had no plans yet to evacuate tourists or residents. They urged residents to secure their boats and encouraged visitors to consider altering plans until Eta had passed.
Eta initially hit Nicaragua as a Category 4 hurricane, and authorities from Panama to Mexico were still surveying the damages following days of torrential rains during the week.
In Guatemala, search teams first had to overcome multiple landslides and deep mud just to reach the site where officials have estimated some 150 homes were devastated.

In the worst-hit village, QuejÃ¡, at least five bodies have been pulled from the mud. The Indigenous community of about 1,200 residents consisted of simple homes of wood and tin roofs clinging to the mountainside.

Rescue workers used a helicopter to evacuate survivor Emilio Caal, who said he lost as many as 40 family members and relatives. Caal, 65, suffered a dislocated shoulder when the landslide sent rocks, trees and earth hurtling onto the home where he was about to sit down to lunch with his wife and grandchildren. Caal said he was blown several yards (meters) by the force of the slide, and that none of the others were able to get out.
â€œMy wife is dead, my grandchildren are dead,â€ said Caal from a nearby hospital.
In neighboring Honduras, 68-year-old MarÃ­a Elena MejÃ­a Guadron died when the brown waters of the Chamelecon river poured into San Pedro Sulaâ€™s Planeta neighborhood before dawn Thursday.

In southern Mexico, across the border from Guatemala, 20 people died as heavy rains attributed to Eta caused mudslides and swelled streams and rivers, according to Chiapas state civil defense official ElÃ­as Morales RodrÃ­guez.
The worst incident in Mexico occurred in the mountain township of Chenalho, where 10 people were swept away by a rain-swollen stream; their bodies were later found downstream.

Flooding in the neighboring state of Tabasco was so bad that President AndrÃ©s Manuel LÃ³pez Obrador cut short a trip to western Mexico and was flying to Tabasco, his home state, to oversee relief efforts.
Hurricane Etaâ€™s arrival in northeast Nicaragua Tuesday followed days of drenching rain as it crawled toward shore. Its slow, meandering path north through Honduras pushed rivers over their banks.
Associated Press writers Kelli Kennedy in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, Marlon GonzÃ¡lez in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, and Frances Dâ€™Emilio in Rome, Italy, contributed to this report.

otherData.headline: Senate Set To Block Joe Biden At Every Turn
otherData.short_description: He could be the first president in decades without his party in control of Congress.

articleContent: Democrats didnâ€™t want to repeat the overconfidence of 2016, but they couldnâ€™t help but start to dream: What would be possible if they won not only the presidency but also a healthy Senate majority as well?

They started talking about adding seats to the Supreme Court, abolishing the filibuster and moving forward with big climate change legislation. Activists around the country poured money into Senate races, and candidates were significantly outraising and outspending their Republican Party opponents.

But President-elect Joe Biden will not have the robust Senate majority for which he had no doubt hoped. In fact, he could be the first president since George H.W. Bush to take office without his party controlling both chambers of Congress.
The filibuster will be sticking around, at least for now. And many of those big plans that Democrats had wonâ€™t be happening.

â€œLegislating in the next Congress just got a lot tougher. Among other things, the progressive wishlist from the House is in serious trouble in the Senate,â€ said Jim Manley, who served as a top aide to former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.).
Control of the Senate remains uncertain, but it could very well remain in Republican hands. Even if Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) does become majority leader, it wonâ€™t be with much of a cushion.

Right now, the makeup is split, with four races yet to be called. Democrats picked up two seats, and Republicans picked up one. But Democrats were widely expected to net more. Control of the Senate could have to wait until Jan. 5, when Georgiaâ€™s two Senate seats will be determined in runoff races.

â€œFor a President Biden, governing will have a Jekyll and Hyde feel,â€ said a senior Democratic Senate aide. Like others interviewed for this article, they requested anonymity to speak freely. â€œOn one level, there is a substantial number of steps he can take via executive action. Moreover, a sizable portion of the country will be relieved that the person sitting behind the Resolute Desk is no longer a madman.â€

â€œOn another level, legislating will be a real grind,â€ they added. â€œIf Democrats donâ€™t win the Senate, governing in the Biden era will make the post-tea party years of the Obama administration seem idyllic in comparison.â€

Biden already faced enormous challenges in the best of circumstances. He has to tackle a growing pandemic, heal a fractured country and please activists who want him to make big changes to structural problems.

The question now is how he will be able to do any of that with a Democratic-led House and a divided Senate. (Democrats held on to the House, but they appear set to lose ground after expecting to pick up seats.)

â€œSo once this election is finalized and behind us, it will be time for us to do what we have always done as Americans,â€ Biden said in a speech Wednesday afternoon. â€œTo put the harsh rhetoric of the campaign behind us. ... I know this wonâ€™t be easy. Iâ€™m not naÃ¯ve. Neither of us are. I know how deep and hard the opposing views are in our country on so many things. But I also know this as well: To make progress we must stop treating our opponents as our enemy.â€

Biden has long pitched his ability to work across the aisle as a selling point, saying he believes that GOP lawmakers will be different once Trump is gone. In May, he lamented that â€œan awful lot of Republicans have become intimidated by the president.â€
