otherData.headline: James Randi, Famed Magician And Skeptic, Dies At 92
otherData.short_description: The Amazing Randi challenged spoon benders, mind readers and faith healers and became regarded as the countryâ€™s foremost skeptic.

articleContent: James Randi, a magician who later challenged spoon benders, mind readers and faith healers with such voracity that he became regarded as the countryâ€™s foremost skeptic, has died, his foundation announced. He was 92.
The James Randi Educational Foundation confirmed the death, saying simply that its founder succumbed to â€œage-related causesâ€ on Tuesday.

Entertainer, genius, debunker, atheist Ì¶ Randi was them all. He began gaining attention not long after dropping out of high school to join the carnival. As the Amazing Randi, he escaped from a locked coffin submerged in water and from a straitjacket as he dangled over Niagara Falls.
Magical as his feats seemed, Randi concluded his shows around the globe with a simple statement, insisting no otherworldly powers were at play.
â€œEverything you have seen here is tricks,â€ he would say. â€œThere is nothing supernatural involved.â€
The magicianâ€™s transparency gave a glimpse of what would become his longest-running act, as the countryâ€™s skeptic-in-chief. In that role, his first widely seen exploit was also his most enduring.

On a 1972 episode of â€œThe Tonight Show,â€ he helped Johnny Carson set up Uri Geller, the Israeli performer who claimed to bend spoons with his mind. Randi ensured the spoons and other props were kept from Gellerâ€™s hands until showtime to prevent any tampering.
The result was an agonizing 22 minutes in which Geller was unable to perform any tricks.

Randi had bushy white eyebrows and beard, a bald head, and gold-rimmed glasses, and bounced his 5-foot-6 (1.6 meter) frame energetically, even in his final years. He sought to disprove not just those who read palms and minds, but chiropractors, homeopaths and others he saw as predators seeking innocent peopleâ€™s money.

Randi targeted those he saw as frauds with a tenacity and dedication he admitted was an obsession. His efforts were reminiscent of those of his great predecessor Harry Houdini, who devoted large portions of his time to debunking spiritualists and their seances.

â€œI see people being swindled every day by medical quackery, frauds of every sort, psychics and their hot lines, people who claim to be able to find lost children or to help them invest their money,â€ Randi told The Associated Press in 1998. â€œI know they are being swindled because I know the methods being used.â€
Once, awaiting the chance to sift through the trash of a faith healer, Randi spent days in his car, eating Twinkies and drinking Pepsi.
â€œI suffer from this obsession that I have something important to do,â€ he explained in a 2007 interview with The AP.

There were other coups for Randi: He once showed the messages television faith healer Peter Popoff claimed to be getting from God about his audience were actually coming from his wife through an earpiece. But the vast majority of those he aimed to show were frauds were lesser known, lured to prove their abilities by the James Randi Educational Foundation.
Through that organization, Randi was guardian of a $1 million prize he promised to give anyone who could prove either their own supernatural powers or the presence of a supernatural being.
His loudest detractors said they didnâ€™t believe the money even existed, but Randi had the bank documentation. No one ever came close to collecting.
Randi gave up the day-to-day operation of his foundation in 2009 and retired in 2015.

Born Randall James Hamilton Zwinge in Toronto on Aug. 7, 1928, Randi Ì¶ known by everyone simply by that surname Ì¶ had a nagging desire to question from a young age. Academically, he said he was bored in school and teachers acknowledged he was prodigy far ahead of his peers. He never earned a high school diploma or went to college but in 1986 was awarded a prestigious MacArthur fellowship, often known simply as a â€œgenius grant.â€
He spoke with certainty. While he said he never really questioned his beliefs, he acknowledged there was always a chance he was wrong.
â€œI am probably right. But Iâ€™m always only probably right,â€ he said. â€œAbsolutes are very hard to find.â€

For all the analysis Randi put into seemingly everything, he still found delight in observing magic he knew was a stunt or watching a film that was just fantasy. He talked about the crushing feelings of watching a friend die and spoke of the magic of love. In 2010, he announced he was gay. In 2013, he married his longtime partner, Deyvi Pena, at a ceremony in Washington, D.C. He was the subject of a 2014 documentary, â€œAn Honest Liar.â€

Penn Jillette, a magician in the mold of Randi, mourned his friend on Twitter on Wednesday night, writing: â€œWe will never forget that without Randi, there would not be Penn & Teller. Itâ€™s really that simple.â€

Randi said he couldnâ€™t help feeling angry that his targets always seemed to perform escape acts of their own, continuing to win new followers and earn checks he said were cashed at realityâ€™s expense. He wanted to see frauds punished, but he recognized most people wanted to believe.
â€œThe true believers,â€ he said, â€œwill not pay any attention to evidence that does not show that they believe to be untrue.â€

It was frustrating to Randi and fueled an underlying anger toward those he labeled frauds. When he let his displeasure slip out, though, it often was mixed with wit, as when asked about his final wishes and how heâ€™d like his ashes disposed.
â€œMy best friend is instructed to throw them in Uri Gellerâ€™s eyes,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™d like him to get an eyeful of my ashes. I think that would be appropriate.â€
The day of death has been corrected to Tuesday, not Monday.

otherData.headline: Republican Mask Manufacturer Says He'll Vote Biden After Trump 'Politicized' COVID-19
otherData.short_description: "There is only one scientifically minded person in the race," said Prestige Ameritech executive Mike Bowen. "That person is Joe Biden.â€

articleContent: The Republican executive of a company that manufactures medical masks said Tuesday that he will vote for Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden, due to President Donald Trumpâ€™s â€œpoliticizedâ€ response to the coronavirus crisis.

Mike Bowen â€• executive vice president of Texas-based Prestige Ameritech, the largest producer of N95 masks and respirators in the U.S. â€• said in a statement to HuffPost that Trumpâ€™s handling of the pandemic has â€œgreatly increased death and suffering in America.â€

â€œPresident Trump downplayed the virus, missed opportunities, and wasted precious time,â€ Bowen said in his statement. â€œHe has also politicized the wearing of masks. ... The man has politicized a life-saving medical device and has teased people for wearing it!â€

â€œMr. Trump is a self-proclaimed â€˜geniusâ€™ who prefers his own magical thinking to the advice of experts and scientists,â€ Bowen continued, adding: â€œThe next time that there is a scientifically minded Republican presidential candidate, I will vote for her or him. This time, however, there is only one scientifically minded person in the race. That person is Joe Biden.â€
Bowen, who describes himself as a lifelong Republican, testified before Congress in May that the countryâ€™s dependence on foreign masks had been a national security risk for several years.

During that same hearing, Dr. Rick Bright, the former director of the U.S. Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA), testified that Bowen had warned federal officials as early as January that the country faced a mask shortage.

Bright served as director of BARDA for nearly four years until, in his words, he was ousted in April for objecting to pressure from Trump administration officials who wanted the agency to invest in unproven COVID-19 drugs and vaccines.

â€œIâ€™ll never forget the emails I received from Mike Bowen indicating that our mask supply, our N95 respirator supply, was completely decimated,â€ Bright testified. â€œAnd he said, â€˜Weâ€™re in deep shit. The world is. And we need to act.â€™ ... We were already behind the ball.â€
Bowen appears in the newly released documentary â€œTotally Under Control,â€ which examines the Trump administrationâ€™s response to the pandemic.

â€œAround 2005, all of the major mask makers left the country,â€ Bowen says in the film. â€œIt put the U.S. mask supply in the hands of foreign control and could be subject to diversion during the pandemic. And thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve been warning about for years.â€

He added: â€œI voted for Donald Trump. I thought, you know, if I contact enough people in the administration somebody â€• one of these people â€• is going to look at this and say, â€˜Hey, this is a problem. Maybe we ought to call this guy.â€™ And no, I couldnâ€™t get any â€• I didnâ€™t get any response there.â€

As of Wednesday, the U.S. continued to lead the world in confirmed coronavirus cases and deaths. Nationwide, there have been more than 8.2 million cases and at least 221,000 deaths, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University.

A HuffPost Guide To Coronavirus
Get the latest coronavirus updates here.
What will life be like once a coronavirus vaccine arrives?
Everything you need to know about face masks right now.
What should you still be disinfecting to prevent COVID-19?
Is it possible you had coronavirus earlier this year?
Constantly arguing with your partner about coronavirus risks? You are not alone.

Everyone deserves accurate information about COVID-19. Support journalism without a paywall â€” and keep it free for everyone â€” by becoming a HuffPost member today.

otherData.headline: Trumpâ€™s Crackdown On Diversity Training Is Fascist. And Terrifying.
otherData.short_description: The White House ban on anti-racism training is an authoritarian attack on free speech and already doing serious damage.

articleContent:
One of the presidentâ€™s most dangerous attacks on civil rights and free speech is getting relatively little attention amid the firestorm of news as Election Day approaches.
In an executive order and a series of administrative actions issued over the past month and a half, the Trump administration effectively banned diversity and inclusion training in the federal workforce and at any company or entity that contracts with the government or receives federal funding, a huge swath of American businesses and universities, covering millions of workers and students.
As part of the administrationâ€™s continued efforts to effectively ban anti-racism training, the Labor Department announced Wednesday it would begin collecting information on diversity training from contractors (Verizon, which owns HuffPost, is one such company) as a way of policing the way diversity is discussed within private companies.
The president ironically claims to be doing this in the name of equality. The administration says these trainings are un-American propaganda, claiming that learning about the history of race in the United States teaches the language of hate.
But diversity training is standard corporate practice, meant to encourage workers of all backgrounds to treat each other fairly. As the Me Too movement began, there was a shift to focus on sexual harassment education. These days, companies are increasingly concentrating on racism.
In the case of diversity training, the White House is basing its opinion on the findings of one conservative activist, Christopher Rufo, who has appeared on Fox News and written for the New York Post and Wall Street Journal.
The word Orwellian is thrown around quite a bit in the Donald Trump era, but the doublespeak in this order stunned the lawyers, executives, activists and academics who have pushed for diversity, inclusion and equality for decades.
The order is the bureaucratic equivalent of telling white supremacists to â€œStand back and stand by,â€ or of claiming there were â€œvery fine peopleâ€ on both sides of a deadly neo-Nazi rally and counterprotest in Virginia.
â€œThis is far more serious than a lot of people think,â€ said KimberlÃ© Crenshaw, a law professor at UCLA and Columbia Law School, and an early pioneer of the academic theories now under attack from the administration. â€œThis is no minor thing. This is an effort to put the weight of the federal government behind ideas that say anti-racism is racist itself.â€
Crenshaw and others view the administrationâ€™s moves as a direct attack on their right to share thoughts and ideas. At least one person called the order fascist. Theyâ€™re a huge and powerful move by the White House to curb the right of workers, businesses and universities to discuss one of the most pivotal issues in the United States: racism.
Itâ€™s a clear assault on free speech, in the name of equality, against efforts to learn about equality.
â€œWhen a society is moving to authoritarianism, it goes after the ideas. It goes after speech,â€ Crenshaw said.
The administrationâ€™s actions are a way of opposing the reckoning with race thatâ€™s taken place around the country in the wake of the murder of George Floyd, a Black man who died after a white police officer knelt on his neck for 8 minutes and 46 seconds on May 25, a killing that stunned the nation.
The NAACP Legal Defense Fund told HuffPost it is weighing legal action against the Trump administration.
â€œThis is an extraordinary and alarming act by our federal government and our president,â€ said Jin Hee Lee, the fundâ€™s deputy director of litigation. â€œThe order is using the power of the federal government to essentially censor and police the actual thoughts and ideas and perspectives of not only federal employees and the U.S. military but also federal contractors that are private entities and grant recipients.â€
Timeline Of The Attack
The crackdown on diversity training began in September and has escalated over just the past few weeks.
The White House put out its order to ban diversity training, or what it called â€œdivisive, anti-American propaganda,â€ on Sept. 4, just two days after Rufo appeared on Tucker Carlsonâ€™s Fox News show and directly appealed to the White House to ban such seminars, calling them dangerous and â€œterrifying.â€
In the executive order, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget directed all federal agencies to cease funding such training, as it is â€œcontrary to all we stand for as Americans and should have no place in the Federal government.â€
The memo even identified specific terms that could not be used, including â€œcritical race theoryâ€ and â€œwhite privilege,â€ or any other teaching that would suggest the â€œUnited States is an inherently racist or evil country.â€
Trump tweeted the news the next day: â€œThis is a sickness that cannot be allowed to continue. Please report any sightings so we can quickly extinguish!â€ The conservative press and Republican lawmakers, including Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri, quickly got in line. â€œMarxist-influenced nonsense that is racially divisive,â€ Hawley said. â€œIf you didnâ€™t know better, if you read this stuff, youâ€™d think it was put out by some white nationalist. Itâ€™s unbelievable.â€
The Congressional Black Caucus and other groups of lawmakers of color quickly responded, saying the administration was â€œtrying to sweep our nationâ€™s history of racism under the rug.â€
Less than two weeks later, on Sept. 17, Trump broadened his attack to include The New York Timesâ€™s 1619 Project and seemingly any kind of study of history that examines race in America. â€œCritical race theory, the 1619 Project, and the crusade against American history is toxic propaganda,â€ the president said. â€œAn ideological poison that, if not removed, will dissolve the civic bonds that tie us together.â€
Then on Sept. 22, the administration went further, issuing the â€œExecutive Order on Combating Race and Sex Stereotyping,â€ which extended the ban to any training that promotes race or sex stereotyping or scapegoating in the military; at any company with federal contracts, which could include such behemoths as Microsoft and Boeing; and any organization that gets federal grants, which would include universities around the country.
Incredibly, the order claims its actions are in the name of equality. â€œThe President, and his Administration, are fully committed to the fair and equal treatment of all individuals in the United States.â€
But the administration is shutting down training meant to facilitate understanding, equity and belonging in the workplace.
On Oct. 4, the White House went further still, ordering all agencies to suspend diversity training until they are deemed to be in line with the presidentâ€™s order.
The Labor Department has even set up a hotline that workers can call to complain about diversity training.
The Damage Is Already Done
Though Rufo, Hawley and others are calling this training Marxist, the capitalists of Corporate America actually seem to like diversity training. Not only because it feels like the right thing to do and it helps foster a welcoming atmosphere for women and people of color, but also because itâ€™s a relatively simple way to deal with the hard issues of racial and sex discrimination.
A few years ago, for example, Sephora convened a one-day diversity training after a well-known R&B artist said she was racially profiled at one of the makeup storeâ€™s retail outlets.
This week, the traditionally conservative U.S. Chamber of Commerce signed on to a letter to the president from more than 150 business and nonprofit organizations asking Trump to withdraw his executive order.
â€œThe [order] is already having a broadly chilling effect on legitimate and valuable D&I training companies use to foster inclusive workplaces, help with talent recruitment, and remain competitive in a country with a wide range of different cultures,â€ the letter says, noting that the order is ambiguous as to what is and isnâ€™t permissible to discuss in these trainings.
There are growing reports that because of the order companies are increasingly wary of continuing with diversity efforts. A few businesses have put programs on hold.
The order has a possibly even more harmful effect on universities, especially public institutions loath to risk federal money during a severe recession.
The University of Iowa and Texas State University have put programs on ice. John A. Logan College in Illinois canceled its programming, including a talk by an anthropology professor about his own Latino identity.
A screening of the movie â€œMalcolm Xâ€ and a planned talk was reportedly canceled at a military nonprofit.
Last month, the White House canceled a training on racism and public health at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is currently grappling with the coronavirus pandemic that has disproportionately affected Black and Latino people. The death rate for Black people from COVID-19 is twice that of white people; the rate of infections among Latinos is nearly three times higher than for non-Latino whites. (These are current examples of systemic racism, which Rufo and Trump and other conservatives claim is not real.)
Diversity Training Was Hardly Radical, Until Now
Whatâ€™s particularly startling is that diversity training in the workplace is hardly radical stuff. At least not until now. If anything, these efforts have long been criticized as something companies do instead of actually hiring more people of color and women.
These trainings have exploded in popularity since the summer, when millions took to the streets to protest police brutality. Companies at the time spoke up, too, asserting that Black lives matter; they doubled down on these kinds of trainings as a way to show their commitment to the cause. Diversity consultants said business was booming.
Businesses wanted to find a way to acknowledge what their employees of color were going through in a way that was constructive.
â€œWe knew there was a lot of trauma in the nation and among our employees. We know individuals donâ€™t leave that pain and confusion at the door when we come to work,â€ Lorraine Cole, director of the Office of Minority and Women Inclusion at the Treasury Department, told a congressional subcommittee in September, explaining why she helped put together an online seminar on racism in June for some federal workers.
â€œWe knew it was important for us to address these issues, not only as a compassionate activity but as an important business decision. We know that this can affect productivity.â€
The webinar on June 24 was viewed by 8,500 federal employees and was a pretty open and, at times, moving conversation about race, Floydâ€™s murder and the experiences of Black Americans in the United States.
Notably, it was moderated by Rodney Hood, chairman of the National Credit Union Administration, a Trump appointee and the first African American ever appointed to lead a federal banking agency. He spoke candidly about his experiences with racism in the financial industry.
A few weeks later, in mid-July, Rufo, the conservative activist, wrote about the event for his blog, condemning it. The next day, July 17, he wrote about it again, for the New York Post, and also appeared on Laura Ingrahamâ€™s Fox News show. (He appeared on her show again this week.)
Things settled down a bit as the story circulated on conservative websites. Then on Sept. 2, Rufo appeared on Tucker Carlsonâ€™s Fox News show.
On air, Rufo called for the White House to outright ban diversity training.
Two days later, the White House put out its first order banning diversity training in federal agencies.
Anatomy Of The Backlash
The conservative media and Rufo appear to believe diversity training is radical and somehow racist and anti-white. In part thatâ€™s because they cherry-pick examples to distort meaning.
Take the June webinar for federal employees. Critics of the event appear most incensed over not what was discussed but about the text of a supplemental resource guide given to attendees afterward.
Rufo has portrayed the guide as some sort of directive, but really itâ€™s just resources for those who want to learn more: a link to Ta-Nehisi Coatesâ€™ seminal Atlantic article â€œThe Case for Reparations,â€ and oral histories about the civil rights movement. There was also information for people of color looking for counseling or other support during a traumatic time.
What got conservatives worked up is a description and link to the work of Robin DiAngelo, the author of â€œWhite Fragility: Why Itâ€™s So Hard for White People to Talk About Racism,â€ which hit the bestseller list this summer, as more Americans were buying books about race, and has been criticized among both liberals and conservatives.
The manual links to a video of DiAngelo on YouTube, and there is text next to that link that says: â€œShe discusses the roots of White supremacy, of which she asserts virtually all White people, regardless of how â€˜wokeâ€™ they are, contribute to racism.â€
That last clause of that passage has been repeated and replayed in the conservative press as evidence that diversity training teaches people they are racist.
Again, thatâ€™s not what is happening. For the most part in anti-racism training, Americans are being taught history and sharing their personal experiences with racism in hopes of furthering understanding of why racism persists today and how they fit into that history.
â€œI can tell you definitively that the kind of training Howard and I do is not centered in hating white people,â€ said Johnnetta Cole, who took part in the conversation that day with the well-regarded diversity consultant Howard Ross on the webinar. Cole is the president emerita of Spelman and Bennett colleges, and president and board chair of the National Council of Negro Women. Sheâ€™s done consulting work for years.
â€œIt is not centered in hating white people. It is centered in trying to understand the current state of our country and how, 401 years ago, language was created. Systems were invented. Policies were made that explained why it was all right to brutally, inhumanely enslave Black people for the economic good of some white folk,â€ she said.
Cole, who is 84 and grew up in the Deep South in the Jim Crow era, characterized the crackdown on diversity training as deep denial of the reality of systemic racism in the United States.
â€œDenial is perhaps among the most dangerous reactions to reality,â€ she said. â€œWhen systemic racism is denied. How will we ever move beyond it?â€
Twisting The Study Of Critical Race Theory
In his writing and on Fox News, Rufo particularly went after something called critical race theory, which he mischaracterizes as the idea that the U.S. and white people are racist and evil, a line of argument picked up in the conservative press and elsewhere.
In fact, critical race theory is a line of legal scholarship that for decades has sought to understand why structural racism persists in the U.S. despite laws on the books ensuring equality and prohibiting discrimination.
Why is there a racial wealth gap? Why are Black mortality rates higher than white mortality rates and life expectancy lower? Why is K-12 education still so segregated?
Crenshaw, an early pioneer in the field, (she also coined the term â€œintersectionalityâ€) calls it a framework through which to view history and the law in the U.S. Through the prism of the theory, you might ask, â€œWhy do we still have a society in which itâ€™s predictable who is going to occupy the CEOâ€™s office and whoâ€™s going to clean it?â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s a way of thinking about race that challenges the idea that we can do away with racial inequality by not paying attention to race at all.â€
Typically these arenâ€™t ideas that come up in corporate diversity training. Though, after this summer, more workplaces were open to discussing the roots of inequality and racism in the United States.
Some backlash was inevitable, though the fact that itâ€™s coming from the White House was not.
The executive order reflects the deepest fears that some white folks have when it comes to diversity, equity and inclusion training, said Evelyn Carter, managing director at Paradigm, a diversity consulting business. (She said the company already lost one client in the wake of Trumpâ€™s order.)
â€œOur general stance is that the executive order is meant to sow confusion that will make people pause and wonder if they should keep going,â€ Carter said. â€œIt is essentially propaganda, and Iâ€™m concerned what this means in terms of a descent into fascism.â€
Oftentimes discussions of racism can bring up a lot of anxiety for those groups in the majority; in this country thatâ€™s white people, Carter said. That fear looms large especially for those who have little experience talking about these issues.
Thereâ€™s an underlying fear that conversations about racism will â€œbelie their egalitarian self-concept,â€ as researchers from the University of Virginia and Northwestern explain in a 2012 paper in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology.
In plain terms, theyâ€™re afraid that theyâ€™ll appear racist if they talk about racism.
That fear can trigger defensiveness, anger and lashing out. White people might feel like itâ€™s unfair to have to even hear about discrimination.
By shutting down the conversation on race inside the government and within companies and universities, Trumpâ€™s order caves to that fear and lets aggrieved and scared white people off the hook.
â€œThis is a way to say, if you feel angry that you are being forced to consider a different perspective or being made to feel your identity is being privileged, then we are going to protect you,â€ Carter said.
The executive order and the conservative talk about how anti-racism training is racist are also clearly examples of the backlash against the growing conversation about race in America thatâ€™s been taking place since the summer amid protests over the police killing of George Floyd. Thereâ€™s also a growing fear that more white people are joining the fight against racism.
Crenshaw said itâ€™s absolutely necessary to keep the conversation going, as she has in her work for more than 40 years. The idea is to continually work to perfect the American experiment â€• and the notion that all people are created equal.
â€œItâ€™s part of what it means to be a part of a society that had a flawed start,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not easy work to do.â€

otherData.headline: â€˜The Undoingâ€™ Is Unoriginal But Highly Watchable
otherData.short_description: Two HuffPost reporters investigate the whodunnit allure of Nicole Kidman and Hugh Grant's new HBO limited series.

articleContent: Another day, another show about murderous intrigue.

â€œThe Undoingâ€ premieres Sunday on HBO, giving Nicole Kidman another prestige project from the network behind the similarly themed â€œBig Little Lies.â€ This time Kidman plays Grace Fraser, a wealthy Manhattan therapist who finds her polished lifestyle suddenly unraveling when her husband (Hugh Grant) is accused of killing his paramour Elena (Matilda De Angelis).

Reviews of the six-episode limited series have been mixed, with IndieWire calling it â€œmisguidedâ€ and Vulture deeming it â€œseductive.â€ But with such star power (Donald Sutherland, Lily Rabe, Noah Jupe and Ã‰dgar RamÃ­rez round out the supporting cast), there must be something worthwhile in â€œThe Undoing.â€
To find out, HuffPost reporters Leigh Blickley and Matthew Jacobs fired up a few episodes and chatted about their findings.
The Bottom Line
â€œThe Undoingâ€ isnâ€™t fresh enough to constitute must-see TV, but it has plenty of allure, including twisty cliffhangers, a chilly atmosphere and a few exemplary performances.
Cast And Characters

Matthew Jacobs: â€œThe Undoingâ€ couldnâ€™t be more indicative of TV in the early 2020s: two certified movie stars uniting for the sort of pulpy literary adaptation that 25 years ago would have lit up the box office. Itâ€™s wealth porn, murder mystery and domestic-discord noir. I was hooked after one episode. Whatâ€™d you think?

Leigh Blickley: Couldnâ€™t agree more. Give me a thriller set in pre-COVID New York City and Iâ€™m all yours. â€œThe Undoingâ€ grabbed my attention the minute Nicole Kidman brushed her teeth in a flowing bathrobe while walking through an enormous, wallpaper-adorned Upper East Side brownstone. The glamour. The predictable terror. Itâ€™s also unreal to me that Kidman and Hugh Grant have never worked together before. What a treat for us.

MJ: I suppose â€œrich people on the verge of a breakdownâ€ has always been Kidmanâ€™s specialty (see: â€œEyes Wide Shut,â€ â€œThe Others,â€ â€œBirthâ€), which means David E. Kelley is keeping an entire subgenre alive. Kidman and Grant get equal billing, but itâ€™s really her show, spotty American accent and all. In â€œBig Little Lies,â€ her best scenes occurred during therapy sessions. In â€œThe Undoing,â€ sheâ€™s the therapist â€” arguably not a great one, but thatâ€™s another matter â€” yet that doesnâ€™t provide Grace any detailed understanding of her husbandâ€™s behavior. Iâ€™ve seen three episodes, and Iâ€™m worried the show is too familiar (messy affairs, class disparities) to pull off a real surprise in the end. But Iâ€™ll certainly stick around to find out.

LB: Thank you for calling out Kidmanâ€™s accent, which perplexed me at times. Grant, luckily, gets to stick with his British brogue playing her husband, respected pediatric oncologist Jonathan Fraser, who seems as dedicated to his family as he is to his relentless job. Yet Jonathan carries some dark secrets â€• secrets that blow up the Frasersâ€™ seemingly idyllic life.
Just Another Whodunnit?

LB: â€œThe Undoingâ€ is based on Jean Hanff Korelitzâ€™s novel â€œYou Should Have Known,â€ which I have not read but might dip into now that Iâ€™ve become wrapped up in this story. Have you read it, Matt?

MJ: I havenâ€™t, and I was intrigued when I saw a recent Vulture story call the show â€œmore of a whodunnit than the novel.â€ That tweak also seems indicative of the Peak TV era. (Or have we already graduated to Post-Peak TV? I canâ€™t keep up.) Maximized intrigue is what keeps people coming back for more, or so networks think. To get a green light, you need cliffhangers. It can be a bit exhausting, but I found the thriller aspects of this show far more absorbing than some of the similar programming weâ€™ve seen this year. Iâ€™m thinking of â€œLittle Fires Everywhere,â€ â€œRatchedâ€ and the latest â€œFargoâ€ season.

LB: Yes, when I went into the series, I was honestly set to give up after an episode or two due to my expectations surrounding these types of series recently. (How many more murder mysteries and/or crime shows do we need, truly?) But I ended up absorbed by Kelley and director Susanne Bierâ€™s storytelling and the way they unravel the psychological states of these characters. Bier zooms all the way in, literally and figuratively, with each passing glance. Her distinct style of filmmaking (â€œThe Night Manager,â€ â€œBird Boxâ€) definitely grabs you.

I also found myself feeling for, and believing, almost all of the men in Graceâ€™s life â€• whether thatâ€™s Jonathan, their teenage son Henry (played by Noah Jupe) or Graceâ€™s utterly rich and intense socialite father Franklin (Donald Sutherland). The study of these men intrigued me alongside, of course, the analysis of Grace herself â€• a therapist who seemingly â€œshould have knownâ€ of her husbandâ€™s sociopathic tendencies.

MJ: Yes, and the fact that itâ€™s set at a fancy private school seems pretty typical, too. Thereâ€™s even a high-class charity event at the center, just like there was in â€œBig Little Lies.â€ (That show had a lot more humor, though.) But I like the relationship between Grace and Henry, who is mature for his age and forced to confront the complexities of his fatherâ€™s wrongdoings. How much should Grace tell him? How much can he handle?

Having seen more episodes, what do you make of Elenaâ€™s murder? Itâ€™s the inciting incident, leading to flashbacks of what came before. The show gives Elena an exoticism thatâ€™s both enticing and troubling. Sheâ€™s a vaguely bisexual, working-class artist whose presence makes the tony Upper East Side moms uncomfortable. But sheâ€™s dead and can no longer speak for herself, especially if the back half of the season is just a courtroom drama.

LB: Elenaâ€™s introduction is immediately telling â€• as a viewer, you can sense sheâ€™s at the center of this story from her first closeup. Actress Matilda De Angelis brings a mystery to the character. As we discover more about her following her death, Elenaâ€™s enigmatic energy becomes more clear. The mother of two was in a love quadruple of sorts with her husband Fernando (Ismael Cruz CÃ³rdova), Jonathan and Grace, all of whom are confused about their feelings for her. This adds to the whodunnit aspect of the series as true intentions start to untangle. Is Jonathan really a killer? Was Grace involved in any way? Did jealousy lead Fernando to murder? Then, of course, supporting players like Henry and Franklin, as well as a lawyer (Noma Dumezweni) and a detective (Ã‰dgar RamÃ­rez), muddle everything even more.
Highs And Lows

MJ: To that end, I wonder if â€œThe Undoingâ€ would have been better as a movie. The gradual pacing is going to turn some folks off, and for me, it made Elena seem like even more of a cipher than sheâ€™s meant to be. The show is at its best when focused on Grace and her inner circle, yet the whole thing hinges on this inscrutable dead woman whose key trait was living in a different ZIP code. Maybe Iâ€™m just a sucker for Noah Jupe, arguably the greatest child actor working today, who carries a ton of weight in the show and holds his own opposite Kidman.

LB: Ever since I saw Jupe in â€œWonder,â€ Iâ€™ve been such a fan of his. â€œA Quiet Place,â€ â€œHoney Boy,â€ â€œFord v. Ferrariâ€ â€” heâ€™s been a solid standout over the years. But youâ€™re right. â€œThe Undoingâ€ has its strengths as a series but couldâ€™ve, and maybe shouldâ€™ve, just been a movie. After all, itâ€™s all said and done in six episodes. Two and a half hours wouldâ€™ve sufficed?
MJ: And now weâ€™ve pinpointed the problem of Peak TV. Still, the schadenfreude of seeing the 1% unravel hasnâ€™t gone away, and Kidman is reliably great.
So, Should You Watch It?

LB: I must say that out of all the shows Iâ€™ve devoured lately, this one really stuck with me. The prep school world of New Yorkâ€™s elite is so enticing, especially when murder is mixed in. And with COVID delays impacting the TV space, a visionary limited series just hits the spot. Plus, Kidman delivers, as does Grant, whoâ€™s lately had an impressive run of projects (â€œPaddington 2â€ forever).

MJ: Thereâ€™s a chilliness to Bierâ€™s approach that is undeniably effective. Iâ€™m not sure the series can rise above its â€œrich people problemsâ€ trappings, but Iâ€™m on board for the journey anyway.
â€œThe Undoingâ€ airs Sundays at 9 p.m. Eastern Time on HBO and HBO Max.

otherData.headline: The Most Popular Horror Reads Of The Past Year, According To Goodreads
otherData.short_description: Looking for a fright? These scary books for adults were popular among avid readers this year.

articleContent: HuffPost may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Prices and availability subject to change.
Itâ€™s the spookiest season of all â€” when weâ€™re all on the lookout for full moons, things that go bump in the night, tricks and treats.

You might be ready to take a trip to the dark side right about now â€” whether that means taking out your tasteful Halloween home decor, finding Halloween decorations that you donâ€™t have to put away on Oct. 31 or putting your cat in her own Halloween costume.

If youâ€™re looking to take a break from a marathon of creepy flicks or a slew of spooky shows, you could turn to spine-chilling, hair-raising and blood-curdling books for frights thatâ€™ll feel oh so real.

Thatâ€™s why we asked the folks at Goodreads for the top horror books that have been popular with their book-loving members throughout this year. These books have vampires who bite and mysterious witches, along with enough twists to be thrilling. A few have even made it to our monthly â€œMost Anticipated Booksâ€ guide that Goodreads also helps us curate.

Truth may be stranger than fiction, but in these strange times, lots of us have been searching for fictional spooks. Thereâ€™s an essential pandemic reading list from Vulture. Electric Literature picked out books about plagues back in March. Even The New York Times has the â€œQuarantine Readerâ€ featuring authors Edgar Allan Poe and Stephen King.

â€œAs we all learned to navigate the uncertainty and loss of normalcy that this year has brought us, we saw readers flock to horror novels, propelling tales of terror to the top of our most popular lists,â€ said Cybil Wallace, a senior editor at Goodreads. â€œAnd the genre was ready for the extra attention, with some very compelling and terrifying reads.â€

If youâ€™ve been looking for a horror book that you wonâ€™t be able to put down, Goodreads gave us their scary suggestions based on books that were published in the last year and have at least a 3.5-star rating from members. Maybe these popular picks will help you escape from this world for a little while.
As always, you should check to see if a nearby independent bookstore has these titles in stock. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re linking the books below to Bookshop. You can find all 10 books on Amazon as well.

If you donâ€™t know, on Bookshop you can opt to have all the profits from your purchase go to a local bookstore that you choose. Or your order can contribute to a fund thatâ€™s split between different independent bookstores.
No spoilers, so youâ€™ll have to see the list down there for the top scary stories that Goodreads members have been devouring this year. Just make sure youâ€™re not reading these in the dark.

otherData.headline: Most Presidents Who Lose Deal With Shame. Trump Could Have To Deal With Prison.
otherData.short_description: Winning a second term could put him beyond the reach of many of the possible charges, thanks to statutes of limitations that would run out.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• If Donald Trump seems more desperate than most incumbents about the coming election, he may have good reason: Presidents do not typically have to worry about going to prison if they lose.

But Trumpâ€™s activities in recent years â€• from paying hush money to a porn star to his claiming of a massive tax refund to obstructing an investigation into his campaignâ€™s ties to Russia â€• combined with a ticking statute of limitations clock potentially make Election Day far more consequential for him than it had been for his predecessors.

If Trump wins a second term, the time limit for starting a prosecution would run out in the next four years for a number of those activities, given Justice Department guidelines not to prosecute a sitting president. If Trump loses, indictments could quickly follow.

â€œWinning this election for him is not an option. Itâ€™s a necessity,â€ said Michael Cohen, Trumpâ€™s former personal lawyer and â€œfixerâ€ who was sentenced for, among other charges, arranging illegal payments to keep women heâ€™d had affairs with from speaking out before the 2016 election.

â€œHe knows that if his tax returns are revealed that he and his children â€• Don Jr., Ivanka, Eric â€• and others will be charged with a host of criminal tax issues, which will not only cost him his freedom but his entire business,â€ Cohen said.
Neither the White House nor the Trump campaign responded to HuffPost queries for this report.

Trump was already described as â€œIndividual-1â€ in Cohenâ€™s prosecution. With a five-year statute of limitations for many federal crimes, the clock would run out on the hush money cases in late 2021.

Daniel Goldman, a former federal prosecutor who a year ago served as the lead lawyer in the Houseâ€™s impeachment of Trump, said an ex-President Trump in 2021 could also face charges of bribery for his commutation of aide Roger Stoneâ€™s prison sentence as well as extortion charges for his attempts to coerce Ukraine into smearing his political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden. Trump was impeached for that but was permitted by Republicans in the Senate to remain in office.

â€œThereâ€™s so much criminality here,â€ said Nick Ackerman, a former federal prosecutor and, prior to that, a prosecutor in the task force created to investigate President Richard Nixon for the 1972 Watergate break-in and subsequent cover-up.

Any federal tax or bank fraud Trump may have committed in the first three years of his first term would likely be beyond the reach of prosecutors if they have to wait until the end of a second term in January 2025. A similar fate could befall Trumpâ€™s work to throttle special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s 2017-2019 investigation into Russiaâ€™s work to help Trump win the last presidential campaign.
â€œAgain, it would lapse in a second term,â€ Ackerman said.

Though there is no prohibition on state-level prosecutions against a sitting president, a New York City district attorney told the U.S. Supreme Court in a case involving Trumpâ€™s business records that they were cognizant of the time demands on a president.

â€œWeâ€™re mindful that as a state actor, our office cannot investigate a president for any official acts and that we cannot prosecute a president while in office,â€ said Carey Dunne, general counsel for the Manhattan district attorneyâ€™s office during oral arguments in May.
The possibility of prosecution and incarceration may explain Trumpâ€™s apparent mania in recent months, with repeated use and, at times, abuse of the powers of his office to aid his reelection.

In spring, a mailing to every household in the country from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention about the coronavirus prominently included Trumpâ€™s name, even though he had spent months downplaying the virus, at one point even calling it a hoax. When the Treasury Department sent out $1,200 relief checks to Americans, those also included Trumpâ€™s name.

More recently, Trump has resisted warnings from public health experts to curtail large gatherings by resuming a frantic schedule of the campaign rallies that he believes are key to winning on Nov. 3. He has again started downplaying the virus and insisting â€• against all evidence â€• that the pandemic is all but over.

And on Tuesday, he added to his baseless claims of â€œcorruptionâ€ against Democratic opponent Biden by calling on Attorney General William Barr to open an investigation. â€œWeâ€™ve got to get the attorney general to act. Heâ€™s got to act, and heâ€™s got to act fast,â€ Trump said during a lengthy interview with Fox News. â€œThis is major corruption, and this has to be known about before the election.â€

America has a history of treating presidential losers poorly, essentially stamping a giant capital â€œLâ€ on their foreheads. Democrat Jimmy Carter was scorned, even by many Democrats, after losing in 1980 to Ronald Reagan. Republican Bob Dole, a longtime senator, was left to making self-deprecating television commercials after losing in 1996 to incumbent Bill Clinton.
But though they and others faced ignominy, they never had to worry about the possibility of years of imprisonment in the event of a loss.

The sole possible precedent in American politics is that of Republican Nixon, who resigned from office in 1974 after GOP senators made it clear they would not save him if articles of impeachment regarding his role in the Watergate scandal made it to their chamber. Gerald Ford, who had been appointed Nixonâ€™s vice president in 1973 after the resignation of Spiro Agnew following his indictment for bribery, issued Nixon a blanket pardon just 30 days after assuming the presidency. â€œI cannot prolong the bad dreams that continue to reopen a chapter that is closed,â€ Ford said in a taped 10-minute Oval Office speech.
Similarly, just because Trump could face criminal charges does not mean he necessarily will.

Biden, who has run on the theme of bringing the country together and â€œhealingâ€ after Trumpâ€™s years in office, in May committed in an MSNBC interview not to pardon Trump but said he would not direct his attorney general to do anything one way or the other. â€œIt is not something the president is entitled to do, to direct a prosecution or decide to drop a case,â€ Biden said.
Others, though, including Republicans, say it is critical to bringing back a sense of normalcy that a president as openly and regularly lawless as Trump be held to account.

â€œThe integrity of our constitutional republic depends on holding our elected leaders accountable. Trump is no exception,â€ said Rick Tyler, a GOP consultant who worked on Texas Sen. Ted Cruzâ€™s 2016 bid for president.

â€œWe cannot reward criminal behavior, by Trump or any of his miscreants in the Cabinet, White House or elsewhere,â€ agreed Norman Ornstein, with the conservative-leaning American Enterprise Institute.

We want to know what youâ€™re hearing on the ground from the candidates. If you get any interesting â€• or suspicious! â€• campaign mailers, robocalls or hear anything else you think we should know about, email us at scoops@huffpost.com.

otherData.headline: Thoughtful Quotes About Being A Stepparent From Kamala Harris
otherData.short_description: The Democratic vice presidential nominee is "Momala" to her two stepchildren.

articleContent: Kamala Harris has made it clear she loves being â€œMomalaâ€ to her stepkids.

The Democratic vice presidential nominee is stepmother to her husband Doug Emhoffâ€™s son Cole and daughter Ella. Since marrying Emhoff in 2014, Harris has shared glimpses of her blended family experience.
In honor of her birthday, weâ€™ve rounded up nine quotes about being a stepparent from Harris.
On Treading Carefully

â€œAs a child of divorce, I knew how hard it could be when your parents start to date other people. And I was determined not to insert myself in their lives until Doug and I had established we were in this for the long haul. Children need consistency; I didnâ€™t want to insert myself into their lives as a temporary fixture because I didnâ€™t want to disappoint them. Thereâ€™s nothing worse than disappointing a child.â€
On Becoming â€œMomalaâ€
â€œA few years later, when Doug and I got married, Cole, Ella, and I agreed that we didnâ€™t like the term â€˜stepmom.â€™ Instead they came up with the name â€˜Momala.â€™â€
On The Power Of Family
â€œMy family means everything to me. Iâ€™ve had a lot of titles over my career and vice president will be great, but â€˜Momalaâ€™ will always be the one that means the most.â€
On Her First Time Meeting Cole And Ella

â€œWhen the day finally came, I had butterflies in my stomach. The plan was to go to a seafood hut off the Pacific Coast Highway called the Reel Inn, a favorite of the kids. On my way to meet Doug, I picked up a tin of cookies and tied a ribbon in a bow around them. I took a few deep breaths. I was excited, and I was nervous. I rehearsed what I would say. Would the kids think the cookies were really nice or really weird? Was the ribbon too much?â€
On Her Relationship With Dougâ€™s Ex-Wife

â€œTo know Cole and Ella is to know that their mother Kerstin is an incredible mother. Kerstin and I hit it off ourselves and are dear friends. She and I became a duo of cheerleaders in the bleachers at Ellaâ€™s swim meets and basketball games, often to Ellaâ€™s embarrassment. We sometimes joke that our modern family is almost a little too functional.â€
On Making Blended Family Life Work

â€œOne of the keys to my relationship with Cole and Ella is their mom. We are friends. We have a very modern family ... The thing about blended families â€” if everyone approaches it in the way that thereâ€™s plenty of love to share, then it works. And we have plenty of love to share within our extended family.â€
On Her Stepkids
â€œThey are brilliant, talented, funny kids who have grown to be remarkable adults. I was already hooked on Doug, but I believe it was Cole and Ella who reeled me in.â€
On Balancing Work And Family

â€œI sought the advice of my female colleagues in the Senate. And it was Maggie Hassan, the senator from New Hampshire, who offered me some sage wisdom. â€˜Our kids love us for who we are and the sacrifices we make,â€™ she said. â€˜They get it.â€™ I believe you donâ€™t have to be a U.S. senator or a candidate for president of the United States for that to ring true. Time is precious, and so many of us understand the struggle to seek balance.â€
On Supporting All Families

â€œThatâ€™s one of the things [Joe Biden and I] have in common. My children donâ€™t call me stepmom, they call me Momala. Weâ€™re a very modern family. Their mom is a close friend of mine. ... Joe and I have a similar feeling that really is how we approach leadership: family in every version that it comes.â€

otherData.headline: Trump Blames 'Fauci And These Idiots' For His Own Coronavirus Ineptitude
otherData.short_description: â€œPeople are tired of Covid,â€ the president complained on a call with campaign staff.

articleContent: President Donald Trump on Monday lashed out at medical experts and complained about people being tired of hearing about COVID-19, as the confirmed death toll in the U.S. ticked closer to 220,000 and the spread of the disease continued to accelerate.
Trump made the comments on a call with campaign staffers, seeking to pass blame for the pandemic and seemingly lamenting his inability to shift the national conversation.
â€œPeople are tired of Covid,â€ Trump said. â€œPeople are tired of hearing Fauci and these idiots, all these idiots who got it wrong.â€
â€œEvery time he goes on television, thereâ€™s always a bomb, but thereâ€™s a bigger bomb if you fire him,â€ Trump added. â€œThis guyâ€™s a disaster.â€

The president was referring to Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nationâ€™s leading infectious disease expert and a member of the White House coronavirus task force. Trump has repeatedly sought to undermine and distort Fauciâ€™s comments as the public health expert has called for the implementation of safety protocols throughout the pandemic.
â€œIf thereâ€™s a reporter on [the call], you can have it just the way I said it, I couldnâ€™t care less,â€ Trump said.

The president returned to the theme in a series of tweets Monday afternoon, claiming Fauci â€œseems to get more airtimeâ€ than he does and contending that Fauci â€œsaid â€˜no masks & let China in.â€™â€

Early in the pandemic, Fauci didnâ€™t recommend wearing masks out of concern there wouldnâ€™t be enough for front-line workers, but he changed his tune once research showed simple homemade cloth masks worked.

Trump also criticized Fauci for wearing a Washington Nationals mask and having a â€œBad arm!â€ â€” a reference to Fauci throwing the ceremonial first pitch for the team earlier this year. (Trump has never thrown a first pitch as president, despite several invitations. In July, Trump announced â€• then said he had canceled â€• plans to throw the first pitch at Yankee Stadium, only for a source to reveal that heâ€™d never actually been invited.)
Roughly 30 minutes after Trumpâ€™s tweets, Sen. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) dismissed the presidentâ€™s claims without mentioning him by name:

Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden called out the presidentâ€™s attacks as misplaced and counterproductive. He urged Trump to instead formulate a cohesive national strategy to confront the virus.

â€œCoronavirus infections are spiking across the country, but President Trump decided to attack Dr. Fauci again today ... instead of laying out a plan to beat this virus or heeding their advice about how we can save lives and get our economy moving again,â€ the Biden campaign said in a statement Monday afternoon.

â€œThe American people have never backed down from a challenge,â€ the statement continued, â€œbut they need a leader to show the way and all President Trump has done is cower and wallow in self-pity.â€

Trumpâ€™s comments represent a doubling down on a new presidential pandemic strategy: Blame the experts.
On Sunday, Trump attempted to attack his opponent in the election by saying Biden would follow expert guidance if he were elected.

â€œHeâ€™ll listen to the scientists,â€ Trump warned at a campaign rally in Nevada. â€œIf I listened totally to the scientists, we would right now have a country that would be in a massive depression, instead of, weâ€™re like a rocket ship. Take a look at the numbers.â€

Broadly speaking, it is true that Trump has ignored established science. Evidence suggests, however, that his inaction has inflamed the pandemic and its economic repercussions, not made the situation better.

The president has steadfastly refused to endorse a national mask mandate, going so far as to block a draft order last month from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that would mandate that masks be worn on public transportation.
Scientists and medical experts consider masks to be an effective way to prevent transmission of the coronavirus and safely reopen the economy.

otherData.headline: The â€˜Boratâ€™ Sequel Is Shameless, Damning And Weirdly Humanistic
otherData.short_description: Sacha Baron Cohen resurrects his most famous character for the Trump era, with Mike Pence and Rudy Giuliani as targets in "Borat Subsequent Moviefilm."

articleContent: Another Borat movie shouldnâ€™t exist. Not because â€œBorat Subsequent Moviefilm: Delivery of Prodigious Bribe to American Regime for Make Benefit Once Glorious Nation of Kazakhstanâ€ is bad, but because Sacha Baron Cohenâ€™s infamous troublemaker seems too recognizable to pull off the same stunts he did in 2006. Back then, Borat and his boxy gray suit (or was it blue?) were anonymous enough to trick unsuspecting locals into showing how much intolerance they were willing to tolerate. The entire thing was a litmus test for participants and moviegoers alike, a study in offensive stereotypes weaponized to provoke reactions. The joke was on us, and it was too specific to repeat.
And yet here we are.

Premiering Friday on Amazon Prime Video, â€œBorat Subsequent Moviefilmâ€ resurrects its titular Kazakh journalist to confront the seismic changes the United States has undergone in the intervening years. Boratâ€™s latest mission? To deliver a gift to someone in Donald Trumpâ€™s inner circle â€” he decides itâ€™ll be â€œladiesâ€™ manâ€ Mike Pence â€” so America will consider Kazakhstan an ally. Even though Trump peddles some of the same prejudices, Borat canâ€™t present the souvenir directly to the president because of that one time he defecated outside a Trump tower. The â€œsouvenirâ€ turns out to be his 15-year-old daughter, Tutar (hilarious 24-year-old newcomer Maria Bakalova), who is trained to believe that women belong in cages and who is described as â€œtoo oldâ€ for Rudy Giuliani.

The question any Borat fan (or nonfan) wants to know is whether the sequel is funny, to which I respond in the affirmative. Baron Cohenâ€™s quick-witted fish-out-of-water humor still excels, for the most part, and at times it can feel particularly pointed given Americaâ€™s current condition. En route to a conservative convention where Pence will downplay COVID-19 concerns, Borat visits a social media influencer who touts the â€œsugar babyâ€ lifestyle, a dress saleswoman who cracks up when Borat asks where he can find the â€œâ€˜no means yesâ€™ section,â€ a cosmetic surgeon who offers to give Tutar a nose job and breast augmentation for $22,000, and a pair of macho conspiracy theorists who blame the coronavirus on Bill Clinton. The somewhat cruel tension derived from duping people who donâ€™t know theyâ€™re part of a mockumentary is still entertaining. Borat circumnavigates the fame monster by dressing incognito.

But for all of Baron Cohenâ€™s insensitive posturing, these movies contain a surprisingly humanistic through line. Entering scenarios with Americans who believe he really is just some foreign reporter with a garbled accent, Baron Cohen lets racists be racist and misogynists be misogynistic. But he also encounters a handful of folks who do nothing of the sort. In the first â€œBoratâ€ film, he found a group of Alabamans who patiently explained rudimentary restroom etiquette despite his coarse antics. In â€œSubsequent Moviefilm,â€ he meets two sweet Jewish ladies who embrace him even though he is wearing a long plastic nose and talons. When he leaves Tutar in the care of a babysitter, she shows genuine interest in the girlâ€™s wellbeing and teaches her that women have rights.

Sometimes these encouraging exchanges get lost in the â€œBoratâ€ discourse, especially given how many lawsuits arose after the original became a commercial smash. But theyâ€™re even more important this time around, partly because the everyday bigotry coursing through the film feels far less novel than it did circa 2006. Baron Cohenâ€™s jokes hinge on the idea that America does not recognize its own provincialism, but that has been the subtext of late-night quips, John Oliver gags and viral tweets for the past four years. Itâ€™s not surprising to see a crowd cheer as Borat sings off-key about how Barack Obama should go to jail. What is surprising is that Borat returns to the babysitterâ€™s home later in the movie, after COVID-19 has spread, and she still takes the time to show him compassion when she doesnâ€™t have to.

Humanism aside, we have to talk about one scene in particular: the one with Giuliani. Maybe youâ€™ve already heard about it. Late in the film, Tutar poses as a very bad television journalist who lands an interview with a very willing Giuliani. She goads him into flirting (not that it takes much effort) and eventually asks if heâ€™d like to have a drink with her in a nearby bedroom. There, she encourages him to untuck his shirt, and suddenly his hand is reaching inside his pants, until Borat bursts in and interrupts. It is a damning moment for Giuliani, who appears oblivious to his own creepiness.

That moment explains the ethos of â€œBorat Subsequent Moviefilm.â€ Baron Cohen aims higher with his targets than he did before, clearly anxious to explore Trump-era sensibilities as our prelude to the 2020 election comes to a close. His non-â€œBoratâ€ work has been spotty, but this particular iteration of his satire still has a lot to say for anyone mature enough to grasp it. Even when the material isnâ€™t as fresh and sophisticated as it was 14 years ago, thereâ€™s an ingenuity to what Baron Cohen is doing. And if nothing else, his commitment to the bit is impressive. Apparently, he spent five days in character while quarantining with the conspiracy theorists.

Comedyâ€™s drastically changed intuitions about what will pass muster are another reason a â€œBoratâ€ sequel seemed unlikely. Mainstream movies â€” the kind that once would get nationwide multiplex releases, at least â€” are now designed to be as inoffensive as possible. Yet hereâ€™s one trafficking in humor that is nakedly anti-Semitic, jingoistic, racist, homophobic and/or misogynistic. Iâ€™m shocked a major corporation was willing to back Baron Cohenâ€™s shamelessness, which can be so easily misinterpreted. Then again, COVID-19 theater closures aside, itâ€™s telling that Fox â€” the studio behind the original, since acquired by toothless Disney â€” had nothing to do with the new filmâ€™s existence. A streaming service less reliant on box-office figures picked up the torch instead. Of course.

Directed by Jason Woliner, whose credits include sitcom â€œParks and Recreationâ€ and popular Adult Swim farces, â€œBorat Subsequent Moviefilmâ€ defies a lot of what Hollywood wants from its comedies in the age of social media backlash. But what I keep coming back to is the fact that Borat does (sort of) learn how to be a better person by the sequelâ€™s end. Itâ€™s not preachy or overly contrived, nor is it wildly unique. But itâ€™s a necessary evolution for a character who is finally realizing that heâ€™s not the king of the castle.

otherData.headline: David Byrne's Scene-Stealing Dancers Break Down The Making Of 'American Utopia'
otherData.short_description: Chris Giarmo and Tendayi Kuumba on the "naturalistic" choreography, getting makeup advice from Spike Lee and singing with Mavis Staples.

articleContent: â€œDavid Byrneâ€™s American Utopiaâ€ begins with Byrne alone onstage, crooning about different parts of the human brain. Bathed in a soft blue glow, he sits at a table, barefoot, for a few minutes. Byrne first rises when another person emerges from behind the shimmering backdrop. Seconds later, someone else steps forward. They join him in song, at one point leaning on each other like conjoined twins. Together, the three of them â€” Byrne and his principal support â€” set the tone for the show, gliding across the stage with outstretched arms, their movements welcoming the audience to something both intimate and grand.

Those two dancer/singer/expressionist extraordinaires are Chris Giarmo and Tendayi Kuumba. Without them, â€œAmerican Utopiaâ€ wouldnâ€™t be what it is. The filmed version of Byrneâ€™s concert, directed by Spike Lee and newly available on HBO, makes that abundantly clear. Giarmo and Kuumba often flank Byrne, wearing cerulean eyeshadow and loud red lipstick. Leeâ€™s camera makes them part of the main attraction.

That egalitarian approach reflects the spirit of Byrneâ€™s show, which toured the world in 2018 and set up shop on Broadway in 2019. Through his solo work and with the Talking Heads, Byrne has always made music that speaks to everyday concerns. Between songs in â€œAmerican Utopia,â€ his pithy monologues address the everyday concerns of today: fascistic governments, voter turnout, television and unwanted houseguests. His singers, dancers and musicians, all of whom performed live without a backing track, are part of an interconnected whole. They arenâ€™t just a garnish meant to direct attention to the headliner.

Because Giarmo and Kuumba have such a memorable presence in â€œAmerican Utopia,â€ I spoke to the two of them via Zoom about what it was like to be part of the production, the surprising makeup advice they received from Lee and celebrity guests they spotted in the crowd.
Getting Started

Giarmo and Kuumba came to â€œAmerican Utopiaâ€ through two very different routes, but what appealed to both was Byrneâ€™s desire to address the state of the nation. Giarmo had worked with Byrne before, serving as assistant choreographer on the tour that accompanied his 2008 album â€œEverything That Happens Will Happen Today.â€ During those rehearsals, Giarmo mentioned he was the captain of his high school color-guard team, so when Byrne mounted his color-guard-esque 2016 show â€œContemporary Color,â€ he again enlisted Giarmoâ€™s help. Kuumba, on the other hand, had never met Byrne. She replaced another performer during the tour. Whatever stage the cast graced, they did so without shoes.

Giarmo: I emailed David Byrne and said, â€œI hear youâ€™re looking for backup singers that can dance. Iâ€™m free.â€ But of course that email was after working with him for 10 years on various things. He said, â€œWould you also be willing to be dance captain?â€ I said, â€œSure, letâ€™s do it.â€

Kuumba: I was coming from another tour and I got off the plane and turned my phone on and had an email from David that said, â€œHi, would you like to join my show?â€ Honestly, I had to google to say, â€œIs this real?â€ First I thought it was spam because, if you know David and his personality, which I appreciate so much, the email was written majority in all lowercase letters. Long story short, Lizzy Dement is the assistant choreographer to [lead choreographer Annie-B Parson]. We worked together on a different piece, â€œElectric Lucifer.â€ They were looking for someone that could be a vocalist and a mover. I basically had about two weeks to rearrange my whole schedule and learn all 24 songs, both for festivals and for theaters, which are very different.
Giarmo: We all just came together and figured it out. There was a lot of trust and a lot of freedom, I think, in how we put it all together initially.
Kuumba: Weâ€™re movers and dancers anyways, so Iâ€™m comfortable without shoes all the time. To me, it seems so normal. Iâ€™m like, â€œIâ€™m barefoot all the time, just as life and profession.â€

Giarmo: I would say itâ€™s maybe the first time Iâ€™ve really gotten a pedicure to make sure my feet look good. Iâ€™ve never been filmed that close-up. But Annie-B Parson, her company, Big Dance Theater, Iâ€™ve performed with them since 2005, and Iâ€™ve never worn shoes in any of those shows. Maybe for Broadway thatâ€™s weird, but itâ€™s actually kind of the norm in the dance world, generally.
They Dance Like This

The choreography is another extension of Byrneâ€™s democratic vision for the show. He wanted the movement to be naturalistic. Some of it can seem deceptively accessible, like something you or I could replicate at home. For Giarmo and Kuumba, â€œdeceptiveâ€ is the key word.

Giarmo: The thing I think youâ€™re responding to is that the kinesphere is really small. Kinesphere is what space your body takes up. A big high kick is a big kinesphere. I wonâ€™t speak for Annie-B, but I know sheâ€™s said this about dance before: Her fascination with dance is this catharsis of, â€œEveryone has a body.â€ So when we see a body onstage moving, whether or not we can do that movement in that way, we have something in us that responds to that and is like, â€œI feel that.â€ I think using pedestrian movement just means taking formal movement that seems like itâ€™s naturalistic or something that people would just do normally, like a normal gesture, but formally warping that and modifying it and making it something else, elevating it. You could look at it and say, â€œOh, I could do that.â€ Thereâ€™s something I think thatâ€™s actually welcoming and inviting.

Kuumba: I definitely came with being a mover and touring with dance companies that are rooted in very big movement. When coming into this work, I got approached many times like, â€œOh this must be a piece of cake for you.â€ Iâ€™m like, â€œYou know, you would think that.â€ I think part of that is shaped specifically from Annie-B and knowing David. It is shaped in a way so that it does look accessible because weâ€™re not the only two that are dancing. The rest of the band is moving as well, and theyâ€™re not all technically movers, as well as David. We all have to be able to complement each other.

Giarmo: As someone that has done it for so long, I would say that there are fully dances that you can do. Please, do the â€œNaÃ¯ve Melodyâ€ dance with us. Easy-peasy, itâ€™s going to be fine. I will also say if you try to do some of the other dances with us, youâ€™re going to lose your goddamn mind. Thereâ€™s some stuff that looks very easy but is really hard.

Kuumba: It lives in the body â€” how, even if something looks small, it actually can sometimes be that much more strenuous or that much more complex because the work it takes to make it look small on a big stage actually requires a lot more than you would think.

Giarmo: Even before the tour began, there was so much discussion and creative work with David just from a technological perspective. Formally, this is like something nobodyâ€™s ever seen before, but technologically, itâ€™s also that. Every single person had in-ear monitors with their own individual mix. I think there was something like 90 wireless mic channels overall. Every musician is wireless. Everything is live. The lighting is also this crazy high-tech thing. Itâ€™s a system called BlackTrax where we each have RFID sensors sewn into our suits, and so all the lights have cameras that can track them.
Finding The Politics In â€˜Utopiaâ€™

A lot of Byrneâ€™s music uses surreal imagery to address the passage of time and the way individualism haunts humanity. â€œOnce in a Lifetime,â€ arguably Talking Headsâ€™ most famous song, is about experiencing life on autopilot, while â€œI Should Watch TV,â€ a soaring rock anthem he recorded with St. Vincent, finds Byrne turning to the boob tube â€œto know what folks were thinking.â€

During â€œAmerican Utopia,â€ Byrne made the political subtext more overt (though never preachy). He points out that many of his musicians are immigrants and announces voter-registration tables in the theaterâ€™s lobby. But the most powerful moment comes toward the showâ€™s end, when Byrne and his band cover â€œHell You Talmbout,â€ a Janelle MonÃ¡e protest chant that lists the names of Black Americans killed by police violence. Byrne saw MonÃ¡e perform the song at the Womenâ€™s March on Washington in 2017 and asked her permission before including it.

Kuumba: When I first was asked to be a part of the show, seeing that David decided to do this song was the reason that I said yes. Because one, Iâ€™m a Black woman and I am consistently being aware of who I work with and why and how and in what capacity and the many ways Iâ€™m representing myself and my community and having artistic integrity. For an older white man to put this in his work when he does not have to necessarily, to not have to be accountable for these things, for him to take that choice and not only just implement it in the show, but continuously implement this from day one was the main reason why I said yes. I was like, â€œOK, I can fuck with this.â€

Giarmo: We did modify it almost everywhere we went around the world. We added names and we changed names depending on where we were, which is really unfortunate. In America, you could pretty much find an unarmed Black person that was murdered by the police in almost every place that we toured. It was a really interesting experience. We had a lot of discussions about it on the bus at the beginning when we were on the road: where it is in the show, how it works with the show. It was a really experiential process for us. On the road, it was our last encore. It was the final song.

Kuumba: I felt like with this song specifically and with Broadway, my mom had an understanding because we had some confusions when we first went to Broadway [where they performed â€œTalmboutâ€ earlier in the setlist]. Like, â€œNo, this is supposed to be the last song. When did the switch come around?â€ But as we know, itâ€™s Broadway, the Great White Way, and weâ€™re down the street from â€œLion Kingâ€ and â€œFrozen.â€ My mom was just summing it up as, â€œIt seems that heâ€™s taking this approach and is trying to bring us through to the other side of leaving with hope.â€ I think on tour it was a really wonderful way of ending it because itâ€™s very easy to get into this euphoric mindset when you go to a concert and leave feeling on cloud nine to escape your reality. Since weâ€™re living in this home on Broadway, I think you canâ€™t necessarily throw mud on everybody and walk away and come back the next day over and over again. In the realistic world that we live in, we know we have to hold hands and walk people through difficult moments. I think that David took it upon himself to find a way of how to come out on the other side with â€œOne Fine Dayâ€ and â€œRoad to Nowhere.â€ Weâ€™re still on a road to nowhere, but we can do this together.

GIarmo: Itâ€™s a really important message that a lot of his audience might not hear coming from someone that doesnâ€™t look like them. David has this privilege and opportunity to maybe reach an older, white audience that wouldnâ€™t find Janelle MonÃ¡e on their own.
Enter Spike Lee

To preserve â€œAmerican Utopia,â€ Byrne called upon Lee, who has previously filmed a Luciano Pavarotti benefit concert, â€œThe Original Kings of Comedyâ€ and the Broadway musical â€œPassing Strange.â€ Byrne told The New York Times he sought out Lee because of the directorâ€™s visual flair and willingness to confront social issues. Lee didnâ€™t merely record the show, though. He immersed himself in it so the final product would feel as dynamic as possible. (Lee had to live up to the legacy of â€œStop Making Sense,â€ the beloved Talking Heads concert film directed by the great Jonathan Demme.) So he set up overhead cameras, plotted out meticulous angles that emphasize the performersâ€™ movements and captured the show multiple times alongside cinematographer Ellen Kuras (â€œEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mindâ€). By then, the magic of the experience was evident to everyone involved.

Giarmo: I think itâ€™s always great to talk about how long things take. Spike did come and see our show 20 times before he filmed it. He is a genius, clearly, but he also saw it 20 times. Itâ€™s a lot of work.

Kuumba: Aside from him filming the live show once, we did extra shots with a limited audience and he was really trying to get these close-cut angles that he may have felt really passionate about. It felt like we were all understanding it more once we kept going through the process of the motions. There were some actual conversations of specific angles that were being caught. I know that birdâ€™s-eye-view angle is very beautiful and important, especially for â€œBurning Down the House,â€ to capture these beautiful formations that we do.

Giarmo: Spike Lee did tell me to wear red lipstick. Iâ€™d been doing a nudy pink. He said that wasnâ€™t enough. It was a really exciting surprise to get that note. He was like, â€œI need you to have fire-engine red, FDNY red, and I need the nails to match.â€ Iâ€™m a drag queen, so a matte red lip is a tricky lip, for all your readers out there that may not understand the nuances. Especially a liquid lipstick. Youâ€™ve got to make sure you have the right brand, the right finish, one thatâ€™s going to last through the show. I had to experiment for a couple performances to make sure that it was the right one.
Kuumba: You would always see his glasses peeking over the edge of the stage in the corner. Like, â€œWhat is that? Oh, Spike.â€

Giarmo: The icing on the damn cake was when Mavis Staples came and saw our show. Then after the show, she was just hanging out and started singing and a bunch of us just sang â€œSlippery Peopleâ€ with Mavis Staples.
Kuumba: Sometimes you just get surprised and you look at each other onstage like, â€œIs that who I think it is?â€ Bette Midler fucked my mind.

Giarmo: She had a turban and sunglasses. Seeing the film, I was thrilled to see all of the little tidbits, for lack of a better term, like the musical-theater cheesiness that we bring. I will say, at least for me, when I knew that Bette Midler was in the audience, I kicked that up a couple of octaves.
Kuumba: Michelle Obama came. I donâ€™t think we knew until that day, though. Youâ€™ve got to know for security reasons. Sometimes itâ€™s a really nice surprise and you just ham it up a little bit.

Giarmo: I think maybe on most Broadway shows thereâ€™s more of a fourth wall where the actors donâ€™t look [at the audience]. Weâ€™re used to these concerts where itâ€™s all about looking at people and connecting to individuals. On Broadway, we just did the same thing. Itâ€™s so funny. Youâ€™re looking into peopleâ€™s eyes and encouraging them. At first I think people were scared. Or, â€œYou can see me? What?â€ But no, youâ€™re here too. Itâ€™s cool. Come on.

Kuumba: â€œOnce in a Lifetime,â€ one moment that hit me was just from touring. I remember one show, this one kid just bawling his eyes out in the front row. It just gives such a sense of freedom onstage. Weâ€™re just shifting and moving through each otherâ€™s space, jumping and dancing with everybody in the audience. There were some really emotional moments that I captured every time we sang that song that I saw in specific audience members. And I always love to connect with other fellow Black women in the crowd that jump up and sing with me. Itâ€™s like Iâ€™m a stake in a part of this history, and it feels sweet.
These quotes have been condensed and edited for clarity.

otherData.headline: The Best Cute Essential Oil Diffusers Of 2020
otherData.short_description: If you want the benefits of a candle without the fire risk, you might consider getting an ultrasonic diffuser.Â Many double as humidifier, light up and can shut off automatically.

articleContent: HuffPost may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Prices and availability subject to change.

Fall is one of the coziest seasons because itâ€™s perfect for snuggling up with a blanket, baking treats and lighting your favorite candle. Thereâ€™s something soothing about a flickering flame and a fall scent in your space.

But what if youâ€™re not into candles or just donâ€™t trust yourself to blow them out when youâ€™re not in the room? Maybe youâ€™re not sure if you can easily keep a candle away from flammable objects, or maybe youâ€™re the parent of small kids and donâ€™t want them near the flame.
If you want the benefits of a candle without the fire risk, you might consider getting a diffuser.

There are four types of diffusers out there: ultrasonic, nebulizing, heat and evaporative. Ultrasonic diffusers are the ones you might be most familiar with. They work by turning water thatâ€™s been mixed with essential oils into vapor. Nebulizing diffusers donâ€™t use water, and instead use air to shoot the essential oils out as a mist. Evaporative diffusers, commonly known as reed diffusers, use small reed sticks to absorb the oil and emit the scent. Heat diffusers use an open flame or electricity to melt wax, similar to how melted candle wax gives off scent.
