Everyone deserves accurate information about COVID-19. Support journalism without a paywall â€” and keep it free for everyone â€” by becoming a HuffPost member today.

otherData.headline: Thousands Protest Anti-Coronavirus Restrictions In Germany Over Weekend
otherData.short_description: The marches have attracted a mixed crowd of civil rights activists and people who oppose vaccinations, as well as neo-Nazis and members of the far-right.

articleContent: BERLIN (Reuters) - Thousands of demonstrators in southern Germany protested against coronavirus restrictions over the weekend, police said on Sunday, although organizers failed to mobilize enough people for a planned human chain around Lake Constance.

Thousands of counter-demonstrators in Constance also turned out to show support for the governmentâ€™s measures to contain the coronavirus while also protesting against right-wing supporters in the other group, police said.
Overall, police counted between 10,500 and 11,000 people taking part in the different demonstrations on Saturday and the two-day protests continued on Sunday with sunny weather likely to draw in further participants, a police spokesman said.
â€œSo far, the situation is calm,â€ the police spokesman added.
Organizers of the protests against coronavirus curbs had initially hoped to mobilize more than 200,000 people.

Local authorities had imposed restrictions such as respecting social distancing to avoid further infections. They also banned the use of Germanyâ€™s imperial Reichsflagge, a symbol used by neo-Nazis and other far-right groups as an alternative to the forbidden swastika flag.

The marches have attracted a mixed crowd of civil rights activists and people who oppose vaccinations, as well as neo-Nazis and members of far-right groups including the opposition party Alternative for Germany (AfD).

During mass marches against coronavirus curbs in Berlin in late August, protesters stormed the steps of the Reichstag parliament building, some of them holding far-right Reichsflagge. The images went around the world and were condemned by leading German politicians.
Germany so far has managed the COVID-19 pandemic relatively well by keeping infections and deaths low compared to other European countries during the first wave in spring.

But infection numbers are rising again and authorities are mulling further restrictions which could limit public life and slow down the economic recovery after Germany suffered its worst recession on record in the first half of the year.
Reporting by Michael Nienaber; Editing by Raissa Kasolowsky

otherData.headline: Lawyer At White House COVID-Cluster Event Spoke Later To Group Fighting Mail-In Votes
otherData.short_description: Attorney Cleta Mitchell was photographed without a face mask at a conference days after a Rose Garden event linked to an outbreak of coronavirus infections.

articleContent: A prominent conservative attorney who attended a White House event linked to a cluster of COVID-19 infections was the featured speaker days later at a conference fighting to restrict mail-in voting.

Cleta Mitchell, a partner in the politically connected law firm Foley & Lardner, was photographed without a face mask and failing to social distance at both the Sept. 26 White House event celebrating the Supreme Court nomination of Amy Coney Barrett and the FreedomWorks â€œElection Protection Summitâ€ that began on Friday with a reception.

At the Rose Garden event, Mitchell sat in the row behind former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and was seen with White House counselor Kellyanne Conway. Both have since tested positive for the coronavirus. Mitchell also was photographed near Attorney General William Barr, who has gone into self-quarantine.

Still, Mitchell attended the weekend FreedomWorks conference in Washington and was a key speaker. She told HuffPost that she first heard that Conway and Christie had tested positive as the conference was winding down on Saturday. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advises people exposed to COVID-19 to isolate themselves for 14 days. FreedomWorks did not respond to HuffPostâ€™s requests for comment.

Events like the Rose Garden celebration and the FreedomWorks conference threaten to extend the reach of the coronavirus as it spreads through the upper reaches of the GOP, sickening President Donald Trump, members of his administration and at least three senators. Mitchellâ€™s connection to both events was first reported by Wisconsin watchdog group Documented, which probes corporate influence on public policy.

At least 17 people who either attended the White House event or were in contact with guests have since been diagnosed with the coronavirus. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nationâ€™s top infectious disease expert, on Monday called the Rose Garden ceremony the kind of â€œdangerous situationâ€ medical officials have long warned could become a COVID-19 superspreader event.
Mitchell is not the only person at the White House event who later attended another major gathering.

Trump attended a fundraiser at his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, on Thursday, even after knowing his close aide Hope Hicks had tested positive. Early the next morning he announced that he and the first lady had also tested positive.

Wisconsin GOP Sen. Ron Johnson took a COVID test on the way to a fundraising event in his state on Friday and said he found out later it was positive. Johnson wasnâ€™t at the Rose Garden event, but took the test after learning that fellow Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah) tested positive after attending the Barrett celebration.

Mitchell has played a prominent role in President Donald Trumpâ€™s battle to suppress voting by mail. No one was â€œbeing cavalier about COVID-19,â€ at the Rose Garden event, Mitchell told The Bakersfield Californian last week.

Photos and videos of the FreedomWorks Election Protection Summit showed few attendees following face mask and social distancing health guidelines. Right-wing radio host Sebastian Gorka, who also spoke at the event, posed maskless for photos with his arms around participants. FreedomWorks said about 80 people attended.

Mitchell told HuffPost that she thought she wore a mask at the conference, except during her speech and while eating. The photo below, from a video of the reception, shows her without a mask, near other maskless attendees.

On Monday, Mitchell participated in a FreedomWorks remote group press conference that also included Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) and Rep. Andy Biggs (R-Ariz.). She attacked voting by mail and â€œthe left,â€ and suggested that if the president can get COVID-19, anyone can.
â€œFrankly, we have to live our lives and go on with business ... people are going to get COVID, as we see,â€ she said. The coronavirus has killed more than 210,000 people in the U.S.
FreedomWorks, a partisan nonprofit working against Democratic nominee Joe Biden, hosted the summit to organize activists against mail-in ballots.

otherData.headline: It's OK To Be A 'Good Enough' Parent Right Now
otherData.short_description: As the pandemic wears on, being adequate is more than enough.

articleContent: During a Zoom class meeting last week, my 5-year-old â€” who was inexplicably stringing dried mango on a strand of dental floss and dangling it in front of the laptop camera â€” leaned back in his chair, flipped it and hit his head. While I got him resituated, my toddler emptied all of our toothbrushes and a box of Q-tips into the toilet. I screamed, we all cried and I parenting-shame spiraled in a way I havenâ€™t since the pandemic was in its infancy and I still cared about things like screen time or whether everyone in my home is wearing pants.

Iâ€™m being such a crappy parent right now, I told myself after the Zoom/Q-tip debacle. My older kid is comically bad at remote learning. My toddler is basically feral. I feel so depleted, all the time, and I know Iâ€™m not giving anyone â€” my kids, my husband, my boss, my friends â€” anything close to what Iâ€™d like.
So now, with the new school year in full swing, I am on a new quest: learning to be truly OK with being an adequate (at best) parent.

As the pandemic moves into what feels like its 167th month â€” and as parents have begun to really settle into an academic year unlike any other â€” now more than ever is the time for grace. We parents must cut ourselves slack, mental health experts say, and embrace the fact that being adequate is more than enough. We donâ€™t have sufficient help. We donâ€™t have enough time. More than 50 million parents have lost income during the COVID-19 pandemic, millions of parents have left their jobs because itâ€™s their â€œbestâ€ option and parental burnout is rampant. And who knows how long this is going to continue?

But developing self-compassion is surprisingly hard, particularly because it goes against so much of what weâ€™ve been conditioned to expect of ourselves in this competitive, social media-saturated era of parenting. In my less secure moments, Iâ€™m certain there are scores of other parents who have figured out this whole parenting-during-COVID thing in a way I cannot.

So I spoke with a person who literally wrote the book on the topic â€” psychologist Claire Nicogossian, a clinical assistant professor at Brown University and author of â€œMama, You Are Enough: How to Create Calm, Joy and Confidence Within the Chaos of Motherhoodâ€ â€” about how parents can really, truly learn to be OK with simply being OK right now.
1: Remind yourself that we are still in survival mode.

Parents are all dealing with varying degrees of crisis: Some of us have no child care, weâ€™ve lost jobs and our kids have no school. Others of us have help, our kids are decently settled into whatever school situation theyâ€™ve got and weâ€™re not confronting personal health or financial crises. Itâ€™s still hard, all of it. Together, we are all in survival mode.

Nicogossian often uses this metaphor in therapy: If you were swimming in an ocean and knew there were sharks all around you, you wouldnâ€™t pause and ask yourself: Am I good swimmer? Am I doing this right? Youâ€™d put your head down and swim. Youâ€™d do what you needed to stay safe â€” and thatâ€™s it.
Itâ€™s a good metaphor to have in mind in those moments when you find yourself spiraling, worried youâ€™re failing to live up to your typical expectations in these truly insane times.
2: Examine your standards
Nicogossian then recommends spending some time thinking about where those typical expectations of yourself as a parent actually come from.

â€œThatâ€™s super varied and variable, because none of us have the same experiences,â€ Nicogossian said. So carve out the time to think on it a bit. Like: Huh, why do I think XYZ is what should happen? Why do I think my family should be doing this particular thing? Personally, I realize Iâ€™m susceptible to self-doubt when I engage too much with local parenting forums. No matter what I read about, it always seems to end with me questioning the extent to which Iâ€™m being a horrible, neglectful parent by sending him into school two days a week.

With a bit of digging, you might realize some of those standards and expectations are things you truly do not care about. Think about ways to cut down on some of the noise. Like unfollowing. Or not engaging in conversations about pandemic parenting with people who just donâ€™t get how challenging it can be.
3: Keep a time log

Nicogossianâ€™s final suggestion? For a few days, jot down how much one-on-one time youâ€™ve given your kiddo â€” time when you have not been multitasking or barking at them to stick with remote learning or cleaning... or whatever.

If you feel like maybe you could carve out five minutes a day to really give them that undivided attention, try it, Nicogossian urged. It could go a long way in helping you really make peace with being a good-enough parent right now â€” and could give kids, whoâ€™ve really been dealt a tough hand, the care and attention theyâ€™re craving.
Then pat yourself on the back. Youâ€™ve fed them, kept them safe (to the best of your ability during a completely bonkers time) and even managed to hang out with them a bit. Adequate, indeed.

Experts are still learning about COVID-19. The information in this story is what was known or available as of publication, but guidance can change as scientists discover more about the virus. Please check the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the most updated recommendations.

otherData.headline: Amy Schumer Loses It When Her Son Says 'Dad' For The Very First Time
otherData.short_description: â€œThis video was clearly a surprise to us,â€ the actor and comedian captioned the funny clip.

articleContent: Amy Schumer shared everything with fans throughout her pregnancy with her first child, Gene, and sheâ€™s continued to share major milestones along the way.
Over the weekend, Schumer posted the sweetest video that shows her trying to get her little one to say â€œDadâ€ for the first time for husband Chris Fischer.
When Gene actually does say â€œDad,â€ the comedian â€• and everyone else in the video â€• loses it and freaks out.
Even Gene, who goes from smiles to tears in no time at all:
â€œThis video was clearly a surprise to us,â€ the actor captioned the clip. â€œGetting to experience these first moments with my son makes me feel so lucky.â€
All of Schumerâ€™s celeb friends praised the sweet video.
â€œBest video ever,â€ actor Krysten Ritter wrote, while fellow actor Beanie Feldstein reacted with â€œMY HEART.â€
Schumerâ€™s former co-star Goldie Hawn added, â€œHeâ€™s gorgeous.â€
The comedian also added a call to action on her Instagram, asking fans that watched the video and read the caption to also â€œgoogle DJ Henry.â€
Danroy â€œD.J.â€ Henry was a Black Pace University student who was shot to death by a white police officer in 2010. The grand jury involved later declined to bring charges against the cop.
Recently, Henryâ€™s death received renewed attention after celebrities called on U.S. Attorney General William Barr to reopen the case.
Schumer also added a call to action for her followers when she posted a clip of Gene saying â€œMomâ€ for the first time last month.
â€œThe world is burning but this was a nice moment,â€ she wrote. â€œPlease make a voting plan and make sure everyone in your phone has a voting plan supermajority.com can help.â€

otherData.headline: Timeâ€™s Most Influential Indigenous Activist: â€˜Capitalism Destroys The Whole Planetâ€™
otherData.short_description: Nemonte Nenquimo, lauded by Leonardo DiCaprio for her work protecting Ecuador's Amazon, speaks about her life, activism and motherhood.

articleContent: Nemonte Nenquimo wore a bright crown of blue, yellow and red macaw feathers that, for the Waorani people of Ecuador, represent the power of women in the forest. But her suntanned face looked tired.

It had been a whirlwind 48 hours since Time magazine named the 35-year-old Indigenous activist one of its 100 most influential people of 2020. Peering into her computer screen, she smiled and said this was her 26th media appearance, discussing her fight to protect 180,000 acres of virgin forest in northeast Ecuador from drilling, mining and logging.

The spotlight is uncomfortable for Nenquimo. Indigenous people, she said, arenâ€™t used to individual appearances; they always lead collectively. Their decisions and opinions are communal. Yet now she finds herself on the global stage representing not just her people, but all Indigenous peoples fighting deforestation, genocide and destruction around the world.

Nenquimo, whose first name means â€œconstellation,â€ was born into a tribe where both women and men serve as warriors. Her grandfather was a leader who defended what is now known as YasunÃ­ National Park, one of the most biodiverse rainforests on Earth.
HuffPost spoke to Nenquimo in Spanish about her activism. This interview, translated into English, has been edited and condensed for clarity.
How did you learn that Time was including you on its annual list?

I was working for the Coordinating Council of the Waorani Nation of Pastaza (Conconawep), which I lead. Iâ€™d been planning to have volunteers provide lectures in the territory because, during the pandemic, education has been abandoned, as thereâ€™s no internet or phone lines available for online learning. We were making plans, coordinating meetings, then I suddenly received the call.

It made me feel that it was recognition for those who are already dead, but also for those who are alive and fighting. I felt very encouraged, I felt strengthened to continue fighting. We have lived free and happy. We donâ€™t want any more contamination or death from disease. Our message is that capitalism destroys the whole planet; it contaminates, it extracts. They donâ€™t realize that they are leaving nothing for future generations. We, the Indigenous people, know that we have to be the keepers, and we have always done it.
How have Ecuadorâ€™s Indigenous communities fared in the pandemic?

When the pandemic arrived, the Ecuadorian government didnâ€™t respect the communities where the Waorani people live and didnâ€™t stop the oil activities. This was the first time COVID-19 was transmitted and spread to other communities because, in Waorani culture, we are collective and collaborative. This caused the spread [of COVID-19].

Men were sick, they were unable to go out hunting, they stayed in their hammocks shivering. Women were shaking in the hammocks with the children in their arms; they couldnâ€™t go out to look for cassava, food; it was very difficult, very hard. But with the knowledge of the plants, they began to heal. Most of the grandparents were saved. As a leader, I was worried. I said, â€œnobody goes in and nobody goes out into the jungle,â€ but the virus came.

I went to seek help, support from other organizations, because the Ministry of Public Health didnâ€™t have that priority. In that attempt to help my people, I became infected and sick. I lost my sense of smell, I couldnâ€™t taste, and I lost my memory. I was ill for about 14 days. I went into the jungle for eight days and came back healthy. Now my concern is the consequences of the disease.
What has been the most frustrating moment of your work so far?

The pandemic. It was something new. I had never felt weak or sick before, but I felt that I was going to die. I was breathless, had a high fever and chest pain. My throat felt swollen. I had to face the possibility of dying and not knowing who my daughter would stay with. It shattered me.
You have said that you began to fight for the Waorani future with strength and rage. What was your awakening?

When I was a child, my father used to tell me that my grandfather had a lot of love for the forest. That love was transmitted to me. The jungle has given me freedom, strength. I was shocked when I saw with my own eyes the impact of the oil companies on the territory of the CofÃ¡n and Siona brothers, and I listened to their testimonies. They didnâ€™t know the consequences of the oil spills in the rivers; they bathed in that black water without knowing how that would affect them. I know of cases of children dying from it.

That gave me the courage to protect the 180,000 virgin acres that we have in the Waorani community of Pastaza. We donâ€™t want a reoccurrence of the story that the northern brothers experienced.
The actor Leonardo DiCaprio nominated you for the Time list. How did you two connect?

Before becoming a leader, I founded the organization Ceibo Alliance with Indigenous people in Lago Agrio (in northern Ecuadorâ€™s Amazon), where the first contact with the oil company Chevron happened. â€¦ I was working on the creation of rainwater systems, solar panels, exchange of experiences, and made connections with other organizations that came to work in Lago Agrio. In 2017, DiCaprio invited me to a presentation by his foundation. I traveled to San Francisco, California, and I met him personally. Heâ€™s a good man, he has a good heart, and he supports us even through distance.

Iâ€™ve seen how the monster of oil extraction has come to destroy life. Leo and I have talked about how the government does not respect our right to life, there is no support, what we do is for the life of our children. I hope that soon, heâ€™ll come to visit the territory we preserve.
Without government support, who finances the struggle for the forest?

Small conservation groups have helped our organization raise money. Now we are looking for alternative ways to provide programs in the territory that focus on education and leadership. We will continue to look for resources to make alternative, sustainable economies. Most of the time, we donâ€™t ask the government for help; when I do, they ignore us.
Has this struggle involved risks in your life?

Capitalism always wants to devour, to devastate. If we go out to defend our life, our home, it is a very dangerous risk. They realize that we go out to protect, and they can kill, discriminate. My family is very big. My grandfather had three wives, 20 children. In the territory, we are a large majority. Iâ€™m not the only one. Iâ€™m not afraid of dying. If I die, itâ€™s for the sake of the future.
Have you been threatened?
I havenâ€™t been threatened. But itâ€™s a fact that women who protest have been annihilated all over the world.
How has the forest changed since you were a child? What will it be like when your daughter is an adult?

I donâ€™t think anything has changed. Recently, Iâ€™ve seen only one change: There was a lot of rising water that has concerned me because itâ€™s a consequence of climate change, of logging, of the imbalance of the planet. There are also very high temperatures in the Amazon, and thatâ€™s also linked to deforestation.

If we keep fighting collectively, the Earth will remain as such, full of animals, fish. If we donâ€™t protect it, the forces of capitalism will come in and destroy us. The jungle will disappear.

otherData.headline: 'SNL' Perfectly Parodies 'The Drew Barrymore Show' With Dig At Ellen
otherData.short_description: Stop sleeping on Chloe Fineman, the master impressionist of "Saturday Night Live."

articleContent: Sure, Jim Carreyâ€™s Joe Biden might top the headlines from the â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ premiere over the weekend, but please stop sleeping on the showâ€™s master impressionist, Chloe Fineman.
Sandwiched in between the season openerâ€™s many political sketches was a pitch-perfect parody promo of the recently launched and endearingly chaotic â€œThe Drew Barrymore Show.â€

Fineman assumed the role of actor-turned-talk show host (â€œIâ€™m just like you, a boho free spirit mommy mother movie star since I was 6!â€) lovingly capturing Barrymoreâ€™s essence and side-of-mouth-style of speaking.
And given the tumult in the daytime television landscape as of late, â€œSNLâ€ couldnâ€™t help but address the workplace misconduct allegations leveled against Barrymoreâ€™s competitor.
â€œThere is a new face in daytime,â€ a voiceover announces during the promo. â€œAfter seeing what went down with Ellen, we took a hard turn in the other direction.â€

Finemanâ€™s Barrymore is basically the anti-Ellen, carpet bombing her â€œempty studioâ€ with joy, referring to her audience as â€œmy beautiful wildflowersâ€ and doing her best not to pull in her masked cameraman for a hug.
â€œDonâ€™t worry about her being mean to the crew,â€ the voiceover adds. â€œThey say she maintains eye contact too long and is too emotionally supportive.â€
But Fineman doesnâ€™t just imitate Barrymore, she truly outdoes herself by bringing out her fine-tuned impressions of Nicole Kidman and Reese Witherspoon as guests on the fake talk show.
And in case youâ€™re wondering how the real Drew Barrymore might feel about the sketch, she gave the â€œSNLâ€ star her stamp of approval.

â€³@nbcsnl and @chloeiscrazy is the greatest thing,â€ Barrymore wrote on Instagram Sunday morning, alongside photos of herself watching the premiere. â€œI have loved SNL for as long as i know, and to also have the @thedrewbarrymoreshow brought to the party is so fun. Honored to be apart of it.â€
To stream NBCU shows featured in this piece sign up to Peacock

otherData.headline: MyPillow Guy Mike Lindell Shouts Out Unproven COVID-19 'Cure' To Trump
otherData.short_description: The Trump-loving executive guaranteed oleandrin was "100% effective," though there's no public coronavirus test data on humans or animals.

articleContent: MyPillow Guy Mike Lindell, dubbed a â€œsnake oil salesmanâ€ by CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper for pushing the unproven plant extract oleandrin as a coronavirus cure, appears to be at it again.
The bedding company executive on Friday urged his pal Donald Trump to take oleandrin after the president announced he and first lady Melania Trump tested positive for COVID-19.
â€œIt does work,â€ Lindell wrote on Twitter to the president. â€œ100% effective!â€
Lindell, a Trump backer who owns a stake in a company promoting oleandrin as a coronavirus cure, was seconding a tweet from conservative author David J. Harris Jr. urging Trump to try it.

Lindell, who thanked God that Trump got elected in a White House speech back in March, promoted oleandrin during a White House meeting with Trump in July. Thereâ€™s no public data that oleandrin, an extract from the toxic oleander plant, has ever been tested in humans or animals against COVID-19.

The businessman, who talks to sleepless potential customers behind a mirror in one of his MyPillow ads, is on the board of oleandrin developer Phoenix Biotechnology.

â€œHow do you sleep at night?â€ Cooper asked Lindell on CNN in August.

Lindell said Trump expressed enthusiasm for oleandrin during their July meeting. The president told CBS News in August: â€œWeâ€™ll look at it.â€

But unlike hydroxychloroquine, an unproven malaria drug the president pressured the Food and Drug Administration into approving as a coronavirus treatment, Trump hasnâ€™t publicly touted oleandrin.

otherData.headline: 17 GOP Congressmen Vote No On Resolution Condemning QAnon
otherData.short_description: Jewish groups expressed anger at those who voted against the resolution that strongly denounces the far-right, anti-Semitic conspiracy movement.

articleContent: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed a resolution Friday condemning the far-right conspiracy movement QAnon, yet 17 white Republican men and one independent voted no on the measure, demonstrating the sway of the movement â€” which the FBI considers a potential domestic terrorism threat â€” over a significant portion of the GOP.
The resolution, which passed by a vote of 371-18, was introduced in August by Rep. Tom Malinowski (D-N.J.) and Rep. Denver Riggleman (R-Va.) in response to an alarming rise in QAnonâ€™s popularity.

It â€œcondemns QAnon and rejects the conspiracy theories it promotes,â€ encourages federal law enforcement agencies to focus on the movement and calls on intelligence agencies to investigate â€œany foreign support, assistance or online amplification QAnon receives.â€

The text of the resolution amounts to a withering takedown of the QAnon phenomenon, which is an ever-evolving collection of pro-Donald Trump conspiracy theories based on cryptic clues posted to message boards by an anonymous poster known as â€œQâ€ who claims to be a senior government official with inside knowledge of a globalist cabal of Satan-worshipping pedophiles waging war against the president.
The resolution lists some of the crimes committed by QAnon believers:

According to BuzzFeed, Malinowski himself received death threats this week after â€œQâ€ named him in a post Tuesday. The post from Q mentioned the resolution and parroted a false accusation made by the National Republican Campaign Committee that Malinowski has â€œlobbied to protect sexual predators.â€

Despite the obvious danger the QAnon movement poses, 17 Republicans still decided to vote no on the resolution, which simply asserts the opinion of the House and does not have the effect of law. Here are their names:

Rep. Jodey Arrington (R-Texas)

Rep. Brian Babin (R-Texas)

Rep. Rob Bishop (R-Utah)

Rep. Mo Brooks (R-Ala.)

Rep. Michael Burgess (R-Texas)

Rep. Buddy Carter (R-Ga.)

Rep. Warren Davidson (R-Ohio)

Rep. Jeff Duncan (R-S.C.)

Rep. Drew Ferguson (R-Ga.)

Rep. Bill Flores (R-Texas)

Rep. Paul Gosar (R-Ariz.)

Rep. Mike Kelly (R-Pa.)

Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa)

Rep. Ralph Norman (R-S.C.)

Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.)

Rep. Tom Tiffany (R-Wis.)

Rep. Daniel Webster (R-Fla.)

Rep. Justin Amash, a Michigan independent who left the Republican Party in July 2019, also voted against the resolution. He defended his vote in a tweet, stating that the â€œresolution threatens protected speech (absurd as that speech may be).â€
QAnon is a deeply anti-Semitic conspiracy theory, and Jewish groups on Friday expressed anger over the Republican congressmenâ€™s no votes.

Emily Mayer, political director of IfNotNow, a progressive Jewish American activist group, told HuffPost in a statement that the congressmen had taken â€œanother step in mainstreaming QAnon,â€ which she called â€œthe same set of age-old, anti-Semitic tropes that have been used against Jews for hundreds of years, just repackaged for the 21st Century.â€
â€œThe conspiracy theory is, at its core, a modern-day blood libel,â€ Mayer said.

Many QAnon followers believe, absurdly, that prominent Democrats and other elites are harvesting abducted childrenâ€™s blood in order to conduct Satanic rituals, mirroring â€œblood libelâ€ conspiracies that have historically targeted Jews.

Stosh Cotler, CEO of Bend the Arc: Jewish Action, told HuffPost in a statement that it was â€œastounding that 17 House Republicans voted against condemning a fundamentally anti-Semitic conspiracy theory just days after President Trump refused to condemn a white supremacist group on the national debate stage.â€

Cotler noted that QAnon believers often promote conspiracy theories about â€œshadowy global puppet mastersâ€ that â€œhave been used to stir up fear and violence against Jewish people for centuries â€• including the Tree of Life massacre in 2018.â€
The congressmenâ€™s actions, Cotler added, â€œwill only make Jewish Americans and other communities targeted by white nationalism less safe.â€
Many in the GOP have often condoned those who follow QAnon or are believers themselves.

In August, a QAnon believer named Marjorie Taylor Greene won a Republican congressional primary, earning praise from Trump, who called her a â€œfuture Republican Star.â€ (Greene is expected to win in the general election next month.)

Alex Kaplan, a senior researcher at the liberal watchdog group Media Matters, has counted 81 current or former for congressional candidates who say they are QAnon believers, along with 23 for current or former state legislative candidates.
Gosar, one of the GOP congressmen who voted no on the resolution Friday, has promoted QAnon-related conspiracies in the past.
Yet as widespread as the conspiracy theory is among the Republican Party, those who study the QAnon phenomenon were still relieved Friday to see that the resolution had at least passed.
â€œItâ€™s absurd that QAnon has grown to the point that such a resolution is even necessary,â€ said Travis View, who researches conspiracy theories and hosts the â€œQAnon Anonymousâ€ podcast.
â€œBut the resolution does articulate the very real damage and dangers of the conspiracy theory-driven movement, so itâ€™s good to see it has bipartisan, if not unanimous, support.â€

otherData.headline: Fed Up With Politics, She Left The U.S. 20 Years Ago. Has Anything Changed?
otherData.short_description: When the Supreme Court handed George W. Bush the White House, Jennifer Berdahl knew democracy was broken.

articleContent: Twenty years ago, Jennifer Berdahl was on the tenure track at the University of California-Berkeley when she lost faith in the democratic process in the United States.

Back then, the presidential election was too close to call. Floridaâ€™s vote was in question. Talk of hanging chads was inescapable. George W. Bush had a slight edge, Al Gore wanted a recount. The case Bush v. Gore made its way to the Supreme Court. And, along strictly partisan lines, the courtâ€™s five Republican-appointees stopped the recount and handed the election to Bush.

â€œThat was the point at which I felt that the government was fundamentally broken,â€ recalls Berdahl, whose work focuses on the intersection of gender and power. She and her husband, also an academic, snagged positions at the University of Toronto and moved with their young daughter on July 4, 2001.

Now, teams of lawyers for President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden are gearing up for another bruising fight. Trump has already said he believes the election will wind up at the court, and has fast-tracked a nomination to further cement a conservative majority. The scenario could end up â€œa wilder sequel to Bush v. Gore,â€ Paul Blumenthal wrote in HuffPost.

Berdahl, now 53-years-old with dual citizenship and teaching at the University of British Columbia, will be watching from home in Vancouver. HuffPost called her to check in on her decision to leave the country.
What was it that disturbed you back in 2000?
The Supreme Court basically prevented democracy from being carried out. It effectively chose our president for us.

I lost faith in the court. I remember eighth-grade civics class, learning about the three branches of the government: You vote for your congressional representative, if you donâ€™t like what theyâ€™re doing you can vote them out. You vote for your president, if you donâ€™t like what theyâ€™re doing, you can vote them out.

The Supreme Court is not supposed to be political. Itâ€™s supposed to interpret the laws. Of course people get appointed to the court and lean one way or the other. The idea was they were interpreting the laws in good faith, according to the Constitution.

When they stopped Floridaâ€™s recount and effectively said your votes donâ€™t matter, thereâ€™s no recourse. We canâ€™t replace [the justices]. We canâ€™t vote them out. They are lifetime appointments. They are acting as a political body and they are intervening in political processes.
That was the point at which I felt that the government was fundamentally broken.

At the time I didnâ€™t appreciate how racialized that was. I just knew votes werenâ€™t counted. Turns out, a disproportionate amount of the votes that were not counted were votes by Black people. That is the history of our country, trying to disenfranchise Black voters.
Maybe it opened your eyes to what Black Americans have long dealt with.

I guess you can call me a naive white girl who was like, it works, itâ€™s fair. Up until that point. To some degree. I knew there was voter suppression. I had volunteered in Illinois in graduate school at the polls. My role was to observe. The neighborhood was mostly white. A white person would show up and say their name, maybe show one piece of ID. Theyâ€™d be given a ballot and theyâ€™d go vote. A Black person would show up and they were asked for multiple pieces of ID. They were asked what their profession was. They were basically subjected to an inquisition.

So I knew already there were attempts to suppress certain peopleâ€™s votes. But usually they ended up voting. I reported it to the party. I just didnâ€™t think you could throw out thousands of ballots like the Supreme Court did.
Was Bush the president you wanted?
He wasnâ€™t. I wouldâ€™ve accepted him as president if the recount had shown that he had won by a democratic process.
Have you been watching U.S. politics since you left?

I try to minimize it because itâ€™s just so depressing and predictable at this point. Tuesday nightâ€™s debate was really depressing. It confirmed our choice. [Google searches for â€œhow to apply for Canadian citizenshipâ€ also peaked that night.]
Did you watch the Trump election in 2016?

Oh yeah, we had the bowls of popcorn ready. We were with our daughters, our young teenage daughters, ready to watch the first woman get elected president. We just thought it was a no-brainer. She had the majority vote.
So, right now people are afraid of Bush v. Gore happening again.
I think thatâ€™s a very realistic fear.
Seems like you did the right thing.

Iâ€™m really glad I did. I remember when I was little and youâ€™d read things about people in other countries somewhere far away. And it would be like those people are crazy, what are they doing? Now the U.S. seems that way. Itâ€™s like what is the U.S. doing? How could it possibly be doing these things.

The U.S. used to hold a lot of esteem in the world and it just doesnâ€™t anymore. Itâ€™s almost like people feel pity for the U.S. People are worried for the U.S. Itâ€™s like this sad dying experiment that everyone is seeing as a tragedy. That makes me really sad.
What would you say to someone now whoâ€™s looking at the election and thinking they should follow in your footsteps?
I feel torn. On the one hand, I totally get it. And sure, people are welcome. Come to Canada. It might be best for your family. Thatâ€™s what I concluded.

But I donâ€™t think ultimately itâ€™s going to solve the problem. The kind of challenges weâ€™re facing like climate change, these are global, collective problems that weâ€™re going to have to fight somehow in unison. If everybody progressive evacuates the U.S. I donâ€™t know what that would look like.
I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s really the answer. I do think we need to try to fight if we can. Definitely vote. Iâ€™m still voting.
Do you regret leaving the U.S.?

No. I am so glad that Iâ€™ve had the cross-cultural experience. That my children and my spouse and I have both citizenships and options. Thereâ€™s lots of talk in my broader family that is American about leaving.
With COVID-19, you guys did better up there than weâ€™re doing.

In Canada, thereâ€™s just a lot more trust and faith in government. I donâ€™t think weâ€™ve gotten to the point where the U.S. has gotten where we just donâ€™t trust the government. Everything is political in the U.S.
In Canada thereâ€™s still faith in science and scientists. The health minister, who is empowered in each province, is leading the response and calling the shots. They are medical experts.
It would be like putting Dr. Anthony Fauci in charge of the U.S. response completely. And empowering him.
Are there things you gained by leaving the U.S.?

Thereâ€™s a lot. One of the first things you notice is universal health care. That completely changes the game. The worth of human life has been elevated for everyone in a country where itâ€™s seen as a human right to get health care. Thereâ€™s no question that you will get it. Itâ€™s a collective effort in making that happen. Itâ€™s not an individual problem that you have a heart attack that you have to then pay for. Even a homeless person has health care. That changes the whole sort of feeling of humanity and togetherness and compassion. Thereâ€™s kindness in the culture.
Another one, of course relatedly, is guns. You donâ€™t worry about sending your kids to school and thinking theyâ€™ll be shot up.

Education is really different. There is a much stronger commitment to public education. All the universities are public. That also changes things. Instead of having this extreme hierarchy of universities, Ivy League or bust, theyâ€™re all good. Maybe none is as good as the very top 10 in the U.S., but none of them are really bad either. Thereâ€™s excellence in all of them. And theyâ€™re affordable. The students that Iâ€™ve had [in Canada] are every bit as good as the students I had at Berkeley.
Thatâ€™s so much more egalitarian.
Yeah. Itâ€™s much more egalitarian.
This interview has been edited for length and clarity.

otherData.headline: 'Emily in Paris' Is As Boring And Basic As A Sponsored Instagram Story
otherData.short_description: Netflixâ€™s new series aims for cosmopolitan fantasy but doesnâ€™t quite hit the mark.

articleContent: Wanna get away (from 2020, from the country, from the universe)? Who doesnâ€™t. For fans of frothy romantic comedies and fashion eye candy, Netflix has the perfectly timed autumn offering: â€œEmily in Paris,â€ an aptly named series featuring the holy union of creator Darren Starr and costume consultant Patricia Field. The show offers an escape into a world of power clashing and intoxicating love triangles at a time when many of us sorely need it.

Emily (Lily Collins) is a rising associate at a Chicago marketing firm. Her boss Madeline (Kate Walsh), a worldly and sexually adventurous single woman who speaks fluent French, is on the cusp of realizing her lifelong dream of moving to Paris for a year. Madeline will be overseeing the merger between their firm and a French one they have recently acquired.

Instead, Madeline pukes in a wastebasket. Yes, she is unexpectedly pregnant, and now Emily will be going to Paris in her stead. Emily doesnâ€™t speak French, and she has a solid boyfriend in Chicago. But she informs him that theyâ€™ll be long-distance for a year and jets off to France without a backward glance. Once there, she joins the team at Savoir, the French firm she must integrate into her Chicago companyâ€™s workflow, begins snapping selfies of herself eating pastries, and befriends the sexy chef, Gabriel (Lucas Bravo), who lives below her.

At Savoir, all is not quite well. Her new colleagues see her as provincial and frumpy, both obnoxiously work-obsessed and a professional liability. Her boss, Sylvie (Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu), is an older Frenchwoman, naturally glamorous and sophisticated, and she sees Emily as nothing but an annoyance. On the other hand, Emily seems to win male admirers wherever she goes â€• clients, random men at cafÃ©s, and, of course, the sexy chef. She also quickly makes friends with women she encounters on the street â€• Mindy (Ashley Park), a Chinese expat and nanny who has been disinherited by her zipper tycoon father, and Camille (Camille Razat), a stunning blonde gallerist. Together they drink wine at cafÃ©s, exchange naughty gossip about love interests, and attend glittering high-fashion events.

This, of course, feels like a dispatch from another universe. The picture-perfect trip to Paris, complete with dark lipstick, beret-topped ensembles and spontaneous affaires with French semiotics professors, has never been more out of reach for the basic â€• sorry, ringarde â€• American woman. Travel restrictions, mask requirements, social distancing, and residence in a country rapidly sliding into authoritarian decline all conspire to make a carefree day spent wandering along the Seine with a croissant seem almost unimaginable.

But does this make â€œEmily in Parisâ€ awkwardly out of step with the current moment, or the ideal escapist confection? Emma Gray and Claire Fallon sat down to discuss whether the Lily Collins vehicle offers a refreshing taste of frivolity in a hellish time, or whether itâ€™s as flat as day-old Champagne.
The Bottom Line
â€œEmily in Parisâ€ is no â€œSex and the City.â€ It has all of its predecessorâ€™s frivolousness and capitalism, and none of its heart.
The Rundown

Claire: An American girl in Paris â€• what could be a more seductive premise for a glossy, CW-style dramedy? The women of American TV all want to be in Paris, but they rarely seem to get there. Thereâ€™s Lauren Conrad, the girl who didnâ€™t go to Paris; thereâ€™s Rachel Green, the girl who didnâ€™t get on the plane (to Paris). Thereâ€™s Carrie Bradshaw, the girl who moved to Paris and was promptly chewed up and spat all the way back to New York. All of those women stayed in America at least in part for a boyfriend, though Carrie at least made an effort to actually make it in France (for a different boyfriend).
That was then. Itâ€™s 2020, and weâ€™ve made an enormous step forward: Emily actually moves to Paris, leaving her boyfriend behind in Chicago, and tries to make it there without him.

Emma, Emily is put forward as our American feminist heroine. In fact, like you, she is outspoken about sexism in the media, has shiny dark hair and enviable eyebrows (I mean, itâ€™s Lily Collins), and always has the perfect matte lip and statement jacket for any occasion. Did you identify with her? Is Emily a protagonist you could get behind?

Emma: First of all, there has never been a greater compliment than â€œenviable eyebrows.â€ And I agree that Lily Collins has some great ones, so I will take it. Unfortunately, other than her A+ grooming and delightfully fantastical styling, there was very little about Emily that struck me as heroic or feminist. Truly, I should be the target audience for this show and for Emily as a character. Iâ€™m a middle-class white woman in her early 30s who grew up absolutely obsessed with â€œSex and the City.â€ But despite my eternal problematic fave-ing of â€œSATCâ€ and the much-maligned Carrie Bradshaw, I couldnâ€™t help but wonderâ€¦ Is Emily the most grating protagonist on television?

Whereas Carrie Bradshaw was single and in her 30s when we meet her, and thus had spent more than a decade honing her (still questionable) professional talents and forming a close-knit group of women friends, Emily is a plucky white heroine who has very little work experience, very little experience being an independent person, and very few real obstacles set in front of her that make her worth rooting for. But despite these privileges, she walks around as though she is the authority on life, love and work. Mostly, I was annoyed. And I couldnâ€™t tell if it was because of the sub-par acting or the sub-par character development or maybe just a combo of both. I also viscerally resented that every hot man she encountered on a Paris street fell in love with her, despite the fact that she had incredibly awkward energy and spoke no French.
Claire, were you as disappointed by Emily as I was? And if so, how do you think she fits into the canon of romantic comedy protagonists?

Claire: â€œEmily in Parisâ€ is a bland title, so it came as no particular surprise that Emily herself is a bland character. Sheâ€™s slender and so beautiful that itâ€™s quite believable when, in one episode, a fashion executive mistakes her for a movie star. The show doesnâ€™t even make an effort to quirk her up or give her a more relatable, girl-next-door roughness: sheâ€™s always immaculately coiffed and made-up, and garbed in effortfully eye-catching outfits. But thereâ€™s not much to the character, except for enormous amounts of self-confidence and the inexplicable ability to attract new friends and love interests on every street corner. Collins seems to be powering through her performance on sheer enthusiasm, delivering her lines and reactions with gusto if not much finesse. Combined with the characterâ€™s clearly intentional (but still irritating) American-style narcissism, the result is a bit exhausting. Whenever Sylvie told Emily to leave her alone, I found myself silently agreeing.

In classic fish-out-of-water fashion, of course, Emily is meant to be changed by Paris. In one early episode, she tells a fellow account executive at Savoir, Luc, that heâ€™s arrogant for criticizing American culture. â€œYou came to Paris and you donâ€™t speak French,â€ he retorts. â€œThat is arrogant.â€ But in her new job at Savoir, she goes from success to success â€• largely because of her unique American takes on things. She stresses social media gimmicks, which strike the Parisians as tacky, and is never hesitant to call her colleagues out on their sexism.

In a rather half-hearted nod to the #MeToo movement â€• and its French counterpart, #BalanceTonPorc (expose your pig) â€• Emily brings a fragrance ad shoot to a crashing halt in order to explain that women in her demographic will find the concept offensive. Though her insights are ultimately rejected, they draw the attention, both professional and perhaps romantic, of the handsome perfumier, Antoine (William Abadie), who is married and having a longstanding affair with Emilyâ€™s boss, Sylvie. (Meanwhile, Emily mostly laughs off truly inappropriate behavior in and out of the workplace, including an incident in which she sleeps with a boy who turns out to be 17.)

In another episode, Emily accidentally markets a feminine hygiene product by tweeting her outrage that the French word for â€œvaginaâ€ is a masculine noun; we even see the back of Brigitte Macronâ€™s head as she retweets it approvingly. Itâ€™s a version of feminism that feels extremely 2015: at its heart, itâ€™s just another way to sell stuff.
Emma, what did you think of the depiction of Emilyâ€™s marketing career and Savoir? Advertising is obviously a foundational theme of the show.

Emma: Look, Iâ€™m no marketing executive, so the people can feel free to tell me if Iâ€™m wrong, but I suspect that the way Savoir is depicted in the show is not quite reflective of what a career in marketing and advertising looks like in real life. Emily struts into Savoir as if all a masterâ€™s in marketing in the United States leaves you with is the ability to enthusiastically say â€œSocial media! Social strategy!â€ over and over again until your product goes viral.

The show felt like people trying to engage with the weirdness of current influencer culture and marketing, but just not really nailing it. The whole game of influencer marketing is subtlety â€• like, if you scrolled by an ad in someoneâ€™s feed, it would take you a minute to realize it was an ad. This is what makes influencer advertising both so effective and so insidious. But nothing in â€œEmily in Parisâ€ is subtle. Especially not her work. If I took the show at face value I would believe that a high-end designer could craft an entire collection in 10 hours by himself, that influencers go to events and film full advertisements mid-lunch, that an Instagram account blows up if you post 5 mediocre selfies paired with bad hashtag puns, and that sexual harassment is just par for the (hilarious!) course in French firms.

I also want to talk about the way watching this show felt in a moment when we, as Americans, are quite literally banned from France. It certainly impacted the escapism of the project for me. How did you feel watching it?
Claire: Itâ€™s a masterâ€™s in communications, Emma. Look, sheâ€™s qualified.

To be candid, I donâ€™t know that it did affect the escapism for me. A picturesque French getaway is out of reach for most American viewers at any time, especially one featuring so much couture and Champagne, and while Iâ€™ve been fortunate enough to visit Paris for a few days, my experience bore no resemblance to Emilyâ€™s. The show is more like a Disney ride than an actual trip abroad: a highly Americanized, sanitized, buffed-and-shined product that signifies â€œParisâ€ to its audience through the deployment of famous buildings and clichÃ©d accessories (croissants, baguettes, berets). It really is as if the whole city is a pop-up installation designed for influencers, much like the Museum of Ice Cream or the luxury beds Emily has placed underneath Parisian landmarks for an Instagram campaign for one of Savoirâ€™s clients.

In that sense â€• maybe Iâ€™m giving the show too much credit â€• it does seem to capture that influencing life. The whole series is a testament to how American capitalist culture grinds up beauty, pleasure, and art and transforms them all into product. Everything is monetizable, and monetizability is everything. As Emily tells Luc, who is explaining the French philosophy of prioritizing life above work, â€œI enjoy work and accomplishment. It makes me happy!â€ Yuck! Imagine a less relatable sentiment right now.

But speaking of Luc, letâ€™s talk about Emilyâ€™s supporting cast. In addition to her Savoir frenemies and the hot chef downstairs, Emily befriends two random women on the street â€• Mindy, a spunky Chinese zipper heiress and nanny who dreams of being a singer, and Camille, a gorgeous and sweet-natured gallerist who turns out to be Hot Chefâ€™s girlfriend. Any standout characters or performances for you, Emma?
Emma: I think you hit the nail on the head with the showâ€™s meta-commentary on the absolute emptiness of American capitalism. However, Iâ€™m not sure that commentary was intentional.

In terms of standout characters, I have to shout out to my girl Sylvie, Emilyâ€™s very French, very over it boss who has the appropriate level of disdain for Emilyâ€™s endless pluckiness and attitude of American exceptionalism. Maybe itâ€™s the sexy accents, but the French actors charmed me far more than the American ones did, in general. Truthfully, I would far rather watch a show about Sylvie, a 40-something, unmarried, professional powerhouse, than about Emily, a 20-something who continuously fails up and has zero problems finding a partner other than the fact that too many men adore her. (But Gabriel, the Hot Chef, is indeed very hot.) Throughout the season, we see Emily struggle with trying to assert her value within the French marketing firm and try to fit in within Parisian society. But Emily is the consummate try hard. Her outfits, her work ideas, even her very sentences are hyper-calculated. Itâ€™s no wonder that Sylvie is dismissive and annoyed when she sees her lover/client Antoine, a married French perfumier, mooning over Emily and her trÃ©s ringard ideas.

Maybe thatâ€™s part of why this show made me annoyed rather than vacantly delighted. Because, truthfully, Iâ€™m no snob when it comes to TV. I love me some screen-based candy and I love clothing and I love aspirational travel. But maybe I donâ€™t like being so acutely aware that that is what Iâ€™m consuming? Or I want that candy to go down seamlessly rather than sticking in my throat? Or maybe itâ€™s just the contrast between the casually oblivious American in Paris setup that the show portrays at a time when itâ€™s never felt clearer just how dangerous American self-importance is?

While I was watching â€œEmily In Paris,â€ I kept thinking about the Latin phrase, â€œpanem et circenses,â€ or bread and circuses, referring to a steady diet of entertainment meant to keep the poor, oppressed masses docile. Little does Emily know that sheâ€™s mere months away from being in a months-long quarantine.
Any final thoughts, Claire?

Claire: Watching the whole show wasnâ€™t exactly a punishment, but it was hard to ignore the many ways it fell short. The performances, across the board, are broad and stilted. The depiction of Paris is cartoonish. Mindyâ€™s storyline, about reclaiming her dreams of singing stardom, is given too little space to develop and feels shoehorned in. And Emilyâ€™s repeated rhapsodies on the value of marketing made me want to sell all my possessions and move somewhere with no Netflix access.
So, Should You Watch It?

Emma: Look. Desperate COVID-19/election year times call for desperate measures. Like watching â€œEmily in Paris.â€ If you need something watchable but fairly bad, go for it. If not, feel free to skip.

Claire: â€œEmily in Parisâ€ is lucky that we arenâ€™t likely to see a new episode of â€œThe Bold Typeâ€ any time soon. There isnâ€™t the usual profusion of new TV right now. Still, if youâ€™re on the fence, Iâ€™d recommend going with a â€œSex and the Cityâ€ rerun instead.

otherData.headline: 8 Problems You May Encounter Going To Vote In The Election
otherData.short_description: Here's what you need to know if you're dropping off your ballot at a polling location or voting in-person in the 2020 presidential election.

articleContent: Voting is going to look a little different this year, thanks to the coronavirus.

The number of Americans voting by mail is expected to double compared to 2016 amid worries of COVID-19 transmission at the polls. (For what itâ€™s worth, in early July, Zeke Emanuel, a bioethicist and former Obama administration health adviser, said that voting in person during the coronavirus pandemic is about as safe as going to the grocery store.)

But other voters â€• both Democrats and Republicans â€• are reluctant to cast their ballots by mail, their doubts fueled by President Donald Trumpâ€™s baseless claims that mail-in voting will lead to a â€œriggedâ€ election and by some Democratsâ€™ accusations that the newly installed postmaster general, Louis DeJoy, is plotting to sabotage the vote in favor of Trump.
The stakes are high. If youâ€™re voting in person on Nov. 3 â€” or early, your best bet to avoid crowds â€• youâ€™re very likely concerned about making sure your vote is counted.

What should you do if you have to wait in line for hours to vote, like people did during Georgiaâ€™s primary election in June? What if the voting machines donâ€™t work or poll workers give you incorrect information about casting your ballot?
Youâ€™ve got questions, weâ€™ve got answers.
Below, voting rights experts share eight problems you could encounter as voting gets underway and what to do to ensure your voting experience is as hiccup-free as possible.
What if I go to my polling location and they say Iâ€™m not registered there?

Avoid this issue altogether by making sure youâ€™ve registered to vote at vote.org. While youâ€™re at it, double-check that your address is correct. Do all of this prior to your stateâ€™s voter registration deadline. (For many states, that is Oct. 5.)

You should also double-check your precinct location prior to voting, especially since COVID-19 may force some precincts to close or relocate, according to Cecilia Aguilera, a counsel at the Fair Elections Center, a national, nonpartisan voting rights and election reform organization.
If youâ€™re voting early, this is going to be less of an issue for you.
â€œMany states that offer early voting allow voters to vote at any early voting center so that they donâ€™t need to worry about voting at the wrong precinct,â€ Aguilera said.
In many states, a photo ID is required to vote, so be sure to check your stateâ€™s voter ID laws here before hitting the polls.

You can cast a provisional ballot if you vote at the wrong location on Election Day in most states. But given the many complications that can arise with provisional votes, requesting a provisional ballot should always be your last resort, said Leigh Chapman, the voting rights program director at the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights.
â€œIf you vote with a provisional ballot, follow up with your local elections office to make sure that you provide the additional information to make sure your vote is counted,â€ she said.
If you have any issues voting by mail or in person on or before Election Day, call the nonpartisan voter protection hotline at 1-866-OUR-VOTE. (1-866-687-8683).
What if a polling place opens late or closes early, claims to have run out of ballots, or the machines break down?
If you encounter any issues like this, contact the nonpartisan voter protection hotline immediately at 1-866-OUR-VOTE.

â€œAs a general rule, if a voter is in line at the time her polling place closes, they have a right to vote,â€ said Michelle Kanter Cohen, a senior counsel at the Fair Elections Center. â€œOtherwise, this is another area where early voting can help avoid issues. In the rare chance that an early voting site opens late, closes early, or runs out of ballots, thus preventing the voter from casting a ballot, they can return on another early voting day.â€
What if I have to stand in line for hours to cast my vote?
Again, you can do your part to minimize lines now, weeks before Election Day, by voting early, whether you decide to vote in person or by mail.
Still, if you are stuck in line on Election Day, bring a snack and stay in line!

â€œAs long as you are in line before the polls close and stay in line, you have the right to cast a ballot, even if thatâ€™s after the time the polls are scheduled to close,â€ said Molly McGrath, a voting rights campaign strategist at the American Civil Liberties Union.
For those with disabilities worried about lines, many states have laws that allow voters with mobility issues or physical disabilities to move to the front of the line, according to Aguilera.

â€œIf someone has concerns about long lines, though, they should contact their local election officials ahead of time to determine their options,â€ she said. â€œThey may be able to find out when the volume of voters tends to be lowest, and about other options like early voting or curbside voting. If a voter is in line by closing time, she has a right to vote.â€
What if a poll worker challenges my eligibility to vote?

This is extremely rare. If youâ€™re not able to prove your eligibility but believe you properly registered, you have the right to cast a provisional ballot, which will count once election officials determine your registration and eligibility. Generally, you should be fine if you verify your voting status, your address and your voting place.

If youâ€™re worried, you can bring your voter registration card and a document proving you live at the address listed on your registration, Kanter Cohen suggests. If youâ€™re challenged, â€œcall the election protection hotline,â€ preferably before leaving your polling place, she advised.
What if Iâ€™m disabled and my polling place hasnâ€™t provided adequate assistance?

One in five people eligible to vote has a disability. The Americans with Disabilities Act, or ADA, requires that voter registration and voting be accessible to people with disabilities and that poll workers assist voters with disabilities if they need help.

â€œItâ€™s worth noting that voters with disabilities are allowed to bring in the person of their choice to assist them at the polls (so long as that person is not their employer or an agent of their employer or an agent or officer of their union),â€ said McGrath. â€œThey can also request reasonable accommodations from poll workers.â€
For more information on fair access to voting, contact the National Disability Rights Network-affiliated organization in your state.
â€œEvery state, jurisdiction and polling place [is] different, so this type of personalized assistance is going to be the most effective,â€ Chapman said.
What if I encounter a poll-watcher who seems to be trying to intimidate voters?
A poll watcher is a person appointed to observe the conduct of an election on behalf of a candidate, a political party or the proponents or opponents of a measure.

But poll watchers are not supposed to interfere in the voting process, aside from reporting issues to polling place authorities and party officials. Anyone who tries to â€œintimidate, threaten, or coerceâ€ individuals to interfere with their right to vote can face up to a year in prison under federal law against voter intimidation.

Tell a poll worker if you feel intimidated and report the incident to your local election officials, whose offices will be open on Election Day. Also, call the nonpartisan voter protection hotline at 1-866-OUR-VOTE.
What if Iâ€™m told I canâ€™t cast my absentee ballot in person and should have mailed it?

Chapman said that in most states, vote-by-mail ballots donâ€™t always have to be mailed back. They can also be dropped off at a dropbox, at an early voting location, or at an in-person voting location on Election Day. To find a list of local election offices, you can search your state board of elections website or your stateâ€™s secretary of state website.
What if I make a mistake on my ballot?
Given how different this election will be logistically, itâ€™s important to carefully read the instructions that come with your ballot prior to marking it.

Many jurisdictions have a â€œcureâ€ process wherein they contact a voter if their signature or ID is missing, does not match, or if there are other reasons for rejecting the ballot package, Aguilera said.
But be your own fact-checker first.

Before submitting a ballot, voters should â€œdouble- and triple-check that they have properly enclosed their ballots in any secrecy envelopes accompanying their ballot, sealed all envelopes, provided all of the required information, signed everywhere that they need to, and depending on their state, that they have a witness signature if itâ€™s required there,â€ she said.
If you make a mistake or have any questions, you can call and ask your local election official for a replacement ballot.

â€œWe are strongly encouraging all voters who plan to vote by mail to request their mail-in ballots now (if required by state law) and complete and submit their ballots as soon as they receive them so that they are received on time and any issues can be addressed before Election Day,â€ Aguilera said.
For more information on how to vote, head over to our TurboVote module.

otherData.headline: Jason Alexander Reveals The Violent Backlash He Got For Starring In â€˜Pretty Womanâ€™
otherData.short_description: â€œWomen hated me,â€ the "Seinfeld" star revealed.

articleContent: Jason Alexander is famous for his beloved character George Costanza on â€œSeinfeld,â€ but the actor is also well-known (and despised) for his role as lawyer Philip Stuckey in the iconic 1990 film â€œPretty Woman.â€

The actor was candid about the effect the role had on his life â€• and why the film was originally a lot different than how it turned out â€• during an appearance on the podcast â€œAt Home With The Creative Coalitionâ€ with CEO Robin Bronk.
â€œIt was an odd way to meet a national audience because I was known around the world as the asshole that tried to rape Julia Roberts,â€ he said on the episode, which dropped Tuesday.

â€œAnd so women hated me,â€ Alexander explained. â€œI would walk down the street and women would say mean things to me. I got punched many times, I got spit on by one woman â€• it was a rough year.â€

The â€œSeinfeldâ€ alum also said that the film was actually supposed to be much different and much darker than the final product.
â€œWhat many people donâ€™t know is â€˜Pretty Womanâ€™ the script and â€˜Pretty Womanâ€™ the movie are similar, but theyâ€™re far from identical,â€ Alexander revealed on the podcast.

â€œâ€˜Pretty Womanâ€™ the script was a pretty dark affair. It was more of a dramedy than a rom-com. And [director Garry Marshall] was executing a lot of that film out of his head and encouraging people to create moments that werenâ€™t there and feelings that werenâ€™t there,â€ Alexander added.

â€œAnd I got onto the set the first day â€• and it was a scene with Richard [Gere] â€• and Richard had said to me in the makeup room, â€œGet ready, cause I donâ€™t know what film weâ€™re making here.â€

Alexander said he had a rough time going into filming because director Garry Marshall didnâ€™t originally want him for the role.

â€œI had auditioned for him. He was very sweet, and he basically said, â€˜Youâ€™re too young, youâ€™re too baby-faced, youâ€™re too little,â€™ Alexander said, explaining that Marshall wanted other actors but â€œcouldnâ€™t make a dealâ€ with any of them.

Luckily, casting director Dianne Crittenden was keen on Alexander getting the role and repeatedly stuck her neck out for him.

â€œShe kept bringing me up and bringing me up to the point where Garry said, â€˜If you say his name again Iâ€™m gonna fire you.â€™ And I got the part because they couldnâ€™t make a deal with the actor they wanted and they were desperate â€• the movie already started shooting â€• and they didnâ€™t have this character.â€

Marshall came around quickly on the first day of filming, Alexander said, and the rest is history.

Julia Roberts has spoken about the filmâ€™s original gritty ending before, back when it was called â€œ3,000â€ instead of â€œPretty Woman.â€

In the first iteration, Roberts told Variety, her character Vivian Ward was thrown out of a car in the end and a man â€œthrew the money on top of her, as memory serves, and just drove away leaving her in some dirty alley.â€

â€œThank god it fell apart,â€ she said.

otherData.headline: How TV Networks Are Combating COVID-19 Production Setbacks This Fall
otherData.short_description: Pre-existing series like "One Day at a Time" and "L.A.'s Finest" are getting a prime-time chance as broadcast networks attempt to fill their schedules.

articleContent: When â€œL.A.â€™s Finestâ€ was dropped by NBC ahead of the 2018-19 season, it came as a shock. The â€œBad Boysâ€ offshoot featured two women of color â€• Gabrielle Union and Jessica Alba â€• leading a cop drama, something that was desperately missing from broadcast TV. And with movie stars as headliners, the Sony Pictures TV project, whose pilot reportedly cost around $12 million, had been a shoo-in for a primetime spot.

But Sony refused to give up on the show, which eventually became the flagship series for original content on Spectrum, a channel available exclusively to subscribers of cable provider Spectrum on-demand and ad-free.
â€œL.A.â€™s Finestâ€ arrived in May 2019 and earned 3 million viewers for its first 13 episodes. Shortly after, it was greenlighted for Season 2, which debuted on Spectrum earlier this month.

â€œWe were originally an NBC pilot, but we got to rework the show for the Spectrum audience and live in a little more of a streaming world, which opened up the possibilities for stories for us to tell beyond the standard network cop procedural,â€ creator Brandon Margolis told HuffPost during an interview this month.

For Margolis and co-creator Brandon Sonnier, that switch in tone comes very much in handy now as, amid coronavirus shutdowns and production delays, â€œL.A.â€™s Finestâ€ has been picked up by Fox as a way to fill some Fall 2020 schedule space. The female-led cop drama has the chance to grab a new network audience when it airs Monday nights ahead of the Kim Cattrall-fronted pilot series â€œFilthy Rich.â€

Interestingly enough, this isnâ€™t a one-off thing. A few of the major networks have acquired pre-released series as a way to expand their lineups. CBS is airing the fourth season of the Netflix-turned-Pop series â€œOne Day at a Time,â€ as well as Spectrumâ€™s anthology series â€œManhunt: Deadly Gamesâ€ and Season 1 of CBS All Access series â€œStar Trek: Discovery.â€ And The CW picked up CBS All Accessâ€™ psychological thriller â€œTell Me a Storyâ€ and DC Universeâ€™s â€œSwamp Thing.â€
Most of these shows have enough episodes banked to hold over at-home audiences while productions kick back into gear and new content rolls out.

â€œI certainly would imagine that having two seasonsâ€™ worth of episodes already produced, that can fill up an entire seasonâ€™s worth of airtime, was a big upswing for Fox in their decision to pick [â€˜L.A.â€˜s Finestâ€™] up,â€ Margolis said, with Sonnier noting how ecstatic they are that unaware viewers will now get to see their work.

â€œThe Spectrum subscriber base came through for us and gave us the kind of viewership and numbers that said this could be successful on a larger platform with more eyeballs,â€ Sonnier said. â€œItâ€™s so gratifying to now put it out there and let people experience the show who havenâ€™t had the opportunity to do that.â€

Fellow picked-up series â€œOne Day at a Timeâ€ has faced its fair share of ups and downs, as well. The critically acclaimed reboot of the classic Norman Lear sitcom â€• which follows a Latino family helmed by single mom and veteran Penelope Alvarez (Justina Machado) â€• was canceled by Netflix in 2019 after three seasons. Then, thankfully, it was saved by Viacomâ€™s â€œSchittâ€™s Creekâ€ network Pop TV amid outcry from fans. Now, it will air its latest six episodes on CBS beginning Oct. 5 as part of Viacomâ€™s overall purchase of the series. (Viacom owns both Pop TV and CBS).

â€œItâ€™s a great opportunity,â€ co-showrunner Gloria CalderÃ³n Kellett told HuffPost. â€œI think itâ€™s very smart for [networks] to go ahead and say, â€˜You know what? Letâ€™s partner and letâ€™s give some of these shows a shot at more eyeballs.â€™ Itâ€™s kind of making lemonade out of lemons and we are the bearers of the benefits of that. We just hope that that means that itâ€™ll give us a shot at continuing to make the show.â€

Both â€œOne Day at a Timeâ€ and â€œL.A.â€™s Finestâ€ have yet to be renewed by their primary networks, so a prime-time jolt to viewership might be the key to future seasons. If all goes well enough, Kellett, Margolis and Sonnier could even see the potential of CBS and Fox personally renewing their series.

â€œHopefully, we will do well on CBS and they will pick us up, and we can start our writersâ€™ room back up and get back to it so that we can shoot in the new year,â€ Kellett, who produces â€œOne Day at a Timeâ€ with co-creator Mike Royce, said.
Margolis and Sonnier have similar aspirations.

â€œYouâ€™re always hopeful that your show gets to life beyond the one episode you produce if you get to do a pilot or the one half-season if you get to a 13 order,â€ Sonnier said. â€œAnd here we are sitting on two seasons ready to roll out and we are absolutely hopeful that there will be the possibility of telling the story for as long as people are willing to give it a shot and and experience it with us.â€

The pressure is on in other ways, as well, as both series feature characters and storylines that are underrepresented on network television. Multi-camera comedy â€œOne Day at a Timeâ€ follows a Cuban-American family as they grapple with racism, immigration laws, LGBTQ issues, post-traumatic stress disorder and veteran care. According to Kellett, it is the only Latino family show that will be on broadcast this fall. And â€œL.A.â€™s Finestâ€ takes the police procedural and flips it on its head with two women who are just as skilled and complicated as any of their male counterparts.

â€œAs a white man who is writing a show about two women of color, authenticity to these characters is incredibly important to myself and to my partner Brandon,â€ Margolis said. â€œWe need people who can represent different points of view than what we bring. If we want that show to really feel authentic and be real it starts with our leads. Theyâ€™re very thoughtful about the things that their characters would say and do. And we have a great dynamic with them where they trust us to tell compelling stories and we trust them to bring the grounded authenticity to the character. It allows us to write these characters in an honest way and know that everybodyâ€™s intention is to make the most authentic experience possible.â€

Actors Alba and Union have spoken about their collaboration with Margolis and Sonnier, and the diverse crew that brings dynamic storylines to life. Union, however, does recognize that cop shows need to have â€œmore accurate portrayals between the police and marginalized communities.â€

â€œWe all have a lot of work to do if weâ€™re going to tell truthful stories because, as it is right now, our show is pure fantasy, itâ€™s pure escapism,â€ she told Meghan McCain on â€œThe Viewâ€ earlier this month. â€œIt is not rooted in the reality that weâ€™re seeing every day on the news.â€
For Kellett, she hopes â€œOne Day at a Timeâ€ can act as a microcosm for whatâ€™s happening in the country right now.

â€œWeâ€™re doing the work of trying to set straight the community out there in terms of knowing who we are as as Latino Americans in this country,â€ Kellett said. â€œThis is also a family that has three different generations â€• a young liberal (Isabella Gomez), a moderate of middle age (Machado) and a very traditional, conservative grandmother (Rita Moreno) â€• all living under one roof, all having difficult conversations, but doing so in a loving manner and trying to find ways to coexist peacefully. So weâ€™re hoping that it can be something that provides a little bit of laughter and joy to America.â€
If audiences flock toward network reruns of these picked-up series this fall, perhaps weâ€™ll get to see some more honest storytelling in 2021.
CORRECTION: This article previously misstated that â€œL.A.â€™s Finestâ€ follows â€œFilthy Richâ€; it airs before â€œFilthy Rich.â€

otherData.headline: Has The Pandemic Turned You Into A 'Shouty' Parent? You're Not Alone.
otherData.short_description: With the stresses of Covid-19, it's even harder to keep your cool. But give yourself a break â€“ youâ€™re parenting through a pandemic.

articleContent: Are you a â€˜shouty parentâ€™? If youâ€™re anything like me, the honest answer is... sometimes. I try my hardest not to be, but Iâ€™ll confess, I do end up shouting up the stairs to get my childrenâ€™s attention.
Itâ€™s mostly when Iâ€™ve asked them five or six times to put their shoes on for school, or brush their teeth â€“ or to tell them again that dinner is ready.

I always regret it, and I resolve at the end of every day to be a better parent the next morning. But itâ€™s been harder during the pandemic to keep my cool all the time. Like everybody else, Iâ€™m at the end of my rope â€“ particularly after six months of trying to work from home while homeschooling.

Iâ€™m not alone, either. Social media is awash with distraught parents confessing theyâ€™ve found themselves losing their temper with their kids (and wishing they hadnâ€™t). Itâ€™s also full of people witnessing parents shouting, and feeling bad for both the kids and the grown-ups.
â€œI wonder if itâ€™s a sign of stress due to the pandemic,â€ one dad tweeted. â€œIâ€™ve noticed parents shouting at their kids a lot more when Iâ€™m out with mine.â€

Nanny and maternity nurse, Louenna Hood, who runs Nanny Louenna, told HuffPost UK being confined to the house for long periods of time with no breaks â€“ as weâ€™ve all experienced during lockdown â€“ definitely makes tensions rise. â€œWhen you canâ€™t see an end in sight to something, your anxieties rise and ultimately make you less tolerant and more likely to shout,â€ she said.

While itâ€™s natural to feel guilty for shouting afterwards, she said whatâ€™s important is recognizing when weâ€™re feeling like this and working on ways to â€œstay calm and see the bigger picture.â€
So, what can parents and care givers do to keep their cool? Hood gave us her tips.
Take a deep breath.

â€œSometimes, just giving yourself two breaths before reacting can avoid a rash shouty reply,â€ Hood recommended. â€œWhen things get stressful, say to yourself â€˜will this matter in a yearâ€™s time?â€™ If the answer is no, thereâ€™s no point stressing.â€
Reset the day.
â€œIf everything seems too much and your children are running around or arguing, explain in a nice way that everyone â€• the whole family â€• is having some time out,â€ she said.

â€œEveryone can go to their own area and do something quietly for 20 minutes. Whether this is playing alone in their bedroom, or sitting on the sofa with a book. Having a moment of calm will help your feeling of being overwhelmed,â€ Hood added.
Go for a walk.
â€œBeing outside and in the fresh air can really clear your head,â€ said Hood. â€œChildren have the freedom to run and shout without the confinement of the house which allows them to let off steam.â€
Leave yourself plenty of time to get to places.
â€œThereâ€™s nothing more stressful than being late and trying to get children organized!â€ she said.
Keep children informed.

â€œTell your kids about plans for the day so they arenâ€™t surprised or unprepared for whatâ€™s going to happen,â€ added Hood. â€œSaying, â€˜In half an hour, weâ€™re going to go to XYZ, so if you need the loo or to pack anything then nowâ€™s the time to get ready,â€™ is much better than â€˜hurry up, weâ€™re late and weâ€™re meant to be at XYZ, quick get ready!â€™â€
But of course, as we know, itâ€™s near impossible to stay calm all the time. Give yourself a break â€“ after all youâ€™re parenting through a pandemic.

otherData.headline: What Marie Kondo Has To Say About Tidying In The Age Of WFH
