otherData.headline: Trump DOJ Calls Out D.C.'s Democratic Mayor For Ignoring Protesters' Constitutional Rights
otherData.short_description: D.C.'s top prosecutor told Muriel Bowser that police didn't have probable cause for mass arrests, and that "guilt by association" doesn't warrant felony charges.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• Attorney General William Barrâ€™s Justice Department is calling out D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser (D) â€• who had a massive â€œBlack Lives Matterâ€ mural painted on a street near the White House that she renamed to honor the movement for Black lives â€• for blowing off the constitutional rights of anti-racist protesters in her own city.

This story begins on the evening of Aug. 13, when a group of protesters was being trailed by police officers in the Adams Morgan neighborhood of the nationâ€™s capital. After some people damaged property, D.C. Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) officers encircled a large number of protesters â€• maybe one-third of the overall group â€• in a â€œkettle,â€ detaining them for hours as they processed the arrests.

Protesters on the scene didnâ€™t understand why officers swept them up, deployed pepper spray and shoved them. Police released very little information justifying an aggressive response that swept up so many people. A MPD press release showed images of a Starbucks umbrella and newspaper boxes that had been set ablaze, but didnâ€™t explain why police kettled protesters, a tactic that has often been found unconstitutional.

Dozens of people were seized and held overnight. MPD wanted 42 of them charged with felonies under a rioting statute. But MPD officers didnâ€™t identify the individuals actually responsible for property damage. Instead, they just sought to bring felony charges against most of those theyâ€™d trapped in their kettle.

In the nationâ€™s capital, the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office â€• currently headed by a Trump administration official Barr appointed â€• prosecutes both federal and serious local crimes. Prosecutors in the office evaluated MPDâ€™s arrest reports and determined that nearly every one lacked probable cause. The office essentially determined that the rioting arrests, based on the information presented by MPD, were not justified.

Absent a lawsuit against the city by the people who were arrested, that likely wouldâ€™ve been the end of the story. But in an Aug. 31 letter to Acting U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia Michael Sherwin, Bowser wrote that she was â€œdismayedâ€ that prosecutors in his office â€œdeclined to prosecute 41 of the 42 rioting arrestsâ€ that were made on Aug. 13 and 14.

It was a strange position for the mayor to take, but one that highlights the tension nationwide between anti-racist activists and protesters and the primarily Democratic mayors that preside over their cities.

Bowser, a Black female Democrat in an overwhelmingly Democratic city, renamed a part of 16th Street NW â€œBlack Lives Matter Plazaâ€ in defiance of Trump and spoke out against the federal governmentâ€™s response to protests on the cityâ€™s streets. Yet here she was, accusing the Trump administrationâ€™s Justice Department â€• which has enthusiastically seized any opportunity to prosecute left-leaning rioters since protests broke out after the death of George Floyd in May â€• of going soft on protesters who were indiscriminately seized by her own police force.

So instead of quietly fading away, Bowserâ€™s letter set off a new round of media coverage and allowed Sherwin to criticize Bowser â€• quite credibly â€• of brushing aside the protections guaranteed in the U.S. Constitution because she wanted to see â€œriotersâ€ locked up. Bowserâ€™s office did not respond to a request for comment.

â€œAs I am sure you are aware, without some evidence to establish probable cause of a particular arresteeâ€™s criminal conduct â€• e.g. police officerâ€™s observations or video footage of the alleged crime â€• we cannot bring federal charges,â€ Sherwin wrote. â€œSurely, by your comments, you are not suggesting that this Office skirt constitutional protections and due process.â€

Sherwin went on to say that â€œMPDâ€™s arresting documents lacked sufficient probable cause to support any criminal charge,â€ publicly airing an embarrassing MPD failure that likely wouldâ€™ve stayed mostly quiet were it not for Bowserâ€™s letter. Sherwin also wrote that he met with MPD leadership to help develop the cases and â€œestablish a bare minimum of probable causeâ€ but said â€œno sufficient evidenceâ€ had materialized to justify the arrests of Aug. 13 and 14.

â€œThe â€˜42 riotersâ€™ were arrested as a collective by MPD and presented to the Office without any articulable facts linking criminal conduct to each individual arrested,â€ he wrote. â€œSimply put, we cannot charge crimes on the basis of mere presence or guilt by association.â€

Sherwin said the pattern repeated itself when MPD arrested 19 people for rioting over the weekend, but officers â€œfailed to provide the bare minimum of articulable facts linking the charged persons with alleged individual criminal conduct.â€ Due to MPDâ€™s lack of evidence, just one individual was charged.
Sherwin also seemed to hint at the irony of Bowser laying into the federal response to protesters in D.C. even as her own police force engaged in what looked like unconstitutional conduct.

â€œYour recent portrayal fo the federal response to violence in the District as insufficiently vigorous seems to contrast sharply with your earlier criticism of the federal response in the District as overly aggressive,â€ Sherwin wrote.

Thereâ€™s one huge factor looming over the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Officeâ€™s decision-making process: Its near-total failure to secure convictions against hundreds of defendants swept up in a police kettle during demonstrations and rioting surrounding President Donald Trumpâ€™s inauguration on Jan. 20, 2017.

The government took an extremely aggressive posture in the â€œJ20â€ cases, pursuing felony rioting conspiracy charges against defendants who they never alleged actually destroyed any property or committed any acts of violence.

In an admission that sheds some light on Bowserâ€™s current push for prosecutions, a former government prosecutor told HuffPost that Bowserâ€™s office was advocating for charges against the J20 protesters as well.

In tweets sent the day of Trumpâ€™s inauguration, Bowser wrote that she could â€œnot condone crime and vandalism which are the antithesis of what we hope to accomplish todayâ€ and said that they would not allow visitors to â€œdestroy our neighborhoods.â€ She tweeted that she supported MPD â€œas they have handled crowds and this event.â€

Rizwan â€œRizzyâ€ Qureshi was one of the Justice Department prosecutors on the J20 case. Now in private practice, he said heâ€™s a Democrat who supports the Black Lives Matter movement and attended the 2017 Womenâ€™s March, which took place the day after Trumpâ€™s inauguration.

Qureshi said it was important to note that Bowserâ€™s office â€œpushed hardâ€ for prosecutions after J20, and that politicians like her were no longer supportive when the case became a political liability for them. Now Bowserâ€™s political rhetoric is impacting another case, only this time her actions are backfiring on the MPD.

â€œIs Muriel Bowser taking political advantage of this because the guy who happens to be there happens to be a Trump guy? Yeah, sure, why wouldnâ€™t she? Trumpâ€™s easy to rag on, and I think people should rag on him more often, especially after what his Department of Justice did in Roger Stone and other cases,â€ Qureshi told HuffPost. â€œBut you shouldnâ€™t make the prosecutors and the police officers who work tirelessly to enforce the laws and protect victims the collateral damage of your politics.â€
Qureshi said he believed that career prosecutors in the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office were making the calls on prosecutions and were not allowing politics to dictate their charging decisions.

â€œWhat the acting U.S. attorneyâ€™s letter to Bowser makes clear is exactly what the jurors told us in the J20 cases,â€ Qureshi said. â€œProsecutors are not going to proceed unless thereâ€™s actual evidence of that individual breaking property or engaging in violence, and I think that makes sense. You have to listen to juries because their guidance is instructive on the viability of a prosecution.â€

Kropf said thereâ€™s â€œno questionâ€ that Sherwinâ€™s concerns about MPDâ€™s lack of probable cause were rooted in the legal issues that came up during the J20 trial. She finds the politics of the dispute fascinating.
â€œIâ€™m like, wait a minute, Iâ€™m on the side of a Donald Trump-appointed prosecutor more than the mayor,â€ Kropf said. â€œThe alignments here are interesting.â€

It may have taken a lot of resources, but Kropf said prosecutors were generally able to individually identify defendants using surveillance video and connect them with specific actions, even though most were wearing all black. She said thereâ€™s no reason why police couldnâ€™t do the same here: actually attempt to connect individuals to specific conduct, and charge them under law.

â€œI donâ€™t think heâ€™s holding MPD to an absurd standard,â€ Kropf said. â€œI do think what heâ€™s saying is you canâ€™t just kettle a big group of people, knowing that some people in that group committed property damage or assault on an officer, and expect that weâ€™re going to charge all of those people. Thereâ€™s nothing unusual about that standard.â€
Even in Democratic D.C., Kroft said, jurors would be willing to convict defendants if the government proved they engaged in property damage and violence.

â€œD.C. is obviously a liberal community, but you donâ€™t meet a lot of people who say, â€˜Yes, in support of a cause â€• no matter how much I agree with that cause â€• that itâ€™s OK to destroy property or, particularly, injure a police officer.â€™ I donâ€™t think youâ€™re going to see a lot of potential jurors who say that,â€ Kropf said. â€œIf they can show itâ€™s a person whoâ€™s actually damaging property or throwing something at an officer and so forth, I think a jury in D.C. would absolutely find someone guilty.â€

Steven McCool, a former federal prosecutor and defense attorney who represented a J20 defendant, said that D.C. jurors would fairly consider cases against people â€œdestroying personal or business property,â€ so long as they believe â€œthey have been fairly investigated and are prosecuted in an unbiased manner.â€

Broadly speaking, MPD had been known for taking a more progressive approach to protest policing than departments in many parts of the country. Thatâ€™s both because protests occur so frequently in the nationâ€™s capital and because extensive litigation has forced MPD to curb some of its worst behaviors.

Yet despite their extensive protest experience and the outcome of the J20 cases, MPD has occasionally continued to kettle protesters. In the early days of the Floyd protests, a man living near D.C.â€™s historic U Street became a local folk hero after he allowed protesters into his home to protect them from the police officers who kettled them on his street.

Bowser is â€œtrying to say that she protected D.C. citizens, but under her watch mass arrests became a common police tactic to suppress demonstrators,â€ said Dylan Petrohilos, a J20 defendant who was also caught in the police kettle last month and was among those D.C. police wanted to charge, yet again, with a felony. â€œNo one should expect to be mass arrested in the nationâ€™s capital, right? This is where politics happens.â€

Bowserâ€™s decision to go to the mat to defend questionable arrests has many wondering why she picked this battle. D.C. hasnâ€™t exactly been overwhelmed by unrest in recent weeks. There have been a few high-profile incidents â€• one involving confrontations between protesters and customers dining in outdoor street cafes amid an ongoing pandemic â€• but nothing that would necessarily rise to the level of making Bowser politically vulnerable.

â€œThe only thing I can imagine is that she is feeling pressure from MPD, from the police union, to back up MPD, and the officers who are arresting people and believe they should be charged,â€ Kroft said.

Bowserâ€™s support for police â€• even when theyâ€™ve tried to bring charges the Trump administration considered an overreach â€• reveals why sheâ€™s not beloved by many in the local activist movement. She supported billionaire Michael Bloomberg in the Democratic primary and opposed a $15 million cut to the police department from the cityâ€™s overall $8.6 billion budget back in July.

Anthony Lorenzo Green and other Black Lives Matter DC organizers denounced Bowser for touting her Black Lives Matter Plaza during the Democratic National Convention while opposing shrinking the police budget in her own city. Activists want governments to downsize their police budgets and reallocate that funding to integral, and often underfunded, social services like mental health care, affordable housing, job programs and education.

â€œMayor Muriel Bowser must be held accountable for the lip service she pays in making such a statement while she continues to intentionally underfund services and programs that meet the basic survival needs of Black people of Washington, D.C.,â€ Green told HuffPost in the days following Bowserâ€™s DNC speech. â€œMayor Bowser refused to answer the call and chose to stand with our oppressors.â€
â€œShe is the closest thing to a Republican in Washington, D.C.,â€ says Petrohilos.

Looking back at the J20 cases, Qureshi said the prosecutions would have been â€œway more successfulâ€ if prosecutors had â€œfocused on only the breakersâ€ instead of pursuing what he acknowledged was a â€œnovelâ€ and â€œaggressiveâ€ prosecution strategy under a law that hadnâ€™t been used since the 1960s.
McCool said elected officials in D.C. need to revisit the cityâ€™s rioting laws, especially considering the history of the statute.

â€œThese vague DC anti-rioting laws were written, after Dr. King was assassinated, to deter Black people, during the civil rights movement, from exercising their constitutional rights or even peacefully using the public streets,â€ McCool said. â€œThe Council should take a hard look and rewrite these statutes so that those who commit crimes are prosecuted and people who are protesting or merely present at an assembly are not arrested without cause.â€
Qureshi pointed out that many of the victims who testified during the J20 trial were working-class people of color, and that the vast majority of J20 defendants were white.

â€œThereâ€™s no question that the statute is imperfect,â€ says Qureshi. â€œBut overwhelmingly, the breakers and the people who were arrested in connection with the Inauguration Day riots were white people, not Black people.â€
Additional reporting by Alanna Vagianos.

otherData.headline: Fonio: Try This Nutrient-Packed Ancient Grain When You're Over Quinoa
otherData.short_description: It's low in calories, high in protein and healthy for the environment, too. Here's how to cook it.

articleContent: Ancient grains, which are described by the advocacy group Whole Grains Council as those that have been largely unchanged over the last several hundred years, have become quite the contemporary commodity. Over the past decade, grains like buckwheat, spelt, millet and, of course, the ever-present quinoa have become starchy staples on wellness-minded restaurant menus as well as many personal grocery lists.

Given the many nourishing qualities attributed to ancient grains, itâ€™s ironic that the grain packing the most powerful punch when it comes to health benefits happens to be the smallest in actual size and the newest available on the U.S. market â€• fonio.
Fonio is good for your health.

Ancient grains, in general, are coveted for their nutritional value. Much more beneficial to the body than some of the most widely used varieties of rice, corn and wheat â€• which have undergone centuries of breeding â€• ancient grains offer an abundance of advantageous vitamins and nutrients.

DJ Blatner, a Chicago-based registered dietitian, nutritionist and winning trainer on the 2016 ABC competition series â€œMy Diet Is Better Than Yours,â€ recommends adding ancient grains to your diet for their â€œstress-fighting B vitamins, magnesium for muscle health, blood-building iron, and fiber for regularity and gut health.â€ She advises that â€œancient grains can help feed good bacteria in our gut and healthier gut bacteria can help with everything from digestion to immunity to mood.â€ Ancient grains are also known to be relatively high in protein, which is beneficial for anyone on a plant-based diet.
But fonio, specifically, goes above and beyond most ancient grains in many nutritional categories.

Native to West Africa and considered â€œthe seed of the universeâ€ by ancient Egyptians, fonio has been grown in that region for over 5,000 years and is likely Africaâ€™s oldest cultivated grain. This tiny member of the millet family is much more nutritious than its larger kin â€• and most other grains, for that matter. Itâ€™s a great source of complex carbohydrates. Fonio is also a gluten-free grain with a low glycemic index, making it ideal for gluten-sensitive eaters and those who monitor their blood sugar.

Fonio also fares much better than its fellow grains in calorie count. According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, 1 cup of cooked fonio has 140 calories vs. 216 calories per cup of brown rice, 300 calories per cup of wheat pasta and 222 calories per cup of quinoa. Fonio is also high in the amino acids methionine and cysteine, both of which promote healthy hair, skin and nail growth but are not present in any other grain.
Itâ€™s good for the planet, too.

As beneficial to the body as fonio is, how itâ€™s grown helps the environment as well. Fonio is generally a product of climate-smart agriculture â€• that is, farming practices that sustainably increase productivity while reducing greenhouse gases.

Pierre Thiam, co-founder and president of YolÃ©lÃ© Foods (a Brooklyn, New York-based fonio brand available at Whole Foods and Thrive Market), explained that fonio seeds are typically broadcast in soil, meaning theyâ€™re scattered by hand over soil that has been lightly prepared. Growing the grain requires no deep plowing, which is harmful to the soil.

The resilient little seeds also tolerate a wide variety of soil types, varying rainfall levels and assorted elevations. Fonio is part of a traditional crop rotation in countries like Guinea, Nigeria, Cameroon and Senegal, which are among the largest producers of the grain.

Thiam, who is a New York-based chef, seeks not only to return fonio â€œto its original glory that had been stifled by colonization,â€ but also to ensure that the regions that produce it, like his native Senegal, benefit long term from the grainâ€™s global expansion.

Like quinoa, fonio has the potential to be a huge economic boon for the small farms that grow it. But Thiam cautioned, â€œWe are hoping to avoid quinoaâ€™s disruptive boom and bust cycle, which posed problems for growing communities.â€ He said his company contracts with farmers to buy their crops at â€œattractiveâ€ prices while also working with them â€œto help them increase their productivity and thus their profits.â€
What it tastes like and how to eat it.

If fonioâ€™s nutritional benefits, environmental advantages and potential to financially assist the economy of African nations isnâ€™t enough of a draw, the grainâ€™s taste and texture, coupled with its foolproof and speedy preparation, should definitely seal the deal.

Thiam described fonio as â€œlight and fluffyâ€ with â€œa slightly nutty, earthy flavor.â€ He said that it â€œsoaks up spices and sauces beautifullyâ€ and that it can â€œreplace any grain in your favorite recipes ... you can even use it in baked goods.â€

The recipe below should give you perfectly cooked fonio in approximately 6 minutes. However, all is not lost if for some reason it doesnâ€™t go to plan. Thiam said itâ€™s a very forgiving grain: â€œFonio never embarrasses the cook!â€
His advice: â€œIf it comes out too soggy, leave it on the heat for a little bit longer to cook off the liquid. If itâ€™s dry, add a spoonful of water, cover, and cook for one minute.â€
How to cook fonio.
In a pot with a lid, coat 1/2 cup fonio with 1 tablespoon oil. Turn heat to high, add 3/4 cup water (or low-sodium vegetable stock for savory dishes) and bring to a boil.
Add a pinch of salt, stir, cover and turn heat to low for 1 minute.
Turn off heat and let sit covered 5 minutes. Fluff with a fork. Serve hot or cold.
Easy enough!

otherData.headline: â€˜Didnâ€™t Take Any Of It For Grantedâ€™: How Chadwick Bosemanâ€™s Humility Made Him A Star
otherData.short_description: Aakomon Jones, the choreographer who trained Boseman for "Get On Up" and "Black Panther," reflects on the late actor's spirit.

articleContent: Many of the tributes pouring in for Chadwick Boseman, who died last week at age 43 after a private battle with colon cancer, have emphasized his grace. â€œBlack Pantherâ€ made Boseman one of the worldâ€™s preeminent movie stars, but those who knew him say he remained loyal, humble and philanthropic, leaving behind a legacy defined by forward-thinking generosity.

Aakomon Jones witnessed Bosemanâ€™s ascent firsthand. A veteran choreographer who has worked with Usher, Madonna and Jennifer Lopez, Jones taught Boseman â€” an untrained dancer â€” how to capture James Brownâ€™s famous moves for the under-appreciated 2014 biopic â€œGet On Up.â€ They had three short months to achieve a physicality that takes some performers years to perfect. Along the way, Jones found himself learning as much from Bosemanâ€™s dedication as Boseman did from Jonesâ€™ techniques. When the actor went on to make â€œBlack Pantherâ€ a few years later, he asked Marvel to hire Jones to choreograph the spirited scene set at Warrior Falls, Wakandaâ€™s king-making epicenter.

In the wake of Bosemanâ€™s death, I asked Jones to reflect on their work together, from suggesting the actor do all of his own dancing in â€œGet On Upâ€ to observing the spiritual journey that accompanied his superhero renown. What resulted was a conversation about a man who exuded dignity.
Letâ€™s start with how â€œGet On Upâ€ entered your life and your initial thoughts about working on a project that required you to capture someone as specific as James Brown.

Mick Jagger was one of the executive producers. I had worked with him on a music video before. By the time I was involved, [the producers] were considering a number of actors, but they were really more interested in Chadwick, so they brought me in to work with him on his screen test. I didnâ€™t rehearse with him prior. It was literally that morning. I just tried to get him worked up enough for his screen test. We connected really quickly on that. He got the role and we got straight to rehearsals. Iâ€™m a student of James Brown. A lot of roads lead back to James Brown in terms of stage energy.

I promise you â€• and I remember it as though it was yesterday â€• from day one of our rehearsals with Chadwick, I was absolutely convinced that he was going to be able to pull this off. And it wasnâ€™t because he walked in day one already having it. Heâ€™s 6 feet tall [and] thin, trying to play this guy who was short, bowlegged and 5â€™7â€ â€• a little running-back type of guy. So the physicality already had us at a disadvantage, but Chadwick had impressed upon me a work ethic and a passion for the arts that had me reassured that this is going to work because this guy is showing up to work before I am. Heâ€™s dancing as long as I can dance, and I think I can go for hours and hours. He can go for a couple more.

At that point, you were accustomed to working with experienced dancers, having choreographed for folks like Usher and Madonna. Chadwick was not a dancer. So what did it take for both of you to feel ready and comfortable to carry the movie?

For me, it was just time. Thatâ€™s all I would just ask for. Weâ€™re trying to pack 30 years of dance experience into three months. Thatâ€™s crazy to think of, but thatâ€™s what weâ€™re all charged with. Chadwick was so invested beyond the moves because thereâ€™s the physical, technical aspect of it and then thereâ€™s also the â€œHow do I connect this to the character?â€ That was always the angle with which Chadwick would approach our rehearsals. In the moment that I would force him to sit down and take a break and have some water, I would step away and turn right back around and heâ€™s reading another chapter in some James Brown biography that he had read because he remembered something that he connected to the dance we were doing.
Do you have a specific example of an emotional trigger point from either James Brownâ€™s life or the way Chadwick related to James Brown that directly informed some of the choreography?

Yes, one thing in particular. Chadwick is a martial artist â€• well before â€œBlack Panther,â€ he was always practicing martial arts â€• and very athletic. I always reference dancers as being athletes because you literally have to be that. But before James Brown became the James Brown we all know and love, he was a boxer, and Chadwick picked up on that. If you look at James Brown in that context, you see how he would ball his fist or how he would work his footwork or how he would dance holding up a guard, in a boxing stance. I would watch Chadwick explain it to me and do it better than I was trying to teach it to him.
How ready was he by the time cameras were rolling?

Were we prepared on that first shoot date? Yes. He was confident. I was confident in him. He was ready. From the moment we started principal photography, there may have been one and a half numbers that we had yet to design that he would have to find time to learn. And number one on the call sheet, itâ€™s hard to get access to them after we start shooting. But he was so good at that point, to where the process and teaching him something new was like lightning speed because he was such a well-oiled machine with regards to being James Brown. So, a new number? Easy. We can knock it out quick because he had done the work. My relationship with him would be just to keep him anchored. And to be able to share the stage in a couple of those numbers [as singer Bobby Bennett], that meant the world to me.

In many movies where actors play dancers, the camerawork is designed so we never see the personâ€™s full body and can never know thereâ€™s a double doing most of it. â€œGet On Upâ€ is different. Those strategic cuts donâ€™t exist, so we know that Chadwick is doing all of his own work. Was that the plan all along?

That was not the thought going in. The thought from producers was, â€œWe need to discuss ways to double Chad.â€ That kind of was everyoneâ€™s anticipation because thatâ€™s what we do [in movies]: We protect the artists with regards to making sure they come across on-screen. I personally was anti that, but I wasnâ€™t going to speak on that until I was certain that we were going to be able to pull this off. So day one in rehearsal, I was like, â€œOh no, weâ€™re not doing any body doubles. Nope.â€ And he was down for it. He felt and he understood â€” and Iâ€™ll say this because Iâ€™ve heard him say it in an interview, and I say this with the utmost humility â€” my level of confidence in him. Because if youâ€™re not a professional dancer and youâ€™re now playing James Brown, what an undertaking. But he did it. As one of the accessories to that journey, it made me want to work that much harder.
What was the dance move that was the hardest to work through and achieve the results that both of you wanted?

Thereâ€™s so much that you have to do to try to perform like James Brown, but the toughest thing for him physically was being able to drop down into that split and come right back up. I mean, heâ€™s blessed to be 6 feet. Thatâ€™s a blessing, unless youâ€™re trying to do that. We would work on that, and he understood the muscle groups that were required so he could train on those. Those hamstrings and that inner leg strength to draw your body back up off of the floor, thatâ€™s tough. And youâ€™re in dress shoes. That was the toughest thing physically for him to do at that rate of speed in the middle of a performance when youâ€™re already fatigued and sweating and singing.
What do you remember about seeing the film for the first time and how you and Chadwick felt about it?

The experience was a dream experience. Iâ€™ll tell you this specific memory. Tate [Taylor, the director] invited Chadwick and I to his offices to watch his first edit and get our feedback. So it was just three of us sitting in the room. We looked at it and he had his notes, but it was really beautiful and awesome to sit with the two of them and watch that first draft. After we talked about it, we started talking about what our next projects were. And in that conversation, Chadwick said, â€œI have some meetings with Marvel coming up.â€ And they didnâ€™t tell him what those meetings were for. Being comic book heads, weâ€™re sitting there speculating on, â€œWho is it? I think I know.â€ Itâ€™s just fun for me to think back to that day, as we watched â€œGet On Upâ€ for the first time and he was on his way to have these meetings, not knowing what they were for. Years later, here we are.
You were catching him on that last wave before he entered the huge, global stardom that comes with being part of that franchise.

Absolutely, and Marvel couldnâ€™t have chosen a better guy for that. All the things that â€œBlack Pantherâ€ role embodies, he was really that beforehand. He was always about upward mobility. He was about the underdog. He was about taking his artistry seriously, and he was forever a student.
You did some work on â€œBlack Panther.â€ How did that come about?

I was there doing â€œPitch Perfect 3â€ in Atlanta [where Marvel movies also shoot] and so we were able to cross paths a couple of times: â€œOh, Iâ€™m having a barbecue, come through,â€ or â€œOh, youâ€™re in town? Letâ€™s kick it.â€ We would hang out. But then there were the scenes [in â€œBlack Pantherâ€] where there was an opportunity for dance. Thatâ€™s one thing that I always said about Chadwick: He used his leverage at every stage of his career to help someone else, to bring someone else on. I personally heard him have conversations with producers about the importance of choreography and dance. Choreographers are oftentimes an anomaly in the industry, so we have to fight to get that appreciation because you wonâ€™t see one of us on set every day.
So he brought you on for â€œBlack Pantherâ€?

He brought me on for â€œBlack Panther.â€ In African tradition, a lot of tribes would have a war dance. In Asian martial arts, you call it a kata. So I would work with him on some of that. For the Warrior Falls scene where they choose the new king, you can have an opportunity to challenge the king. I worked on all the tribes and their movements, driving on the boats, up in the waterfall, what have you.

They werenâ€™t looking for a choreographer to help with that, but Chadwick expressed the importance of it. He called on me, and you got to know I came running top-speed. It was, of course, Marvelâ€™s â€œBlack Panther.â€ Who doesnâ€™t want to be a part of that? But Iâ€™m not lying to you: My reasoning for not thinking twice was because he called. That meant the world to me that he put his neck on the line even in a small way. I canâ€™t thank him enough for that.

You mentioned what it was like for him to be number one on the call sheet during â€œGet On Up,â€ so I can only imagine what it was like to be number one on â€œBlack Panther,â€ which was budgeted around $200 million. How did the machinery of that franchise and the size of the production change the nature of what you guys were doing together?

Well, the nature of what was required meant that I didnâ€™t need as much time with him. But in terms of the scale, when you got to Chadwick, you didnâ€™t feel the scale. It still felt small and personal, in a good way. He has a theatrical background, so he just made it seem like, â€œHey, I know you, we cool. Iâ€™m so glad youâ€™re here. Hey, check this out. What do you think about this or that?â€ Heâ€™s immediately engaging you in a way that makes you forget this is the biggest, craziest, most amazing thing you would ever want to be involved in.

I donâ€™t think anybody at the time could have predicted that â€œBlack Pantherâ€ would cross a billion dollars, even though there was a lot of enthusiasm around the movie. Still, he had to know that it would vault him into this upper echelon of fame and also that the movie would mean a lot to a lot of people. Iâ€™m curious whether you saw that in him and whether he was readying himself for that change in his life.

Absolutely, because he would use his leverage in the way that he did. He was already in the culture of helping others and bringing others with him: â€œIf Iâ€™m about to skyrocket into the stratosphere, Iâ€™m not going alone just to make new friends when I get there. No, I want those others who were with me to experience that.â€ He was very well-prepared from a spiritual standpoint. The movie touched upon the importance of staying connected to ancestors. He already had that language. He would bring a djembe drum to rehearsals for â€œGet On Up.â€ We were doing soul music in the â€™60s, but thatâ€™s the rhythms that really got him going in the morning.

Itâ€™s poetic that he was chosen for [the Black Panther role] because he was more than deserving. Heâ€™s very kinglike, and not king like â€œI rule over,â€ but â€œIâ€™m the king who brings the community, and I lead from that perspective.â€ I canâ€™t say enough on that. On day one of our rehearsal for â€œGet On Up,â€ he told me, â€œMan, as a kid growing up, I always wanted to be in an action movie, and Iâ€™m fortunate enough to play in all these biopics when I really got into acting to one day be in an action movie.â€ And then fast-forward, you are the greatest action character that we know right now. I think he handled that level of success with such grace and responsibility because he always felt responsible and respectful of what was happening. Didnâ€™t take any of it for granted. Thatâ€™s one thing that I know for a fact.
Is there a defining anecdote or memory about Chadwick that I havenâ€™t already prompted that sticks out to you?

Sometimes itâ€™s the small things that let you know the character of a person. There have been two times that Iâ€™ve been out in public where he has gone out of his way to say hello. This is after the major success of â€œBlack Panther.â€ One of them was at the airport. I was coming in, he was coming out. Another time, we were literally on the street. He was just always sending love and sending vibes and checking in on you. Iâ€™m like, there must be 10,000 people in your life every day, but you would still take time to reach out to people and to connect with them.
This interview has been edited for clarity and length.

otherData.headline: The 10 Best Instagram Recipes From August 2020

otherData.headline: 500 Faith Leaders Endorse Joe Biden And Kamala Harris For The White House
otherData.short_description: The diverse group of backers includes an evangelical preacher who last voted for a Democratic presidential candidate in 1976.

articleContent: Five hundred religious leaders â€• Christians, Muslims, Jews, Hindus, Sikhs and others â€• have jointly endorsed the Democratic presidential ticket of Joe Biden and Sen. Kamala Harris, according to the multi-faith advocacy group Faith 2020.

The endorsees include some who have never publicly backed a White House candidate, such as Ron Sider, the founder of Evangelicals for Social Action. The list also includes clergy from diverse theological positions â€• from the progressive Christian pastor Rev. Nadia Bolz-Weber, long a critic of President Donald Trump, to the evangelical preacher Rev. Rob Schenck, a former militant anti-abortion rights activist who has pledged to vote for a Democrat for the first time in 44 years.

Other prominent backers of Biden and Harris include Imam Talib Shareef of â€œThe Nationâ€™s Mosqueâ€ in Washington, D.C., Greg Epstein, a Humanist chaplain, Rev. John McCullough, president of the Christian humanitarian group Church World Service, Bishop Vashti McKenzie of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, and Rev. Greg Boyle, a Los Angeles Roman Catholic priest.

Lisa Sharon Harper, a Christian writer and founder of the faith-based consulting group Freedom Road, told HuffPost she believes Biden is a â€œman of true faithâ€ who is guided by Jesusâ€™ commandment to love God and love oneâ€™s neighbor. Harper decided to break from her regular practice and explicitly endorse the Biden-Harris ticket because she believes â€œnow is the time for clarity.â€

â€œThere is no time to mince words. A second Trump term could deal a mortal blow to our democracy. It would surely deal a mortal blow to the witness of the evangelical faith,â€ Harper, who identifies as evangelical herself, told HuffPost.
â€œFaith leaders will be held accountable by God and history for how we used our voices right now,â€ she added. â€œDid we bless our neighbor or did we curse them. That will be the question.â€

Faith 2020 calls itself a â€œgroup of friends and neighborsâ€ who are backing Biden and Harris to â€œlead us in restoring our nationâ€™s values.â€ Its bid to create a â€œbig-tent, multi-faith coalitionâ€ echoes one of the main messages of outreach that marked last monthâ€™s Democratic National Convention.
The endorsement list was spearheaded by the head of Faith 2020â€²s board, Rev. Fred Davie, the executive vice president of New Yorkâ€™s Union Seminary, according to the Religion News Service.

The list of supporters, first published with about 350 names last Thursday before swelling in size, comes as the Biden campaign expands its outreach to communities of faith. The former vice presidentâ€™s team hired an evangelical Christian and former Republican, Josh Dickson, as its national faith engagement director in July. Religious voters were explicitly courted during the partyâ€™s convention that sought to highlight Bidenâ€™s faith as a Roman Catholic. Bidenâ€™s campaign has also been targeting specific groups of faith voters in swing states, including Latino evangelicals, Catholics, Hindus and young people of faith.

â€œFor too long the Republican Party has hijacked faith,â€ Faith 2020â€²s executive director Rev. Adam Nicholas Phillips told HuffPost in an email. â€œItâ€™s outrageous to think that Donald Trump would be â€˜the values candidateâ€™ in 2020, especially, as he consistently stokes racial division and lets neighbors near and far lose loved ones and livelihoods amidst the pandemic.â€

Phillips, a progressive evangelical pastor from Portland, Oregon, also pointed to the scandals surrounding Trumpâ€™s â€œso-called faith supportersâ€ â€• such as Liberty Universityâ€™s ex-president Jerry Falwell, Jr., who was pushed out of his post after a sex scandal, Pastor John MacArthur, whose church has been flouting COVID-19 regulations, and the conservative activist Charlie Kirk, who has helped to spread the patently false QAnon conspiracy theory.
â€œThese guys are outliers, not representative of faithful Americans,â€ Phillips said.

Phillips said he believes Biden and Harris are the â€œmorally serious candidatesâ€ that faith-motivated voters are looking for, especially on issues such as systemic racism. He also said he believes religious voters across party lines are deeply committed to â€œwelcoming the stranger,â€ a goal that in his view Trumpâ€™s â€œcruelâ€ policies toward migrant children and refugees has harmed.
â€œMost faithful Americans are increasingly inclusive and forward-looking â€• looking for justice and healing, not tired old toxic ways,â€ Phillips said.

otherData.headline: For Country's Brandon Stansell, The Fight To Sing Truthfully As A Gay Man Isn't Over
otherData.short_description: In "Three Chords and a Lie," the Tennessee-born artist lays bare his struggles with his Southern Baptist family as he prepares for his first hometown concert.

articleContent: As Brandon Stansell took the stage in his hometown last year, he hoped his show would earn him new fans as well as â€œjump-start conversationsâ€ with loved ones whoâ€™d rejected him more than a decade ago when he came out as gay.

Though the rising country artistâ€™s October performance in Chattanooga, Tennessee, was enthusiastically received, both his father and four siblings chose to skip the show. The sole family member in attendance that night was his mother, Pam, who still publicly disapproves of her sonâ€™s sexuality.

Now based in Los Angeles, Stansell has captured these experiences for posterity in a new documentary. Directed by Trent Atkinson, â€œThree Chords and a Lieâ€ follows the singer-songwriter as he revisits his adolescent haunts, including the school and Southern Baptist church he attended as a child.
Catch the â€œThree Chords and a Lieâ€ trailer above.

The movie, which had its U.S. premiere at Outfest Los Angeles last week, succeeds in placing Stansellâ€™s story in the broader context of country music, still seen as a conservative genre. Gay CMT personality Cody Alan and singer Shelly Fairchild, who lost a recording contract when she came out as a lesbian, appear in interviews.

But the filmâ€™s most poignant moments show Stansell breaking down in tears in rehearsal while recalling his familyâ€™s refusal to accept him as his authentic self, and being approached by young LGBTQ people at a Pride festival who thank him for living his truth.

â€œI think the movie can potentially help people like me, and families with people like me in them,â€ Stansell, 33, told HuffPost. â€œEven though I want to share my experiences, theyâ€™re really hard to share. I donâ€™t take people home with me. There are sides of the coin I donâ€™t really talk about â€• not intentionally, but just because theyâ€™re hard to talk about. But if I had thrown up walls along the way, we wouldâ€™ve ended up with something a lot different.â€

Five years after the release of his debut single, â€œDear John,â€ Stansell has come to occupy a unique niche within country music. Earlier songs like â€œSlow Downâ€ and â€œNever Know,â€ for example, directly speak to the men he has loved. Newer tracks like â€œHurt Peopleâ€ and â€œLike Usâ€ relay the broader struggles of the LGBTQ community, namely the ostracism many queer people face at home and in the workplace.
In 2018, he set a new precedent when the video for his song â€œHometownâ€ premiered on CMT and became the first queer-themed clip to receive airplay on the country music network.

â€œIf country music is about storytelling, then it should be about telling everybodyâ€™s stories, all stories,â€ he said. â€œUntil now, the queer stories in this genre have been missing. I have the vehicle of music and a passion for sharing my experiences in a way that I think can help change the way that we treat queer people in this world. I want to be a part of that.â€

Following the premiere of â€œThree Chords and a Lie,â€ Stansell plans to spend the remainder of 2020 collaborating remotely with songwriters and producers on a six-song EP, slated to drop next year. The new music, he said, the â€œantithesisâ€ of the four acoustic tracks he recorded for the film and more in the celebratory vein of his 2019 single, â€œTop Shelf.â€

And he remains hopeful his parents and siblings will make a point to watch the documentary. Regardless of whether that happens, however, he believes its family-focused message will resound among viewers who are open to hearing it.

â€œTrying to convince my family that Iâ€™m not a broken person, that thereâ€™s nothing wrong with me â€• that isnâ€™t my job,â€ he said. â€œSo I just keep rolling along and singing the songs, and doing what I do.â€

otherData.headline: Chadwick Boseman Helped Create This Iconic â€˜Black Pantherâ€™ Line
otherData.short_description: Director Ryan Coogler penned a heartfelt tribute to the late actor, explaining how they came up with the character Erik Killmongerâ€™s final line.

articleContent: â€œBlack Pantherâ€ director and co-writer Ryan Coogler revealed that his late friend Chadwick Boseman helped come up with one of the filmâ€™s most memorable lines.

In an emotional tribute to Boseman, who died at his home in Los Angeles on Friday after a lengthy battle with colon cancer, Coogler explained how Boseman was deeply involved in the filmmaking process.

â€œHe would come to auditions for supporting roles, which is not common for lead actors in big budget movies. He was there for several Mâ€™Baku auditions. In Winston Dukeâ€™s, he turned a chemistry read into a wrestling match. Winston broke his bracelet,â€ Coogler said on Sunday. â€œIn Letitia Wrightâ€™s audition for Shuri, she pierced his royal poise with her signature humor, and would bring about a smile to Tâ€™Challaâ€™s face that was 100% Chad.â€

During filming, Coogler said he and Boseman would often meet to â€œdiscuss lines and different ways to add depth to each scene.â€

â€œWe talked costumes, military practices. He said to me, â€˜Wakandans have to dance during the coronations. If they just stand there with spears, what separates them from Romans?â€™â€ he continued. â€œIn early drafts of the script, [Erik] Killmongerâ€™s character would ask Tâ€™Challa to be buried in Wakanda. Chad challenged that and asked, â€˜What if Killmonger asked to be buried somewhere else?â€™â€

The director was referring to Michael B. Jordanâ€™s character, Killmonger, whose final line in the film is, â€œWhy? So you can just lock me up? Just bury me in the ocean with my ancestors who jumped from ships, â€™cause they knew death was better than bondage.â€

Last year, Marvel Studios Chief Kevin Feige told The Hollywood Reporter that he thought the line was â€œone of the best linesâ€ he had ever read, and that heâ€™d even encouraged filmmakers to â€œbuild more of the movie around it.â€

Since Bosemanâ€™s death, fans and co-stars in the Marvel community have come out in droves to mourn his loss. On Monday night, Jordan shared a similarly heart-wrenching tribute to his friend.

â€œIâ€™ve been trying to find the words, but nothing comes close to how I feel. Iâ€™ve been reflecting on every moment, every conversation, every laugh, every disagreement, every hugâ€¦everything,â€ he wrote on Instagram. â€œI wish we had more time.â€

otherData.headline: The Weeknd Looks Like He Got Beat Up At Video Music Awards
otherData.short_description: The singer won two VMAs, but his bruised and bloody appearance made it look as though he'd lost a fight.

articleContent: The Weekndâ€™s face told a bruised and bloody story at the Video Music Awards on Sunday â€” but it wasnâ€™t real.
The singer wore makeup to make it look as if heâ€™d been worked over.
Turns out he didnâ€™t lose a fight â€” but he did win VMAs for Best R&B Video and Video of the Year for â€œBlinding Lights.â€
The Weeknd has put on his battered look before in a short film for â€œAfter Hoursâ€ and in a video for â€œBlinding Lights,â€ which he performed for the awards.
He did the same on â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ in March.
While accepting one of his awards on Sunday, The Weeknd spoke out against racial injustice and police brutality.
â€œHard to celebrate, so Iâ€™m gonna say justice for Jacob Blake and justice for Breonna Taylor,â€ he said, echoing his sentiments from a previous acceptance speech.

otherData.headline: Mariah Carey Says Ellen DeGeneres Made Her 'Extremely Uncomfortable' In Pregnancy Interview
otherData.short_description: The singer reflected on a 2008 appearance on the comedian's talk show, during which DeGeneres pressured her into revealing a rumored pregnancy.

articleContent: Mariah Carey wonâ€™t be joining the long list of celebrities defending Ellen DeGeneres as she faces allegations that she fostered a toxic work environment on her long-running talk show.

The R&B icon reflected on her own brush with DeGeneres years ago, when the host essentially manipulated Carey into revealing she was pregnant amid rumors that she was expecting a child with then-husband Nick Cannon.
Reflecting on the 2008 interview in an expansive Vulture profile published on Monday, Carey said that she was â€œextremely uncomfortableâ€ with the exchange at the time.
During her appearance on the talk show, DeGeneres appeared to surprise Carey by mentioning the speculation about her personal life.

â€œDonâ€™t discuss that,â€ a shocked Carey said in response, before DeGeneres handed her a flute of champagne, in an attempt by the host to get Carey to prove she wasnâ€™t pregnant. â€œI canâ€™t believe you did this to me, Ellen.â€
When Carey pretended to sip from the glass, DeGeneres declared that she was indeed pregnant.

While the exchange might have seemed relatively innocuous at the time, Carey later had a miscarriage, a fact she didnâ€™t reveal until years later when announcing she was pregnant again. Carey and Cannon welcomed twins Monroe and Moroccan in 2011.

â€œI was extremely uncomfortable with that moment is all I can say. And I really have had a hard time grappling with the aftermath,â€ Carey told Vulture. â€œI wasnâ€™t ready to tell anyone because I had had a miscarriage. I donâ€™t want to throw anyone thatâ€™s already being thrown under any proverbial bus, but I didnâ€™t enjoy that moment.â€
For months, DeGeneres has been at the center of a slew of workplace misconduct and harassment allegations, stemming from two BuzzFeed articles published in June.

The reports featured troubling accounts from one current and 10 former employees, who said they faced â€œracism, fear, and intimidationâ€ at work, prompting Warner Bros. Television to launch an internal investigation.

Earlier this month, executive producers Ed Glavin and Kevin Leman, as well as co-executive producer Jonathan Norman, â€œparted waysâ€ with the show, while DeGeneres has reportedly apologized to her staff multiple times.
Ashton Kutcher, Diane Keaton and Kevin Hart have all spoken in defense of DeGeneres, citing their own positive interactions with the talk show host.
When describing her own experience, Carey kept it classy, saying that there is â€œempathy that can be applied to those moments that I would have liked to have been implemented.â€

otherData.headline: How A Massachusetts Primary Could Affect The Puerto Rican Debt Crisis
otherData.short_description: Holyoke, Massachusetts, Mayor Alex Morse, who is challenging Rep. Richard Neal, wants to cancel the island's debt.

articleContent: Puerto Rican voters stand to play a critical role in the Democratic primary for Massachusettsâ€™ 1st Congressional District, where progressive Holyoke Mayor Alex Morse is hoping to unseat Rep. Richard Neal, one of the most powerful Democrats in Congress.
Nearly one in five residents of the vast House district, which encompasses parts of central and Western Massachusetts, is Latino, the overwhelming majority of whom are Puerto Rican.
But who wins the race could also have an effect on the lives of Puerto Ricans who remain on the island.

Thatâ€™s because Morse and Neal have staked out starkly different stances on how the United States should respond to Puerto Ricoâ€™s decadeslong debt crisis, compounded by a series of deadly hurricanes in recent years and the COVID-19 pandemic.

On his campaign website, Morse declares his support for getting rid of the U.S.-run fiscal oversight board (known in Puerto Rico as â€œLa Juntaâ€) that has veto power over Puerto Ricoâ€™s budget, canceling Puerto Ricoâ€™s debt, and giving the people of the U.S. commonwealth full â€œself determinationâ€ to decide their status vis-a-vis the mainland United States.

â€œAlex understands the urgency of this moment for Puerto Rico, having served people migrating from the Island to Holyoke searching for economic stability,â€ Morse campaign manager Max Clermont told HuffPost in a statement. â€œWe canâ€™t expect to trust Neal to act with urgency on this issue when heâ€™s failed to use his accumulated power through a quarter century to fix a crisis that heâ€™s helped create, nor when heâ€™s had a shared agenda with Wall Street.â€

At least one Puerto Rican Morse supporter said his stance on Puerto Rico was a motivating factor for her. Morse â€œunderstands the need for Puerto Ricans to determine our own destiny, and that starts with abolishing La Junta, followed by canceling the debt, and entrusting working committees composed of on the ground grassroots organizations, community and municipal leaders to move the nation forward,â€ said Gladys Franco, a school administrator from Springfield who supports Morse.
Nealâ€™s campaign website has a far glossier section on Puerto Rico, complete with photos of Neal attending Puerto Rican parades in the district.

But while it notes Nealâ€™s efforts to secure additional aid for victims of Hurricane Maria, and his efforts to celebrate Puerto Rican culture through the creation of a Hispanic Heritage Month and the construction of the National Museum of the American Latino, it does not reference the debt crisis directly.

Asked what Neal thought about the fiscal oversight board and restructuring Puerto Rican debt, his campaign spokesperson Kate Norton responded with a statement that did not explicitly address either topic.

â€œRichie Neal believes that the fundamental issue of rebuilding and stabilizing the economy must be the highest priority, and without this resolved the debt will only grow exponentially without any hope for a sustainable future for Puerto Rico,â€ Norton said.

At the heart of the discussion over how the U.S. government should proceed in Puerto Rico is a debate about the effectiveness of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA), a bipartisan bill enacted in June 2016.

The billâ€™s proponents cast it as a positive, if imperfect, source of relief for Puerto Rico, which suffers under a $74 billion public debt burden that most experts believe the island will never be able to pay down.

On paper, the bill created a path for Puerto Rico to discharge debt that it was previously unable to write off. Unlike municipalities and public corporations on the mainland, Puerto Ricoâ€™s indebted public entities do not have the authority to declare bankruptcy to restructure their debts.

The problem is that the law also created a seven-person, unelected fiscal oversight board that must approve any write-downs of the debt. Critics charge that the panel, which is stacked with fiscal conservatives like Andrew Biggs of the American Enterprise Institute and corporate executives like JosÃ© CarriÃ³n III, has proved far more willing to keep the burden of fiscal austerity on the islandâ€™s most vulnerable residents, rather than the bondholders who own Puerto Ricoâ€™s debt.

Under the boardâ€™s watchful eye, the island has been forced to slash spending on public university tuition and public employee pensions. Those cuts, the continued economic stagnation on the island, and Hurricane Maria in 2017, have accelerated an exodus of working- and middle-class families to the mainland U.S. Due to the hurricane alone, an estimated 100,000 Puerto Ricans migrated to the mainland, including a significant number who have arrived in Holyoke and Springfield.

Whatâ€™s more, some of the bondholders to whom Puerto Rico is indebted are â€œvulture capitalistsâ€ who purchased the debt from other creditors at a discount and are now using their deep-pocketed political influence to ensure they are repaid at the original dollar value of the debt.

PROMESA, passed by the Republican-controlled Congress and signed by then-President Barack Obama, had the support of the vast majority of congressional Democrats. Just 12 members of the Senate Democratic Caucus voted against the bill, and 24 Democrats in the House. Neal was not among the two dozen â€œnoâ€ votes.

Former Rep. Luis GutiÃ©rrez, a Chicago Democrat from Puerto Rico who served with Neal for 26 years, told HuffPost unprompted that reelecting Neal is an important step in the fight to restructure Puerto Ricoâ€™s debt on more favorable terms. (GutiÃ©rrez, who retired at the beginning of 2019, voted against PROMESA.)

â€œMassachusetts is going to play a great role in Puerto Ricoâ€™s development,â€ said GutiÃ©rrez, who moved to Puerto Rico after leaving Congress. â€œLet me tell you why: There is no one who was clearer on reducing the debt in Puerto Rico and dismantling this terrible fiscal control board than Richie Neal.â€

Asked how GutiÃ©rrez reconciled his confidence in Neal with Nealâ€™s vote for PROMESA, GutiÃ©rrez responded that many progressive lawmakers with whom he works closely voted for the bill at the time, including fellow Puerto Rican lawmakers Nydia Velazquez and JosÃ© Serrano of New York. (Another Massachusetts Democrat facing a tough reelection battle, Sen. Ed Markey, voted against the bill; his challenger, Rep. Joe Kennedy III, voted for it.)
â€œNow a lot of people see the damage that [PROMESA] is causing,â€ GutiÃ©rrez said.

Massachusetts state Rep. Carlos GonzÃ¡lez, another Puerto Rican who has endorsed Neal, had a similar defense of Nealâ€™s vote for the bill, claiming that many Puerto Ricans in Western Massachusetts supported the bill at the time.
Four years after its passage, though, Puerto Ricans in Massachusettsâ€™ 1st District have turned against the law, and GonzÃ¡lez expressed confidence that Neal would hear them out.

â€œItâ€™s time to eliminate the PROMESA and eliminate the debt that Puerto Rico has acquired because of vulture capitalists. â€¦ Thatâ€™s an issue that we will be addressing with the congressman as well,â€ GonzÃ¡lez said, though he conceded he had not received any assurances on the matter yet from Neal.

As chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Neal does not have direct jurisdiction over Puerto Rico. U.S. policy for the island is usually under the purview of the House Committee on Natural Resources.

But as Neal is fond of noting, his nearly 32 years in Congress have afforded him influence that extends far beyond the boundaries of his committee. He has, for instance, the ear of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), who starred in one of the Neal campaignâ€™s TV ads.

Morseâ€™s Puerto Rican backers are skeptical, though, that Neal would ever be inclined to side with Puerto Rico against the islandâ€™s creditors given the massive sums of campaign cash that Neal receives from Wall Street. Executives at BlackRock, an asset management fund that holds over $110 million in Puerto Rican debt, contributed $10,000 to Nealâ€™s reelection campaign this cycle through the firmâ€™s political action committee.

Neal â€œcan be trusted to do what the bondholders tell him to do,â€ said San Juan, Puerto Rico, Mayor Carmen YulÃ­n Cruz, who is supporting Morse. â€œHe cannot â€• he absolutely cannot â€• be trusted to fight for the best interests of the Puerto Rican people.â€
Neal has said that his policy positions are not influenced by donors.
â€œIf you contribute to my campaign, you buy into my agenda,â€ the congressman said during a televised debate with Morse on Aug. 17. â€œIâ€™m not buying into yours.â€

otherData.headline: Monsoon Rains Wreak Havoc Across Pakistan, Killing At Least 63 People
otherData.short_description: Major flooding and widespread power outages have hit the coastal city of Karachi as authorities scramble to evacuate residents.

articleContent: KARACHI, Pakistan (AP) â€” Heavy rains hit parts of Pakistan for a fifth straight night, bringing more flooding to the financial capital Karachi and towns and villages and leaving at least 63 people dead, officials said Friday. Rescuers evacuated people from flooded neighborhoods.

About 30 inches (76 centimeters) of rain have fallen in Karachi since Sunday, when monsoon rains began lashing the coastal city, forcing authorities to use boats to evacuate people trapped in flooded streets.

Forty-seven people were killed this week in Karachi in rain-related incidents, according to Murad Ali Shah, chief minister of southern Sindh province. He said authorities were working day and night to help rain-affected people in the city and elsewhere in Sindh, where Karachi is the provincial capital.

At least 16 people were killed in the northwestern province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa because of flash flooding overnight, said Taimur Ali, a spokesman for the disaster management agency in the northwest.

Downed power lines caused widespread electrical outages in Karachi, adding misery to the lives of many of the 15 million residents in Pakistanâ€™s largest city. Some workers stayed at their offices and others spent the night in open areas because there was no transportation to get home in many parts of the city.
Hundreds of vehicles were dragged along city streets by powerful flood waters.

The military said it provided food to at least 10,000 people and dozens of relief camps were set up for residents. Troops also repaired embankments of a swollen canal by which floodwaters entered the city.

Eight of those killed in Karachi died when a wall fell on them in a residential area. They included children, who were playing at the time. Other casualties were reported in various parts of Sindh in the past 24 hours. More than 150 people have died in various parts of Pakistan since June in rain-related incidents and many residents were angry with authorities for not helping them.

Monsoon rains are hitting Pakistan at a time when authorities are trying to contain the spread of the coronavirus, which has caused more than 6,283 deaths since February. Pakistan reported nine more deaths Friday from COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.
Every year, many cities in Pakistan struggle to cope with the annual monsoon deluge, drawing criticism about poor planning. The monsoon season runs from July through September.
Associated Press Writer Riaz Khan contributed to this story from Peshawar, Pakistan.

otherData.headline: When Will We See Queen Elizabeth Again?
otherData.short_description: Her Majesty has shown up virtually in video calls and pictures. But the pandemic is still keeping her away from in-person events.

articleContent: As other members of the British royal family are carefully making in-person appearances post-lockdown, Queen Elizabethâ€™s reemergence on the public stage looks to be some time off.

The monarch recently made the trek to Balmoral, her estate in Scotland, for her annual summer stay, which typically covers most of August and September. But instead of returning to Buckingham Palace in London afterward, as she normally would, the Sunday Times recently reported that the queen will most likely head back to Windsor Castle outside the city.

Amid the chaos and uncertainty of the coronavirus pandemic, the palace communications team has reassured the public that the queen is doing well â€• through radio and TV addresses, photos of her riding her horses, and a glimpse here and there of the sovereign on a video call.
But itâ€™s no doubt hard for the monarch who once said she must â€œbe seen to be believedâ€ to remain isolated from the public. And many royal fans want to know: When will they see the queen again?

The 94-year-old queen began quarantining at Windsor Castle alongside the 99-year-old Prince Philip in March, arriving a week earlier than normal due to the pandemic. By May, royal biographer Andrew Morton declared that COVID-19 had rendered her reign â€œeffectively over.â€

â€œItâ€™s terribly sad but I canâ€™t see how the Queen can resume her job,â€ he told The Telegraph, as reports swirled that Elizabeth would be withdrawing from public life for months and Prince Charles would be named Prince Regent (a title he would only assume while the queen was still alive). â€œThe Covid-19 virus isnâ€™t going away soon and will be with us for months if not years,â€ Morton said.
â€œThe brutal truth is that her reign is effectively over,â€ he added. â€œCovid-19 has done more damage to the monarchy than Oliver Cromwell.â€
At the time, Buckingham Palace told HuffPost, â€œThe Queen continues to be busy and will follow appropriate advice on engagements.â€
Though it might seem like this particular pandemic could prematurely end Queen Elizabethâ€™s reign, the monarchy has survived worse.

Carolyn Harris, author of â€œRaising Royalty: 1000 Years of Royal Parentingâ€ who also runs royalhistorian.com, notes that British royalty has been through public health crises before. Call it another annus horribilis.

â€œThere have been monarchs in the past who have reigned during periods of plague and pandemic,â€ Harris told HuffPost, pointing to King Edward III, who lost three of his dozen children to the Black Death plague in the mid-14th century.

â€œIn the early 1660s, there were numerous outbreaks of plague in Restoration London, especially the Great Plague of 1665, during the reign of Charles II,â€ she said, which drove the king and his court out of the city for months.
â€œFor centuries, the monarch has faced the challenge of acting as a unifying force while remaining in comparative seclusion during times of plague and pandemic,â€ said Harris.
Windsor Castle hardly represents a flight from the queenâ€™s duties either. Harris said it is â€œa place that symbolizes the continuity of the monarchy over the past thousand years.â€

â€œWindsor Castle has existed since the Norman Conquest (though it has been renovated and rebuilt many times since then, most recently after the fire of 1992) and the reigning dynasty also took its name from the castle in 1917,â€ the author noted.

Harris predicts that one of the queenâ€™s first public engagements again will be coronavirus-related and deal with essential workers, just like Prince William, Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwallâ€™s first events out of quarantine.

â€œThe Queen will probably meet with health care workers and other first responders to thank them for their efforts during the pandemic,â€ she said. â€œThe Queen may also want to meet with individuals who contracted the illness and recovered in order to hear about their experiences.â€

Throughout the past few months, weâ€™ve heard little about the queenâ€™s own experience with the pandemic and only seen one in-person event, when she knighted Capt. Tom Moore at Windsor. But William Hanson, etiquette coach and executive director of The English Manner, described it as a sign of sacrifice that Elizabeth has limited her in-person engagements and carried on without a word of public complaint.

â€œBy The Queen scaling back her commitments, making big changes to her lifestyle, she once again sets the tone for the nations over which she reigns,â€ he said. â€œIf The Sovereign can make personal sacrifices and not see her family and friends without grumbling, so can the rest of us.â€

While itâ€™s unlikely that the queen will return to Buckingham Palace before the end of the year, the Sunday Times expects that she will still head to her Sandringham estate for the Christmas holiday.

If the queen needs any guidance as to what she should say in her annual Christmas address this year, she can look for inspiration from her famous â€œAnnus Horribilisâ€ speech in 1992 â€• the year in which a fire destroyed 115 rooms in Windsor Castle; Sarah, Duchess of York was caught in a toe-sucking scandal; and the queenâ€™s three oldest children announced they were separating from or divorcing their spouses. That November, the queen said:

1992 is not a year on which I shall look back with undiluted pleasure. In the words of one of my more sympathetic correspondents, it has turned out to be an â€œAnnus Horribilis.â€ I suspect that I am not alone in thinking it so. Indeed, I suspect that there are very few people or institutions unaffected by these last months of worldwide turmoil and uncertainty.

In the meantime, as Hugo Vickers, a broadcaster, royal biographer and author of â€œThe Crown Dissected,â€ told HuffPost, it is important to take as many precautions as possible to safeguard the health of the queen and the Duke of Edinburgh. Not just because theyâ€™re royal, but because theyâ€™re in a vulnerable age group.

â€œUnder normal circumstances, we would not be wondering why two nonagenarians were living quietly,â€ he said, adding that the queen â€œshould not emerge until it is known that it is safe, and that may be a long time off.â€
Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: Pro-Cop Rally Draws Scores To Kenosha Amid Protests Against Police Violence
otherData.short_description: The rally pushed back on the Wisconsin city's protests against police brutality and racial injustice happening daily since police shot Jacob Blake this month.
otherData.authors: Jennifer Peltz and Russell Contreras, AP

articleContent: KENOSHA, Wis. (AP) â€” Scores of police supporters gathered Sunday in downtown Kenosha where protesters have been demonstrating against police brutality since the shooting of Jacob Blake last weekend.
Some attending the rally in the Wisconsin city wore â€œback the blueâ€ shirts. Others carried American flags. They applauded when law enforcement vehicles rolled by.

â€œWith the things that they face on a daily basis, they need that little extra push of love and to show that they are needed,â€ said Jennifer Peyton, 44, who attended the rally. â€œI mean, if you went in to work every day, and you were told that you were bad or had things thrown at you, I think it would weigh on your psyche a little bit, too.â€
A Kenosha police officer shot Blake in the back Aug. 23, leaving the 29-year-old Black man paralyzed.

Protesters have marched in Kenosha every night since Blakeâ€™s shooting, with some protests devolving into unrest that damaged buildings and vehicles. Authorities say a teenager from northern Illinois shot and killed two protesters in Kenosha on Tuesday night.
A 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. state of emergency curfew that was set to expire Sunday has been extended through 7 a.m. Wednesday, the Kenosha County sheriffâ€™s office said.
Blakeâ€™s shooting sparked renewed protests against racial injustice and police brutality several months after George Floydâ€™s May 25 death touched off a wider reckoning on race.
Floyd, another Black man, was handcuffed and died after a Minneapolis officer pressed his knee into Floydâ€™s neck.
Blake was shot after three Kenosha officers responded to a domestic dispute call.

In cellphone video recorded by a bystander, Blake walks from the sidewalk around the front of an SUV to his driver-side door as officers follow him with their guns drawn and shout at him. As Blake opens the door and leans into the SUV, an officer grabs his shirt from behind and opens fire. Three of Blakeâ€™s children were in the vehicle.
City officials have identified Rusten Sheskey as the officer who shot Blake.
The Kenosha police union said Blake had a knife and fought with officers. State investigators have said only that officers found a knife on the floor of the car.
Blake is being treated in a hospital. His father, Jacob Blake Sr., said heâ€™s paralyzed from the waist down.

Ben Crump, an attorney for the family, told CBSâ€™ â€œFace the Nationâ€ on Sunday that the younger Blake suffered â€œcatastrophic injuriesâ€ that include a pierced spinal cord and shattered vertebrae. He has lost his colon and most of his intestine, Crump said.
Like Floydâ€™s death, Blakeâ€™s shooting has fueled a national movement against police brutality and the slayings of Black people by law enforcement officers.
The movement has further exposed deep divisions in the country.

Some people at Sundayâ€™s rally signed petitions urging the recall of Gov. Tony Evers and Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes, both Democrats, and added messages of support on handwritten posters thanking police as heroes.
About 1,000 people attended a rally to protest police violence Saturday.
The cityâ€™s mayor, John Antaramian, said Sunday that he will ask the state for $30 million to rebuild parts of Kenosha destroyed or damaged by the violence, according to the Kenosha News.

President Donald Trump has spoken out against the summer-long protests. He is expected to visit Kenosha on Tuesday to meet with law enforcement and survey damage from the demonstrations. Barnes indicated that Trump may not be welcome.

â€œI donâ€™t know how, given any of the previous statements that the president made, that he intends to come here to be helpful and we absolutely donâ€™t need that right now,â€ Barnes told CNN on Sunday.
Crump said the Blake family â€œhas not been contacted at this timeâ€ by Trump.

On Sunday, some Kenosha residents gathered around a Family Dollar as volunteers passed out donations and painted messages of peace on boarded up buildings. A DJ played house music and hip-hop while volunteers danced, wearing masks to protect against the coronavirus.
â€œI needed this today,â€ said David Sanchez, 66, who is retired. â€œI went to church this morning and it was all about Jacob Blake and his family. Itâ€™s 100% positive.â€
Sanchez said the Blake shooting forced Kenosha to â€œcome out of the closet.â€
â€œThereâ€™s been a lot of prejudice here, for years,â€ said Sanchez, whose family relocated to San Antonio, Texas, in the 1950s. â€œWe need to confront it.â€

otherData.headline: The VMAs Went Virtual, But The Stars Dressed Up Anyway: See All The Looks
otherData.short_description: No red carpet? No problem! Celebrities still brought their fashion A-game from home to Sunday night's show.

articleContent: No, not even a pandemic could stop the stars celebrating the 2020 MTV Video Music Awards from dressing up in epic outfits â€• some from the comfort of their own homes, some socially distanced on the red carpet.

The showâ€™s primary broadcast aired live from New York City, with some celebrities IRL and many others serving serious looks on social media.

Hereâ€™s what our favorite artists brought to the unconventional VMAs.

otherData.headline: Dem Rep Warns Trump's Kenosha Visit Is Meant To 'Agitate' And 'Make Things Worse'
otherData.short_description: Rep. Karen Bass said Sunday that Trump's scheduled visit to Wisconsin in the wake of protests against police brutality is meant to cause harm.

articleContent: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMPâ€™S motives for a planned visit to Kenosha, Wisconsin, this week are already being called into question. The White House announced Saturday that the president intends to visit Wisconsin following the police shooting of a Black man, Jacob Blake, and the filing of charges against a Trump supporter suspected of killing two protesters who gathered on Blakeâ€™s behalf.
On Sunday, California Rep. Karen Bass (D) said Trumpâ€™s plan to visit Kenosha on Tuesday serves â€œone purpose and one purpose only, and that is to agitate things and to make things worse.â€
Wisconsin Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes also commented Sunday about the pending visit, saying the people of the state â€œdonâ€™t need that right now.â€

The state attorney general on Wednesday identified the officer who shot Blake as Rusten Sheskey. Blake, 29, was shot in the back at least seven times as he walked away from police and tried to enter his car. Blakeâ€™s children were in the back seat when he was shot, and his attorney says Blake is now paralyzed from the waist down.

Blakeâ€™s shooting ignited protests for racial justice in Wisconsin, much like similar protests that have been smoldering around the United States following the widely publicized police killings of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor months ago. On Tuesday, Gov. Tony Evers (D) declared a state of emergency as protesters clashed with police through the night and armed vigilantes with assault rifles arrived on the scene, characterizing themselves as a pro-police presence. That night, two protesters were killed. A 17-year-old from Illinois has been charged in the deaths.

The suspected shooter has been celebrated by prominent conservative figures, including Fox News anchor Tucker Carlson. On Sunday, the president liked a tweet celebrating the teen â€• who was once pictured in the front row of a Trump rally â€• and justifying why people like him vote for Trump. The president was far more reserved in discussing Blakeâ€™s shooting by police, saying Friday he will â€œpretty soonâ€ announce whether he thinks police were justified in shooting Blake seven times.

On Saturday, the White House said Trump plans to speak with law enforcement and survey property damage during his visit to Kenosha. Blakeâ€™s family members said Friday they had not heard from the White House and didnâ€™t know of any plans for Trump to meet them.

Trumpâ€™s hypocrisy when it comes to violence isnâ€™t new. He has eagerly stoked and celebrated racist violence when it has served him politically. Before this week, the most glaring example of such allyship was, perhaps, his claim that some of the white supremacists who gathered in Charlottesville, Virginia, in 2017 were â€œvery fine people.â€

But Trump has leaned more heavily into white grievance politics since then. Particularly, as polls have continued to show him trailing Democrat Joe Biden in the presidential race, Trump has used the levers of government more overtly to incite and inflict fear and violence on his political rivals.

As protests against police violence toward Blake were ramping up this week, Trump was accepting the Republican Partyâ€™s nomination for president on the White House lawn, during a convention designed to inflame white anxiety over racial justice movements. Throughout the week, prominent GOP politicians touted Trumpâ€™s respect for â€œlaw and order,â€ but others highlighted during the Republican National Convention revealed the racist contradiction in their message.
Two featured speakers were a white couple charged with unlawful gun use after aiming weapons at racial justice protesters in their neighborhood in St. Louis.

â€œThey are not satisfied with spreading the chaos and violence into our communities. They want to abolish the suburbs altogether by ending single-family home zoning,â€ Patricia McCloskey said during a video she filmed with her husband, Mark.
â€œThese are the policies that are coming to a neighborhood near you. So make no mistake: No matter where you live, your family will not be safe in the radical Democratsâ€™ America,â€ she added.
During his closing RNC speech on Thursday, Trump used similar language to instill fear in Americans over movements for racial justice in cities across the U.S.

â€œIn the strongest possible terms, the Republican Party condemns the rioting, looting, arson and violence we have seen in Democrat-run cities like Kenosha, Minneapolis, Portland, Chicago and New York,â€ he said.

Although anti-racist protests have gained traction in every state since June, Trumpâ€™s focus on demonizing specific cities is heightening concern that Kenosha â€• like Portland and Washington, D.C., recently â€• will become the latest stage for Trumpâ€™s desperate, political show of force.

otherData.headline: Trump DOJ Targets Democratic Governors For COVID-19 Outbreaks In Veterans Homes
otherData.short_description: "This really does smell," said one former Civil Rights Division official who worries the Justice Department is weaponizing its power for political purposes.

articleContent: President Donald Trumpâ€™s top civil rights official at the Department of Justice announced this week that he was considering launching investigations into how state-owned nursing homes responded to the coronavirus.
