What coronavirus questions are on your mind right now? We want to help you find answers.

Everyone deserves accurate information about COVID-19. Support journalism without a paywall â€” and keep it free for everyone â€” by becoming a HuffPost member today.

Experts are still learning about the novel coronavirus. The information in this story is what was known or available as of press time, but it's possible guidance around COVID-19 could change as scientists discover more about the virus. Please check the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the most updated recommendations.

otherData.headline: Can A Book Club Fight Racism?
otherData.short_description: White people are turning to anti-racist reading groups to make sense of this moment â€” and, they hope, to make change.

articleContent: This summer, as Black Lives Matter protesters dodged rubber bullets fired by police and Black and brown communities were hit hard by COVID-19, book clubs sprang into being, and into action.

Shoshanna Hecht, an executive and personal coach from New York City, had just joined a book club themed around racial justice in March; she also signed up for a Zoom study group that would complete Layla F. Saadâ€™s â€œMe and White Supremacyâ€ workbook together. Joanna Mang, an adjunct English instructor in North County San Diego, was invited to join a new book club, called the Equity Re-Education Discussion Group, by a friend from her Stroller Strides group.

Jaâ€™Rod Morris, founder of the Atlanta-based book club Black Men Read, didnâ€™t have to form a new group. â€œThe truth is, we have been having these conversations about police brutality,â€ he told HuffPost. Though the club was designed for literary discussion rather than activism, any space where Black people gather, he said, is a good space for political mobilization. â€œWeâ€™re on the front lines. We are the subject of this.â€ As the protests broke out, he called a â€œstate of emergencyâ€ meeting to discuss how members could get involved.
Many white Americans, however, have not been having these conversations. The protests following the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis seem to have changed that.

â€œI have been very, very surprised by the apparently sudden outpouring on the parts of what appears to be millions of people, many of them white, who realize, wow, we have a lot of work to do, we have a lot we need to learn in order to do that work,â€ said Dr. Crystal Marie Fleming, author of â€œHow to Be Less Stupid About Race: On Racism, White Supremacy, and the Racial Divide.â€

Since late May, it seems like every well-meaning, left-leaning white person in America has been trying to get their hands on a copy of â€œWhite Fragilityâ€ by Robin DiAngelo. Or â€œHow to Be an Antiracistâ€ by Ibram X. Kendi. Or â€œSo You Want to Talk About Raceâ€ by Ijeoma Oluo. Or, hey, maybe all of them. Anti-racist manuals have been cleaned out from virtual bookstore shelves and pushed to the top of bestseller lists.
And often, these buyers donâ€™t want to read alone. Enter the anti-racist book club.

Anti-racist book clubs hold great allure, and potentially great power, at a moment when many, particularly white people, are becoming conscious of their own educational blind spots around Black history and racial justice. Book clubs sit at a slippery nexus between education and relaxation, radicalization and affirmation; thereâ€™s a vibrant history of reading groups expanding peopleâ€™s political consciousness and moving them to action, but also a deeply entrenched tradition of book clubs for white women as social spaces. This tension likely makes them an appealing starting point for people who want to dip their toes into the struggle for perhaps the first time, in a setting that theyâ€™re familiar with. The real test, of course, will be what comes next, once the book club attendees have gotten their feet wet with some radical reading.

The problem of white supremacy, said Dr. Fleming, a professor of sociology at Stonybrook University, â€œis not something that an anti-racist reading group will fix. Itâ€™s something an anti-racist reading group can help facilitate.â€ To make change, people will need to leave the warm uteri of their reading circles and put their knowledge into bold, concrete action.

â€œWe have definitely seen a surge of interest in group reading for our anti-racist titles,â€ Sanj Kharbanda, sales and marketing director at Beacon Press, told HuffPost. Beacon publishes numerous anti-racism books, including â€œWhite Fragilityâ€ and Flemingâ€™s â€œHow to Be Less Stupid About Race.â€ He noted that this interest came from â€œtraditional book groupsâ€ as well as clubs newly formed to discuss race. Churches, universities and bookstores have launched anti-racist book clubs (often virtual, in deference to social distancing measures); friends are organizing reading groups among their social circles.

Though itâ€™s impossible to know exactly who is joining these groups, or even how widespread they are, it seems likely that those turning to literary discussion are disproportionately people who already participate in book clubs: mostly women, mostly well-educated, and mostly in their 30s or older. What could be more natural for a white woman who already belongs to a book club with her friends to ask that â€œHow to Be an Antiracistâ€ be the focus of next monthâ€™s meeting, or to start a spinoff group?

â€œA lot of people, a lot of college-educated women, seem to be attacking this problem from the books angle. What if I amass a lot of books â€” this has to be a way in,â€ Mang said. â€œTheyâ€™re realizing that, now is a time that I need to be reading.â€

But reading what? Despite the proliferation of reading lists, even picking the right book to read leaves some feeling paralyzed. More than one person HuffPost spoke to mentioned â€œWhite Fragility,â€ and the competing recommendations to read it (because it introduces white people to methods for decentering themselves during conversations about racism) and to not read it (because, among other concerns, it perpetuates the centering of whiteness and white feelings itself).

Mang, who has taught racial justice texts as a college instructor, had some pedagogical quibbles with â€œWhite Fragilityâ€; she considers it dry, corporate jargon that does little to convey the urgent moral clarity of the issues to readers. Nevertheless, her club ended up reading it for their first meeting, and she was struck by the resulting discussion. â€œWhile I think â€˜White Fragilityâ€™ is a silly book,â€ Mang said, â€œI think it could be a gateway.â€ Her group, populated with affluent, mostly white women, felt ready to get more radical in their reading afterward.

Kate Dearing, a TV writer based in Los Angeles, said that her club eased into things as well, reading â€œStamped,â€ the young readers adaptation of Ibram X. Kendiâ€™s â€œStamped From the Beginningâ€ by Kendi and Jason Reynolds. Her clubmate, Sami Kriegstein Jacobson, a creative consultant in New York, said there was an unexpected upside to the choice.

â€œAfter reading this book, I felt so frustrated at my own middle school and high school education,â€ said Kriegstein Jacobson, who attended a prestigious East Coast boarding school. â€œThere was so much that was new to me in what was this actually very simple book that was meant for kids that age.â€

She was so frustrated that she responded to the schoolâ€™s latest donation solicitation by writing back to ask them what they were doing to decolonize the curriculum and to hire and retain teachers of color. â€œIt made me glad that my eyes are open and that I could do something about it. I donâ€™t know if we had started with a more rigorous book if I would have made the connection of, we should have been taught this so much earlier in life.â€

For several years, the Bay Area chapter of Showing Up for Racial Justice (SURJ), a national organization which focuses on bringing white people into the struggle against white supremacy, has hosted study and action groups for allies looking to learn and get involved. Their ever-evolving, carefully designed curriculum goes a bit deeper than the most frequently recommended texts for beginners.

â€œWe lean more towards articles, videos, speeches, relatively short pieces that we can group together,â€ Lizzie Humphries, one of the organizers behind the study and action reading group program, told HuffPost.

In shaping the curriculum, she and her fellow organizers were inspired by Black Panther study and struggle groups: spaces for learning and developing a shared political language that were inextricably connected to the on-the-ground work. Though the SURJ Bay Area groups do use â€œWhite Fragilityâ€ and other texts about how white people experience white supremacy, she said, â€œwe really focus on pieces by authors of color.â€ Authors like James Baldwin and texts like the policy platform for the Movement for Black Lives, she said, â€œare really the central texts of the reading group.â€

This focus, Fleming said, is key. Though â€œwhite anti-racists have a very important role to play in promoting anti-racist change,â€ she told HuffPost, â€œIf your antiracist reading group or your antiracist initiative is not centering the work of Black people, indigenous people, and people of color, then theyâ€™re not antiracist.â€

In choosing books to study, Carla Bruce-Eddings, a writer and senior publicist at Catapult/Counterpoint/Soft Skull Press, urged readers to â€œlook to the work of queer Black women; they have been paving the way for radical thinking for generations.â€

While curating the right curriculum is valuable, itâ€™s not a panacea. â€œThereâ€™s no anti-racism checklist. Itâ€™s not something that can be mastered by reading a couple of books and itâ€™s not something that can be bought,â€ anti-racist author and educator Tiffany Jewell said. Though sometimes, unsettlingly, it seems as though many white people believe otherwise. In a rich landscape of social justice literature, the skyrocketing sales of certain titles suggest not merely an eagerness to learn, but perhaps an almost talismanic attitude toward the most-recommended hits.

To see such a flurry of interest in anti-racist learning has been heartening for some. But for others, the timing and the type of action looks suspicious. As critic and academic Lauren Michele Jackson argued in a skeptical piece on the anti-racist reading list phenomenon in Vulture, the very word â€œanti-racistâ€ â€œsuggests something of a vanity project, where the goal is no longer to learn more about race, power, and capital, but to spring closer to the enlightened order of the anti-racist.â€

This impression has only grown as Black booksellers have reported that customers have been quick to berate them for not shipping backordered titles popularized by these reading lists quickly enough. When I reached out to one Black-owned bookstore for this piece, an autoreply email responded that there would be a â€œSIGNIFICANT DELAYâ€ in response time and asked for patience, as they were overwhelmed filling orders for in-demand anti-racist titles.

In July, Sruti Islam, events coordinator at Librairie Saint-Henri Books in Montreal, tweeted that after people had flooded the store with orders for anti-racist literature, they were failing to pick up their reserves; the tweet went viral. (After her tweet, she told HuffPost in an email, the storeâ€™s regulars â€œswiftly sent folks to pick up the remaining stock,â€ and the problem has not persisted.)

Besides, amid historic nationwide uprisings demanding an end to police brutality against Black people, surely buying a book or two is a tepid reaction to the state-sanctioned violence on display. Buying a book isnâ€™t revolutionary; itâ€™s easy, even a bit indulgent. In one sense, itâ€™s a consumerist response to a crisis that calls for something deeper: putting bodies on the line. As writer Kelsey McKinney argued in June, turning to book purchases and book clubs can be a way of staying self-centered, of channeling newly aroused anxiety about racism back into spending money on yourself, spending time thinking and talking about yourself, and adding a new social activity to the calendar.

But there are practical reasons for many people to join a reading group as a way into, or a supplement to, anti-racist work. A deeper understanding of white supremacy and Black struggle can make newbies more adept at the nitty-gritty work, and forming bonds with like-minded people is a great basis for organizing. â€œIâ€™m glad that white people are doing the work,â€ Bruce-Eddings told HuffPost. â€œTheyâ€™re late, but I hope theyâ€™re reckoning with that too.â€

Islam told HuffPost that Librairie Saint-Henri Books held outdoor, socially distanced book club meetings specifically in response to the demand for anti-racist literature. â€œWe were concerned that people would be buying the books, Instagramming the books, and never actually engaging with the books,â€ she explained. â€œWe wanted to bring back the book club in order to hold ourselves and these readers accountable.â€

As white people grapple with the inadequacy of their good intentions and look into doing anti-racist work, many come to realize that one crucial form of it is countering racism within their own friend groups and families, as well as their own hearts and minds.

â€œWe need to take initiative within our circles,â€ Kriegstein Jacobson said. â€œItâ€™s our job to make sure to not only hold ourselves accountable but our friends, our families, our schools, our places of work.â€

Being an effective advocate, however, requires a depth of knowledge that many are lacking. â€œA lot of people have more conservative family members and friends and they want to be able to talk to them,â€ said Mang of her book club. â€œSomeone will say something, or write something on Facebook, and theyâ€™ll think, this feels wrong, but I donâ€™t know what to say.â€

Dearing said that in the past she found herself often staying silent instead of speaking up about racism she encountered because â€œI felt I didnâ€™t know enough, that I didnâ€™t know where I fit or how this would be useful or enough context, so I got scared that I would be called out.â€ Forming the book club was a way of building her resolve and her arsenal so that she would be prepared to, as she quoted late Rep. John Lewis, â€œmake good trouble.â€

A book club can provide a richer experience than just reading a book â€” a setting in which to practice having those tough conversations, other people to call you on your errors, and solidarity to strengthen your dedication. And, temptingly, it can mingle the tough intellectual work with social connection. This balance of joyful togetherness and political engagement can be valuable, said Bruce-Eddings, who has worked as books editor and helped plan festivals for the popular club Well-Read Black Girl.

â€œI think both things can happen simultaneously, and in fact, I think itâ€™s more impactful when they do,â€ she said. She recalled her first Well-Read Black Girl meeting, where serious conversation about how the women could take action to change their lives was intermingled with lighthearted gossip and laughter. â€œAs a Black woman, Iâ€™ve grown up very accustomed to witnessing and partaking in moments like this: the joy is inextricable from the pain, but that makes it all the sweeter. Political work has to be grounded in our humanity, otherwise itâ€™s simply hypothetical; meaningless.â€

As white people join anti-racist book clubs, the ideal approach may look a bit different. â€œA book club that is for Black women is going to have a completely different purpose than a book club for white people focused on their own [and small-group] learning/unlearning,â€ Jewell pointed out.

And the cozy kaffeeklatsch vibe may be too cozy to keep a predominantly white club serious. Imagine a book club full of well-off white women, nursing glasses of Pinot and plates of banana bread, the prototypical American book club: It doesnâ€™t seem like the prime setting for harsh callouts. â€œIn our dominant white culture, conflict, disagreement, the feeling of discomfort, those are all really unusual things to happen in a book club,â€ Humphries said. â€œAnd I think there needs to be room for those things in this kind of book club.â€

Though Jewell said she hoped white anti-racist reading groups could stay on task and avoid becoming an unchallenging space for members, she expressed skepticism that this would be the case. â€œIâ€™m not sure this is what is happening,â€ she said. â€œI have noticed how quickly the stamina of a lot of white people who seemed fully outraged in early June has waned.â€

Morris, the founder of Black Men Read, suggested that having Black people present was important to counter the drift into ease. â€œWhat I caution folks to do, if white people are going to be putting together book clubs to read books about Black stories: Donâ€™t get caught in your bubble,â€ Morris said. He suggested inviting Black friends to offer their perspective, and not requiring them to complete the reading. â€œA white-only group, it just satisfies your comfort level.â€

Thereâ€™s no one simple answer, however, to this problem. While inviting Black friends may prevent white people from lapsing into mutual reassurance, it also demands a great deal from those Black friends â€• as does, as Rachel Charlene Lewis argued in Bitch, asking Black people for reading recommendations and tips for oneâ€™s book club. Bruce-Eddings noted that she was glad to see white people â€œplace the onus of this education and radicalization on themselves, rather than reach out to the Black people in their lives for hand-holding and emotional excavation for the sake of their guilt.â€ She added, â€œI understand the intent, but it does more damage than they realize.â€

For Dearing and Kriegstein Jacobson, the latter concern was front of mind. â€œKate and I have talked a lot about not wanting to put that educational burden on someone who is living this every day. It doesnâ€™t feel right,â€ Kriegstein Jacobson said. â€œI wouldnâ€™t want to bring a Black person or BIPOC [Black, Indigenous, or other people of color] person into this space this early on. Personally I feel like we are way too novice and clumsy. Weâ€™re like a toddler thatâ€™s running around the house and falling down and breaking shit.â€

In their group, they said, theyâ€™re trying to cultivate an ethos of resisting white fragility and calling each other out. â€œMy hope for this was that we hold each other accountable in this group,â€ Dearing said. â€œI think there is that desire. Iâ€™m sure we will still, in our whiteness, miss things.â€

A firm structure can help maintain focus, and resources abound for groups who want to guard against attention drift. Humphries suggested that groups studying independently should find a curriculum to follow. Hechtâ€™s â€œMe and White Supremacyâ€ Zoom discussion group follows the textâ€™s suggestion of using the Circle Way method (including assigning members to roles like â€œscribeâ€ and â€œguardianâ€) to keep discussions on track. â€œThere isnâ€™t chitchat about our lives,â€ she said. â€œSome fragility has maybe come up, and itâ€™s had to get dealt with, and itâ€™s taken very seriously.â€

But no matter how well-intentioned or determined, â€œwhite people cannot hold each other accountable for ending white supremacy,â€ Fleming said. â€œThis is something that requires a shift of power relation.â€ For white people looking for genuine growth and accountability around racial justice, she argued, itâ€™s vital to seek out guidance and teaching from Black communities and communities of color. Seeking that guidance ethically may be a daunting task, but she suggested getting involved with or taking cues from existing groups for white people involved in antiracism, like SURJ, to learn how to appropriately approach and compensate speakers and educators who are Black and people of color.

â€œSURJ develops these really deep and powerful relationships of accountability with organizations that are led by people of color. Our chapter has like 16 organizations that really set our agenda,â€ Humphries explained. â€œI think there is a pattern around which kind of study groups are really radical and transformative, that is connected to the way that those groups are happening in the setting of an organization or some kind of organized movement space.â€

Joining a local organization with ties like this, she said, can make sure readers are held accountable â€” not just for what they say during meetings, but for how they channel their study into action.

The study and action program at SURJ Bay Area, as indicated by its name, is intentionally structured to integrate hands-on work into the conversation. Each meeting follows a â€œthree-part framework for personal transformation that draws on your heart, your head and your hand,â€ Humphries said. In addition to exploring a deep spiritual and emotional response to the reading, and to intellectual discussion of what theyâ€™re learning, each meeting the members discuss future action they can take and check in on whether they followed through on past commitments.

â€œI think what feels different about just starting a book club amongst friends, is it feels disconnected from the hand work that is already happening in a local area,â€ cautioned Humphries. â€œEspecially because I do think that there is a cultural tendency amongst white people to stay up in our heads about things, to really only do the head piece of the work. It does help to be in the context of a movement to help move you toward a heart and a hand piece.â€

Those solitary study groups may provide some shared motivation to take action, however. â€œThe woman who invited me to the group, she was like, I feel like we need to use our Karen power to do something,â€ Mang said. â€œWe donâ€™t know what it is. We know we have this power. And we know we need to use it.â€
At their best, anti-racist book clubs can push members to think of ways to help â€” and to actually show up â€” instead of turning into solipsistic self-help circles.

â€œIf you have time to read, youâ€™re probably in a decent space in your life,â€ Morris said. â€œSo what Iâ€™m trying to push the guys to do is for us to continue to do what we can with the power we have, the success that weâ€™ve had in life, to leverage our positions to help bring other people up.â€

At Black Men Readâ€™s emergency meeting, they discussed how members of different generations and backgrounds felt inspired to pitch in, and Morris took notes on the resources and ideas that came out of it to send to all the clubâ€™s members: a list of Georgia state representatives to contact, a Black gun organization for those who want to responsibly get a firearm. â€œEveryone has to move the needle in their own way,â€ he said.
The white book clubbers buying up anti-racism manuals, meanwhile, are at least hearing the message that reading books does not count as doing the work.

â€œWhat we are learning from everything weâ€™re reading is that you canâ€™t be anti-racist devoid of action. You just kind of canâ€™t be,â€ said Kriegstein Jacobson. â€œIf you want to call yourself an anti-racist, it must include action with impact. Intention counts for very little.â€

Their group has become a space to share organizations that need donations or initiatives that could use a set of hands â€” and having like-minded people to volunteer and protest with can make getting involved look less intimidating and more sustainable.

â€œYouâ€™re connecting people who have never been politically active to people who have been politically active before,â€ said Mang, who had her own awakening after the 2016 election. The newcomers hear about their friends calling members of Congress, attending protests, and speaking up at city council meetings. â€œYou influence them to do those things too. Things they want to do, but feel shy.â€

The book club itself, the people I spoke to emphasized, is not a wormhole into an antiracist future or a tool for easing oneâ€™s own guilt, nor is it a version of doing the work. Though there are pitfalls that are important to avoid in creating and running such a group, the most central is ensuring that the book club doesnâ€™t become a cul de sac for activist urges.
â€œBooks are a great way to begin a journey,â€ Jewell said. â€œThey should not be the end goal.â€

otherData.headline: Here Are Affordable Lookalikes To Michelle Obama's "VOTE" Necklace
otherData.short_description: The necklace the former first lady wore for her DNC speech retails for $295. If you like the look but don't have that much to spend right now, here are some affordable alternatives.

articleContent: HuffPost may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Prices and availability subject to change.
Michelle Obama sure knows how to make a fashion statement.
Her latest internet-breaking message came in the form of a 14-karat gold â€œVOTEâ€ necklace the former first lady wore during her speech at the 2020 Democratic National Convention on Monday night.

Searches for Obamaâ€™s necklace later sent the internet ablaze. As HuffPost previously reported, the necklace is designed by ByChari, a Black-owned jewelry brand, and retails starting at $295. It comes in three colors, and you can adjust the length and letter sizes â€” even add diamonds.

The former First Lady has a record of making headlines for her fashion choices â€” inspiring trends and advocating for young designers. The â€œBecomingâ€ author even talks in her book about how fashion became a vehicle for conveying important messages during her time in the White House â€” and it appears that sentiment hasnâ€™t changed.
Obamaâ€™s â€œVOTEâ€ necklace is a stunning accessory that serves as a not-so-subtle reminder to those around you to get out and vote.

Weâ€™re obsessed with this necklace, and adding it to your collection is a great opportunity to support a creator of color. However, if thatâ€™s a little outside your budget, we found some similar alternatives that you can wear to send the same message.

Many of these finds come from small businesses on Etsy that will allow you to personalize the jewelry with custom engravings or stamps, too. That includes the Etsy shop The Pink Locket â€” one of our favorite Black-owned Etsy jewelry shops.

otherData.headline: How To Get Michelle Obama's 'Vote' Necklace
otherData.short_description: The necklace, designed by Black-owned jewelry brand ByChari, went viral during the Democratic National Convention.

articleContent: Michelle Obama has used fashion to send subtle messages through the years. Her most recent look was a bit more straightforward.

Obama spoke at the digital Democratic National Convention on Monday night wearing a â€œVoteâ€ necklace from ByChari, a Black-owned jewelry brand. The necklace is available in different colors and sizes, starting at $295.

If searches for the necklace are indicative of voting trends this election, it will have done its job. According to Google Trends, it was the â€œtop trending search on all of U.S. Google in the last hour of the event.â€
Once people realized what the necklace said and it was ID-ed on social media, it took no time for people to start obsessing over it.
One Twitter user had some keen words of fundraising advice for the Biden campaign.

â€œI had created a VOTE necklace for the last election and knew I was going to do it again,â€ ByChari said in an email via a brand representative. â€œAs we started our outreach, I was honored when Michelle Obamaâ€™s Stylist asked for one and am thrilled she is wearing it!â€
When ByChari shared the necklace in 2018, it came with a message too.

â€œI rarely voice my political views on social media, but there is too much at risk for us as women and individuals to not do our part,â€ the brand wrote on Instagram. â€œI encourage everyone to go out and vote tomorrow. Make your voice heard.â€

Obama didnâ€™t let her necklace do all the inspiring, though. During her speech, in which she called Donald Trump the â€œwrong president for our country,â€ she encouraged voters to come out with the same enthusiasm as they did for her husband during his two presidential elections.

â€œWe have got to vote like we did in 2008 and 2012,â€ she said. â€œWeâ€™ve got to show up with the same level of passion and hope for Joe Biden. Weâ€™ve got to vote early, in person if we can. Weâ€™ve got to request our mail-in ballots right now, tonight, and send them back immediately and follow up to make sure theyâ€™re received. And then, make sure our friends and families do the same.â€
Heard, seen and understood.
You can watch her entire speech below and get a â€œVoteâ€ necklace of your own from ByChari.

otherData.headline: An Elite Consulting Firm Said 'Black Lives Matter,' But Staffers Never Got The Message
otherData.short_description: Partners at Red Associates described Black women as â€œangryâ€ and â€œscary,â€ and one person was asked to use eugenicist-approved â€œThe Bell Curveâ€ in research.

articleContent: After four months of working for the small management consulting firm Red Associates in New York City, Funke Sangodeyi felt like something was â€œoff.â€

Sangodeyi, who has a bachelorâ€™s degree and a Ph.D. from Harvard and a masterâ€™s from Cambridge, was at a company retreat in the spring of 2015. There were workshops and team-building exercises typical of such gatherings. The setting was posh, the south of France, a couple of hours outside Nice, recalled Sangodeyi, who is Nigerian American and in her early 40s.

Then at a party one night at a villa overlooking the lush countryside, a senior manager, a white man, approached her. â€œOh my God, your skin is so dark,â€ Sangodeyi recalled him saying. â€œDoes it come in shades darker than yours?â€
She was shocked. â€œYou donâ€™t say that,â€ she told him. â€œItâ€™s a bizarre thing to say.â€
That was just the start of a disturbing few years for Sangodeyi at Red Associates, a management consulting firm based in Copenhagen and New York City that currently has 51 employees.

Red is small compared to competitors like McKinsey, but not insignificant; its clients have included global giants such as Lego, Facebook, Google, Samsung and the Ford Motor Company. Red is also partly owned by Cognizant, a multibillion-dollar, publicly traded global tech consultancy.
Like many consulting firms, Red markets itself as an elite group that offers brilliant insights. But a close look at the firm raises questions about what â€œeliteâ€ actually means.

HuffPost spoke with 11 former employees and others close to the firm, a mix of white and nonwhite men and women. Nine requested anonymity, fearing reprisals from the firm. Together, they paint a picture of a company led by mostly white partners, some of whom appear to view themselves as superior to people of other races, nationalities and classes.

Partners mocked the accents and appearance of Indian colleagues, characterized Black female employees as â€œangryâ€ and â€œscary,â€ and used stereotypes about Chinese people while doing work for clients in that country. Class distinctions were particularly fraught: One former employee says she was mocked for the brand of tea she drank.

â€œComments like these are of course completely inappropriate and wrong,â€ the company said in a statement to HuffPost. â€œThey do not reflect the culture of ReD where we value diversity of thought and experience.â€

These kinds of views seeped into the firmâ€™s work, when one partner became obsessed with â€œThe Bell Curve,â€ the widely discredited 1994 book that tries to link IQ and race, and pushed to research inherited intelligence for a prospective pitch to the Lego Foundation. (The research never made it to the company.)
Rhetoric vs. Reality

Redâ€™s story is not unusual: Corporate America likes to broadcast its commitment to diversity, but isnâ€™t exactly known as welcoming for people of color. A minuscule percentage of corporate leaders are Black. In a 2018 survey, 58% of workers of color said theyâ€™re always or often on guard against racist comments and behaviors. Outright racist comments, microaggressions and mistreatment are not uncommon, and little is done about it. The federal agency handling race discrimination complaints gets at least 100,000 each year, but most go nowhere.

As nationwide protests over police brutality and systemic racism swept the country this summer, companies around the world doubled down on promises to diversify their offices. Red Associates was no different. The firm posted on LinkedIn, declaring â€œBlack Lives Matterâ€ and decrying systemic racism.
Current and former employees were stunned at the hypocrisy. The post prompted Sangodeyi to reach out to HuffPost.

Red told HuffPost that it cares â€œdeeply about racial justiceâ€ and employs people with diverse backgrounds. â€œ[W]e are continually striving to build an ever more diverse collective of thinkers, in particular through the addition of more Black voices,â€ the firm said.
Most of the leaders listed on the firmâ€™s website are white.

In recent years, Red has hired people of color at the entry level, particularly as some clients and junior staff complained about the lack of diversity. But those new hires have mostly left, and many felt beaten down, isolated and repelled by the culture. At least 13 people of color, including all of the firmâ€™s Black female employees, have either quit or say they were pushed out over the past two years.
Some close to the firm wonder if it could ever truly diversify.

â€œThe people who ran the company had a very narrow understanding of what it means to be elite, valuable and successful, and that was always being a white man,â€ said Luke Johnson, 26, who worked as a consultant at the firm from 2017 to 2018.

Eliot Brown, a partner at the firm who describes himself as â€œmixed black Trinidadian and British,â€ said he was surprised to hear that others werenâ€™t comfortable at Red. He has worked there since 2008.

â€œI believe that these people experienced what they claimed to experience, but itâ€™s a long way away from what I and many other people of color Iâ€™ve known at Red have experienced,â€ he told HuffPost. â€œThe whole thing is really upsetting to me because of that. I feel like a place that should at least be given a break for trying and possibly even celebrated for getting it right is being depicted as a place that intentionally got it so wrong. It feels unfair.â€
The firmâ€™s current managing partner, Millie Arora, is not white, and she told HuffPost that she realizes the firm can do better at diversity.

â€œAs an Indian American woman, as managing partner, it is one of my key priorities. Itâ€™s something we continuously want to do better at,â€ she said. â€œRecent events have prompted a lot more introspection.â€
â€˜A Notorious Elitistâ€™

Former employees and others close to the firm said its culture is exemplified by co-founder Christian Madsbjerg, a Danish man who has lived in New York City for years. He teaches at the New School and has written for the Financial Times, The Wall Street Journal and Quartz.
Johnson called Madsbjerg â€œa notorious elitistâ€ who is very much against what he perceives as political correctness, an attitude that prevails at the firm.
Johnson laid out why he was leaving Red in a 2018 email pointing to remarks Madsbjerg made that he believed were troubling.

In the email reviewed by HuffPost, Johnson said heâ€™d just heard Madsbjerg make â€œa seemingly off-hand, seemingly joking remark about how France and Germany are the only places â€˜where thereâ€™s any civilization left.â€™â€
Madsbjerg made the remark to a female partner at the firm and a new hire, a woman of color, as well as to Johnson, he wrote.
He said they laughed awkwardly. â€œOh just ignore the crazy old Dane,â€ the â€œclearly uncomfortableâ€ partner told the new consultant, according to Johnsonâ€™s email.

â€œBut Christian persisted,â€ he wrote, â€œinsisting that it wasnâ€™t just a jokeâ€•that he did indeed believe that thereâ€™s a small triangular region situated, of course, in Europe, where â€˜the only real valuable cultural and historical progress has happened.â€™â€ As an â€œafterthought,â€ Madsbjerg said Japan is included in this group, Johnson wrote.

He also wrote that heâ€™d heard Madsbjerg say of Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein, â€œNobody would have complained about Weinstein if he were attractive.â€ (Weinstein was convicted of rape in 2020.)

In the email, Johnson said comments like these were part of the reason he was leaving the company earlier than planned to go to graduate school. Those kinds of remarks made Red a â€œhostile placeâ€ for people who are not straight white men and could also turn off prospective clients, he wrote.

In a long statement to HuffPost, Madsbjerg insisted he was passionate about diversity. â€œI never in my wildest dreams thought that one day I would have to ward off allegations of bigotry,â€ he said, emphasizing that his wife is Muslim and that he converted to Islam. He also said he moved to the U.S. from Denmark to escape bigotry.
â€œI am perplexed and hurt by it,â€ he added. â€œIt is just not who I am.â€
â€˜The Bell Curveâ€™ Controversy

In 2018, according to several former employees and others close to the firm, Madsbjerg became â€œobsessedâ€ with â€œThe Bell Curve,â€ a widely discredited 1994 book by Charles Murray about inherited intelligence thatâ€™s favored by those who subscribe to racial eugenics. Madsbjerg pushed for research into the work, according to Johnson and several other former employees.

Madsbjerg assigned one of the firmâ€™s entry-level consultants to write up a research proposal citing Murrayâ€™s work, former employees said. He was particularly interested in the notion that intelligence is inherited, the consultant wrote in notes titled â€œQuick overview of what Christian askedâ€ that were shared with others at the firm at the time, and have since been obtained by HuffPost.
In another document, the consultant prepared more detailed notes and research about what he said he and Madsbjerg discussed.

â€œTask: write a 1 page memo to Lego Foundation convincing them to commit their time [and] money to promoting learning/development among the â€˜stupid,â€™â€ state the notes, also obtained by HuffPost, in a section titled â€œOverview.â€

In a list titled â€œFind information/figures Christian mentioned regarding,â€ the consultant included â€œThe Bell Curve,â€ â€œRacial correlationâ€ and â€œCoverup/repression (why it isnâ€™t popular in society today).â€

Deeper into the document, the consultant wrote: â€œPrivate note to Christian: weâ€™re putting ourselves out on a limb here. It wouldnâ€™t take much digging to find well-structured, empirically-reviewed studies that undermine the heritability of intelligence.â€ He then listed some citations.

Such a proposal is typically a first step in putting together a client pitch, and the consultant ultimately wrote a draft memo titled â€œAcknowledging Hard Truths To Discover New Solutions.â€ The memo, addressed to the CEO of the Lego Foundation and obtained by HuffPost, argues researchers have for years ignored the â€œinconvenient truthâ€ that intelligence is passed down genetically and social factors are less significant. It proposed that the Lego Foundation needed to acknowledge this in order to truly help children.

Lego has long been a client of Red, but the Lego Foundation did not ask for the research, Red Associates told HuffPost in a statement. The Lego Foundation confirmed that it had never asked for this material nor seen the memo.

The consultantâ€™s source materials delved into race and intelligence, but the draft memo HuffPost saw doesnâ€™t explicitly mention race. Still, itâ€™s the unavoidable subtext whenever the subject of heritable intelligence comes up, said Kathryn Paige Harden, a behavioral geneticist and a professor of psychology at the University of Texas at Austin.
â€œAnyone who talks about â€˜The Bell Curveâ€™ without addressing race, it feels like a dog whistle to me,â€ said Harden, who reviewed the draft memo for HuffPost.

Younger staff members at Red and a number of people of color at the company, aware of the yearslong controversy surrounding Murrayâ€™s work, spoke out against the research. At the height of the controversy, one consultant threw a copy of â€œThe Bell Curveâ€ in the trash in front of his colleagues and poured ranch dressing over it, according to one former employee.

Sangodeyi said she recalled a conversation with Madsbjerg at the time in which she told him that â€œdebates around IQ are racially charged in the U.S. and that the whole thing was extremely dicey to venture into.â€
In a statement, Madsbjerg said that he had little to do with the research and that heâ€™d never seen the memo until HuffPost asked about it.

As for â€œThe Bell Curve,â€ he said in the statement, â€œI didnâ€™t even know what it was until it was brought to my attention as part of general research conducted by a new consultant at ReD about how job automation and job loss might be predicted.â€

â€œIn Denmark, the debate about intelligence is not about race or ethnicity at all,â€ he said. â€œI find even the suggestion that there is any connection between race and intelligence repulsive, but also simply untrue.â€
Red also blamed the consultant who was tasked with writing the memo.

â€œ[T]his research was conducted by a staff person in an effort to understand the correlation between employment and IQ. After the research was complete and synthesized in a memo, it was dismissed as without merit,â€ the company said, emphasizing that the research was never shared outside the firm and that Red has never used it in any way.
But former employees said Madsbjerg initiated the research.

â€œI felt bad for the guy tasked with writing it,â€ said one former employee familiar with the project. â€œThese were not his views at all. This was not a consultant gone rogue. Instructions came from higher up.â€

Madsbjerg is no longer running the firm day to day, but he sits on its board and brings in business from prominent clients. He told HuffPost he takes â€œfull responsibilityâ€ for the firmâ€™s culture.

â€œFrom the beginning I wanted a global culture and I have tried to make sure that we transformed from a Danish to a global, generous culture the best we could,â€ he said. â€œThis was important to me for business reasons, but also because it reflects my personal values.â€

Madsbjerg is set to teach a course at the New School this fall called Human Observation. â€œTrue observation is the ability to look and listen without the interference of assumptions and prejudices,â€ reads the course description found online. Only white authors are listed in the description.
â€˜Thereâ€™s Just Something Offâ€™

Although no one HuffPost spoke to alleges that Madsbjerg made overtly racist statements to employees, other partners and managers have been heard making comments about Black people, as well as about their counterparts within Cognizant. That company, which bought a 49% stake in Red in 2016, has a big presence in India.

At a 2018 meeting, a top partner at Red described an Indian colleague at Cognizant as looking like Apu from â€œThe Simpsonsâ€ and laughed to himself, according to contemporaneous notes a former employee shared with HuffPost.

It wasnâ€™t unusual for partners to mock Indian accents, several former employees said, or to look down on Cognizant employees more generally. â€œThere was a dismissiveness to the value of Cognizantâ€™s math and science [expertise],â€ Sangodeyi said.
Partners at Red would say that they needed to teach their counterparts at Cognizant â€œhow to think,â€ Johnson said.
Brown was one of the people to put on an Indian accent. Some employees of color were offended by this, according to a former Red employee.

Brown said he meant it in fun. â€œI do all sorts of accents at work and in life. I do posh English people, Danish people, Trinidadian family, my London family and yeah, I do Indian accents. Iâ€™m quite good at accents,â€ he said. â€œI wouldâ€™ve hoped that people wouldâ€™ve realized that I meant no malice by it. India is one of my favorite countries on the planet. I lived there for six months. I get on well with my Indian colleagues at Cognizant and celebrate them sincerely. Iâ€™d hope all that considered, people would realize I meant not to belittle by doing an accent.â€

Ethnic stereotyping wasnâ€™t confined to Indian people. If a client was trying to understand the Chinese consumer, partners would at times fall back on certain â€œOrientalist cliches,â€ using words like â€œinscrutableâ€ and characterizing Chinese people as mysterious, said one former employee.

Another former employee, a 29-year-old woman with an Indigenous background, recalled bringing Twining tea to the office. She said one of her male colleagues told her it was â€œproletariatâ€ tea, as though the brand wasnâ€™t fancy enough.
She said she never felt like she fit in at the firm.
â€œI donâ€™t want to call them all racists, thatâ€™s not true,â€ she said. â€œBut they didnâ€™t think of people of color as their equals or worthy enough to be accepted into the doors of Red.â€

Sangodeyi takes care to point out that there were a lot of good people at the firm, but said things could get uncomfortable with the most senior managers and partners. â€œI told the HR person when I left, â€˜Thereâ€™s just something off about this place,â€™â€ she said.

In 2015, after the incident in the south of France, Sangodeyi wanted to give the firm the benefit of the doubt. She was new to the company. â€œPerhaps the comment was coming from a place of ignorance, since the manager was from a more provincial part of Denmark,â€ she thought. Many partners and managers at Red, which was founded in Copenhagen, are Danish, including the man who made the remark. Denmark is relatively small and homogenous.
â€œPossibly a dynamic at play here is that Red is a global company founded on non-American, not exclusively American dynamics,â€ Brown said.

One of the challenges at Red will be â€œbridging the cultural divide,â€ said Mathew Yazzie, a San Francisco-based diversity consultant Red hired. Yazzie, who has worked on diversity issues at Google and for other Silicon Valley firms, said he didnâ€™t think Red was that unusual. â€œI wasnâ€™t surprised by a lot of it,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™ve seen everything.â€ He plans to do a diversity audit in the coming weeks, looking at the firmâ€™s processes such as hiring and performance reviews.
â€˜This Felt Differentâ€™
In a statement to HuffPost, Red Associates claimed that the man who exclaimed about Sangodeyiâ€™s skin color â€œmade an immediate and deeply sincere apology.â€
Sangodeyi said that was absolutely not true â€” and that the man just walked away after she told him his remarks were bizarre.
She said she was mainly happy day-to-day working at the company, but that her time at Red Associates was marked by these kinds of off-putting moments.

There was the time she was at the daily communal lunch, where everyone stands and shares a meal around a tall white table in the companyâ€™s meeting room. Flowers are usually on display, too. Always white.
Sangodeyi was eating with a group of colleagues when a white female partner started talking about the term â€œNegro,â€ she said.
â€œItâ€™s like, why are you talking about this?â€ she recalled thinking. She walked out.
Sangodeyi is a historian of science by training. She grew up in the suburbs, went to a private school, spent years at Harvard.
â€œIâ€™m used to being in [white] spaces and not being bothered by microaggressions,â€ she said. â€œThis felt different.â€

Partners at the firm also called her â€œangryâ€ or â€œdifficult,â€ both to her face and to others within the firm, even after Sangodeyi pointed out to her managers that such characterizations were steeped in stereotypes. Former colleagues told HuffPost neither term applied even remotely to Sangodeyi.
Comments like these could help explain why women of color didnâ€™t seem to advance at the company.

Women of color took nearly four times as long as white men to get promoted to manager, according to an analysis that was created by a consultant at Red in 2018. Some men led only one project or no projects before getting promoted, according to the spreadsheet obtained by HuffPost. Two white women were promoted after leading a single project. No women of color were.

Sangodeyi led five projects over her nearly four years at the company without being promoted. She left the firm two years ago, frustrated after watching less experienced, less credentialed male colleagues be promoted to manager while she was skipped over because she wasnâ€™t â€œready.â€

Red Associates said it canâ€™t comment on individual employees. But it did say Yazzie will develop a training program â€œto make sure everyone understands microaggressions, and why they are racist and harmful to their colleagues and to the overall culture of a workplace.â€
â€˜It Seemed Tone Deafâ€™

In June, Red Associates declared on LinkedIn that â€œBlack Lives Matterâ€ and condemned systemic racism. â€œWe want to see change and we need to move beyond social media statements. Inequity is only addressed through long term, sustained efforts at the root of the social and racial issues,â€ read the post.

The firm also seemed to acknowledge its own shortcomings. â€œ[W]e also have much to interrogate, and so much we can and must do better,â€ said the post. â€œIf you have thoughts or resources to share, experts you recommend we learn from, or partner with, please comment or email us ...â€
Current and former employees were outraged.

â€œIt seemed tone deaf, given the lack of diversity, to say we stand with this movement,â€ said one person who is close to the company and familiar with the recent turmoil, noting it also seemed like Red was soliciting free advice from people of color. â€œIt should be something the company should be actively seeking out and paying for.â€
Soon the firm hired Yazzie.

Leaders at Red should look inward, wrote Nelson Saldana, a former consultant who left the firm this spring, in a comment on the LinkedIn post: â€œThe fact that no one internally can act as a thought leader on these issues demonstrates the types of people who are valued internally.â€ That comment has since been deleted, and Saldana did not respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for further comment.

Inside the company, the LinkedIn post prompted consultants and partners to have an open conversation about diversity on a conference call. One consultant, a person of color who already had a foot out the door, talked about how they had always felt uncomfortable at Red and never felt OK speaking up, according to someone familiar with the call.
Arora, the managing partner, also sent out emails to staff in early June, acknowledging the firm needed to do more.

â€œWe are a small company who values inclusion and diversity of ideas and perspective, yet we donâ€™t have enough diversity on our team, have struggled to retain people of color and I worry that means our culture hasnâ€™t felt as welcoming to all as it should,â€ she wrote.
It Affects Your Work
Sangodeyi left the firm in 2018, fed up with its â€œcasual racism, implicit and explicit bias,â€ and with the inequities in promotion, she said. She founded her own consulting company last year.

About 13 people of color â€” including four Black women â€” have left the firm since then, according to those familiar with the firmâ€™s numbers. Some quit; others were laid off after a recent bout of downsizing.
One of the Black women who left said working at Red Associates was a painful experience.

This woman, who was relatively new to the firm and young, said her manager called her â€œscaryâ€ during a 2018 meeting with a client at which she was presenting. She said she complained about this to him, and finally to another senior manager â€” but nothing happened. In fact, she said, her manager was promoted.
The remarks, the way the incident was handled, and the feelings of otherness wore her down.
â€œAfter a while, those things make you question your voice, your team, the trust of the people you work around,â€ she told HuffPost.
Red said these comments were â€œcompletely inappropriate and wrong.â€

Itâ€™s not unusual for people of color working in the corporate world to wind up questioning themselves and those around them, said Dnika Travis, lead researcher at Catalyst, a nonprofit that advocates for diversity, inclusion and equality in the workplace. Travis, who is Black, has been interviewing women and men of color about their experiences for years.
The â€œcomments, the slights and insultsâ€ amount to what Travis calls an emotional tax. Women and men of color pay the tax with their very souls.
â€œThe stories are harrowing and heartbreaking,â€ Travis said.

The Black employee who was called â€œscaryâ€ by her manager said she felt like she shut down after that. â€œThat shutting down let me be less creative at work,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™d stop speaking up as much in meetings. Iâ€™d stop speaking up as much in group sessions. I felt invalidated. Like I didnâ€™t matter.â€

otherData.headline: Robert Trump, The Presidentâ€™s Younger Brother, Dead At 71
otherData.short_description: The president visited his brother at a New York City hospital on Friday after White House officials said he had become seriously ill.

articleContent: NEW YORK (AP) â€” President Donald Trumpâ€™s younger brother, Robert Trump, a businessman known for an even keel that seemed almost incompatible with the family name, died Saturday night after being hospitalized in New York, the president said in a statement. He was 71.
The president visited his brother at a New York City hospital on Friday after White House officials said he had become seriously ill.

The youngest of the Trump siblings remained close to the 74-year-old president and, as recently as June, filed a lawsuit on behalf of the Trump family that unsuccessfully sought to stop publication of a tell-all book by the presidentâ€™s niece, Mary.
Robert Trump had reportedly been hospitalized in the intensive care unit for several days that same month .

Both longtime businessmen, Robert and Donald had strikingly different personalities. Donald Trump once described his younger brother as â€œmuch quieter and easygoing than I am,â€ and â€œthe only guy in my life whom I ever call â€˜honey.â€™â€
Robert Trump began his career on Wall Street working in corporate finance but later joined the family business, managing real estate holdings as a top executive in the Trump Organization.

â€œWhen he worked in the Trump Organization, he was known as the nice Trump,â€ Gwenda Blair, a Trump family biographer, told The Associated Press. â€œRobert was the one people would try to get to intervene if there was a problem.â€
Robert Stewart Trump was born in 1948, the youngest of New York City real estate developer Fred Trumpâ€™s five children.
The president, two years older than Robert, admittedly bullied his brother in their younger years, even as he praised his loyalty and laid-back demeanor.

â€œI think it must be hard to have me for a brother but heâ€™s never said anything about it and weâ€™re very close,â€ Donald Trump wrote in his 1987 bestseller â€œThe Art of the Deal.â€ â€œRobert gets along with almost everyone,â€ he added, â€œwhich is great for me since I sometimes have to be the bad guy.â€

In the 1980s, Donald Trump tapped Robert Trump to oversee an Atlantic City casino project, calling him the perfect fit for the job. When it cannibalized his other casinos, though, â€œhe pointed the finger of blame at Robert,â€ said Blair, author of â€œThe Trumps: Three Generations that Built an Empire.â€
â€œWhen the slot machines jammed the opening weekend at the Taj Mahal, he very specifically and furiously denounced Robert, and Robert walked out and never worked for his brother again,â€ Blair said.
A Boston University graduate, Robert Trump later managed the Brooklyn portion of father Fred Trumpâ€™s real estate empire, which was eventually sold.
Once a regular boldface name in Manhattanâ€™s social pages, Robert Trump had kept a lower profile in recent years. â€œHe was not a newsmaker,â€ Blair said.
Before divorcing his first wife, Blaine Trump, more than a decade ago, Robert Trump had been active on Manhattanâ€™s Upper East Side charity circuit.

He avoided the limelight during his elder brotherâ€™s presidency, having retired to the Hudson Valley. But he described himself as a big supporter of the White House run in a 2016 interview with the New York Post.
â€œI support Donald one thousand percent,â€ Robert Trump said.
In early March of 2020, he married his longtime girlfriend, Ann Marie Pallan.

The eldest Trump sibling and Maryâ€™s father, Fred Trump Jr., struggled with alcoholism and died in 1981 at the age of 43. The presidentâ€™s surviving siblings include Elizabeth Trump Grau and Maryanne Trump Barry, a retired federal appeals judge.

Authors Michael Kranish and Marc Fisher described Robert Trump as soft-spoken but cerebral in â€œTrump Revealed: The Definitive Biography of the 45th Presidentâ€: â€œHe lacked Donaldâ€™s charismatic showmanship, and he was happy to leave the bravado to his brother, but he could show flashes of Trump temper.â€
AP researcher Jennifer Farrar contributed to this report from New York.

otherData.headline: Is It Possible To Have A Healthy Relationship With Social Media?
otherData.short_description: The rise of digital detoxesÂ shows just how damaging our social media habits can be for our well-being. What can we do about it?

articleContent: â€œSocial media is bad for your mental healthâ€ â€“ itâ€™s a phrase weâ€™ve heard over and over again. The stresses of lockdown have driven more of us to take breaks from social networking sites, and the rise of digital detoxes shows just how damaging our social media habits can be for our well-being.

During the pandemic, some people have witnessed â€“ perhaps more than ever before â€“ abusive and hateful messages online. Throughout this period, JK Rowling attracted criticism for her comments on trans issues, and rapper Wiley made the news for his anti-semitic outbursts.

This prevalence of hate led the European Union Commission to prepare new guidelines in an attempt to eradicate hate speech on social media by making platforms more transparent, according to Tech Crunch.
But how can we cope in the meantime, if our social media feeds are affecting our mental well-being?
Be active about when you engage â€“ and when you donâ€™t.

Social media is becoming harder to ignore, so itâ€™s almost essential to manage it properly. Is it even possible to have a healthy relationship with the online world? Social media expert and psychotherapist Aaron Balick believes so.
â€œThe important thing is to be active about the way you engage with social media and not passive,â€ says Balick. â€œThis means managing your notifications.â€

Ideally, Balick says, you should turn off notifications and only check social media when you choose to â€“ rather than habitually looking at your feed. â€œBe vigilant as to how it makes you feel,â€ he says. â€œIf it makes you feel depressed, stressed or anxious, come off straight away and give yourself a break.
â€œAlso, think about which feeds are more nourishing to you, and which less so, and plan accordingly.â€

Luring ourselves off from social media takes some getting used to â€“ many of us check our feeds whenever thereâ€™s a quiet second. And the phenomenon of the â€œzombie scrollâ€ epitomizes the problem: users scroll for hours for quick, instant hits of dopamine released when they get a like, comment or follow.

â€œWe tend to be addicted to being stimulated by information, checking our feeds at every quiet moment, which stops us having quiet moments that are actually necessary for positive mental health,â€ explains Balick.

You should have a social media detox when socializing with friends, too. Put your phone out of sight, he suggests. â€œIf you find yourself getting anxious when you canâ€™t check social media, this may be an indication of a dependency, and you should wean yourself off. Come off a platform if it brings you no joy.â€
Diversify the content youâ€™re consuming.

Once you have a more balanced approach, itâ€™s time to think about the content youâ€™re taking in. Having your own views backed up by 100% of your feed isnâ€™t necessarily healthy, as it doesnâ€™t provide an authentic view of the world.

Diversity is important, even if you disagree with what another user thinks, says Balick. â€œItâ€™s important we peer outside our filter bubbles every now and then, but it should be done with an open mind and curiosity.â€

â€œEach person should make their own judgements about this, as peering into some bubbles can be distressing and upsetting,â€ he adds. â€œSo if youâ€™re going to do it, do it with a purpose and be ready.â€

That purpose may be to educate yourself why other people share beliefs you canâ€™t understand, and to humanize people, or to simply gain a broader understanding of conversations going on outside your own friendship circle.

â€œIt can also be a source of important information as to how other people think and feel, so engaging in that can be informative, but also challenging. If you do this, do it to learn, and not pick fights,â€ warns Balick.

Monitoring new additions to your feed is important, he adds, as they may throw up hateful comments unexpectedly, or make you feel anxious or nervous. Itâ€™s important to keep a critical eye on new followers, and old ones too.
Acknowledge that you may get upset.

Feeling upset on social media is, often, inevitable. Even if you run a tight ship with your feed, users re-sharing posts from others on Twitter, Instagram or Facebook may mean youâ€™re exposed to content you find hateful.

â€œDonâ€™t engage with trolls or haters if you can,â€ says Balick. â€œThey live off the energy of kicking up a storm. Gently mute and get on with your life.â€ Although, he adds, â€œdissociating from an attack is easier said than done.â€

If possible, â€œput some distance between yourself and the attack,â€ he says, which may mean working up a defense mechanism, denouncing attacks as childish, or reading more about why people feel they are safer to be hateful behind screens. Whichever works for you.
â€œRemember, these attacks often have very little to do with who you are, and more to do with someone getting some anger off their chest,â€ he warns. It may feel personal, but it often isnâ€™t.

While thereâ€™s joy to be extracted from online conversations, the relationships that can be built and nurtured in the digital sphere are often limited. â€œSocial media isnâ€™t often the best arena to have rational discussions about different points of view, which are important discussions to have,â€ urges Balick.
â€œAlways prioritize face-to-face encounters,â€ he says, and importantly: â€œFind other ways to share ideas and work through differences that arenâ€™t on social media.â€
This post originally appeared in HuffPost UK.

otherData.headline: U.S. Says No Financial Bailout For Lebanon, Calls For Systemic Reforms
otherData.short_description: The FBI will assist with an investigation into the massive blast in Beirut that killed more than 170 people.
otherData.authors: Bassem Mroue and Andrea Rosa, AP

articleContent: BEIRUT (AP) â€” There can be no financial bailout for Lebanon, a senior U.S. official said Saturday, calling on the countryâ€™s political leaders to heed popular calls for change, real reform and an end to endemic corruption.

David Hale, U.S. undersecretary of state for political affairs, said the U.S. and its allies will respond to â€œsystemic reforms with sustained financial support.â€ He also called for a thorough and transparent investigation into the Aug. 4 blast that killed nearly 180 people and wounded thousands.
He said an FBI team is arriving this weekend to take part in the probe at the invitation of Lebanese authorities.
Hale arrived in Beirut on Thursday, where he met with volunteers helping out at the site of the blast, as well as the countryâ€™s top political and religious leadership.

â€œAmerica calls on Lebanonâ€™s political leaders to finally respond to the peopleâ€™s longstanding and legitimate demands and create a credible plan â€“ accepted by the Lebanese people â€“ for good governance, sound economic and financial reform, and an end to the endemic corruption that has stifled Lebanonâ€™s tremendous potential,â€ he said.
â€œBut as the dozens of young activists and volunteers I met so bluntly demanded, there can be no bailout,â€ Hale said in a recorded message posted on the U.S. Embassy website Saturday.

Haleâ€™s comments were in line with Washingtonâ€™s message before the visit. But he didnâ€™t detail whether the U.S. and Western allies are ready to support a government in which Lebanonâ€™s powerful Iran-backed Hezbollah group has clout.
After visiting the site of the blast, Hale called for the state to exercise control over its borders and ports, in a clear reference to claims Hezbollah group controls them.
â€œWe can never go back to an era in which anything goes at the port or borders of Lebanon,â€ Hale said.

Washington and its allies consider the Iran-backed group Hezbollah a terrorist organization, and have accused it of abusing government funds and undermining state authority. There was speculation in the local media that Hale would be pushing for a government that excludes the group.

In a clear message, Hezbollahâ€™s leader Hassan Nasrallah said his group is pushing for a national unity government that has wide political representation and backing. Seeking a â€œneutral government,â€ he said, would be â€œa waste of time.â€
Popular anger has been building up in Lebanon against the ruling eliteâ€™s corruption, mismanagement and political uncertainty many blame for pushing the country toward bankruptcy and poverty.

The blast only increased the publicâ€™s rage. The cause of the fire that ignited nearly 3,000 tons of ammonium nitrate at Beirutâ€™s port remains unclear. Documents have emerged showing the countryâ€™s top leadership and security officials were aware of the chemicals stored at the port.

Many Lebanese are calling for an independent international probe, saying they donâ€™t trust the long-entrenched political factions to allow any results to come to light that are damaging to their leadership.

Under pressure, Lebanonâ€™s government resigned Aug. 10 and is serving in a caretaker capacity. So far, there are no formal consultations underway on who will replace Hassan Diab as prime minister and no likely candidate has emerged.
But the flurry of diplomatic visits appeared designed to influence the forming of the new government.
Western leaders have said they will send aid directly to the Lebanese people and that billions of dollars will not be pumped into the country before major reforms take place.

Hale said the United States has so far donated $18 million to the Lebanese people in terms of food and other essential and is preparing to work with Congress for an additional $30 million to ensure the flow of grains after the capitalâ€™s silos were destroyed in the blast. The aid, he said, will be handled directly by the World Food Program.

â€œThis is a moment for Lebanon to define a Lebanese â€” not a foreign â€” vision of Lebanon,â€ Hale said. â€œWhat kind of Lebanon do you have and what kind of Lebanon do you want? Only Lebanese can answer that question.â€

Coinciding with Haleâ€™s visit was that of the Iranian Foreign Minister Jawad Zarif who said Western nations are exploiting Lebanonâ€™s disaster to push their political dictates. Iran is Hezbollahâ€™s main foreign backer and has provided the group with financial and technical support throughout the years.

On Friday, the United Nations launched a $565 million appeal for Lebanon with immediate humanitarian assistance and initial recovery efforts. Last week, international donors pledged nearly $300 million of emergency assistance to Lebanon.
Najat Rochdi, U.N. humanitarian coordinator for Lebanon, called for more funds to cover the critical needs of shelter, food, health and education.
Rochdi said most donors have asked that aid be channeled through the U.N., which she said would be coordinated with Lebanonâ€™s armed forces to ensure access.

â€œWe will be very strict about the use of humanitarian assistance. We will be monitoring closely every single delivery of our humanitarian assistance,â€ she said. â€œWe will be accountable not only to donors because our accountability goes also to the affected population.â€
Also on Saturday, families and friends buried Ralph Malahi, a 23-year old firefighter who was among 10 firefighters killed in the explosion.
Malahi was given a heroâ€™s funeral in Beirut. Lifting Malahiâ€™s coffin, thousands paraded through different parts of the city, firing weapons into the air in commemoration.
Malahi is the seventh firefighter to be retrieved from under the debris in the port at the scene of the blast. Three remain missing.

Malahiâ€™s mother, weeping, blamed the government for her sonâ€™s death. â€œWhy did you not evacuate the port?â€ she said, in reference to the governmentâ€™s knowledge that highly explosive material was stored at the port.
Associated Press writer Sarah El Deeb in Beirut contributed to this report.

otherData.headline: Why These Sexual Assault Survivors Support Defunding The Police
otherData.short_description: These survivors don't want their experiences to justify the continued overfunding of law enforcement.

articleContent: As the rallying cry to â€œdefund the policeâ€ reverberates across the country, some critics have claimed that women will be irrevocably harmed if police budgets are downsized, pointing specifically to sexual assault survivors. The argument, steeped in misogyny and antiquated ideas of what a victim looks like, uses crimes (largely but by no means exclusively) committed against women to justify the continued overfunding of police.

But for survivors themselves, the debate is more complicated. Some went to the police for help and received it; most who reported crimes saw their perpetrators walk free. Many didnâ€™t go to the police at all, fearing they would face victim-blaming questions and get little help. Some were assaulted by the very people theyâ€™d have to report crimes to.
These survivors donâ€™t want more police. They want more help.

HuffPost spoke to more than a dozen survivors of sexual assault about the debate over defunding police. While their views donâ€™t represent those of all survivors â€• nearly 434,000 people are sexually assaulted every year in the U.S. â€• they said police often ended up retraumatizing them instead of helping them find justice.

â€œThe criminal system is built to punish. Itâ€™s not built to support the victim in any way,â€ Thomas Shim, co-founder of #WhyIDidntReport, told HuffPost. â€œAs soon as you report, you have to retell your experience over and over again to complete strangers who often victim-blame. In the name of â€˜Iâ€™m just doing my job,â€™ theyâ€™ll ask you things like â€˜What were you wearing?â€™â€

One look at the statistics, and itâ€™s easy to see why many survivors donâ€™t report their assaults to law enforcement. Out of every 1,000 sexual assaults, 995 perpetrators will walk free. Survivors who do decide to press charges against their attackers are usually in for a long and expensive legal battle that can end with a prosecutor deciding not to pursue a case or a contaminated, untested rape kit.

Just last week, retired Memphis Police Department officers admitted to throwing thousands of rape kits into a nearby landfill in the 1990s, and many of the kits were for prosecutable cases within the statute of limitations.

Police also may fail to take reports seriously, especially from members of marginalized groups or people not stereotypically thought to be victims. Black women and non-binary people are â€œhyper-vulnerableâ€ to sexual violence, according to the ACLU, but not as likely as white women to be believed. And an estimated 1 in 6 men have been victims of sexual violence, yet their stories are often brushed off.

Cops are also perpetrators of sexual assault: Between 2005 and 2013, over 1,200 police officers were arrested for sex crimes, but those were only the ones against victims who were brave enough to report. Law enforcement officers also have a storied history of actively targeting more vulnerable people, like sex workers.

Social services that could receive a reallocation of funding from downsized police budgets are the very types of services survivors need when they report: mental health, addiction and other trauma-informed services.

Many survivors told HuffPost theyâ€™d like to see transformative justice â€• an alternative method of addressing harm by relying on community members instead of police. Transformative justice is about communal healing and prevention. Incarceration does the opposite; between 3% and 9% of male inmates reported experiencing sexual violence while incarcerated â€• thatâ€™s more than 180,000 men.

â€œIf I wanted a process of accountability for the abuse I had experienced and to prevent this person from hurting other people, my only option was to lock my rapist up,â€ said Tani Ikeda, a sexual assault survivor and founder of Survivor Love Letter. â€œAs someone who had family members suffering from PTSD from incarceration, I wanted to search for other solutions.â€

The majority of survivors Shim speaks to through his work support defunding the police, but a few â€• the â€œlucky and privilegedâ€ who had good experiences with the police â€• are not always on board with the movement, he said.

â€œTheyâ€™ve had experiences where the police actually helped them find their perpetrator and punish them. Thatâ€™s amazing. We completely understand where theyâ€™re coming from because, again, they demanded justice and they got that,â€ he said.
The best way to understand how sexual assault survivors feel about defunding the police is to listen to them. In their own words, this is how survivors feel about the movement.
Warning: Some readers may find the below content triggering. These stories have been lightly edited for length and style.

â€œMaggie,â€ a 25-year-old from Iowa, told HuffPost she was raped several times by her then-partner over the course of a few months. She never reported it to police because of threats from her partner, although she did report the abuse to her school after the last assault, which she says was the most severe.

I frequently thought about filing a police report and often came close to doing so. However, my partner regularly used threats and coercion to prevent me from involving the police. While initially after the last incident of rape, he expressed remorse and even encouraged me to seek help, later on, he began to regularly use suicide threats if I mentioned filing a reportâ€¦ In addition, one of his favorite tactics was to try to convince me that he would be repeatedly raped in prison if I reported. Because I loved him and because I did not want him to harm himself or be harmed, I eventually chose not to pursue police involvement because I feared for his safety both inside and outside of prison.

Despite it being used as a threat, I often think about how my abuserâ€™s commentary about prison rape is not without truth. While that threat will forever haunt me, it has taught me an important lesson about how the criminal justice system so often reinforces and perpetuates violence.

I support abolishing and defunding the police. My answer would likely have been different several years ago, back when I believed that law enforcement was a supportive mechanism for survivors. As many other people do, I believe there is significant work to be done to develop systems of community accountability and community public safety, but it has become clear to me that police were never about providing safety.

â€œAlex,â€ a 25-year-old from Denver, told HuffPost she was sexually assaulted by a guy friend while she was at college. Alex, who is Black, said she didnâ€™t report her assault because she was afraid that her attacker, a Black man, would face consequences far worse than his actions due to racism in policing. She also decided not to report because she felt pressure to ensure the representation of the Black community at her school was not affected.

Many Black students at our university had already had issues with the police racially profiling them and harassing them. While what [my attacker] did to me was wrong and illegal, I donâ€™t think it should come with any risk of endangering his life. Additionally, because of the criminalization of Black bodies in our society, I always hesitate to incite police interactions with Black people as Iâ€™m afraid of both perpetuating the narrative of our criminality and putting their lives in danger. Within our sphere of influence, my attacker was also someone who was frequently pointed to as an example of â€œBlack Excellenceâ€ and has been instrumental in many efforts to improve the experiences of Black students on our campus. At the time, it was a cost-benefit of him being investigated and punished for his behavior, and how that would change how our community was seen. While I know ultimately he doesnâ€™t singlehandedly represent Black students and alumni of our university, I donâ€™t think it would help us in our efforts towards racial justice either.

Iâ€™m a strong supporter of defunding the police and making significant other changes to our criminal justice system. Our current systems donâ€™t work for survivors of crime or their assailants. I didnâ€™t report in no small part because I donâ€™t want to perpetuate a broken system that profits on BIPOC bodies. As a survivor, I think I have a stronger sense that the system doesnâ€™t work for anyone except for those in charge of it. We shouldnâ€™t have survivors who arenâ€™t willing to go to the police because they know they wonâ€™t be treated with dignity and respect. We shouldnâ€™t have survivors who see their attackers be given punishments either too lenient or too harsh for their crimes, entirely because of who that attacker is. As a survivor who understands the flaws of the penal systems, I know the system is broken on both sides.

Tara Burns is a 38-year-old sex worker and sex workersâ€™ rights advocate living in Alaska. She was sex trafficked and assaulted at a young age and now documents instances of violence against sex workers, including acts of violence perpetrated by police.

Police have only ever compounded the trauma of sexual assaults for me. No one has ever gone to jail for sexually assaulting me, whether I was sex working at the time or not.

As an advocate for sex workers trying to report violence for the last five years, it has been a struggle to get police to even take reports at times. No one has ever gone to jail for sexually assaulting or sex trafficking any of the survivors who I have supported in reporting. Iâ€™m absolutely for defunding the police and redirecting funds to more effective strategies.

Lane Lofaso, a 17-year-old from New York, told HuffPost he was in a sexually and emotionally abusive relationship for a year, starting when he was 15 years old. He said he plans to report his abuser soon.

Defunding the police is something that should happen immediately. The money is not going to any of the right places, and officers are not trained properly to handle sexual assaults and speaking to victims/survivors.
