My experience as a survivor definitely impacts my feeling and opinion on defunding the police and Iâ€™m glad that it does. Personally, I donâ€™t think I will ever get justice. Sexual assault causes lifelong trauma and nothing will ever fix that. But the closest thing to that is making sure the perpetrator is punished and thatâ€™s where law enforcement comes in.

Amanda Thomashow, a 31-year-old from Michigan, was sexually assaulted by former Michigan State University and USA Gymnastics team doctor Larry Nassar during a 2014 medical exam. At the time, she filed a Title IX complaint with MSU but the school concluded Nassarâ€™s conduct was not sexual in nature. Her Title IX complaint was one of the few breadcrumbs that later led to Nassarâ€™s downfall.

My experience as a survivor has only informed me more on how important it is that we take funds away from the police and redistribute them into community services and education. My experiences with the police have been nothing but negative and terrifying. Those experiences only carried out my trauma longer than was necessary and itâ€™s been very clear that they only care about my cases and the harm thatâ€™s been done to me if they can prosecute, put somebody in jail or get a fine out of them.

Maya Siegel, a 20-year-old who founded the survivor-centered organization Space to Speak, told HuffPost she was raped by a boyfriend at 14 and later sexually assaulted by a different perpetrator at 18. She decided not to report to police because she was afraid of being victim-blamed.

I didnâ€™t report because I didnâ€™t think I would be believed without evidence. Society is full of abuser sympathizers and judges that blame survivors for their clothes, alcohol consumption, or being in a relationship (and I was in a relationship with him at the time); I knew that I didnâ€™t have a case. Additionally, even though I knew that physical evidence is gone in three days, it took me more than three days to comprehend what happened and tell my parents.

I donâ€™t think police are the answer, especially without proper education. After all, 85% of federal funding for domestic violence is dedicated to law enforcement; it should be redistributed to directly help survivors, an example would be helping them cover medical or legal expenses. Itâ€™s been six years and I am still working with doctors; I would have loved an emergency grant or further support.

Riley Reed, a 20-year-old from Chicago, was sexually assaulted two separate times. Reed disclosed the assaults to a professor but did not report to police, knowing the process of reporting can oftentimes be just as traumatic as the initial assault.

I didnâ€™t go forward with a police report because I didnâ€™t want to have to go through a long, arduous processâ€¦ I didnâ€™t want to feel victimized or be scrutinized with so many different questionsâ€¦ I didnâ€™t feel like I had obvious evidence. Women especially are made to feel like itâ€™s our fault and we brought it on ourselves.

I fully support defunding the police. I think we need other resources that can help people in many different dangerous circumstances. The police donâ€™t have the proper training to deal with trauma. The people that helped me the most through my process were counselors. People that are equipped with proper knowledge should be sent to deescalate or help situations that police so often fail to do.

â€œSabrina,â€ a 45-year-old woman from New York City, said she has been sexually assaulted multiple times, but the most traumatic was when she was sexually abused as a 9-year-old. Her family reported the abuse to the police but, looking back, she felt she was not in control of that decision because she was so young.

In some ways, the urgency to go to the police (on my stepfatherâ€™s part) was as traumatizing as the actual attack. My mother did not want to call them. I did not want to call them. We did it because he definitely felt we should. What followed: The police blamed my mother, threatened to report her to CPS, I had to go to a hospital for an exam which was absolutely terrifying.

Iâ€™m curious to know more about the details [of defunding the police]. But if it means reducing budgets and redistributing those funds to the community, then absolutely yes [I support it].

Tani Ikeda, a survivor from Los Angeles, told HuffPost she was sexually assaulted when she was younger and entered into a four-year process with law enforcement and the criminal justice system to try to hold her rapist accountable.

It felt like a secondary violence to have my memories scrutinized by police who asked me clinical details about my assault, like a crime scene from which they were extracting evidence. The way I dressed, the accuracy of my memory, my creative online poetry, and even my smile â€• all became evidence that I was at fault for my own rape.

How can we practice transformative justice in our everyday lives and relationships? In a society that devalues human life, we can build more relationships that are based on curiosity and joy rather than gaining social status and career advancement. We center our own pleasure so what looks good on the outside also feels good on the inside. In elementary school, children who misbehave are given timeout. When we become adults, they go to prison. Instead of looking for people to punish, I am deeply invested in undoing the generational cycles of harm in our community through each of us working on ourselves.

â€œClareâ€ is a 30 year-old-woman living in California. Growing up in Michigan, she was sexually and physically abused by her motherâ€™s boyfriend for 12 years. She did not report the abuse but neighbors frequently called police for noise complaints.

I was questioned by the officers a few times, always in front of my abusers where I did not feel safe to tell them the truth or ask for help.

Every time I see articles and posts about abolishing or defunding the police, Iâ€™m frustrated that this didnâ€™t happen earlier, that I wasnâ€™t saved, and that the system failed me over and over again. I could have been spared if trained social workers had been involved. The police didnâ€™t save me from being molested and assaulted over and over again for twelve years. People argue that if we defund the police, who will be there to protect women from being raped on the streets? But they neglect the fact that itâ€™s already happening, and it feels like each one of these people are saying that my pain, our pain, doesnâ€™t matter, that it isnâ€™t enough of a reason.

Cassandra, an 18-year-old from Maryland, was raped by a classmate on New Yearâ€™s Eve in 2018 when she was 16 years old. She didnâ€™t report her assault because her perpetrator used a condom and because she didnâ€™t leave any marks on him. She also didnâ€™t feel like she truly understood what happened to her until she left for college.

I think we should focus on restorative justice and preventative justice instead of being reactionary and buying into a system that often perpetuates more harm instead of actually helping. My experience has helped me realize that our prison system and justice system is flawed in such a way that it doesnâ€™t achieve meaningful justice. My rapist â€• if he had been charged, tried, and locked up â€• would have eventually gotten out with no better understanding of consent or what he did to me. Heâ€™d probably have lingering feelings or resentment towards me and the justice system while never acknowledging the harm he perpetrated against me. What Iâ€™ve realized is that rape is about power and entitlement. That feeling of entitlement never leaves when the punishment is simply prison time. Furthermore, within the prison system, sexual assault is commonplace. Prisons conduct strip searches, in addition to rape being prevalent in prisons. I personally believe that true justice is not achieved by perpetrating the same harm done to you onto the perpetrator and continuing the cycle of violence but rather promote healing and discussion. All I want is a public apology and an acknowledgment of what my rapist has done. I just want to be able to continue on with my life knowing that he knows what he did to me was wrong and he wonâ€™t do it again.
Need help? Visit RAINNâ€™s National Sexual Assault Online Hotline or the National Sexual Violence Resource Centerâ€™s website.

otherData.headline: Youth Ministry Accused Of Deceiving Queer Teens With â€˜Bait And Switchâ€™
otherData.short_description: Young Life, an evangelical ministry, purposefully hides its anti-LGBTQ theology and turns queer people away after they're already invested in the program, activists say.

articleContent: Elizabeth Garcia wasnâ€™t particularly religious when she first encountered Young Life, a Colorado-based evangelical youth ministry that seeks to win young souls for Christ. Back then, she was just another nervous high school freshman trying to fit in. Young Life took her in, connected her to a Christian community that cared about her, and taught her that Jesus welcomes all kids to his table.

Over a decade later, Garcia learned firsthand that this welcome had a caveat. After serving as a Young Life volunteer and then a staff member, Garcia says she was forced to resign from her job after coming out as queer.
Looking back, she called it a â€œbait and switch.â€
â€œAs soon as I was asked to resign, immediately it was like, â€˜They are not who I thought they were,â€™â€ she said.

Garciaâ€™s story is one of hundreds emerging from a new campaign, Do Better Young Life, that seeks to highlight the voices of LGBTQ people and other minorities who say they have been hurt by the ministry. Former participants and employees who are queer described a pattern of damaging behavior to HuffPost â€• being recruited as children, finding community and belonging in the group, being encouraged into volunteer and staff positions, and ultimately, being pushed away after coming out. They said they lost their jobs at the ministry, were told to just â€œstop being gay,â€ were outed to co-workers without consent, and were treated like a threat to children simply for being queer.

Organizer Kent Thomas, a 30-year-old former Young Life student and staffer from Tacoma, Washington, launched the campaign after learning that the ministry had used a photo of an employee on its Instagram to promote one of its camps â€• an employee it had forced out for being queer. Thomas responded with an Instagram post on June 29 claiming that Young Lifeâ€™s â€œpartial inclusionâ€ was even worse than overt exclusion. He encouraged others to share their stories online under the hashtag #DoBetterYoungLife.

Since then, Thomas says, the group has collected over 400 stories from former Young Life students, volunteers or staff members who allege they experienced queerphobia, racism, sexism or other kinds of discrimination at Young Life. Some of these testimonies have been posted on the campaignâ€™s Instagram and Twitter accounts. Nearly 7,000 people have signed a Change.org petition that lists more inclusive and transparent policies at Young Life as one of its demands.

Young Life told HuffPost that it welcomes all young people as participants in its programs, regardless of â€œrace, religion, ability, sexual orientation or identity.â€ But it expects leaders to align with its theology, which it said includes the belief that sex is reserved for a heterosexual married couple.

U.S. courts have long given religious groups like Young Life plenty of leeway to hire and fire employees according to their religious beliefs. But the activists behind Do Better Young Life arenâ€™t primarily concerned about the legality of what the ministry is doing. Instead, they insist there is something inherently immoral and even cruel about the way the ministry actively pursues young people, then rejects the ones who turn out to be queer.
Former employees told HuffPost that more than the loss of their own jobs, they were motivated to speak up because they are worried about queer youth continuing to get plugged into the ministry.

Garcia and others behind Do Better Young Life arenâ€™t hopeful that the ministry will change its non-affirming theology. But what they are hoping for is greater transparency. As of now, Garcia said she doesnâ€™t think that Young Life is a safe space for queer kids.
â€œIf youâ€™re not affirming, you have to be more upfront,â€ she said of Young Life. â€œYou need to be clear about that or youâ€™re going to hurt a lot more people.â€
Winning Young Souls For Christ

The overarching mission of Young Life, a nearly 80-year-old organization based in Colorado Springs, is to introduce Christianity â€• specifically, a conservative interpretation of Christianity â€• to unchurched middle school, high school and college-aged youth. Young Life does this by â€œgoing where kids areâ€ and earning their trust. With the permission of school administrators, Young Life sends leaders, primarily college-aged students, to public schools during free periods or activities open to the public, such as lunch or sports games.

According to former participants, Young Life leaders target and befriend â€œkeyâ€ kids, usually â€œpopularâ€ kids, at public schools to ensure that Young Life comes across to the student population as a â€œcoolâ€ thing to participate in. During the school year, Young Life holds weekly gatherings, called â€œclubs,â€ where kids learn more about Christianity. Close to 370,000 kids attended Young Life clubs weekly during the 2018â€“2019 school year. Young Life camps, meanwhile, are the main attraction for many kids. Over 240,000 youth attended Young Life camps between 2018 and 2019.

Thomas said that leaders arenâ€™t immediately upfront with new kids or their parents about the ministryâ€™s conservative religious mission. At club, leaders sometimes have kids sing along to secular songs before switching over to worship songs at the end, he said.

â€œItâ€™s absolutely never, â€˜Come and youâ€™ll get this message about Jesus and we want you to become a Christian.â€™ Itâ€™s, â€˜Thereâ€™s going to be this school game of dodge ball, or letâ€™s get this gutter and fill it with ice cream, itâ€™s going to be fun.â€™ And then at the end, Jesus talk,â€ he said.

Once unchurched kids become emotionally invested in Christianity, they are taught that a key way to be like Jesus is to become â€œservant leaders,â€ former participants told HuffPost. That means older leaders will push teens to sign up for volunteer positions at Young Life while they are still in high school. Itâ€™s only when the teens start seeking out leadership roles in an effort to live out their newfound faith that they start hearing about Young Lifeâ€™s non-affirming theology.

In hindsight, Thomas said, he now thinks of Young Lifeâ€™s methods as manipulative â€• especially for the queer kids who naturally get caught in the wide net Young Life casts for its mission work at public schools.
â€œI think itâ€™s so much by design that Young Life gets youth roped in in a casual, social way, and then slowly, it gets more and more intense.â€
Old Beliefs, Repackaged

Young Life told HuffPost that its position on sexuality and gender â€œaligns with historic Christian theology.â€ The group believes that â€œsexuality is a gift from God and that God guides us in how to use this gift, including that intimate sexual activity should occur within a marriage covenant between a man and a woman.â€

â€œWe recognize that some thoughtful and committed Christians have different views, and we are committed to being in conversation with these and others â€“ both inside and outside Young Life,â€ the group added.

Evangelizing to Gen Z, the generation born after 1996, with this conservative set of beliefs has become an increasingly daunting task, given that generationâ€™s affirming views. Roughly half (48%) of members of Gen Z say that allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry is a good thing for our society, compared to 27% of Baby Boomers, according to a Pew Research Center report published in April.

As a result, thereâ€™s been a growing trend towards ambiguity among some conservative churches that want to attract young people, according to Jess Kotnour, a member of the leadership team at Church Clarity, a crowd-sourced database that scores congregations based on how clearly they communicate their actively enforced policies on gender and sexuality.

These churches will present themselves as inclusive, but will ultimately refuse to ordain, hire, or marry queer people, Kotnour said. â€œTheyâ€™ll have really nice websites, they have Instagram, and they look hip. They play into this idea that â€˜Weâ€™re not the church your parents went to, weâ€™re the cool church.â€™ But actually, itâ€™s the same beliefs, but repackaged.â€

Church Clarity hasnâ€™t started to officially score campus or other parachurch ministries. But after taking a brief look at Young Lifeâ€™s website, Kotnour gave the ministry Church Clarityâ€™s lowest score â€• â€œundisclosedâ€ because the groupâ€™s position on sexuality or gender diversity canâ€™t be found in its statement of faith, mission statement, â€œaboutâ€ page, or other main pages.

Since Young Life isnâ€™t affiliated with a specific religious denomination, new students and their parents must depend on the ministryâ€™s website to glean information about where it stands. Being clear about these issues is particularly important when kids and parents are unfamiliar with evangelicalism and may not know what key phrases to look for, Kotnour said.

Young Life declined to answer questions about whether it would update its statement of faith to reflect its views on sexuality and gender diversity.

Thomas believes Young Lifeâ€™s ambiguity around this issue is â€œ100% purposeful.â€ If the ministry believes firmly that LGBTQ relationships are sinful, it shouldnâ€™t be ashamed to make that clear from day one to both kids and parents considering getting involved in the program, he said.

â€œYoung Life is trying to have their cake and eat it too by pretending to youth that theyâ€™re affirming,â€ Thomas said. â€œThe idea that a person would be barred from any activity just because they are queer is horrifying to so many young people. Young Life knows this, theyâ€™re not naive to that. And for that reason, they are toeing this very fine line.â€
A Pattern Emerges

Garcia said she doesnâ€™t think she fully grasped that Young Life was an evangelical ministry when she first heard about it back in 2005. She didnâ€™t have much exposure to evangelicalism at that point in her life. Other than having her grandmaâ€™s funeral at a Catholic church, religion wasnâ€™t a big part of her life.

All she knew was that Young Life was something the popular kids at her public high school in Bradenton, Florida, participated in. Garcia remembers the girls on the schoolâ€™s basketball team pushing her to check it out. Young Life leaders came to her school, got to know her, and encouraged her to attend the ministryâ€™s week-long summer camp in North Carolina, Garcia said.

That week changed the course of Garciaâ€™s life. She still remembers seeing Young Lifeâ€™s Windy Gap camp for the first time and being blown away by the beauty of the Appalachian Mountains, the rustic cabins, the zip line and the basketball courts. And then there was the community, the sense of belonging and acceptance that staff members worked hard to create for kids.

By the end of camp, Garcia had gone from being ambivalent about religion to making an evangelical profession of faith â€• standing up during a meeting and declaring that she had accepted Jesus as her personal savior.
She stayed involved in Young Life for the rest of high school, going to weekly club meetings with friends, attending a local church and volunteering at camp.

â€œI loved that kids come [to Young Life] and they feel so safe, they can be who they want, they can have a good time and forget about whatever else is going on in their lives,â€ she told HuffPost. â€œI thought that this is what Jesus would do, he wants everybody here and everyone to know that theyâ€™re safe and loved and that this life is good.â€

Garcia said she believed so deeply in the groupâ€™s mission that she turned down a basketball scholarship to a secular college in order to attend a Christian college in Florida, just so that she could learn how to be a better Young Life leader. Garcia went on to become a Young Life staff member, working at a camp in California before finally getting a job as a housekeeper at what had long been her dream location â€• Young Lifeâ€™s Lost Canyon camp in Williams, Arizona.

By then, Garcia said, she had known for a long time that she was queer. She had struggled to repress her sexuality for years, but in 2017, with the help of a therapist, she said she felt ready to come out to herself and to the people she loved. She knew that Young Life was a conservative organization, but because of how inclusive and welcoming the organization had seemed for all this time, she said, she still believed that it wouldnâ€™t prioritize its policies over people.

Thatâ€™s not what happened. Instead, Young Life gave Garcia an ultimatum â€• pledge to remain celibate, or be forced to resign. It was presented as a choice, but it didnâ€™t seem like a fair one to her, she said.

â€œOne of the biggest things Iâ€™ve learned over the years with Young Life is to be your most authentic self, your healthiest self. To love others, love yourself, and love God,â€ she said. â€œTo love myself, I needed to accept this part of me. To hear that they were going to tell me to choose to live a life of celibacy, thatâ€™s not living an authentic life.â€
Several queer, former Young Life volunteers and staffers who are part of the Do Better Young Life campaign shared similar stories with HuffPost.

Alyssa Silva, a 24-year-old former Young Life student and volunteer, told HuffPost she was a nonpracticing Catholic before she was introduced to Young Life in 2010. At her public high school in Lucas, Texas, Young Life was the â€œpopularâ€ thing to do, she said.

In her junior year of high school, Young Life leaders asked her to help out with Wyldlife, the organizationâ€™s middle school ministry, she said. During high school, she said, she never heard Young Life leaders in her region explicitly talking to kids about the organizationâ€™s beliefs around sexuality and gender.

Young Lifeâ€™s non-affirming theology became clearer to her when she started volunteering with the ministry as a college student at Texas A&M University, she said. At meetings, the area director for the Brazos Valley region would tell college-aged leaders that if a kid in their care came out to them as gay or lesbian, the children should be told that these feelings stemmed from a â€œmisplaced desire,â€ Silva said.

When Silva decided to come out to that same area director in 2017, she knew she would need to step down. But his reaction still shook her. He told her she needed to â€œstop being gayâ€ and that she was no longer â€œworthy or qualifiedâ€ to serve as a leader, Silva said.
â€œHe told me that I was a wolf in a herd of sheep. He told me a lot of really hurtful things that I still think about to this day, and itâ€™s been almost three years,â€ Silva said.
The director outed her to the rest of the Young Life leadership team and she ended up being ostracized from the community that she had grown to love, she said.

â€œIt was truly devastating,â€ she said. â€œI was alone, I was terrified. There were days on days on days that I couldnâ€™t get out of bed. I would go into these crazy crying spells where I just couldnâ€™t stop. Eventually, I got to the point where I was suicidal. It was a really hard and dark time.â€

The Brazos Valley Young Life chapter did not reply to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment on Silvaâ€™s story. Young Lifeâ€™s central communications team also declined to explain if and how Young Life volunteers and staff are trained to respond when a queer student comes out to them.

Studies have suggested that religiosity could be a protective factor against suicide attempts. But that protective effect hasnâ€™t been documented among LGBTQ individuals. Data from a 2011 survey from the University of Texas at Austinâ€™s Research Consortium, one of the few large-scale studies that investigated suicidal behavior, sexual orientation and religion among college students, suggested that increased levels of religiosity were associated with increased odds of suicidal ideation among queer youth.

Josh Truitt, a 24-year-old former college volunteer for Young Life in Georgetown, Texas, told HuffPost that at first, he bought into the ministryâ€™s position that it is wrong for Christians to be in same-sex relationships. But even then, he says, he was never fully accepted by the ministry as a gay, celibate Christian.

Truitt said he wasnâ€™t allowed to be open about his sexuality while volunteering for the group. When he tried to give a testimony at camp about how being gay doesnâ€™t separate people from Godâ€™s love, staff members not only stopped him from speaking, they also started treating him as if he were a threat to children simply because he was gay, he said.

Truitt said he also heard a speaker at a Young Life leadership conference say that it didnâ€™t matter if a queer person was or wasnâ€™t sexually active â€• and that simply having same-sex attractions disqualified someone from being a ministry leader.
After months of wrestling with depression and suicidal thoughts, Truitt said he decided to leave Young Life of his own accord.

â€œI finally came to the realization, through a lot of therapy and a lot of tough conversations and reading everything under the sun, that God didnâ€™t create me to go through life in a state of mental unhealth,â€ he said. â€œGod created me to live life and live it abundantly. And thatâ€™s not what being closeted was.â€

Young Life presents itself as a ministry where the â€œweirdest, strangest, most out-there kids,â€ can feel safe and accepted, Truitt said. But he believes that in practice, itâ€™s for the â€œwhitest, straightest, most Protestant kidsâ€ at a school.

Do Better Young Life organizers say that the ministryâ€™s anti-queer policies are just one example of a culture that is unwelcoming to kids from marginalized communities. The group has shared stories from former participants who claim they were subjected to racist jokes and tokenization, classism, misogyny and other forms of discrimination.

â€œIâ€™ve been told things like, â€˜Youâ€™re not meant to lead at this school. Youâ€™ll be more of an impact with the urban kidsâ€™ or things like, â€˜Youâ€™re not like everyone else! Youâ€™re different!â€™ Iâ€™ve been used for racial jokes in front of hundreds of campers and Iâ€™ve fallen victim to making those jokes myself simply because I was being influenced by the wrong people,â€ one Black former Young Lifer wrote on Instagram.

To address all of these issues, the ministry has announced it will convene a council of top leaders and â€œstaff and non-staffâ€ to review the stories of former Young Life leaders who say they were deceived and mistreated and â€œrecommend the appropriate course of action in each case.â€

Young Life declined to answer HuffPostâ€™s questions about whether the council will include people in same-sex relationships or those who identify as trans, as well as questions about when the review will be completed and how the results will be shared with kids, parents and the public.

Young Life told HuffPost that the ministry is confident that its theology is faithful to â€œGodâ€™s vision for human sexuality.â€ The stories some former participants have shared â€œhighlight the need to review how we train staff and volunteers to come alongside and love kids who identify as LGBTQ+ â€” without conditions, [judgment] or shame.â€

The organization insisted that â€œthe vast majority of young people, including those who identify as LGBTQ+, have positive experiences in Young Life.â€ HuffPost requested to be connected to a current or former Young Life participant, volunteer or employee who is in a queer relationship or is gender diverse and had an overall positive experience with the organization. Young Life has not responded to that request.
Truitt said his biggest concern now is making sure that others donâ€™t experience what he did.

â€œI never want someone to come out to [a leader at Young Life] and their canned response to be, â€˜Thatâ€™s sinful and you need to change,â€™â€ he said. â€œThat will lead kids down deep dark tunnels that they donâ€™t need to be in and that I found myself in when I was leading Young Life.â€

Three years after being pushed out of Young Life, Garcia said that the emotional and spiritual trauma that came with that rejection still feels fresh. She admitted there are some days when she still wishes she could go back and work at camp.

But ultimately, Garcia said, she decided not to let the ministry decide whom she was going to love. She emphasized to HuffPost that sheâ€™s thankful for the lessons she learned from the pain and for the life sheâ€™s built for herself outside the ministry. Despite the harmful theology Young Life tried to pass on to her, she said she fully believes that â€œwho I am is okay and good.â€
The Do Better Young Life campaign has shown her that sheâ€™s not the only one, she said.
â€œI loved my life there,â€ she said about Young Life. â€œBut it wasnâ€™t worth compromising who I am. And thatâ€™s what I want for kids, I donâ€™t want them to feel like they have to hide.â€
â€œI want people to know that they are seen and celebrated and loved.â€

If you or someone you know needs help, call 1-800-273-8255 for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. You can also text HOME to 741-741 for free, 24-hour support from the Crisis Text Line. Outside of the U.S., please visit the International Association for Suicide Prevention for a database of resources.

otherData.headline: Here's How Long You're Protected From COVID-19 After Recovery
otherData.short_description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention posted new guidance for people who've recovered from the coronavirus.

articleContent: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention put out new guidance this month on retesting and quarantining for people who have been infected with the coronavirus.

The latest information suggests that a person is likely protected for up to three months once theyâ€™ve recovered from COVID-19. During that period, the CDC said, people who had COVID-19 might still continue to test positive, but they may not be infectious to others.

â€œPeople who have tested positive for COVID-19 do not need to quarantine or get tested again for up to three months as long as they do not develop symptoms again,â€ the CDC said. â€œPeople who develop symptoms again within three months of their first bout of COVID-19 may need to be tested again if there is no other cause identified for their symptoms.â€
However, the agency clarified that this does not mean is that people whoâ€™ve had COVID-19 are immune from the disease for three months, nor does it affect a personâ€™s antibodies.

â€œThis science does not imply a person is immune to reinfection with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, in the 3 months following infection,â€ the CDC said in a statement. â€œThe latest data simply suggests that retesting someone in the 3 months following initial infection is not necessary unless that person is exhibiting the symptoms of COVID-19 and the symptoms cannot be associated with another illness.â€

Thereâ€™s still not much we know about COVID-19 antibodies and reinfection. Since the virus is still so new, experts canâ€™t say for certain how long someone can expect to be immune to the virus after theyâ€™ve been sick.

Previous research does suggest that three months may be the duration of immunity. A study from China published in June found that a significant number of COVID-19 patients showed a decrease in immunity levels around two or three months after infection. However, the study size was small and examined only asymptomatic patients.

Other experts believe whatâ€™s more likely is that antibodies wane over time but thereâ€™s still some level of protection. This is thanks to cells in charge of activating the bodyâ€™s immune response, called B cells and T cells, which essentially â€œrememberâ€ how to fight off the virus and may re-trigger antibodies if a person is exposed to the virus again.

â€œWhen the body generates an immune response [to a virus], T cells remember in case of a possibility of future reinfection, so that if presented with the virus again your body recognizes it and knows how to handle it,â€ Christine Bishara, an internal medicine physician and founder of From Within Medical in New York, recently told HuffPost.

Experts have also noted that those who have reported being reinfected with COVID-19 may actually just not have fully recovered from their first infection.
What This New Guidance Means For Us
Does the new CDC guidance suggest that youâ€™re free to return to your pre-pandemic life for a few months after youâ€™ve recovered from COVID-19? Nope, sorry.

While experts say itâ€™s pretty unlikely youâ€™ll be reinfected, itâ€™s not 100% impossible. If youâ€™ve recently been diagnosed with COVID-19, thereâ€™s also a chance you could still be contagious depending on where you are in the course of the illness. People with mild cases can potentially spread the illness for about 10 days after symptoms first appear. Those with more severe cases may be infectious for about 20 days after the initial signs of the illness.
To reiterate, the new CDC guidance applies to those who have recovered.

Until thereâ€™s a vaccine â€• and maybe even beyond that point â€• experts say itâ€™s important to exercise health precautions like wearing a mask, social distancing, washing your hands frequently and staying home if you feel sick. These actions are just generally vital to overall public health during the pandemic.

Experts are still learning about COVID-19. The information in this story is what was known or available as of publication, but guidance could change as scientists discover more about the virus. Please check the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the most updated recommendations.

otherData.headline: House Committee Calls On Postmaster General To Testify On USPS Changes
otherData.short_description: The changes have stoked fears they are aimed at holding up mail-in election ballots.

articleContent: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Top Democrats in the U.S. Congress on Sunday called on President Donald Trumpâ€™s appointed postmaster general to testify this month on changes that have stoked fears they are aimed at holding up mail-in ballots ahead of the November election.

The Postal Serviceâ€™s internal watchdog has begun investigating a wave of cost-cutting kicked off by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy that has slowed mail delivery around the country, alarming lawmakers ahead of the Nov. 3 election when up to half of U.S. voters could cast ballots by mail.
Congressional Democrats called on DeJoy, a donor to Republican President Donald Trump, and U.S. Postal Service Chairman Robert Duncan to testify in an Aug. 24 committee hearing.

â€œThe President has explicitly stated his intention to manipulate the Postal Service to deny eligible voters access to the ballot in pursuit of his own re-election,â€ Democrats including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Oversight Chairwoman Carolyn Maloney said in a joint statement. â€œThe Postmaster General and top Postal Service leadership must answer to the Congress and the American people as to why they are pushing these dangerous new policies that threaten to silence the voices of millions, just months before the election.â€
DeJoy did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Democrats have accused Trump, who is trailing presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden in polls, of trying to hamstring the cash-strapped Postal Service to suppress mail-in voting.

Trump himself on Thursday said he had held up talks with Congress over a fresh round of coronavirus stimulus funding to block Democrats from providing more funds for mail-in voting and election infrastructure.

Trump later walked back those comments, saying he would not veto a bill that included funds for the Postal Service. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows told CNN on Sunday said he would agree to $10 billion to $25 billion in fresh Postal funding. Democrats had sought $25 billion.
Pelosi may recall lawmakers from a summer recess to address changes at the Postal Service, a Democratic congressional aide said on Saturday.
WHITE HOUSE FEARS PELOSI

Separately, Meadows told CNNâ€™s State of the Union that the White House fears a surge in mail-in voting could delay election results and leave the naming of the new president to the speaker of the House.

â€œA number of states are now trying to figure out how they are going to go to universal mail-in ballots,â€ Meadows said. â€œThatâ€™s a disaster where we wonâ€™t know the election results on Nov. 3 and we might not know it for months and for me thatâ€™s problematic because the Constitution says that then a Nancy Pelosi in the House would actually pick the president on Jan. 20. So we need to make sure that we do it right.â€

Trump has repeatedly and without evidence said that a surge in mail-in voting would lead to fraud. Voting by mail is nothing new in the United States, as one in four voters cast ballots that way in 2016.

The House could vote on a measure to prohibit the Postal Service from implementing any changes to the operations or level of service it had in place in January 2020, until the COVID-19 pandemic has ended.
U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders told ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ he would back that move.
â€œThe House should come back and make sure that the U.S. Postal Service is fully funded,â€ Sanders said. â€œThis goes to the fact of whether or not we are a democracy.â€
(Reporting by Jonathan Landay; Additional reporting by David Shepardson; Editing by Scott Malone, Lisa Shumaker and Nick Zieminski)

otherData.headline: Rihanna Spells Out Exactly What She Thinks Of Donald Trump With Graffiti Photos
otherData.short_description: The pop star was dubbed "BadGalBanksy" following her latest social media post criticizing the president.

articleContent: Rihanna is counting down the days until the 2020 election.
The pop star â€” a vocal critic of President Donald Trump â€” on Friday tweeted images of what appeared to be someone painting the words â€œFUCK TRUMPâ€ on the roof of an out-of-commission vehicle.
She captioned the post: â€œArt. #81 days.â€
Itâ€™s unclear if Rihanna is the person featured in the pictures, and representatives for the singer did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for further information.
The exact location of the photos is also unknown, but social media users suggested the photos were taken along Route 66 at the Cadillac Ranch near Amarillo, Texas.
Rihanna confirmed the post was about the election with this response:
The singerâ€™s fans lapped up the photos.
Stylist Matthew Mazur dubbed her BadGalBanksy â€• in reference to the musicianâ€™s â€œBadGalRiriâ€ Instagram handle and the anonymous British street artist, Banksy.

Rihanna has previously slammed Trump over his immigration policies, for failing to call mass shootings â€œterrorism,â€ and his disastrous handling of the federal response to Hurricane Maria that hit Puerto Rico in 2017.
In 2018, she sent Trump a cease-and-desist notice to stop him from playing her songs at campaign rallies.

otherData.headline: 'Devastating': The Census Bureau Is About To Severely Undercount Tribes
otherData.short_description: The agency is ending the 2020 census early. Tribal communities will be skipped over, leaving them poorer and politically weakened.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• The U.S. Census Bureau unexpectedly announced it will end 2020 census field operations early, a decision that will disproportionately hurt Native American tribes that are already historically undercounted, hard to reach and rely on accurate census data for lifesaving federal dollars.

The agency slipped the news into a press release last week: â€œWe will end field data collection by Sept. 30, 2020. Self-response options will also close on that date to permit the commencement of data processing.â€
Thatâ€™s a month earlier than the Census Bureau â€• and any organization focused on a strong census count â€• planned for all year.
So what? Itâ€™s only a month, right? And why does the census matter anyway, beyond showing us how many people live here and where they live?

The census is so much more than a headcount. Census data is used to draw congressional districts, which means, for example, the more that minorities are counted in a given area, the more likely they will be kept together as a community and have a voice in Congress. If fewer minorities are counted in a given area, those communities are broken apart and lumped into other districts.

Census data is also used to decide how much federal money goes to every community. For each person who isnâ€™t counted in the census, their community loses thousands of dollars every year for the next 10 years. That money would have otherwise been used for services like health care, education, infrastructure and housing assistance.

Native Americans were the most undercounted population in the country the last time the census was taken in 2010. This time, itâ€™s going to be even worse because of the Census Bureauâ€™s decision to close up shop early.

Why? People in remote areas, like many tribal communities, often rely on census takers coming to them in the final stage of data collection to do â€œnonresponse follow-ups.â€ They knock on the doors of people who havenâ€™t responded to the census online or by mail, and they interview them. Many people on reservations donâ€™t have internet access or reliable mail, so they get counted in person. But because of the coronavirus pandemic, reservations closed to the public for months. Now, with census field operations cut short, census takers simply wonâ€™t reach some of these communities at all.

â€œIt ensures a historic, devastating undercount for Native Americans,â€ said Natalie Landreth, senior staff attorney at the Native American Rights Fund. â€œIt ensures it. Weâ€™re not guessing. Weâ€™ve run all the numbers, and we know it.â€

Tribes in remote areas rely entirely on federal dollars for health care, which the federal government is required to provide to millions of Native Americans under its treaty obligations. A census undercount means they will get a fraction of the federal money they are owed for the next 10 years, in an already chronically underfunded health care system overseen by the Indian Health Service, amid a pandemic that has ravaged tribal communities.

Native Americans have long been undercounted. The official estimated undercount in the 2010 census was 4.9%, though Landreth said it was likely closer to 7%. But this yearâ€™s pandemic and the Census Bureauâ€™s shortened timeline mean tribes will take a bigger hit.

â€œItâ€™s going to throw people who are already poor into more extreme poverty and diminish their political power so you never get anybody who represents your interests,â€ Landreth said. â€œThink of being powerless and poor. Thatâ€™s what this does.â€

The 2020 census response rate is trackable on the Census Bureauâ€™s website. It currently shows a 63.6% response rate nationwide among people who responded online, by mail or by phone. If you toggle the data, it shows a 20.5% response rate among tribes.

In Alaska, which is home to 229 of the 574 federally recognized tribes in the country, the level of census data collection among tribes sounds abysmal. The state is so big and some tribes are so remote that census takers typically head into communities as early as January, much earlier than in the rest of the country. But bad storms early in the year delayed the process. That was followed by tribesâ€™ shutting down for months because of the pandemic. Now that itâ€™s August, a lot of locals arenâ€™t home. Theyâ€™ve left their villages for weeks of fishing and hunting as part of the seasonal subsistence cycle.

On top of that, the Census Bureau sowed confusion among Alaskan tribes about how census data would be collected this year, said Nicole Borromeo, executive vice president of the Alaska Federation of Natives.

â€œThey had been trained to tell rural residents that they could only do it in person. Now theyâ€™re being told they can do it online or over the phone, when they had neither option before,â€ she said. â€œThen they said theyâ€™d be back in person. But instead, theyâ€™re just mailing them flyers and postcards. Then they said field operations are going to last through October. Now all of a sudden theyâ€™re ending at the end of September.â€
It doesnâ€™t help that there is already a massive amount of distrust of the federal government among tribes due to decades of oppression and broken promises.
â€œThis could not be any worse for Alaska,â€ Borromeo added.
Three major tribal advocacy groups last week issued a rare joint statement sounding the alarm on the Census Bureauâ€™s â€œunwarranted and irresponsible decisionâ€ to cut short the census count.

â€œOur tribal nations and tribal communities have been ravaged by COVID-19, and an extension of the census enumeration period was a humane lifeline during an unprecedented global health catastrophe that provided critically needed additional time to tribal nations to ensure that ... everyone in their communities are counted,â€ said the statement from the National Congress of American Indians, the Native American Rights Fund and the National Urban Indian Family Coalition. â€œFor millions of American Indians and Alaska Natives, whether they live on rural reservations or in Americaâ€™s large cities, an inaccurate census count will decimate our ability to advocate for necessary services for our most vulnerable communities.â€
The groups urged Congress to include language in the next COVID-19 relief bill to require the Census Bureau to stick to its original Oct. 31 deadline to end field operations.

There is some support for this on Capitol Hill. Sens. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) and Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) wrote to House and Senate leaders Tuesday urging them to extend the statutory deadlines to deliver census data to the president and states to the spring of 2021 from Dec. 31. That would extend the entire census process, not just field operations, which is what some census officials have said they need to do an accurate census count.

â€œIn July, the associate director of the census, Albert Fontenot, said, â€˜We are past the window of being able to get those countsâ€™ by yearâ€™s end,â€ said the letter from Murkowski and Schatz, which was signed by a total of 48 senators. â€œExtending the deadlines for the delivery of these files in the next COVID-19 relief package will ensure that the Census Bureau has adequate time to complete a full, fair and accurate 2020 census.â€

But congressional leaders are nowhere near a deal on the next COVID-19 relief bill. Congress doesnâ€™t even return from a break until September. And in a depressing sign that the census itself has become a partisan issue, only two of the 48 senators who signed the Murkowski-Schatz letter are Republicans: Murkowksi and fellow Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska.
HuffPost could only find one other GOP senator, Steve Daines of Montana, who publicly urged the Census Bureau to extend its deadlines.

A spokesperson for Sen. John Hoeven (R-N.D.), who chairs the Committee on Indian Affairs, did not respond to a request for comment on whether he is concerned about census field operations ending early and hurting tribes.
Rep. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.), chairman of the House Subcommittee for Indigenous Peoples of the United States, said thereâ€™s only one reason why the Census Bureau is closing up shop early.

â€œThis is all politically motivated,â€ he said. â€œThis is about Republicans trying to keep control over a changing demographic that they just canâ€™t keep up with. ... Republicans understand if the census data comes back strong, when it comes to reelections, theyâ€™re going to have an even harder time holding power through a gerrymandered district.â€
It makes no sense to stop counting people early, and all signs point to corruption within the Trump administration, Gallego added.
â€œThey could ask for more money if they wanted,â€ he said. â€œThey have given us no real reason for this. Theyâ€™re just not going to count.â€

A Census Bureau spokesperson responded to a HuffPost request for comment by emailing a link to the agencyâ€™s press release announcing its plans to end its field operations early. The spokesperson did not respond to a follow-up email asking if politics are driving the agencyâ€™s decision.

With Congress gone and hardly any Republicans making the issue a priority, thereâ€™s nothing stopping the Census Bureau from ending its count early. Unless something changes, tribal villages and reservations already wrestling with poverty and health disparities will have to brace for even fewer federal resources for another 10 years.
â€œThis is harming their day-to-day ability to live for the next decade,â€ Landreth said. â€œIâ€™ve never seen anything like this.â€

otherData.headline: Dennis Quaid 'Couldn't Resist' Adopting A Cat Named Dennis Quaid
otherData.short_description: The actor, who discovered a cat with his name at the Lynchburg Humane Society, says he is "out to save all the Dennis Quaids of the world.â€

articleContent: Dennis Quaid has found a new home ... with Dennis Quaid.

The 66-year-old Hollywood star came across a recent news report about a cat by the same name at the Lynchburg Humane Society in Virginia, and in an incredible twist, the actual actor decided to adopt him.
â€œIt was really off the wall, but I just couldnâ€™t resist. I had to,â€ said â€œThe Parent Trapâ€ star, who added: â€œIâ€™m out to save all the Dennis Quaids of the world.â€

As for the kitty Quaid, he is a 6-year-old black cat who weighs just under 14 pounds. His bio on the Lynchburg Humane Societyâ€™s website says: â€œI may not live up to my dramatic and artistic actor namesake, Iâ€™d rather watch his movies with you curled up on the couch! Would you like to movie marathon with me? Come meet me!â€

The human Quaid, who happens to host a pet podcast called â€œThe Pet Show,â€ heard about the cat and knew he had to take care of the animal. However, when Quaidâ€™s co-host Jimmy Jellinek contacted the shelter, they didnâ€™t immediately believe it was actually Quaid who wanted the cat.
Danielle Ulmer, adoption center manager at the Lynchburg Humane Society, told local NBC affiliate WSLS that she thought â€œthere is no way this is real, like, someone is pranking us.â€

Eventually, Quaid and Jellinek convinced the shelter staff to take part in a Zoom call, and any notion of a joke faded away. Jellinek, according to WSLS, is slated to fly from Los Angeles to Lynchburg to pick up the cat this weekend.

After Quaid quipped that people should â€œstart naming animals in shelters after different celebrities and see who bites,â€ Ulmer told him: â€œWeâ€™ve already talked about that. Weâ€™re like alright, so everyone pick your top three favorite celebrities.â€
We can only hope that when the Quaids meet, theyâ€™ll snuggle up and watch some of the human Quaidâ€™s films. Weâ€™d recommend â€œFrequencyâ€ to really get the bonding going.

otherData.headline: Meghan Markle Talks 'Clickbait' And 'Toxicity' In The Media
otherData.short_description: The Duchess of Sussex joined The 19th's Emily Ramshaw to talk about what a more equitable newsroom can look like, voter suppression and more.

articleContent: Meghan Markle just added a new job to her resume: interviewer.

The Duchess of Sussex, who once reportedly thought about becoming a journalist herself, sat down with Emily Ramshaw, co-founder and CEO of The 19th*, on Friday for a candid discussion at The 19th* Represents Summit.

Ramshaw, former editor-in-chief of nonprofit media organization The Texas Tribune, spoke with the duchess about how The 19th* came to be and what a newsroom can look like with better representation. Meghan also spoke about the downfalls of clickbait and the â€œeconomy for attentionâ€ in media and what it was like to return to the U.S. after a decade away.

Ramshaw opened with some of the challenges of founding The 19th*, especially in the midst of a global pandemic. But as she saw how COVID-19 personally affected women in terms of issues like job loss and child care and as the U.S. went through a racial reckoning, she realized her mission was more important than ever.
The co-founder said The 19th* was really the first national news outlet to elevate the killing of Breonna Taylor after one of Taylorâ€™s family members approached an editor there.

Ramshaw said she hopes her team, which is 91% women, will set the â€œgold standard for the industry.â€ She added that there is a hunger for the kind of coverage The 19th* provides and the outlet has a â€œmoral obligation to meet women where they are,â€ which is one of the reasons itâ€™s letting people and organizations republish their stories for free.

Ramshaw later switched gears to ask Meghan a few questions about her extremely personal experience with the media and how she thinks coverage would be different with more women and people of color at the helm of news organizations.

â€œI think whatâ€™s so fascinating â€• at least from my standpoint and my personal experience the past couple of years â€• is the headline alone, the clickbait alone, makes an imprint,â€ the duchess said. â€œThat is part of how we start to view the world, how we interact with other people.â€

Meghan added that there is â€œso much toxicityâ€ in this â€œeconomy for attention,â€ something she and her husband, Prince Harry, often talk about. â€œThat is what it monetizable right now when youâ€™re looking at the digital space and media. If youâ€™re just trying to grab someoneâ€™s attention and keep it, youâ€™re going for something salacious versus something truthful.â€

â€œYou want to have trust in journalism and you want to have trust in what youâ€™re reading and hope that itâ€™s fact,â€ she later said. â€œWeâ€™ve been so sadly comfortable with the idea that we are just getting all of this stuff and it becomes noise as opposed to truth and accurate journalism.â€
Ramshaw also asked Meghan, who moved back to her hometown of Los Angeles after about 10 years away, what it was like to be back in the U.S. at this moment in time.
â€œIt was so sad to see where our country was in that moment,â€ Meghan said of returning to LA as the country was mourning the deaths of Black Americans like Taylor, George Floyd, and Ahmaud Arbery.

â€œI think at the onset, if Iâ€™m being honest, it was just devastating,â€ the duchess added. â€œIf thereâ€™s any silver lining in that, I would say that in the weeks after the murder of George Floyd, in the peaceful protests that you were seeing, in the voices that were coming out, in the way that people were actually owning their role and acknowledging their role ... I can see that the tide is turning.â€

â€œItâ€™s not new to see this undercurrent of racism and certainly unconscious bias, but I think to see the changes that are being made right now is something I look forward to being a part of,â€ the duchess added. â€œAnd being a part of using my voice in a way that I havenâ€™t been able to of late. So â€• yeah, itâ€™s good to be home.â€

The 19th* is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom with a focus on the intersection of gender, politics and policy. The organizationâ€™s mission statement is â€œto empower women â€” particularly those underserved by and underrepresented in American media â€” with the information, community and tools they need to be equal participants in our democracy.â€

It gets its name from the 19th Amendment, which, rather than outright giving women the right to vote, guaranteed that states couldnâ€™t bar people from voting due to their sex. This provided enough leeway for states to find ways to continue to disenfranchise women after the amendment was ratified.

The asterisk in the newsroomâ€™s name is meant to symbolize that, in effect, only white women were ensured the right to vote after the amendment was ratified, while Black womenâ€™s right to vote wasnâ€™t solidified until after the Voting Rights Act passed in 1965. And as Ramshaw said during her talk with the duchess, voter suppression is still very alive and real.

Additional guest speakers at the summit included former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Democratic vice presidential pick Sen. Kamala Harris (Calif.), Sen. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.), Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii), and lawyer and voting rights activist Stacey Abrams, among others.

The duchess told Glamour magazine last week in a statement announcing her role and participation at the summit that she was looking forward to asking Ramshaw about â€œwhat it means to build a media outlet with gender equity, diversity, and community at its core.â€
Meghan added that â€œThe 19th*â€™s commitment to reporting and storytelling that lifts up those who are too often underrepresented in the media has never been more important.â€
Ramshaw told CNN that the duchessâ€™s participation in the summit was Meghanâ€™s idea. Ramshaw said she â€œnearly fell out of my chairâ€ after receiving a call from the Sussex team.

â€œThe duchess basically said that the issues that we care about are issues that sheâ€™s really interested in this moment,â€ Ramshaw told CNN, adding that â€œthose things include super-high-quality media, gender equity, racial justice.â€

The Duke and Duchess of Sussex made it clear that they wanted to renegotiate their relationship with the media following their step back as working members of the royal family in January, and theyâ€™ve certainly followed through.

In the weeks and months since their momentous announcement, they have spoken and worked with outlets they might not have collaborated with as members of the royal family, who typically engage with members of the Royal Rota, a pool system used by U.K. journalists.

Prince Harry recently wrote an essay about the divisiveness of social media for Fast Company and spoke to Rashad Robinson, a civil rights activist and president of Color of Change, about systemic racism and online hate in a conversation shared on Instagram.
The Duchess of Sussex shared a powerful graduation address exclusively with Essence following George Floydâ€™s death at the hands of a white police officer.

Meghan also spoke with Glamour to announce her participation in The 19th* Represents Summit and also participated in a Marie Claire feature that asked women why theyâ€™re voting in the upcoming 2020 election.

Omid Scobie, royal editor for Harperâ€™s Bazaar and author of the biography â€œFinding Freedom,â€ told HuffPost this week that the Sussexes are able to do more work in certain areas theyâ€™re passionate about because they donâ€™t have the boundaries they once did as working royals.

â€œPeople often ask us, â€˜Do you think they have freedom?â€™â€ Scobie said of the coupleâ€™s transition. â€œAnd looking at the work that theyâ€™re doing, I do think that they are much freer to do the things that mean the most for them.â€

â€œThey are a couple that talk about impact a lot, and I think that that impact â€• weâ€™re seeing it right in front of us,â€ the journalist said. We â€œsee Meghan talking about voting for the first time in a while because of course, thatâ€™s something she wouldâ€™ve been almost silent about throughout her time as a working royal.â€

â€œI think now we really do hear her voice, as it should be,â€ he added.

Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: Is It Safe To Drink From A Water Fountain During The COVID-19 Pandemic?
otherData.short_description: Here's a brief rundown of the coronavirus risk associated with drinking from a public water fountain.

articleContent: Is it safe to drink from a water fountain during the pandemic?
Thereâ€™s no evidence you can get COVID-19 from the water itself. But since the virus may linger on surfaces, experts say to avoid fountains if you can or to limit any direct contact when using them.

In New York City, for example, posters instruct people to use gloves or a tissue to turn on water fountains. If you donâ€™t have those handy and need to touch the fountain, experts recommend you wash your hands afterward and avoid touching your face until you do. And you shouldnâ€™t let your face touch the spout when leaning in for a drink.

Filling a water bottle is also better than drinking directly from the fountain, says Angela Rasmussen, a virus researcher at Columbia University. That helps ensure you donâ€™t leave saliva on the fountain, making it safer for others.

The precautions are recommended because surfaces are believed to contribute to the spread of COVID-19, even though experts say the main way the virus spreads is through droplets people spray when they talk, cough or sneeze.

To minimize direct contact with fountains, schools and businesses should encourage everyone to bring their own water from home, says the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Fountains should still be cleaned and sanitized for those who need to use them, the agency says.

The CDC also says schools and businesses should check fountains for other safety issues before they reopen. Prolonged closures could increase the risk for Legionnairesâ€™ and other diseases associated with water, since standing water in plumbing systems can cause bacteria to grow.

Experts are still learning about the novel coronavirus. The information in this story is what was known or available as of press time, but itâ€™s possible guidance around COVID-19 could change as scientists discover more about the virus. Please check the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the most updated recommendations.

otherData.headline: Why You Should Start A Journal Right Now (And How To Stick With It)
otherData.short_description: Journaling can help you deal with stress and anxiety, while also documenting life during theÂ coronavirus pandemic.

articleContent: Living through a global pandemic has messed with our mental and emotional health in countless ways. If youâ€™re looking for ways to cope, consider starting a journal.

Mental health professionals have long touted the benefits of journaling: It can alleviate stress and act as a tool to help manage anxiety and depression. Thatâ€™s important right now given that the vast majority â€” 90% â€” of American adults report dealing with emotional distress related to COVID-19, according to a survey from researchers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Harvard Medical School. And people who dealt with mental health conditions before the pandemic may have a more difficult time handling the stress of this crisis, experts say.
Meera Lee Patel, author of â€œCreate Your Own Calm: A Journal for Quieting Anxiety,â€ said a journaling practice can help clear a cluttered mind.

â€œJournaling is a great way to release stress and neutralize anxiety, allowing you to remove the thoughts that are continually cycling in your head by placing them onto paper,â€ she told HuffPost. â€œMany find that after journaling, their minds are clearer, calmer and better equipped to evaluate solutions for the issue at hand.â€

Many of us tend to ignore or suppress difficult emotions. Journaling helps us â€œget acquainted withâ€ these feelings, psychotherapist Kathleen Dahlen deVos said, so we can process them and find ways to move forward.
â€œ[We] learn that while it may still be uncomfortable to tolerate and â€˜be withâ€™ our feelings, we actually have the capacity to handle them,â€ she said.

Plus, journaling is practically free, making it more accessible than other forms of self-care. Lauren Donelson â€” a writer and yoga teacher whoâ€™s studying to be a therapist â€” said sheâ€™s been journaling for seven years and recommends it to almost all of the patients she sees.

â€œI canâ€™t afford therapy every day, but I can check in on my mental health every day by doing some stream-of-consciousness journaling,â€ she said. â€œIt helps me structure my mornings. This sacred time alone each morning has become really important to me over the years. It helps me to connect to myself. If I complain about the same issue for two weeks in my journal, I eventually get sick of myself and do something about it.â€

Another advantage of regular journaling? It can help you spot patterns in your thoughts or behaviors that donâ€™t serve you, connecting the dots between what you think and do and how you feel. Keeping a journal can also help you track progress on your goals and observe your personal growth.
There may be benefits to documenting life during this significant moment in history, too

Between COVID-19 uprooting our daily lives, George Floydâ€™s death spurring a moment of reckoning on race and an upcoming presidential election, 2020 is a tumultuous year by all accounts. While certain memories of the last five months may stick out to you now, theyâ€™ll begin to fade over time â€” if they havenâ€™t already. Keeping a journal can also act as a time capsule of sorts for you to revisit down the road.

â€œItâ€™s incredibly useful both for us personally and on a historical level to keep a daily record of what goes on around us during difficult times,â€ author Ruth Franklin told The New York Times in April.

In a Washington Post opinion piece, â€œWrite It Down. Keep A Pandemic Journal,â€ Columbia University journalism professor Ari L. Goldman notes that chronicling this time on social media isnâ€™t the same as keeping a journal.

â€œFacebook and Instagram are a conversation. They are for others. A journal is for you,â€ he wrote. â€œYou deserve a record. Write it down so you will remember how you got used to this â€” and how you got through this.â€

As humans, we are hard-wired to look for meaning in our experiences, Dahlen deVos said. It gives our lives a sense of purpose and order. Journaling during a difficult time like the one weâ€™re living through can help us â€œfind peace in and acceptance of challenging experiences and learn from them,â€ she said.

â€œWe all want to know that our lives matter, that our lived and shared experiences have meaning,â€ Dahlen deVos said. â€œDocumenting this moment in history may help us find and create meaning in the fear, grief and overwhelm we might currently be experiencing, and offer a bit of soothing by contextualizing this moment in time in the greater arc of our lives and histories.â€
Hereâ€™s how to start journaling â€” and stick with it
Use a pen and paper instead of keeping a digital journal.
â€œI find that writing, as opposed to typing, helps slow us down a bit so we can be more intentional and reflective, and also activates a more creative area of the brain,â€ Dahlen deVos said.
Donelson recommends writing in an inexpensive journal if youâ€™re someone who can be overly precious about things.
â€œWhile I love a good $30 Moleskin, Iâ€™ve noticed I am more afraid to write something â€˜badâ€™ if I invested in a fancy notebook,â€ she said.
Write stream of consciousness for 5 minutes. Then gradually add more time.
With this type of journaling, â€œyou try to write whatever is on your mind even if it doesnâ€™t make sense,â€ Donelson said.
Set a timer, put pen to paper and just let the words flow out without judgment.

â€œThis writing isnâ€™t meant to be â€˜goodâ€™ writing,â€ Donelson said. â€œYou donâ€™t even have to re-read it if you donâ€™t want to! The point is to just get whatever is in your head out onto the page. I suggest starting with five or 10 minutes a day. If you enjoy it, go for 20 minutes.â€
Or use a prompt to get the juices flowing.
â€œIf a blank page seems intimidating to you, there are many journals with insightful prompts and exercises that can help you get started,â€ Patel said.
You can find plenty of ideas online, too.
Write at the same time every day if you can.
Whether you do it right when you wake up, during your lunch break or before bed, it doesnâ€™t matter. Choose a time and stick to it.
â€œIâ€™m a morning person, so journaling first thing in the morning works really well for me,â€ Donelson said.
Remember that your journal is just for you.
You donâ€™t need to impress anyone with your writing â€” not even yourself.
â€œI would suggest keeping your journal private and trying to be as honest and real with yourself as possible,â€ Donelson said.
And if delving into certain subjects is too painful for you, donâ€™t pressure yourself to keep writing. Itâ€™s OK to take a break or stop journaling altogether if itâ€™s not working for you.
â€œExperiencing symptoms of hypervigilance, stress or distress are signals to discontinue your journaling exercise,â€ University of Wisconsin psychologist Shilagh A. Mirgain told UW Health.
Donâ€™t worry if you skip a day.

â€œInstead of beating yourself up for missing a day or two â€” or 12 â€” of journaling, which only creates more disappointment and resistance within you, simply begin again,â€ Patel said. â€œIt takes time for our brains to create new neural pathways, which means that the desire to journal will often follow after youâ€™ve already taken the initiative to begin journaling.â€

otherData.headline: Linxin Wen: Why Big Delivery Apps Are Bad For Small Restaurants
otherData.short_description: The Chowbus co-founder explains the struggles of independent restaurants, and why ordering chicken and broccoli at every Chinese joint is a mistake.

articleContent: Linxin Wen â€” the 29-year-old CEO and co-founder of Chowbus, a delivery app that specializes in high-quality Asian cuisine â€” is intent on providing customers with access to authentic Asian food, and helping mom-and-pop shops break through a system designed to benefit larger chain restaurants. Chowbus does this by providing â€œdish-focusedâ€ delivery service from independent Asian eateries that might not garner much attention on the likes of GrubHub and UberEats. The perspective of Wen â€” himself an immigrant who moved to the United States seven years ago â€” is unique, as seen through the prism of this Voices in Food story, told to Anna Rahmanan.

Most Americans who arenâ€™t interested in authentic Asian food arenâ€™t interested only because they donâ€™t know about it. Thatâ€™s why so many Asian restaurants have a separate menu they give Americans, featuring non-traditional dishes like â€œorange chickenâ€ that Americans are more familiar with. They think they have to [do that] to survive.

The reality is, Americans often love authentic Asian dishes once theyâ€™re introduced to them. Whenever Iâ€™ve brought American friends to eat at some obscure Chinese mom-and-pop restaurants theyâ€™ve never heard of and Iâ€™ve ordered for the table, everyone has loved it.

Most of the time, they donâ€™t know which dishes are good. That means that, too often, they order the same thing over and over again. For example, when they eat Chinese, they order chicken and broccoli. When they eat Thai, they order pad Thai â€” and so on. By taking the time to figure out what a restaurantâ€™s four to five best dishes are and featuring those [on our app, alongside] professional photographs that help newcomers get a better sense of what the dish will look like, we help all kinds of people discover new flavors they otherwise wouldnâ€™t have felt confident ordering.

One of the biggest struggles for independent restaurants has been getting their name out there. Thatâ€™s been a problem since long before the pandemic â€” and itâ€™s one of the major reasons those restaurants sign on with big delivery services that promise to bring them droves of new customers. The problem is, too often those droves of new customers donâ€™t materialize. Thatâ€™s partly because, on most of the major apps, independent restaurants are deprioritized and pushed so far down in the feed that people can hardly find them. Or, sometimes, the delivery apps do bring in new customers but high commissions and other fees mean only a very small amount of that new revenue goes to the restaurant.

We donâ€™t allow big chains on the platform, only authentic, independently owned restaurants. We [also] donâ€™t let restaurants pay to appear higher in our feed; itâ€™s a flat rate for everyone. If you want to support your community and small businesses, you should order from an independently owned restaurant versus a big chain. Also, the food tends to be better, fresher and more authentic [at mom-and-pop eateries].

A lot of our restaurant partners saw business fall off in the first month or two of the COVID-19 outbreak. But itâ€™s hard to say if that was due to anti-Asian racism or just because people were afraid to eat out in general given the fear theyâ€™d catch the virus. In any case, business has rebounded for a lot of these restaurants, in many cases above and beyond where it was pre-COVID-19, so if there was a backlash, itâ€™s long gone by now. Actually, some restaurants are making more money by just doing delivery. Asian food travels well and has a lot of variety, so I think itâ€™s getting better â€” which is what I want to see.

I came to the United States seven years ago to pursue my masterâ€™s degree and, through hard work and some luck, here I am today. Like many immigrants that come to the U.S. to pursue their dreams, Iâ€™ve faced challenges, whether direct or indirect, whether intentional or unintentional. My goal is to bring people together through food, whether thatâ€™s providing Asian immigrants with a sense of home through their favorite dim sum or introducing others to a new culture through Szechuan cuisine. My hope is that Chowbus can take a small part in bringing people together.

otherData.headline: Could Meghan Markle Run For Office One Day?
otherData.short_description: Meghan "has the capacity to really inspire people and I think thatâ€™s what we need in our country right now," author Carolyn Durand said.

articleContent: Meghan Markle spoke out about the importance of voting in a feature for Marie Claire magazine published on Tuesday. But might the royal have a future in U.S. politics herself?

HuffPost spoke with Carolyn Durand and Omid Scobie â€” authors of the bombshell royals book â€œFinding Freedomâ€ that came out earlier this week â€” about their reporting, the Duchess of Sussexâ€™s voting comments, and whether they think she would ever consider getting more involved in politics or running for office herself.
Durand said she would not make a prediction, but added that the Duchess of Sussex is â€œan incredible role model for women and for young people.

â€œSheâ€™s an incredibly eloquent and inspirational speaker and she has the capacity to really inspire people and get involved and I think thatâ€™s what we need in our country right now,â€ the journalist told HuffPost.

â€œI think that would be a wonderful moment if she decided to do that, but I wouldnâ€™t venture a guess nor would I encourage her to do so,â€ Durand said, adding that sheâ€™s â€œsure that there are many people that would love to see that.â€

â€œI think right now [Meghan and Harry] want to focus on the family and really look to the future â€• setting up their Archewell nonprofit,â€ Durand said. â€œMaybe in the future, weâ€™ll see that, maybe we wonâ€™t.â€
On Tuesday, Marie Claire published a piece featuring 100 women, including the Duchess of Sussex, talking about why theyâ€™re voting in the upcoming 2020 election.
Meghan told the outlet that she knows â€œwhat itâ€™s like to have a voice, and also what itâ€™s like to feel voiceless.â€

â€œI also know that so many men and women have put their lives on the line for us to be heard,â€ the duchess added. â€œAnd that opportunity, that fundamental right, is in our ability to exercise our right to vote and to make all of our voices heard.â€

When asked what the duchess meant by feeling â€œvoiceless,â€ Scobie told HuffPost that â€œwithin the institution of the monarchy there is a freedom to talk about many things, but there often many areas that are also deemed as perhaps slightly too politically sensitive.â€
British royals can vote but the queen must remain politically neutral.

Because the Sussexes have stepped back as working members of the royal family, Scobie, who is the royal editor for Harperâ€™s Bazaar, said that the two â€œdonâ€™t have those same boundaries anymore.â€

Before the change in their royals commitments, the couple â€œnever wouldâ€™ve been able to get involved in the Stop Hate for Profit campaign and calling up big organizations to talk to them about the way they sell their advertising or buy their advertising,â€ he said.

The campaign is made up of civil rights and other advocacy groups asking advertisers to boycott Facebook until it curtails the spread of hate speech and disinformation and the amplification of violent content on its platform.

â€œPeople often ask us, â€˜Do you think they have freedom?â€™â€ Scobie said of the coupleâ€™s transition. â€œAnd looking at the work that theyâ€™re doing, I do think that they are much freer to do the things that mean the most for them.

â€œThey are a couple that talk about impact a lot and I think that that impact â€• weâ€™re seeing it right in front of us,â€ he said. We â€œsee Meghan talking about voting for the first time in a while, because of course thatâ€™s something she wouldâ€™ve been almost silent about throughout her time as a working royal.â€

He mentioned a scene from the book that recounts a story from Harry and Meghanâ€™s wedding reception, where she gave a speech, â€œwhich is a slight diversion from protocol anyway and all of her American friends sort of [started] hooting and hollering because they felt they hadnâ€™t heard their friend Meg speak in so long ... I think now we really do hear her voice, as it should be.â€

A spokesperson for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex previously told HuffPost that the couple â€œwere not interviewed and did not contribute to â€˜Finding Freedomâ€™â€ and that the â€œbook is based on the authorsâ€™ own experiences as members of the royal press corps and their own independent reporting.â€

Meghan, who has been a fierce advocate for womenâ€™s rights since she was a little girl, has made her political opinions known in the past. She denounced Donald Trump as â€œdivisiveâ€ and â€œmisogynisticâ€ during an appearance on â€œThe Nightly Show with Larry Wilmoreâ€ prior to the 2016 election.

Trump has called Meghan â€œnastyâ€ twice and later weighed in on the coupleâ€™s decision to step back as working members of the royal family in January.

He tweeted in March that he wouldnâ€™t be providing security for the Sussexes and that they â€œmust pay!â€ after reports that the two had moved to Meghanâ€™s hometown of Los Angeles.

A spokesperson for the Sussexes said that â€œprivately funded security arrangements have been madeâ€ and the couple did not have plans to ask the U.S. for security assistance.

In â€œFinding Freedom,â€ Scobie and Durand say Meghan reportedly rolled her eyes in reaction to Trumpâ€™s Twitter outburst.
Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: How The South Botched Spanish-Language Outreach On COVID-19
