otherData.headline: Trump Clings To Unproven Treatments As U.S. Sinks Deeper Into Pandemic
otherData.short_description: Frustrated with his low approval ratings, the president is once again leaning in to hydroxychloroquine as a COVID-19 treatment.

articleContent: President Donald Trumpâ€™s press conference quickly unraveled on Tuesday as he struggled to defend a video heâ€™d retweeted that is full of false claims about the coronavirus and complained about his low approval rating.

Reporters asked Trump repeated questions about his continued support for hydroxychloroquine as a COVID-19 treatment a day after he retweeted several conspiracy theories about the drug. Multiple clinical trials have found hydroxychloroquine is not an effective coronavirus treatment, despite the presidentâ€™s suggestions to the contrary.

â€œMany doctors think it is extremely successful,â€ Trump claimed when asked about the retweets, adding, â€œI happen to believe in it. I would take it. As you know, I took it for a 14-day period, and Iâ€™m here. ... Itâ€™s safe. It doesnâ€™t cause problems.â€

Trump was also forced to answer for a video he retweeted on Monday that showed a group of self-proclaimed medical experts claiming that social distancing and masks were not necessary to curb the spread of COVID-19 and alleging that officials were suppressing the use of hydroxychloroquine for political reasons. The event was hosted and funded by the right-wing nonprofit Tea Party Patriots, which has been organizing projects to promote that narrative.

A reporter pointed out to Trump â€• whoâ€™d just recently encouraged Americans to wear protective masks (in line with Dr. Anthony Fauci and other real experts in infectious diseases) â€• that one of the main doctors featured in the video is a full-blown conspiracy theorist: â€œSheâ€™s also made videos saying that doctors make medicine using DNA from aliens and that theyâ€™re trying to create a vaccine to make you immune from becoming religious.â€
The president all but shrugged his shoulders.

â€œShe was on air, along with many other doctors,â€ Trump said. â€œThey were big fans of hydroxychloroquine, and I thought she was very impressive. ... She said that sheâ€™s had tremendous success with hundreds of different patients.â€

In reality, studies have found that hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malarial drug, is not effective for COVID-19 treatment or prevention. After Trump began touting it in March, leading to panic-buying of the medication, the Food and Drug Administration had to post a caution against anyone using it to treat COVID-19 outside a hospital or clinical setting â€• because it can trigger serious heart rhythm problems. The doctors speaking in the video presented no evidence of any patients theyâ€™ve successfully treated.

After fumbling through his answer about the video, Trump quickly walked off the podium, ending the briefing after less than 30 minutes. In the past, his coronavirus-related briefings have lasted for over an hour.

But the president appeared eager to wrap up the event on Tuesday, complaining several times that he was being unfairly maligned. At one point he suggested that health experts were not backing hydroxychloroquine to spite him.
â€œIt doesnâ€™t seem to be too popular,â€ Trump said of the drug. â€œYou know why? Because I recommend it. When I recommend something, they like to say donâ€™t use it.â€

Trump, who typically maintains that heâ€™s very well-liked by voters, also complained to reporters that Fauci, the countryâ€™s leading infectious disease expert who frequently contradicts Trump, is more popular than he is.
â€œHeâ€™s got this high approval rating, so why donâ€™t I have a high approval rating with respect â€• and the administration â€• with respect to the virus? We should have it very high,â€ Trump said.

â€œTheyâ€™re highly thought of,â€ he said of Fauci and Dr. Deborah Birx, who are both on the White Houseâ€™s coronavirus task force. â€œBut nobody likes me. It can only be my personality, thatâ€™s all.â€

Only about one-third of the public approves of the federal governmentâ€™s response to the pandemic, a new HuffPost/YouGov survey found last week, marking a new low. Trumpâ€™s ratings on the pandemic are similarly dismal, with just 38% of the public approving and 58% disapproving.

otherData.headline: Democrats Reject Marijuana Legalization In Party Platform
otherData.short_description: The document supports decriminalization but stops short of full legalization.

articleContent: Democratic National Committee delegates voted 105-60 against including marijuana legalization in the party platform on Monday.

The draft version of the platform supports decriminalizing marijuana use and legalizing medical marijuana, adding that it should be left up to the states â€œto make their own decisions about recreational use.â€

The platform was unlikely to ever endorse full legalization, since Joe Biden, the presumptive nominee, does not back the policy. He supports federal decriminalization, which would take away incarceration for possession.

But Dennis Obduskey, a delegate who introduced the legalization amendment during the meeting of the DNCâ€™s platform committee, noted that the current document is a step back from the 2016 platform, which supported â€œproviding a reasoned pathway for future legalization.â€

Both Obduskey and Iowa County Supervisor Stacey Walker, who served as a member of the joint Biden-Bernie Sanders criminal justice task force, argued that the current federal laws disproportionately affect Black people.

â€œIâ€™m imploring all of you to approach this with an open mind and heart. Do something big here,â€ Walker said. â€œTake one small but meaningful step toward changing the course of history. If my Black life matters to you, you will consider this amendment. We want to get in good trouble today, and I urge you to do the right thing and support it.â€

A 15-person panel, including backers of both Biden and Sanders, initially put together the 80-page platform. Many of the planks came directly from the recommendations of the joint policy task forces the two teams put together this summer as an effort to show a united front against President Donald Trump.

On Monday, the official platform committee of about 180 delegates met virtually to further make changes to the document. The next step is for the nearly 4,000 members of the DNC to vote by mail on whether to ratify it ahead of next monthâ€™s national convention.

Public support for marijuana legalization has steadily risen, with about 66% of Americans backing it. Itâ€™s even more popular with Democrats (76%) and is legal in 11 states plus the District of Columbia.
John Fetterman, the progressive lieutenant governor of Pennsylvania, was shocked last week when he saw that the draft platform didnâ€™t back legalization, as he expressed on Twitter.

DNC delegates also overwhelmingly opposed an amendment backing â€œMedicare for All,â€ the health care system pushed by Sanders allies. At least 600 delegates have pledged to oppose the party platform if it doesnâ€™t include support for the policy, although that wonâ€™t be enough members to block ratification.

In the initial drafting process, however, Sanders allies did get a nod to Medicare for All into the platform, which they considered a victory. It states that the â€œparty welcomes advocates who want to build on and strengthen the Affordable Care Act and those who support a Medicare for All approach; all are critical to ensuring that health care is a human right.â€

otherData.headline: GOP Rep. Louie Gohmert, Who Wrote Off Mask Wearing, Tests Positive For COVID-19
otherData.short_description: The Texas Republican lawmaker was tested Wednesday before he was scheduled to travel with President Donald Trump.

articleContent: Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-Texas), who has been seen without a coronavirus face mask in the U.S. Capitol and last month downplayed the importance of wearing one, has confirmed that he has tested positive for COVID-19.

In a video posted to Twitter Wednesday afternoon, Gohmert said he tested positive for the virus during a routine test given to him upon his arrival at the White House earlier that morning. He said he is asymptomatic and that he has been wearing a mask in recent days, including during Tuesdayâ€™s House Judiciary Committee hearing with Attorney General William Barr.

â€œIâ€™ve worn a mask more in the last week or two than I have in the whole last four months,â€ he said, then suggested that his mask may have inadvertently caused his infection since he was frequently adjusting it with his hands.
â€œI canâ€™t help wonder if that puts some germs in the mask,â€ he said. â€œNow that I apparently have it, I will be very, very careful to make sure that I donâ€™t give it to anybody else.â€
The 66-year-old lawmaker was seen wearing a bandana around his neck at Tuesdayâ€™s hearing, during which he questioned Barr about protests taking place and their relation to the virusâ€™s spread.
But Gohmert was not wearing a mask when he arrived for the hearing directly behind Barr, who also wasnâ€™t wearing a mask, according to video shared on social media by a reporter for The Hill.
Gohmert received a coronavirus test before he planned to fly to Texas with President Donald Trump, Politico first reported, citing multiple unnamed sources.
He returned to his Capitol Hill office to inform his staff of his positive test in person, ABC News reported, citing unnamed â€œpeople familiar with the matter.â€

Gohmertâ€™s chief of staff, Connie Hair, did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment Wednesday but tweeted that the congressman wore a mask during Tuesdayâ€™s hearing unless he was speaking and â€œhas been wearing one.â€
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) told an MSNBC reporter that she is â€œso sorry for himâ€ upon hearing the news of Gohmertâ€™s diagnosis.

â€œBut Iâ€™m also sorry [for] my members who are concerned because he has been showing up at meetings without a mask and making a thing of it,â€ she added. â€œHopefully, now, he will look after his health and others.â€

Gohmert, an eight-term representative, said last month that he would not wear a facial covering, which health officials recommend to prevent the virusâ€™s spread. He argued in an interview with CNN that he is tested regularly for the virus and has never had it.
â€œBut if I get it, youâ€™ll never see me without a mask,â€ he told the news outlet.

Gohmert made similar statements during a meeting with Trump in May, when he told attending media outlets that members of Congress are tested regularly for the virus and that â€œthe only reason we would wear masks is if we were trying to protect ourselves from you, in the media. And weâ€™re not scared of you.â€

otherData.headline: Stop Trying To Live Like We Aren't In A Pandemic
otherData.short_description: As COVID-19 cases surge, many Americans are ignoring health guidelines with beach days and vacations. Pretending the coronavirus crisis doesn't exist will just stretch it out longer.

articleContent: In the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, many of us had high hopes for the summer: â€œMaybe by the time the kids are off for summer break, the virus will be under control and we can still go on vacation.â€ â€œMaybe the warm weather will drastically slow the spread of COVID-19.â€

If only. Nearly five months into the pandemic, the virus is clearly here to stay. Summer, sadly, isnâ€™t a magic bullet. As temperatures rise, COVID-19 cases, deaths and hospitalizations are also on the rise in several states. A vaccine is still a hypothetical. Some experts say widespread mask-wearing could slow down infection rates, but the battle over face masks in public has only intensified. Itâ€™s all very concerning, to say the least.

Still, those concerns havenâ€™t stopped many Americans from looking for means to escape. Over the weekend, videos posted to social media showed massive crowds gathered in front of the stage at a Chainsmokers concert in the Hamptons in New York. Your timeline and Instagram story section are probably full of people posting pics and videos from their barbecues, vacations, beach days and pool parties.
The travel industry is ready and waiting, pandemic be damned. â€œWe know you #WannaGetAway so book today to take advantage of our low fares,â€ Southwest Airlines tweeted earlier this month.

Walt Disney World in Florida, a coronavirus hotspot, reopened this month with strict policies in place for visitors (face masks, temperature screenings). Videos on social media show cast members making the rounds in the park, dressed up as Belle and Ariel and other Disney princesses, sans mask. Even in the Florida heat, donning a full Mickey or Mr. Incredible suit seems preferable.

If youâ€™ve been sheltering in place, more or less, seeing people living it up this summer can be a little crazy-making. A recent tweet from journalist Louis Peitzman pointed out the incongruity of seeing people treating this summer just like any other while COVID-19 cases surge.

â€œIf you do break social distancing, consider not posting photos of your group hang or your mask-free beach day,â€ Pietzman said. â€œNot because youâ€™ll get dragged â€” though you might! â€” but because of the effect it has on your followers.â€

Itâ€™s weird to see people partying it up, going to Floridaâ€™s Walt Disney World or New Yorkâ€™s Fire Island in the middle of a pandemic. But as Peitzman said in his Twitter thread, whatâ€™s weirder is forcing yourself to square those images with your own begrudged acceptance of reality. What pandemic are they living in? Because itâ€™s certainly not everyoneâ€™s.

â€œMy reaction to these photos is often anger, but buried under thatâ€™s a seed of doubt,â€ Peitzman wrote. â€œI spend all day reading studies and tracking the numbers of new cases and hospitalizations and deaths, and STILL, I see enough maskless pics and think, maybe Iâ€™m the crazy one. It wears you down.â€

In spite of warnings from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, people clearly have very different takes on what is safe to do and whatâ€™s too risky. Thatâ€™s especially true of younger generations. The belief up until now has generally been that younger people were less likely to have severe consequences from exposure to the coronavirus, which has led some to behave as if theyâ€™re invincible. Thatâ€™s a dangerous gambit; as the first wave of the virus begins to resurge, the average age of U.S. coronavirus patients is actually shifting lower.
Itâ€™s hard for young people to accept this, though, said Susan Newman, a social psychologist and author of â€œThe Book of No: 365 Ways to Say It and Mean It â€• and Stop People-Pleasing Forever.â€

â€œUnlike older adults, it is patently clear that it doesnâ€™t make scientific sense for vibrant, healthy young people to have to worry about getting it,â€ she told HuffPost. â€œBut this virus is insidious and cares not how old you are, that you are â€˜over it allâ€™ and want to take a much-needed break or go about business as usual.â€
Quarantine fatigue has many of us subscribing to a kind of magical thinking.

â€œThe problem is, indulging yourself in a fun or relaxing pastime will not solve what is a rampant crisis,â€ Newman said. â€œThe hours or vacation week you spend away from being more or less confined to your home may feel wonderful, but in the long run it could be foolish.â€

Itâ€™s foolish for several reasons. You may have put your faith in â€œherd immunityâ€ and say, â€œIf I get it, I get it, I canâ€™t stop living my life anymore.â€ But what about your family? Newman asked.

â€œWhen you take a â€˜breakâ€™ that ignores social distancing and mask wearing, you risk bringing COVID-19 home to those you live with or see regularly even if you have no symptoms,â€ she said. â€œIs that worth a brief timeout?â€
Plus, she noted, if youâ€™re traveling any distance, do you really want to be sick in a far-off city, away from the comforts of home and possibly stranded for the indeterminate future?

Of course, the potential harm extends beyond your family: Letâ€™s say you take that trip to Cabo you planned earlier this year. You and your family may have a wonderful, rejuvenating time, but what about the people who are serving you? What about the flight staff that had to come into work because you created a demand?

What about the hotel staff who may have elderly or immunocompromised family at home? What about the restaurant workers whose bosses demand they go in or lose their job? What about the hospital workers whose medical centers are stretched thin and arenâ€™t prepared to handle another outbreak?
The truth is, we all want a vacation, but this virus requires us to take a more holistic view of our personal choices and a less individualistic one.

â€œU.S. culture is known for individualism,â€ said Melissa Wesner, a counselor and owner of LifeSpring Counseling Services in Towson, Maryland. â€œWe think about ourselves and our personal wants, needs and goals. One of the issues that is coming up at this time is our ability to demonstrate care, concern and understanding for others.â€
Countries that are more collectivist may have a leg up with combating the coronavirus since they tend to prioritize the group over the self.

â€œMore collective communities focus on what is beneficial to others or to the community at large,â€ Wesner said. â€œThis relates to something as simple as deciding to wear a face mask. Deciding not to wear a face mask, despite the recommendations shows that Iâ€™m thinking about my own wants and needs and that Iâ€™m not demonstrating care or concern for others or how my decisions will impact others.â€

This isnâ€™t about vacation-shaming. Five months into stay-at-home orders in many parts of the country, weâ€™re all at our witsâ€™ end. Weâ€™ve never needed a break so badly: Weâ€™re working without respite â€• or if we were laid off earlier in the pandemic, weâ€™re exhaustively looking for work. To add insult to injury, weâ€™re seeing other countries that have had a better handle on the virus start to reopen with few hiccups. â€œWhy canâ€™t that be us?â€ we think.
Given all that stress, breaks and personal time need to be taken. Go on a short, safe local road trip. Go on a hike or have a socially distanced picnic with your family.

But recognize that summer 2020 may not be the best time to go big or go home with your vacation plans. Living your best life on a boat or on a tropical island or gathering three generations of your family for a week at the lake isnâ€™t responsible.
As New York City psychologist and anxiety specialist Amelia Aldao told us, no amount of denial or extensive vacation plans will make the current situation easier to swallow.

â€œThere are many situations in life that are so difficult, stressful or traumatic that going to a place in which we pretend problems arenâ€™t there or things arenâ€™t as bad can be helpful psychologically,â€ she said. â€œWe need hope, we need a sense of belonging. And sometimes the facts donâ€™t give us that.â€

But denial also means we underestimate risk, which can end up creating a more dangerous situation, Aldao said. When we crave escapism, itâ€™s really about finding a healthy balance between escape and reality.
â€œA little bit of distraction â€• or perhaps some denial â€• can be helpful at times, but ultimately, we grow and thrive when we face those things that are difficult,â€ Aldao said.
â€œIn the case of COVID, understanding the risks we take and being OK with that ... is a more balanced, psychologically healthy approach than pretending the risk is zero,â€ she explained.
Owning up to our actions is difficult but ultimately extremely empowering.
How to manage our expectations when we really want to get away.

The first step to grappling with a pandemic summer is accepting that it is a pandemic summer. Normalize doing nothing (or next to nothing) and instead start envisioning your big blowout trip for when itâ€™s safe. Take a long view of your vacation goals (and goals in general).
Remember that if you have vacation days, you should still use them. Take some time off work, even if you have nowhere to go and no plans to speak of.

â€œStep away from work, turn off your cellphone and computer for a few days,â€ Newman said. â€œChallenge yourself to longer walks or jogs, paint a room or finish a project you never have time for. You will be surprised how refreshing meeting a self-determined goal or sprucing up your apartment or home can be.â€

Obviously, turning your bedroom or living room into your own personal sanctuary isnâ€™t the same as being sprawled out on the sand in the sun, margarita in hand, but it will lift your spirits and keep you safe.

When the hankering to travel or to go to a friendâ€™s place gets really bad, ask yourself whatâ€™s driving that feeling, Aldao said. What emotional need will that trip or wine night fulfill? Then ask yourself: Are there less-risky versions of that activity (for you and others) that fulfill the same need?

â€œFor example, if youâ€™re itching to go to a house party with friends because you miss laughing with them, can you instead grab a drink or coffee with one or two of them in an open, outdoor space while wearing a mask and practicing social distance?â€ she said.

In times like these, when there are so many restrictions and evolving mandates on whatâ€™s safe and not safe to do, itâ€™s incredibly important to connect with our emotional drivers: why weâ€™re doing what weâ€™re doing, Aldao said.
Newman agreed. Thatâ€™s a far healthier long-term approach to living with the coronavirus than simply denying it exists.

â€œGoing out and about as if life were as it was before the pandemic is a dangerous form of denial,â€ she said. â€œWe have to shift our mindset to accept that the pandemic wonâ€™t go on forever. You can resume dining out with friends or take that weekend break or vacation later. Thereâ€™s going to be so many restaurant dinners and parties with friends down the road.â€

otherData.headline: New Book Traces Roots Of Prince Harry's Rift With Prince William
otherData.short_description: In "Finding Freedom," authors Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand explore the origins of the brothers' crumbling relationship.

articleContent: The beginnings of the rift between brothers Prince Harry and Prince William are explored in the widely anticipated book â€œFinding Freedomâ€ by royal insiders Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand.

Selections from the book were serialized over the weekend in The Times, dishing out details on Harry and Meghanâ€™s first date, the Duchess of Sussexâ€™s relationship with Kate Middleton, and the soured ties between the Sussexes, the royal family, and their aides and courtiers.

The book asserts that the brothersâ€™ division began with the Duke of Cambridgeâ€™s comments about Harryâ€™s new relationship with Meghan Markle. William apparently worried that Harry was â€œblindsided by lust,â€ when he first met the â€œSuitsâ€ actor, and cautioned him against moving too fast.
â€œDonâ€™t feel you need to rush this,â€ William cautioned his brother, according to the book excerpts. â€œTake as much time as you need to get to know this girl.â€

Harry was put off by the talk â€• particularly the words â€œthis girlâ€ â€• and â€œcould see through Williamâ€™s words,â€ the authors wrote. An anonymous friend quoted in the book said of William: â€œHe was being a snob.â€

The brothers became distanced after the talk, and invites from the Cambridges for Harry to see his niece and nephew â€œdried up,â€ the book says. The relationship became even more strained after Harry and Meghanâ€™s royal wedding.

Royal aides and courtiers also apparently had a lot to say about Meghan when she arrived on the scene. The book says some palace employees distrusted her and called her â€œHarryâ€™s showgirl.â€ One said â€œshe comes with a lot of baggage,â€ according to the book.
Kensington Palace had no comment when reached by HuffPost Monday.
A spokesperson for the Sussexes said in a statement to HuffPost that the couple did not participate in the book.

â€œThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex were not interviewed and did not contribute to â€˜Finding Freedom,â€˜â€ the statement said. â€œThis book is based on the authorsâ€™ own experiences as members of the royal press corps and their own independent reporting.â€
In October, Harry addressed talk of a rift between he and his older brother in the ITV documentary â€œHarry & Meghan: An African Journey.â€

â€œWe are brothers. We will always be brothers,â€ the Duke of Sussex told journalist Tom Bradby. â€œWe are certainly on different paths at the moment but I will always be there for him as I know he will always be there for me.â€

Harry added: â€œWe donâ€™t see each other as much as we used to because we are so busy but I love him dearly. The majority of the stuff is created out of nothing but as brothers, you know, you have good days, you have bad days.â€

Bradby spoke about the brothersâ€™ relationship in an interview with â€œGood Morning Britainâ€ in January.

â€œThere are lots of people, who would love there to be â€• including I think the brothers themselves â€• love them to be closer again,â€ Bradby said. â€œAnd with any luck that will happen. But with families, we all know stuff happens, things are said.â€

On the day of Bradbyâ€™s interview, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced their plans to step back as working members of the royal family and pursue financial independence. They officially stepped down on March 31 and have been staying in Los Angeles with their son Archie.
Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: White Supremacy Shaped American Christianity, Researcher Says
otherData.short_description: Racist theology is deeply embedded in the DNA of white Christian churches, influencing even their theology on salvation, PRRI founder Robert Jones argues in a new book.

articleContent: Robert Jones, CEO of the Public Religion Research Institute, comes from a line of white American Christians that stretches back before the Revolutionary War. His ancestors werenâ€™t large plantation owners or Confederate generals, or â€• as far as he knows â€• active members of the Ku Klux Klan. For much of his life, Jones believed the â€œunremarkableâ€ nature of his familyâ€™s background meant that white supremacy wasnâ€™t a part of their history.
But heâ€™s recently started to tell a different kind of story â€• one that acknowledges that white privilege shaped his familyâ€™s sojourn on American soil.

His ancestors were wealthy enough to own slaves, Jones said. The family settled in Georgia on land the government seized from indigenous Creek and Cherokee people. They became Southern Baptists, part of a denomination founded in 1845 on the belief that it was perfectly moral for Christians to be slave owners.

Decades later, after Jonesâ€™s great-grandfather was killed in a clay mining accident, co-workers allegedly killed an innocent Black worker in retaliation. Jones still remembers how satisfied his great-uncle appeared while retelling that story, as if this arbitrary and unjustified act of racial violence helped balance the scales after a white manâ€™s death.

It wouldnâ€™t be hard for many white Christians to find examples of white supremacyâ€™s claims on their own familyâ€™s trees, Jones said. But white Christiansâ€™ image of themselves and their religion has been warped by what Jones calls â€œwhite-supremacy-induced amnesia.â€

Jones wrestles with that amnesia in his new book, â€œWhite Too Long: The Legacy of White Supremacy in American Christianity.â€ He argues that white Christians â€• from evangelicals in the South to mainline Protestants in the Midwest to Catholics in the Northeast â€• werenâ€™t just complacent onlookers while political leaders debated what to do about slavery, segregation and discrimination. White supremacist theology played a key role in shaping the American church from the very beginning, influencing not just the way denominations formed but also white Christiansâ€™ theology about salvation itself.

HuffPost spoke with Jones about his book earlier in July. Just as his own family history would be incomplete without acknowledging the influences of white supremacy, Jones said itâ€™s impossible to talk about American Christianity without recognizing that racism helped shape the church.
How did your own eyes open to the ways that white Christianity and white supremacy are entangled?

I grew up in Jackson, Mississippi. I was deeply immersed in white Southern Baptist evangelical culture. I was that kid who was always at church, four to five times a week. I have a degree from a Southern Baptist college, and I have a Master of Divinity degree from a Southern Baptist seminary. But it wasnâ€™t until I was in grad school in my 30s that I really began to examine the history of my denominationâ€™s direct ties to slavery.

Along with that, in my day job as CEO of PRRI, weâ€™re repeatedly confronted with public opinion data that suggests white Christians really have a blind spot in seeing racial injustice and particularly structural racism. So it was a combination of really reckoning with my own familyâ€™s history, together with seeing patterns in the data that just made it so clear that this is not a story of some distant past, but this is very much still in the DNA of white Christianity today.
So what is the story that white Christians tell themselves about the churchâ€™s relationship to white supremacy?

They tell themselves that their version of Christianity is Godâ€™s means of bringing salvation to the lost world. That they are the embodiment of everything that is good about America, that they are pillars of the community. But that story doesnâ€™t stand up to very much scrutiny.

Along with the good that white Christian churches have done â€” building hospitals, orphanages and other civic institutions â€” they have also pronounced the blessings of God on slavery. They were the main legitimizers of a massive resistance to civil rights and have very consistently been on the wrong side of those issues. You can certainly point to the abolitionist movement and say, yes, that has Christian roots. But the bigger picture is that there were many, many more white Christians resisting desegregation than were on the abolitionistsâ€™ side of things.

The legacy of this â€• the proof in the pudding â€• is what public opinion looks like today. White Christians â€• evangelicals, mainline Protestants and Catholics â€• are 30 percentage points more likely than religiously unaffiliated whites to say the Confederate flag is more a symbol of Southern pride than a symbol of racism. If you ask whether the killings of Black men by police are isolated incidents or part of a pattern, white Christians are twice as likely as religiously unaffiliated whites to say these are isolated instances. They have a very difficult time connecting the dots and seeing the structural justice issues at stake.
You spend some time in the book explaining that white mainline Protestants and white Catholics were also complicit in white supremacy. Why did you feel that it was important to point that out?

Itâ€™s important not to dismiss this as a question of Southern culture. In the book, I developed a racism index, a broad index of 15 different racial attitude questions. I put those into a statistical model that controlled for things like Southern regionalism, Republican identity, education level, all kinds of things that could be driving these attitudes that have nothing to do with Christian identity. Even when I controlled for all of those things, white Christian identity in itself is directly connected to racist attitudes.

Some of this data gets dismissed by white Christians who say those numbers are muddied because they include people who just claim to be Christian but never darken the door of a church. But the data refutes that quite soundly. In fact, among white Christians overall, thereâ€™s a positive relationship between their religious identity and holding more racist views. Perhaps most disturbing is that among white evangelicals, the relationship between holding racist views and white Christian identity is actually stronger among more frequent church attenders. That ought to be a cause for a deep soul-searching among white Christians overall and among white evangelicals in particular.
How do you think racism helped shape white American Christiansâ€™ theology about salvation?

I think itâ€™s helpful to go back and imagine what early church history in the U.S. looked like in the colonies. There was this sense that white people were Godâ€™s chosen instruments to civilize the U.S. and the world. It would not be unusual for white slave owners to bring enslaved people to church with them on Sunday morning. Whites would sit in the front and enslaved people would sit in the back. That context certainly shapes the way Christian theology and practices form. Youâ€™re not going to preach a lot of liberation, freedom and equality from the pulpit. Youâ€™re going to preach more about obedience to the master and fulfilling your roles, those kinds of things. I think that fundamentally distorted American white Christianity from the beginning.

One of the ways this happened is that salvation became this very hyper-individualized concept. So it becomes about a personâ€™s individual relationship to God through Jesus, and itâ€™s very much about personal morality and piety. It was this very privatized and cordoned off way of thinking about spirituality and Christianity. This developed by necessity and by design, as a way of thinking about salvation that would be consistent with a world that was already committed to the idea of white supremacy.

Iâ€™d like to get your thoughts on how white supremacy influenced how white Christians think about the purpose of government. In my own reporting, Iâ€™ve seen white evangelical Christians express the idea that, when it comes to issues such as immigration and policing, itâ€™s the governmentâ€™s God-given duty to keep the country safe, while itâ€™s individual Christiansâ€™ duty to be charitable and care for the poor. Do you think this way of thinking has racist roots?

I do think whenever white Christians declare or draw lines between what is biblical and what is political, I would look for white supremacy to be at work. This kind of boundary drawing is a way of delegitimizing certain kinds of claims and privileging other kinds of claims. One of the most prominent recent examples is from the 1960s, when the Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. and other African American ministers were using churches as places for civil rights organizing.

Jerry Falwell Sr. came out and said that this was not a legitimate thing for a pastor to be doing, that pastors should only be preaching the gospel from the pulpit, that these kinds of organizing things are political and shouldnâ€™t be the concern of the church. Not too many years later, Falwell suddenly changed his mind. The one thing that really made him change his tune on this was that Bob Jones University, an evangelical university, was threatened with losing its federal funding because it didnâ€™t allow interracial relationships. Evangelicals at the time were making very explicit claims defending the separation of races, and all of a sudden, that was a biblical issue.

What is biblical, what is political, often tends to be driven by self-interest. In the case of white Christian churches, I think itâ€™s always appropriate to ask, â€œWhat kind of interest is that? Is it an interest that is privileging the position of white Americans over Americans of color?â€ And if it is, then itâ€™s a straightforwardly white supremacist interest thatâ€™s being reflected in those distinctions.

There still seems to be a lot of skepticism and resistance in white Christian spaces to words such as â€œsocial justice,â€ â€œwhite privilegeâ€ and â€œsystemic racism.â€ At the same time, over the past few weeks, Iâ€™ve seen evangelical news sites emphasizing reconciliation, forgiveness, people coming together. Where do you think that comes from?

The easiest thing for white Christians to reach for is reconciliation. While I think thatâ€™s a laudable goal, if itâ€™s reached for too quickly, I think itâ€™s actually disingenuous. Too often, the formula for white Christians is white apology or lament plus Black forgiveness equals reconciliation. Whatâ€™s missing in that equation is any conversation about justice and repair. If youâ€™re a white Christian, heading straight for reconciliation is the quickest way to protect the status quo without doing the hard work and without really dealing with the past.

Itâ€™s surprising to me in some ways because if thereâ€™s anything I heard and that white Christian churches emphasize is this idea of repentance. But repentance, in the biblical sense of the word, is never just about apology. Itâ€™s about making things right. I think the real test of authenticity for white Christians who want to lament this past is whether theyâ€™re willing to walk through the valley of repair and justice in order to get to that destination of reconciliation or whether they want to skip that part of the journey.

How do you think white Christian churches have responded to George Floydâ€™s death and the Black Lives Matter protests? Do you think the message is sticking, or are you seeing more evidence of what you call in the book the â€œwhite Christian shuffleâ€?

I called it the white Christian shuffle because there does tend to be this one step forward, two steps back movement. Particularly at moments like this one, where thereâ€™s a high social expectation that something will be said, something will be done, the question is whether itâ€™s something authentic or something to just check the box and move on.

In my home state of Mississippi, the legislature finally voted to remove the Confederate battle flag from the state flag. Before that happened, the Mississippi Baptist Convention had a press conference and actually called on the legislature to do that. Now thatâ€™s a pretty big deal. But in my view, we canâ€™t pretend weâ€™ll get on the right side of the battles around symbols without dealing with the way white Christians built white supremacy into their theology and for so many years used Christian theology as a way to legitimize the worldview that put those monuments up in the first place.
What do you think it would it look like if white Christians began reckoning with that theology?

Part of what I hope the book will do is help white Christians tell a truer story about themselves. If itâ€™s an older church, the questions are pretty obvious: â€œWhere were we on the issue of civil rights? Where were we on the integration of our own congregation? Where are we now on the issue of mass incarceration?â€ Even for newer congregations that are predominantly white, itâ€™s worth interrogating things as simple as, â€œAre we in an all-white suburb, and if so, why? Has there been a conversation about police killings of African Americans or about Black Lives Matter that isnâ€™t just about the dangers of rioting but actually about the pain that African Americans are feeling at this moment?â€

The second step after that reflection is to ask, â€œHow can we be in community with African Americans and other people of color in our communities? How can we be allies on issues of racial justice?â€ Those conversations themselves will begin to challenge some of the ways in which white Christian theology has blinded white Christians to these issues.

A defensive reaction is a real temptation for white Christians at the moment. One of the biggest moves white Christians could make is to try to find some deep sense of humility and to listen and resist the urge to rebut and defend and to try to take in the witness that our African American brothers and sisters are trying to bring to white Christians.
This interview was condensed and edited for clarity.

CORRECTION: Due to transcription errors, this article previously misstated the number of questions on Jonesâ€™ racism index, and how much more likely white Christians are to say the Confederate flag is a symbol of Southern pride rather than racism.

otherData.headline: New Book Shines Light On Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle: They Weren't 'At War'
otherData.short_description: "According to a source, Kate felt they didnâ€™t have much in common â€˜other than the fact that they lived at Kensington Palace,'" report Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand.

articleContent: Royal insiders Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand document the relationship between Meghan Markle and Kate Middleton in their forthcoming book, â€œFinding Freedom,â€ out August 11.

According to an excerpt from the book â€• serialized by the British newspaper The Times over the weekend â€• the authors insist that despite persistent feud rumors, the two women werenâ€™t actually â€œat war with each other,â€ though they werenâ€™t the â€œbest of friendsâ€ either.
â€œAt the outset of her romance with Harry, Meghan had fully expected Kate to reach out and give her the lie of the land on everything an outsider to the Firm needed to know,â€ the passage claims.

â€œBut that was not how things turned out. Meghan was disappointed that she and Kate hadnâ€™t bonded over the position they shared, but she wasnâ€™t losing sleep over it,â€ the excerpt continues. â€œAccording to a source, Kate felt they didnâ€™t have much in common â€˜other than the fact that they lived at Kensington Palace.â€™â€

While the Duchess of Cambridge reached out and sent Meghan flowers for her birthday, the book claims that the Duchess of Sussex â€œwould far rather have had Kate check in on her during the most difficult times with the press.â€

The excerpt says rumors of the â€œdueling duchessesâ€ started when it was announced that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex were relocating to Frogmore Cottage at Windsor Castle. The palaces then refused to correct or comment on reports that the move was because of Meghan and Kateâ€™s relationship.

â€œFinding Freedomâ€ also explores Prince Harry and Prince Williamâ€™s relationship, which became strained after the Duke of Cambridge reportedly questioned the pace of his brotherâ€™s courtship with Meghan.
As the strain widened, â€œKate did little to bridge the divideâ€ between the brothers, though the book notes that â€œit was not necessarily her responsibility.â€
Kensington Palace had no comment when reached on Monday.
A spokesperson for the Sussexes said in a statement to HuffPost that the couple did not participate in the book.

â€œThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex were not interviewed and did not contribute to â€˜Finding Freedom,â€˜â€ the statement said. â€œThis book is based on the authorsâ€™ own experiences as members of the royal press corps and their own independent reporting.â€

The book, which comes out next month, promises it will go â€œbeyond the headlines to reveal unknown details of Harry and Meghanâ€™s life together, dispelling the many rumors and misconceptions that plague the couple on both sides of the pond.â€
Subscribe to HuffPostâ€™s Watching the Royals newsletter for all things Windsor (and beyond).

otherData.headline: Charlize Theron Recalls 'Unfair' Treatment On 'The Italian Job,' Shades Mark Wahlberg
otherData.short_description: â€œI made it a point to out-drive all of those guys," Theron said.

articleContent: Mark Wahlberg might need to pencil in some extra gym time in his famously unhinged daily schedule if he wants to keep up with Charlize Theron.
The â€œOld Guardâ€ star has cemented herself as one of the foremost action stars around, but she long had to prove that she could run faster, kick harder and drive better than her male co-stars.

Take for instance, the 2003 remake of â€œThe Italian Job,â€ for which Theron recently revealed she was scheduled to train for six weeks longer than her male co-stars, including Wahlberg, Jason Statham and Edward Norton.

â€œThere was a real pressure to pull off those stunts with the actors. â€¦ There was a very unfair process that went with that,â€ Theron said in a Comic-Con at Home career retrospective. â€œI was the only woman with a bunch of guys, and I remember vividly getting the schedule in our preproduction, and they had scheduled me for six weeks more car training than any of the guys. It was just so insulting.â€
The discrepancy in their preproduction schedules â€œput a real fire under my ass,â€ Theron said, which made seeing her male co-stars struggle on-set that much more gratifying.

â€œI was, like, â€˜All right, you guys want to play this game, letâ€™s go,â€™â€ she recalled. â€œI made it a point to out-drive all of those guys. I vividly remember Mark Wahlberg, halfway through one of our training sessions, pulling over and throwing up because he was so nauseous from doing 360s.â€

The heist thrillerâ€™s most memorable action set-pieces feature the cast as they drive a fleet of Mini Coopers through various global locales. Theron recalled being particularly proud of maneuvering the vehicle for one stunt in â€œa reverse 360 or maybe 180 in a warehouse with props everywhere.â€
â€œI did that stunt completely on my own,â€ she said. â€œIt was a huge moment for feeling, like, â€˜Yeah, we can do all this stuff, and women are so unfairly thought of or treated in genre.â€™â€

The experience filming â€œThe Italian Jobâ€ helped Theron come to terms with the â€œmisconception around womenâ€ in action films, propelling her to seek out and create roles in big-budget projects such as â€œAeon Flux,â€ â€œMad Max: Fury Roadâ€ and â€œAtomic Blondeâ€ in order to upset the norm.

â€œWhen I started my action career, it was so important to sell the authenticity of, â€˜Yes, I can fight, and I can take this guy down, and I can survive this,â€™â€ Theron said. â€œThere was such a level of wanting to prove that to audiences who for years said, â€˜No, a woman could never fight a guy that size.â€™â€

With the recent record-shattering release of Netflixâ€™s â€œThe Old Guard,â€ Theron has no plans to slow down anytime soon. She has already expressed interest in reprising her role in a sequel to the Gina Prince-Bythewood-directed film and recently teased that an â€œAtomic Blondeâ€ follow-up is in development.
The Oscar-winner can also be seen in the next â€œFast and Furiousâ€ film, which will now hit theaters in April 2021 because of the coronavirus pandemic.

otherData.headline: Store Mask Requirements Aren't Really Requirements If They Aren't Enforced
otherData.short_description: A recent memo at one grocery chain said to provide masks at the door, but if the customer refuses to wear it, "let them shop."

articleContent: On July 2, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott (R) issued a statewide mask requirement to dampen a surge in coronavirus cases. Under the order, most Texans would have to cover their faces when entering buildings open to the public, like grocery stores.

The following day, managers at a Sprouts Farmers Market in Texas received a memo related to the new policy. When it came to customers who refused to mask up, the mandate wouldnâ€™t be a mandate after all.

â€œIf customer doesnâ€™t have a mask, we offer them one. If customer still refuses, let them shop,â€ stated the July 3 memo, a copy of which was provided to HuffPost. â€œWE ARE NOT KICKING OUT CUSTOMERS WHO DONâ€™T HAVE A FACE COVERING. That is not Sprouts policy.â€

A Sprouts spokesperson told HuffPost the company implemented a strict requirement for masks the following week, on July 11. The policy applies to the chainâ€™s 300 stores nationwide and is posted at entrances for customers to see.

â€œThe wellbeing of our team members, our customers, and our communities remain our top priority and weâ€™re continually updating our response to COVID-19 as the pandemic quickly evolves,â€ the spokesperson, Diego Romero, said in an email.

But the chainâ€™s initial reaction to the Texas order reflects how many grocers and retailers have been slow to take strong stands on masks for customers. A worker who obtained the memo said employees at their Sprouts location were told the store would rather take a fine than press the issue with a stubborn customer who refused to put on a mask.

â€œI didnâ€™t think that was OK,â€ said the worker, who asked to speak anonymously for fear of getting in trouble. â€œCustomers still come in, some without masks. They expect courtesy clerks to say, â€˜You have to wear a mask.â€™ But whoâ€™s going to listen to a person on the bottom of the totem pole?â€
The worker said several customers came in without masks on a shift just this week but were still allowed to shop.

Romero noted that the Texas order provides an exemption for people with a medical condition or disability that prevents them from wearing a mask, and said Sprouts would not be in a position to question such an assertion from a customer.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, along with other public health experts and worker advocates, have been recommending employees and customers don masks in retail settings for months. The more we learn about the coronavirus, the more evidence we see that face coverings can help slow its transmission, by preventing people who are infected from spreading the disease through droplets.
But the Trump administration has refused to implement a federal requirement, leaving the issue to states and private corporations to figure out.

Many grocers and retailers have held out on requiring customers to wear them as a condition of entering the store, even though it could protect the health of their workers and their families. There are plenty of reasons that could explain why: Companies are afraid to wade into a politicized issue, despite the urgings of experts; they donâ€™t want to escalate tensions with potentially hostile customers; and they donâ€™t want to lose business to more lax competitors.

The United Food and Commercial Workers, a union that represents 900,000 grocery workers, had been urging chains to adopt mask requirements in the spring. â€œIâ€™m pretty aggravated about it,â€ the unionâ€™s president, Marc Perrone, told HuffPost way back in April. â€œThey werenâ€™t telling customers or workers to wear masks while they were inside these transmission points.â€

According to the union, roughly 7 in 10 members in a recent internal poll said their employers were not enforcing mask mandates. At least 93 of the unionâ€™s members have died of the coronavirus since March.

Only last week did Walmart, the countryâ€™s largest brick-and-mortar retailer, announce that customers would be turned away at the door if they werenâ€™t wearing masks. Other companies like the grocer Kroger and the department store Kohlâ€™s made similar pronouncements.

But even at some chains with clear mask mandates, the requirements ultimately remain little more than requests. CNN reported Friday that Walmart, Home Depot and other retailers are still allowing maskless customers in the store despite masks being mandatory. A Walmart list of talking points for managers echoed the Sprouts memo, saying if someone refused to cover up, â€œlet them continue to shop.â€

A Sprouts worker in Colorado said for several weeks customers were allowed to enter her store and shop without a mask despite a local ordinance that made masks a requirement earlier in the pandemic. (Colorado did not issue a statewide mandate until this month.)

â€œWe were told by managers that we did not need to enforce the mask policy regardless of the fact that the city I live in said everybody needed to wear a mask in public places,â€ said the worker, who asked not to be named. â€œI was told by management â€¦ â€˜Weâ€™re not the police, so you donâ€™t need to say anything about it.â€™â€

The worker said the new corporatewide requirement has been an improvement, with customers being told to do curbside pickup if they wonâ€™t wear a mask. But enforcement often falls to cashiers and greeters whose job shouldnâ€™t involve tussling with belligerent customers.

She said a large man recently refused to cover his mouth with the mask that hung around his neck, saying he was sick of wearing it. The confrontation grew tense, and she had to threaten to call a manager.
The worker said there is no security guard at her location and often the greeter is just a teenager.

â€œThey should have security at every single store,â€ she said. â€œI think they really need to reiterate to managers that they need to be willing to stand up for their employees. Iâ€™ve seen people berating employees over masks in ways that are completely verbally abusive, and thereâ€™s nothing that happens with that customer.â€

otherData.headline: 23 Indigenous Fashion Brands: Clothing, Jewelry, Accessories And Shoes
otherData.short_description: Beyond the soulless world of fast fashion and mass retail lies a whole universe of craftsmanship with character.

articleContent: As colonial-era landmarks come toppling down worldwide and people reckon with the many ugly legacies of empire, embracing Indigenous businesses makes perfect sense. It always has.
Indigenous artists have historically been excluded from mainstream commerce and denied retail visibility, even as their unbeatable craftsmanship has been copied and fetishized relentlessly.

These businesses deserve first right of access to your wallet. Wearing Indigenous-made fashion can be both protest and personal reparation, a small overdue acknowledgment of erased histories and ongoing discrimination.

â€œSlow fashionâ€ has been practiced by Indigenous communities for centuries. Painstaking beadwork, sewing and weaving, attention to material and detail, and small-batch production are consistent hallmarks. Indigenous fashion was artisanal before artisanal was a thing.

A common misconception is that Indigenous-made fashion isnâ€™t for everyone. As this 2018 HuffPost Canada piece explains, it very much is. Reject the knockoff apparel and culturally inappropriate imagery common in mass retail. Reject disrespectful festival clothing and holiday costumes. Instead, buy directly from artists and makers, and youâ€™ll be OK.
Weâ€™ve rounded up 23 Indigenous artists and businesses whose work will change the way you look at fashion.
JEWELRY
1. Rainy Dawn Ortiz

Founder: Rainy Dawn Ortiz
Lineage: Muscogee (Creek), Acoma Pueblo

Ortizâ€™s beadwork is so implausibly refined that youâ€™d be forgiven for thinking you were looking at printed fabric. Her pieces are a study in restraint and harmony: She often takes just two or three colors and does glorious things with them. Invest in her work for the heirloom value alone. The cuffs and earrings are meant to be passed down. Ortiz also happens to be the daughter of the United Statesâ€™ first Indigenous poet laureate, Joy Harjo.
2. Ahlazua

Founder: Ahlazua Kemp
Lineage: Choctaw, Euchee-Mvskoke (Creek) and DinÃ©

Ahlazua (ah-la-zu-wa) offers startlingly beautiful pieces in sterling silver and mother of pearl. Kemp sees herself foremost as a story-keeper. The materiality of her art is secondary to its purpose, which is continuing tradition. Naturally, this informs her process: Traditional methods like tufa casting and etching and traditional materials like mother of pearl and mussel shell define her brand. Through her work, Kemp seeks to revitalize and reimagine forgotten legends and imagery. It is no wonder that her work appears in two museums and is routinely feted at prestigious Indigenous art markets.
Shop here.
3. Denise Wallace Jewelry

Founders: Denise Hottinger and the late Samuel Wallace
Lineage: Chugach Sugpiaq

Museums have exhibited Hottingerâ€™s quietly magical work for years. The pieces are a triumph of form and function: Clever little hinges and clasps allow you to open them up so you can wear the elements separately. The maskette is a recurring theme, and she brings silver, gold, coral and fossilized walrus bone together into beautiful miniature studies of life in the Arctic.
Shop here.
4. Huckleberry Woman

Founder: Tiffany Vanderhoop
Lineage: Haida, Wampanoag

Vanderhoop is the queen of geometric design. She boasts serious weaving heritage on her motherâ€™s side and learned how to weave traditional textile from her mother and sister. Identifiable by their contrasting colorways and formline detail, ancient textile patterns like Ravenâ€™s Tail and Naaxiin (Chilkat) come alive in her exquisite beadwork. Finished with just-right hints of gold, her jewelry wears best against monochrome outfits.
Shop here.
5. Only Child Handicrafts

Founder: Krysta Furioso
Lineage: Ojibwe

Furiosoâ€™s command over color is intuitive and absolute. She has great range, and her bright statement pieces are as easy to love as her quieter ones. Sensual ombrÃ© arrangements are a hallmark. Her jewelry is perfect for wallflower and wild child alike.
Shop here.
6. Indi City

Founders: Alexandra Manitopyes and Angel Aubichon
Lineage: Muskowekwan First Nation (Manitopyes), Peepeekisis Cree Nation (Aubichon)

Unpack the brandâ€™s sassy, cheery maximalism and you get an incisive take on tradition. Mirror-finish shoulder dusters that flirt with the light, cute oversize fruit that winks at your ears â€• every piece is a nod to the tribal lived experience. This is immensely wearable jewelry that turns heads and makes a point. Aubichon gets her beading chops, her discipline and attention to detail from her Metis Chapan (great grandmother), who practiced her craft till she was 96 and blind. Manitopyesâ€™ grounding in digital media brings an exciting element of experimentation to the table. Their vision, combined with Aubichonâ€™s grasp of form and material, is why the brandâ€™s dramatic laser-cut pieces are wildly popular.
Shop here.
7. Tashina Lee Emery

Founder: Tashina Lee Emery
Lineage: Ojibwa of Keweenaw Bay

Emeryâ€™s poetic pieces remind us that nature is the ultimate adornment. Cruelty-free and respectfully sourced wild rice, porcupine quills, cedar leaves and shells are transformed into breathtaking works of art. She likes to celebrate imperfection: The raw materials are allowed full play in clear casings, giving them the timeless, poignant quality of amber fossils.
Shop here.
SHOES
1. Jamie Gentry Designs

Founder: Jamie Gentry
Lineage: Daâ€™naxdaâ€™xw of the Kwakwakaâ€™wakw Nation

Leaves and vines curling up buttery leather, a fit like a hug for your feet â€• Gentryâ€™s standout moccasins raise the bar on fashionable, meaningful footwear. Her pieces age beautifully and her dedication to process shines through in the subtle embellishments, glowing raw materials and small personal touches. The beadwork alone takes anywhere between 10 to 30 hours; she stitches each bead herself. She also takes great care to source responsibly and likes helping clients arrive at a design that has personal significance to them.
Shop here.
2. John Murie

Founder: John Murie
Lineage: Cree/Pawnee

Murie cut his teeth in the pow wow circuit beading his own regalia. He got his start making moccasins for a colleague, and then went on to craft an oversize custom pair for a major museum exhibit. A John Murie moc is typically beaded all over and sports clean, fresh design inspired by nature, the seasons and the cosmos. The fadework is impeccable and topped off with a neat contrast piping, a signature element. Murieâ€™s devotion to getting every pair right is evident in his journal-style posts on Instagram.
3. White Bear Moccasins

Founder: Shauna White Bear
Lineage: Arikara/Hidatsa Nation

White Bear does stunning custom pieces that embody comfy chic and feel like a second skin. She turns the idea of mocs being a niche, offbeat accessory on its head: These shoes are for everyone. Pad about the house in them or wear them outdoors. Pair them with dresses or jeans or even a bodysuit. White Bear learned to make moccasins at a 25-year-old cobbler shop called Carterâ€™s Boots and Repair, where she now rents a workshop. Her leather is sustainably sourced and responsibly tanned, and she offers variations on six classic styles, from an ankle-length slipper to a tall boot.
Shop here.
BAGS
1. Hollis Chitto

Founder: Hollis Chitto
Lineage: Mississippi Choctaw, Laguna Pueblo, Isleta Pueblo

Chittoâ€™s masterpieces belong in a period film featuring languid seductresses in opera gloves and shimmering flapper dresses. His work is unmatched in decadence and compositional fidelity. Chitto has been beading since he was 10, so pushing himself on technique is a big part of his creative discipline. Amazingly, spontaneity is too; he doesnâ€™t give much thought to things like palette when conceptualizing. That sense of wonder and discovery communicates beautifully in his work.
2. Kanaine

Founder: Sydelle Harrison
Lineage: Cayuse, Walla Walla, Yakama and Korean American

A Kanaine (ka-nine-ee) bag is a celebration of color and movement. Harrison, who has worked many years in cultural resources protection, makes her bags with blankets from the Oregon-based Pendleton Woolen Mills. The medium is a natural fit: She grew up in Pendleton, and the blankets are a treasured part of local cultural practices. Harrison is a nerd about material and design. In her launch videos on Instagram, she obsesses over leather, over giving fringe detail the right kind of heft, over space and structure and proportion. Her unmistakable erudition and her love for her people form the heart of her brand.
Shop here.
3. Gabriel Frey Baskets

Founder: Gabriel Frey
Lineage: Passamaquoddy from Sipayik (Wabanaki Confederacy)

A Gabriel Frey basket is an investment and a cultural keepsake. In 2018, Frey was awarded the prestigious United States Artists Fellowship for his contribution to the national heritage of Wabanaki basketry. He is a 12th-generation basket maker who has been weaving black ash baskets for two decades. His grandfather, his first real teacher, continues to guide his artistic vision through the basketwork he left behind. Frey personally locates, harvests and hand-dyes weave-worthy wood; he selects only the best leather and hardware. His functional, sophisticated pieces go surprisingly well with city living. Carry your work essentials in one of his roomier bags adapted from the pack baskets historically used for fishing and trapping, or travel light with his smaller styles.
Shop here.
4. Sandra Okuma

Founder: Sandra Okuma
Lineage: Shoshone/Bannock, LuiseÃ±o, Wailaki

You donâ€™t so much admire a Sandra Okuma piece as gawk at it. She paints with beads, achieving a tapestry-like richness and tonal complexity that defies even the HD-attuned eye. Okuma worked as a graphic designer in the entertainment industry for many years, and that experience shows in the dazzling theatricality of her work. Her daughter Jamie is a celebrated artist too, and both mother and daughter push their art in exciting directions independent of each other.
Shop here.
APPAREL
1. Ginew

Founders: Amanda and Erik
Lineage: Oneida & Stockbridge-Munsee of the Turtle clan (Amanda), Ojibwe of the Pine Marten clan (Erik)

Denim from Ginew (gih-noo) is statement utilitarianism at its finest. Their dark wash jean is a must-have; cuff the leg and wear with a strappy heel or bright jewel-toned mocs for best results. With their storied longevity and classic cuts, these garments, especially the outerwear, pay homage to the working class roots of their forefathers. In its imagery, its details, its choice of material, even the people it chooses to collaborate with, the brand is an unflinching confrontation of the erasure of Indigenous peoples. It reframes jeans â€• a staple of nostalgic white Americana â€• as a garment at the heart of Indigenous working-class pride.
Shop here.
2. Makwa Studio

Founder: Maggie Thompson
Lineage: Fond Du Lac Ojibwe and German-Irish

Textile artist and designer Thompson brings soul and intentionality to knitwear.
As she comes from mixed heritage, her work outside the knitting studio has mostly been about processing the fraught identity question and challenging the colonial invalidation of Native experiences. While some Native artists do this by drawing solely on tradition, Thompson chooses to make art that is informed by heritage yet culturally contemporaneous. Her polished machine-knit creations (all hand-loomed, all wool) subtly reference her roots yet are aesthetically secular. There is serenity and restraint to her design. The repeating patterns in variations of black and white infused selectively with pops of bright, earthy color are especially lovely.
Shop here.
3. Niio Perkins Designs
Model: Tia Perkins

Founder: Niio Perkins
Lineage: Mohawk from the Haudenosaunee Confederacy

Perkinsâ€™ easy silhouettes sport prints inspired by Iroquois beadwork and pottery. Her accessible stylings challenge the idea that Native sensibilities canâ€™t go mainstream. Throw her autumnal longline cardigan over jeans and some boots, or practice your asanas in her â€™Gram-worthy workout sets. Perkins is a true design polymath; she is also a formidable beadwork artist. Her jewelry and embroidery come from a place of scholarship, deliberation and evident love. Her statement necklaces, bowties and pack baskets with gorgeous hand-embellished straps (some done in collaboration with other artists) are a collectorâ€™s dream.
Shop here.
4. Decolonial Clothing Co.

Founders: Dakota Bear and Casey Desjarlais
Lineage: Nehiyaw and Saulteaux from Treaty 4 and Treaty 6 territories

You could say that protestwear has come into its own with recent events, or you could argue that garments that shout their politics neednâ€™t wait for an occasion â€• extant structures of oppression are a perfectly good reason to wear them on the daily. Decolonial Clothing Co. gets that sporting anti-colonialist sentiments on your sleeve is important. Emblazoned with punchy fonts, the brandâ€™s cozy hoodies and tees will help you find your flock.
Shop here.
5. Orenda Tribe

Founder: Amy Yeung
Lineage: DinÃ©

Yeungâ€™s upcycled gender-neutral offerings are a cerebral yet playful rebuttal to fast fashion. Her meditative, painterly treatments transform vintage garments into works of art. Look fly as hell while running errands in her rainbow tie-die athleisure sets, dip-dyed military jackets and slouchy boiler suits that redefine streetwear.
Shop here.
6. Winston Paul

Founder: Calandra Etsitty
Lineage: DinÃ© (Navajo)

Winston Paulâ€™s dreamy skirts are all the rage on Instagram. Wear them with a plain black or white tee and youâ€™re set. Big pleats, extravagant tiers, structured ruffles, flirty hand-cut fringes that move with a life of their own â€• this is fun, memorable fashion. Her vibrant Pavlovo Posad-print flat bags are popular too â€• they double up as clutches and makeup storage.
Shop here.
ACCESSORIES
1. Kokom Scrunchies

Founder: Mya Beaudry
Lineage: Algonquin

Nine-year-old entrepreneur Mya Beaudry drops a limited edition scrunchie every Sunday. She kicked off her business in 2019 with a plan to do something nice for her pow wow community. (Beaudry has been attending their events since she was little.) For the 2020 Summer Solstice pow wow, Ottawaâ€™s grandest, Mya planned to host a Special â€• an event that involves performances and giveaways â€• to give back to other little girls. Hosting a Special is an honor and a big responsibility, and thereâ€™s lots of planning involved. Mya decided that she would gift her peers with handmade scrunchies. Today, each scrunchie is named after a role model or someone special in Myaâ€™s life, and they are the perfect #wfh accessory to brighten your day.
Shop here.
2. Rebelina

Founder: Candace Bell
Lineage: Metis from Saskatchewan

Bell does the sexiest beaded sunglasses. Her beadwork adds character to all the classic shapes, and she does only one of each design unless a custom repeat is requested. Sheâ€™s rated very highly on her Etsy store, where customers typically gush about owning more than one pair. Wear these with just about any outfit for instant oomph.
Shop here.
3. Dickson Designs

Founder: Heather Dickson
Lineage: Tlingit from Carcross Tagish First Nation

Dickson was so determined to learn traditional sewing that she forced her way into local granniesâ€™ and auntiesâ€™ sewing circles. Traditional sewing and beadwork are a form of cultural gatekeeping for Native communities but they donâ€™t exactly make for a lucrative career. Dickson decided she wanted to change that â€• for herself and for those pouring literal sweat into keeping custom alive. Her beaded fabric headbands were initially dismissed for being too â€œgrannyâ€ and then caught on so quickly she now works with other artists to meet demand. Today sheâ€™s sold out within minutes of uploading new designs. Her bright, festive pieces need no occasion.
