otherData.headline: Police Violence Against Black Disabled People Canâ€™t Be Ignored Anymore
otherData.short_description: Both Black and disabled Americans experience police brutality at high rates. So why is the plight of Black disabled Americans an afterthought?

articleContent: PEARL PEARSON JR. was driving home from a Starbucks in Oklahoma City in 2014 when he noticed police lights flashing behind him. Oklahoma Highway Patrol troopers suspected him of being involved in a hit-and-run, but Pearson â€” a then-64-year-old Deaf Black man whom his daughter described as â€œgentle and kindâ€ â€” had no idea why he was being pulled over.

He parked his car and placed his hands on the steering wheel as a trooper approached his vehicle with a gun drawn. Pearson couldnâ€™t hear what the trooper was saying and reached for a placard he kept in his car that explained his disability. But before he could grab it, the trooper punched him in the face.
Pearson was dragged from his car, severely beaten and put in a chokehold; one of his arms was ripped from its socket. He experienced brain and eye damage from the encounter, but he survived.

Deborah Danner was a 66-year-old Black woman with schizophrenia. In 2016, an NYPD officer shot her in her Bronx apartment while responding to her neighborâ€™s call that she had been behaving erratically. She did not survive.
Chillingly, Danner wrote an essay four years before her death about the dangers of people with mental health conditions interacting with police that predicted her fate.
â€œWe are all aware of the all too frequent news stories about the mentally ill who come up against law enforcement instead of mental health professionals,â€ she wrote. â€œAnd end up dead.â€

The circumstances of Dannerâ€™s death echo those of Breonna Taylorâ€™s. Louisville, Kentucky, police officers shot the EMT eight times in March after bursting into her home on a â€œno-knock warrantâ€ related to a drug investigation.
Pearsonâ€™s story shares DNA with so many other stories about police violence toward Black people at traffic stops, like Philando Castile and Maurice Gordon.
Yet conversations and media coverage surrounding both Pearson and Dannerâ€™s cases zeroed in on their disabilities and largely treated their race as irrelevant.

Conversely, prominent victims of police brutality like Sandra Bland, Freddie Gray, Eric Garner, Elijah McClain and Tanisha Anderson all had disabilities or underlining health issues that may have played significant roles in their deaths â€” yet these aspects of their identities tend to get glossed over.

In cases of police violence against Black disabled people, the media tends to focus on either the victimâ€™s race or the victimâ€™s disability, instead of examining the overlap between the two identities, said Vilissa Thompson, a Black disabled social worker and activist who is a consultant for the Movement 4 Black Lives. This gives the public an incomplete story.

The â€œerasure of peopleâ€™s disabilities when we talk about themâ€ is a major issue when it comes to Black disabled victims of police violence, Thompson told HuffPost. â€œEither the complete erasure or omission, or leaving it as a footnote and not understanding the connection between race [and] disability â€¦ and who is being disproportionately impacted within the Black and disabled communities.â€

There is no reliable national database tracking how many Black disabled people experience and die from police violence. In fact, thereâ€™s not even a public federal database tracking who dies in police custody in general. But the data we do have sheds some light on how the combination of being Black and disabled may have dire consequences when interacting with law enforcement.

In 2015, The Washington Post began work on a real-time database that tracks fatal police shootings. A 2016 report by the Post compared that data with the most recently available U.S. census figures and found that Black Americans were 2.5 times more likely than white people to be shot and killed by law enforcement.
And the Ruderman Foundation, a philanthropic foundation with a focus on disability advocacy, has estimated that one-third to one-half of all people killed by police are disabled.

The brutal killing of George Floyd has sparked nationwide protests and heated conversations about racial justice and police violence over the past few months. But the issue of disability has been largely ignored, even though disability can increase a personâ€™s risk of death or injury by police, especially if that person is also Black.
For instance, the movements and actions of disabled people can be misinterpreted as out of the ordinary or threatening to law enforcement.
Heather Watkins, a Black disabled activist based in Boston, gave the example of how police could easily misinterpret the speech patterns of someone who has cerebral palsy.
â€œ[If] theyâ€™re talking, then someone might consider them drunk,â€ Watkins said. â€œIâ€™ve had friends who have cerebral palsy that say that theyâ€™ve been targeted for appearing inebriated.â€

Police interactions can turn dangerous when a disabled person cannot immediately respond to an officerâ€™s demands for compliance the same way that a non-disabled person would. And when law enforcementâ€™s default is to respond violently to someone who doesnâ€™t immediately obey demands, a disabled person is certainly at risk. For a Black disabled person, this risk is compounded by biased officersâ€™ perception of them as more threatening than non-Black people.

Disabled people also often face indifference â€• from police, courts and the general public â€• about the legal rights afforded to them by the Americans with Disabilities Act, which prohibits discrimination against disabled people, including discrimination by police.

â€œIâ€™ve been in court cases where lawyers â€” police brutality lawyers â€” had no clue about the Americans with Disabilities Act,â€ said Leroy Moore, a Black disabled activist who is the chair of the Black Disability Studies Committee for the National Black Disability Coalition. â€œThe ADA doesnâ€™t count in court cases around police brutality. And if it does, it gets thrown out constantly.â€
Black Americans are five times as likely as white Americans to say theyâ€™ve been unfairly stopped by police because of their race, according to a 2019 Pew survey.

Disabled people also wind up encountering police even though they are not posing a threat. They get the cops called on them for what others perceive as strange behavior or by family, friends or neighbors requesting so-called wellness checks on their mental health condition. In numerous instances, these situations have ended up deadly for people with disabilities.

â€œBoth people of color and people with disabilities are more likely to come in contact with law enforcement,â€ said Britney Wilson, a Black disabled civil rights attorney. â€œAnd both groups have higher chances of negative things happening as a result.â€

Lisa â€œTinyâ€ Gray-Garcia, founder of Poor Magazine and a self-described â€œformerly houseless incarceratedâ€ person, told HuffPost that the tendency to silo a victimâ€™s identities is â€œabsolutely idiotic.â€
â€œThe connection or the intersectionality of disability, racism, white terrorism and poverty are almost always interlinked,â€ she said.

Black Americans are, in fact, more likely than white Americans to be disabled, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Due to centuries of systemic racism, Black Americans tend to make less money and therefore are more likely to live in less affluent neighborhoods. These communities often have worse access to health care, worse access to healthy food, worse air quality and other environmental factors that contribute to residents developing disabilities, mental health conditions and other health issues.

Black Americans also often donâ€™t have access to unbiased medical and mental health care. Because of this and the barriers to health care in general, disabilities and other health conditions that Black Americans develop can go undiagnosed and untreated.
And the fight for justice is harder when Black disabled people feel they are not fully accepted by either the Black or the disability community.

â€œWe donâ€™t feel safe in either community because we experience harm by both communities,â€ said Thompson, who created the Twitter hashtag #DisabilityTooWhite four years ago. â€œIn many ways, where do we belong? We have the disabled community where the white folks or non-people-of-color can be anti-Black or racist, and you have the Black community where Black folks are ableist. So where do we (A) fit? And (B) feel safe enough to even proclaim that our lives matter too?â€
Thompson said sheâ€™s experienced racism from white disabled activists.

â€œThey feel if you talk about anything other than disability, youâ€™re taking away from the movement and itâ€™s a distraction,â€ she said. â€œI think that a lot of white disabled people are not comfortable with understanding and knowing that they have white privilege even though theyâ€™re also disabled. So I think thereâ€™s a reckoning internally with many of them in seeing how you can be the oppressor and be oppressed at the same time.â€
Thereâ€™s also a stigma against disability within the Black community, which Wilson attributes in part to centuries of oppression.

â€œIf you want me to go back to the slave trade,â€ she said, â€œwe were brought here based on our ability to produce. Thatâ€™s something that inherently links race and ability. Thatâ€™s the function of capitalism, itâ€™s instinctively and intrinsically tied to race and ability,â€ Wilson said. She also discussed this idea in a 2016 article she wrote for The Nation.
â€œWhen you already have one societal strike against you,â€ Wilson said, referring to race, â€œwhoâ€™s going to sign up for two?â€
Proposed solutions to police brutality â€• both against Black disabled people and in general â€• are wide-ranging, and advocates often donâ€™t agree on what strategies are best.
Gray-Garcia and Moore, who work closely together through Poor Magazine, stressed the importance of people not calling 911 about behavior they may perceive as suspicious.

â€œMost humans in the United States have been told that the way to solve all their problems is to call those three numbers,â€ Gray-Garcia said. She described a situation in which an Indigenous man died in police custody after someone called 911 to report he was having a mental health crisis on the streets.
â€œThe reality is somebody called those numbers because they wanted to, quote, â€˜help him.â€™ Their heart wasnâ€™t necessarily wanting to get him killed. But thatâ€™s the system we have.â€

Some initiatives aimed at decreasing police violence, particularly toward people with disabilities or mental health issues, include programs to enhance police training or to redirect some 911 calls to other kinds of responders.

The White Bird Clinic in Eugene, Oregon, for instance, runs a program called CAHOOTS (Crisis Assistance Helping Out on the Streets) that redirects non-emergency 911 calls that involve mental health, substance abuse and homelessness to a team of medics and crisis-care workers.

The Arc, one of the countryâ€™s largest disability rights organizations, launched its own program in 2015 that teaches criminal justice professionals how to identify people with disabilities in order to interact with and accommodate them better.

But not everyone agrees these reforms are enough. Gray-Garcia and Moore argue that solutions focused on better training for law enforcement wonâ€™t work and believe the police should be disbanded entirely.
â€œLetâ€™s expand our search for models and talk about actual livable models without the police when weâ€™re having this conversation,â€ said Gray-Garcia, pointing to efforts outside the U.S.
Both also think that in order to combat police violence, American society needs to grapple with a myriad of issues facing marginalized communities.

â€œThereâ€™s not one big answer for everything. Itâ€™s the small things that are going to make it happen,â€ Moore said. â€œSo thereâ€™s the solution â€• educating the community about mental health, about disability, about the ADA, about being a neighbor, about reshaping your disabled neighbor as a person.â€
Gray-Garcia underscored that the situation is messy and it will take all people â€” regardless of race, ability, gender or class â€” to do the hard work needed to create change.

â€œItâ€™s a mind shift,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not a simple answer. And thatâ€™s the hardest part. Because youâ€™re looking for a nice clean line for your story. But ... itâ€™s a complicated, multilayered process of unpacking 527 years of genocide, lies, racism and murdering. You do not get over that in one day.â€

otherData.headline: The Psychology Behind Why Men Refuse To Wear Face Masks
otherData.short_description: Men are more likely to die from COVID-19 but are less likely to wear a mask than women are. Here's what psychologists say is driving that behavior.

articleContent: In the early months of the coronavirus pandemic, HÃ©lÃ¨ne Barcelo, the deputy director of the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute in Berkeley, California, was strolling around a park when she spotted a family of four all masked up. Well, almost all masked up: The mom was wearing a protective covering. So, too, were the children. But the fatherâ€™s mask was hanging from his neck.

Barcelo is currently studying face mask usage, so the scene at the park piqued her interest. Later on, she brought it up when Skyping with her colleague Valerio Capraro, a senior lecturer in economics at Middlesex University in London.

â€œWhen I mentioned it, Valerio shared a similar story,â€ Barcelo told HuffPost. â€œHe lives in London and saw several couples where the female was wearing a mask, while the male was not. So, we thought: â€˜Perhaps thereâ€™s something in there, with men.â€™â€

Spurred on by what they saw, the pair recently released a study that probes why men are more mask-resistant. The researchers polled 2,459 U.S. participants and found that men were more likely to opt out of wearing masks, believing them to be â€œshameful,â€ â€œa sign of weakness,â€ and â€œnot coolâ€ â€” in spite of the data showing that men are at higher risk than women of dying from a coronavirus infection.
The researchers also found that men were less likely than women to believe they would be seriously affected by the coronavirus.
â€œThis was quite unexpected and somewhat ironic, given the fact that official statistics show that men are more likely than women to die from COVID-19,â€ Barcelo said.

Equally surprising to the researchers is that in counties where wearing a face mask was mandatory, those gender differences almost disappeared, though men still expressed the same negative emotions toward masks.

â€œIn other words, in counties where wearing a face mask is mandatory, men dislike wearing it as they do in counties where wearing a face mask is not mandatory, but at least it increases their intentions to wear it,â€ she said.
Thatâ€™s an especially important takeaway, given how slow some government officials have been to enact mask mandates and even to mask up themselves.

In spite of the CDCâ€™s recommendation to wear masks in public places, Vice President Mike Pence notoriously went maskless while touring the Mayo Clinic facilities that support COVID-19 research and treatment. Though he later said he regretted the decision, his mask usage has still been spotty since.

After months of refusing to wear a mask in public and even questioning their efficacy, President Donald Trump seems to have come around to face coverings. On July 11, four months into the pandemic and with more than 134,000 Americans dead, the president finally slipped on a mask during a visit to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.
Then, earlier this week, he shared a photo of himself wearing one.

â€œWe are United in our effort to defeat the Invisible China Virus, and many people say that it is Patriotic to wear a face mask when you canâ€™t socially distance,â€ Trump tweeted, making a racist reference to the coronavirus.
â€œThere is nobody more Patriotic than me, your favorite President!â€ he added.

Still, the president has said he wonâ€™t endorse the mask mandate lawmakers like Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) have pushed for. And hours after tweeting the mask photo, he was seen mingling with supporters at a fundraiser, mask-free.

Inconsistent messaging, yes â€” but progress nonetheless, given Trumpâ€™s previous personal stance on face masks. (According to The New York Times, the president complained privately to staff that he thought it would make him look weak and would draw attention to the public health crisis.)

Trump and other menâ€™s waffling on wearing a mask â€• or their outright refusal to wear one â€• isnâ€™t surprising, said Shane G. Owens, a psychologist and the assistant director of campus mental health at Farmingdale State College SUNY.

â€œThe results of the study reflect what we would expect, given gender roles in the U.S.,â€ Owens told HuffPost. Traits like â€œself-reliance, individualism, strength and courageâ€ are stereotypically associated with masculinity, and in the eyes of many American men, â€œwearing a mask runs counter to most of those traits,â€ Owens said.
For many men rejecting the mask, â€œthereâ€™s a sense of rugged individualism and a desire to appear impervious to harm,â€ Owens said.

He said the studyâ€™s findings made a lot of sense when you contextualize them with menâ€™s low prioritization of medical care and their health. Think of how many men shrug off annual check-ups with their doctor.

Owens was surprised by the studyâ€™s finding that appealing to menâ€™s sense of family responsibility didnâ€™t much increase their intention to wear masks, whereas appealing to their sense of community did.
â€œMaybe these men are thinking, â€˜I donâ€™t need anyone to tell me how to protect my family,â€™â€ Owens said.

Kurt Smith, a therapist in Roseville, California, works primarily with men. He told HuffPost that he believes the demand for conformity on masks â€• and sometimes, shaming people if masks arenâ€™t worn â€• causes some men to dig their heels in deeper.
â€œFor example, I know people whoâ€™ve been screamed at in stores for not wearing a mask,â€ Smith said. â€œNo one deserves to be treated this way. I think it just fuels further resistance.â€
Couple that with the optics of wearing a mask â€• â€œit makes me look unmanly,â€ some feel â€• and youâ€™ve got a solid recipe for mask resistance.
â€œMasculinity can hinder men in a lot of ways â€” asking for directions, going to counseling, and wearing a mask for the coronavirus fits right in with these,â€ he said.
A shame-based approach wonâ€™t work in convincing guys like that, Smith said, but friendly peer pressure might.
â€œNot wearing one can actually be more uncomfortable than doing so as you stick out so much when surrounded by so many people who are,â€ he said.
Talking about some of the nonmedical benefits can help buy-in, too, Smith said. They make you look kind of cool, like youâ€™re going incognito, he joked.

Anecdotally, women sure seem to find a man in a mask attractive. Look at how much praise â€œWonder Womanâ€ actor Chris Pine got for wearing a mask after making a bookstore run in this viral tweet from a few weeks ago.
Sharing photos of good looking, masked-up actors wonâ€™t work for everyone, but Owens does think some kind of PSA campaign featuring public figures men admire wearing masks could be helpful.

â€œGet people guys idolize to wear masks,â€ he said. â€œAn advertisement that shows menâ€™s favorite sports team or other public figures wearing masks might be useful. Face coverings that sport the logos of favorite teams are a phenomenal idea.â€
As the aforementioned study suggests, it also helps to appeal to peopleâ€™s sense of community or patriotism.

Authorities relied heavily on patriotic messaging during the 1918 influenza epidemic, according to Alex Navarro, assistant director of the Center for the History of Medicine at the University of Michigan and one of the editors-in-chief of the American Influenza Epidemic of 1918-1919: A Digital Encyclopedia.

As Navarro told the Los Angeles Times recently, when the first mandatory mask orders in 1918 were met with opposition, public service announcements by the Red Cross and other groups urged people to â€œdo their part,â€ deeming those who refused to get on board â€œslackers.â€
This time around, Navarro said a focus on getting America back on track economically may be more effective.

â€œThe message is, â€˜We cannot have a normal economy until we get the pandemic under control,â€™ and that is not going to happen 100% until we get a vaccine,â€ he told the Times. â€œBut we can get much closer to having it under control if people comply with social distancing and wearing a mask while in public.â€

Barcelo and Capraro said theyâ€™re working on more research that suggests Americans respond particularly well to messages telling them to â€œrely on their reasoningâ€ rather than their emotion. That was true of men and women, Barcelo said.
Still, as their first study showed, the biggest motivator of all remains a mandatory mask order.

â€œWe did see that in counties where wearing face covering was mandatory, both men and women said theyâ€™d comply with that rule,â€ she said. â€œMaking it mandatory everywhere would seem like an effective way to get through.â€

Experts are still learning about the novel coronavirus. The information in this story is what was known or available as of press time, but itâ€™s possible guidance around COVID-19 could change as scientists discover more about the virus. Please check the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the most updated recommendations.

otherData.headline: 'MacGyver' Star Lucas Till Says He Was 'Suicidal' Over Body-Shaming By Showrunner
otherData.short_description: Cast and crew spoke out against Peter Lenkov, who was recently fired by CBS for creating a toxic work environment.

articleContent: â€œMacGyverâ€ star Lucas Till is speaking out about the toxic work environment that former showrunner Peter Lenkov created on the CBS series, revealing that he was left â€œsuicidalâ€ by the alleged abuse and body-shaming.

The actor is one of a handful of cast and crew members whoâ€™ve come forward about Lenkovâ€™s â€œunacceptableâ€ behavior in a new Vanity Fair piece published Monday, two weeks after the network ended its relationship with the onetime â€œMacGyver,â€ â€œMagnum P.I.â€ and â€œHawaii Five-0â€ boss.

â€œIâ€™ve never worked this hard in my life, and I am fine with hard work,â€ Till told Maureen Ryan, a former HuffPost employee, in the piece. â€œBut the way Peter treats people is just unacceptable. I was suicidal that first year on the show, because of the way he made me feel. But the way heâ€™s treated the people around me â€• thatâ€™s just my breaking point.â€
Till, who has starred on the reboot of the action series for four seasons, alleged that Lenkov repeatedly criticized his physique, which drove the actor to contact CBSâ€™s human resources department.

â€œThere was always something about my appearance that wouldnâ€™t please him like when I was in a hospital gown and our producerâ€¦thought it was funny that [Lenkov] said my legs were â€˜fucking hideousâ€™ and we can never show them again,â€ Till wrote in an email to CBS HR, according to Vanity Fair.

Till alleged that Lenkov also raged against him for looking like a â€œlittle fucking boyâ€ in one scene, which was a sore spot for the actor, now 29, who said heâ€™s struggled with his appearance as a leading man given his age.

â€œJust hire a 35-year-old then,â€ he recalled thinking, adding that heâ€™s â€œstruggled with maintaining â€˜man weightâ€™ on the show because of the stress, no time to work out, and an unpredictable schedule for proper nourishment.â€
An unnamed â€œMacGyverâ€ source told Vanity Fair that Lenkov â€œhas a thing againstâ€ Till, who changed â€œdramatically throughout this period.â€
â€œI hated seeing this happen with him because heâ€™s a great guy, and thereâ€™s nothing wrong with him or his body,â€ the source added.

A representative for Lenkov called Tillâ€™s claims â€œ100 percent false and untrueâ€ per Vanity Fair, adding that Lenkov â€œhas championed him from the very beginning and has been nothing but supportive of him.â€

Elsewhere in the piece, Lenkovâ€™s former employees accused him of particularly targeting women on staff, including threatening their jobs, not giving them fair script credits and, in the case of â€œMacGyverâ€ actor Meredith Eaton, pressuring her to return to work too soon after a serious injury.
Earlier this month, following an investigation into multiple complaints, CBS fired Lenkov with a year left on his multimillion-dollar deal as a top showrunner on the network.

In response to the allegations of manipulative and abusive behavior by Lenkov, CBS said, â€œOur studio is committed to ensuring safe and respectful production environments. Over the past year, we have assigned human resource production partners to every show, expanded staff training and increased reporting options. We will continue to evolve our practices with continued focus on building trust with all who work on our sets. Every complaint is taken seriously, every claim is investigated, and when evidence is clear that policies were violated and values not upheld, we take decisive action.â€
While Lenkov has denied all accusations of abuse and mistreatment, he broadly apologized in his own statement.

â€œNow is the time to listen and I am listening. Itâ€™s difficult to hear that the working environment I ran was not the working environment my colleagues deserved, and for that, I am deeply sorry,â€ he told The Hollywood Reporter earlier this month. â€œI accept responsibility for what I am hearing and am committed to doing the work that is required to do better and be better.â€

In the wake of Lenkovâ€™s departure, â€œMacGyverâ€ executive producer Monica Macer was tapped as the new showrunner for the upcoming fifth season, while â€œMagnum P.I.â€ executive producer Eric Guggenheim will now oversee that series, which was renewed for a third season. â€œHawaii Five-0â€ ended its run in April after 10 seasons.
If you or someone you know needs help, please call 1-800-273-8255 for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline.

otherData.headline: Dad's Comic Sums Up Parents' School Concerns Right Now
otherData.short_description: Brian Gordon's "Fowl Language Comics" is weighing in on the school reopening debate.

articleContent: Dad and â€œFowl Language Comicsâ€ artist Brian Gordon isnâ€™t afraid to weigh in on the issues dominating the national discourse, from racial injustice to mask-wearing to premature reopening amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This summer, heâ€™s drawing comics about a big question now hitting families: what to do about the 2020-2021 school year.

â€œLike many of us, my wife and I are struggling with the prospect of sending our kids back to school in the fall, especially considering that our home state of Kansas has uncontrolled spread of the virus,â€ he told HuffPost.

Gordon, who deals with the added complications of a blended family (four children and additional co-parents), said that two of his kids will continue remote schooling, but theyâ€™re still trying to determine what makes the most sense for the other two. Last week, he illustrated the debate over schools reopening in a ... fiery comic.

â€œOur kids miss school and they miss their friends, and we know that being in school is good for them emotionally and intellectually,â€ he said. â€œBut first and foremost, we want them to be well and, frankly, stay alive. Weâ€™re grappling with the same Catch-22 that all parents are dealing with, so this topic felt very relevant for a comic.â€
Gordonâ€™s school reopening comic has received nearly 40,000 likes on Instagram and sparked some heated debate in the comments. He suggests it was meant to add to the discussion, not resolve it.

â€œThere are clearly strong opinions on all sides of this issue and I get it,â€ he said. â€œReopening schools is a complex issue. There were many fans who loved the comic and felt supported and heard, and then there were those who challenged me to propose a better solution than what already exists. Believe me, if I had one, Iâ€™d be the first to shout it out to the world.â€

â€œIâ€™ve also gotten a fair amount of comments suggesting that I â€˜stick with the funny stuff,â€™â€ Gordon continued. â€œBut unfortunately, all of our lives have become decidedly unfunny lately, and as a comic that reflects the life experience of being a parent, Iâ€™d be remiss to skip over the tough stuff. Rest assured, I look forward to writing about less catastrophic matters eventually.â€
Ultimately, he hopes that parents and teachers who see his school reopening comic feel understood and less alone as they face a â€œhard and crummy and unwinnableâ€ situation.

â€œI also hope it illuminates just how unconscionable it is to send hordes of kids and teachers into a school building when many adults arenâ€™t willing to hold in-person meetings themselves,â€ he added. â€œFor my part, Iâ€™m going to do right by what I think our family needs and can handle. Thatâ€™s all any of us can do.â€

otherData.headline: Beauty2theStreetz Gives Makeovers And Hope To Homeless People On Skid Row
otherData.short_description: Shirley Raines' nonprofit does "more than something superficial," even during the coronavirus pandemic.

articleContent: About 30 years ago, Shirley Raines felt lost and looking for meaning after the tragic loss of her toddler son. A friend invited her to feed the homeless, and as female clients complimented her hair and makeup, a light bulb went off.
She offered to bring beauty products whenever she came out, and after weeks of supplying beauty goods for the cisgender and transgender women on the streets, Raines realized this was her purpose.

Sheâ€™s now 52 years old, and three years ago she founded the nonprofit organization Beauty2theStreetz, comprising a team of roughly 20 volunteers who visit the backstreets of Los Angeles â€• and the Skid Row neighborhood, which has one of the largest homeless populations in the nation â€• to provide food, hot water, hygiene products, beauty services and community for those in need.

Raines recognizes that the lack of a home doesnâ€™t mean the lack of humanity, and provides not just basic necessities but the things that make us feel inherently human, like a hot shower and the hope-inducing feeling of looking in the mirror and loving what you see.

As a self-professed â€œhood stylist,â€ Raines has impressive styling skills without any formal cosmetology training, but sheâ€™s made it a point to add licensed cosmetologists to her team. Her twin sister is a licensed makeup artist who volunteers her services alongside licensed stylists and barbers who help with the more technical aspects of hair care, such as cuts and color.

Though she considers her self-taught skills good enough to make people look fabulous, Raines believes the homeless men, women and children she serves should also have access to professional services. And she does her best to offer choices to her clients because choice is something that has often been taken away from them.

Pre-coronavirus, Beauty2theStreetz would serve about 30 clients a day, four days a week, providing hot meals as they waited for their requested styling services and sending clients off with their choice of snacks and clothes before leaving. When government officials urged people to stay home due to the coronavirus pandemic, Raines and her team followed the guidance and ceased operations.

A few of Rainesâ€™ clients were able to access social media and let her know they were hurting without her. Shelters had started accepting fewer residents, leaving more people homeless, and without regular access to news outlets, many were uninformed about the latest COVID-19 developments.

To continue serving the population but reduce risk of contagion, Raines and her team made arrangements to set up at a local McDonaldâ€™s for roughly six hours once a week on Saturdays, still supplying clients with food and styling services but now adding masks, hand sanitizer and general information about the pandemic to their list of options.
When it came to managing the coronavirus in these communities, Raines said, â€œWe quickly understood that when the world said, â€˜Everybody stay in, we got you,â€™ they didnâ€™t mean the homeless.â€

Beauty2theStreetz relies on donations from Patreon subscribers and thousands of followers on Instagram and Twitter. The 600-700 masks Raines distributes each Saturday are either sewn or purchased by social media followers who send them directly to Raines. Makeup brands NYX cosmetics and Thrive cosmetics have been donating makeup for a long time, and ManicPanic and Lâ€™Oreal have supplied hair color. Raines has also received hand sanitizer donations from brands such as Orly, GreenerWays and toothpaste from Bite.

The organization has even caught the attention of celebrities like Miley Cyrus and Brie Larson, who have not only shared Raines on their own Instagram pages but made donations themselves. Though sheâ€™s applied for grants, Raines suspects the reason sheâ€™s never received any is that people donâ€™t view her services as a necessity; but these makeovers, as Raines puts it, are â€œmore than something superficial.â€

Even if some people canâ€™t understand the power of a shower and makeover, Raines is reassured of her impact when she looks at her clients. â€œNothing else is gonna work for you unless you love yourself and feel good about yourself; and this is helping them get to that level of feeling confident and clean enough and beautiful enough to go into a place and put in a job application or go into an establishment and put in a housing application.â€

Just as Rainesâ€™ services bring joy to her clients, they have brought joy to her as well. Raines said clients have eased the process of mourning her son because â€œall the love and care and all the things I have that I canâ€™t give him, I still can give it to other peopleâ€™s kids, as well as my other five living kids. I kind of adopted a whole community and itâ€™s really helped me to find a purpose, find a reason for my pain.â€
As someone whose calling found her by chance, Raines suggests anyone looking to be of service to others should get familiar with their clientele and pay attention to both their needs and their wants.

â€œBeing organic is very important,â€ she said. â€œI would advise you to go out there and take care of the needs, and the wants will organically appear. If youâ€™re gonna be committed to your community, you have to go out there and build the relationships with them. You have to invest that time with them. They have to learn to trust you and you have to get to know them. Thatâ€™s the only way itâ€™s gonna succeed.â€

otherData.headline: White House Pans More COVID-19 Testing Money As Clock Ticks On New Aid Package
otherData.short_description: The first round of coronavirus aid is running out.

articleContent: WASHINGTON (AP) â€” Top Republicans in Congress are expected to meet Monday with President Donald Trump at the White House on the next COVID-19 aid package as the crisis many hoped would have improved has dramatically worsened, just as emergency relief is expiring.

New divisions between the Senate GOP majority and the White House posed fresh challenges. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell was prepared to roll out the $1 trillion package in a matter of days. But administration panned more virus testing money and interjected other priorities that could complicate quick passage.

Trump insisted again Sunday that the virus would â€œdisappear,â€ but the presidentâ€™s view did not at all match projections from the leading health professionals straining to halt the alarming U.S. caseload and death toll.

Lawmakers were returning to a Capitol still off-limits to tourists, another sign of the nationâ€™s difficulty containing the coronavirus. Rather than easing, the pandemicâ€™s devastating cycle was happening all over again, leaving Congress little choice but to engineer another costly rescue. Businesses were shutting down again, schools could not fully reopen and jobs were disappearing, all while federal aid expired.
Without a successful federal strategy, lawmakers are trying to draft one.
â€œItâ€™s not going to magically disappear,â€ said a somber McConnell, R-Ky., last week during a visit to a hospital in his home state to thank front-line workers.
McConnell and House GOP leader Kevin McCarthy were set to meet with Trump and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin â€œto fine-tuneâ€ the legislation, acting chief of staff Mark Meadows said on Fox News.

The political stakes were high for all sides before the November election, but even more so for the nation, which now registered more coronavirus infections and a higher death count of 140,500 than any other country.

The package from McConnell had been quietly crafted behind closed doors for weeks and was expected to include $75 billion to help schools reopen, reduced unemployment benefits alongside a fresh round of direct $1,200 cash payments to Americans, and a sweeping five-year liability shield against coronavirus lawsuits.

But as the White House weighed in, the administration was panning some $25 billion in proposed new funds for testing and tracing, said one Republican familiar with the discussions. The administrationâ€™s objections were first reported by The Washington Post.
Trump was also reviving his push for a payroll tax break, which was being seriously considered, said another Republican. Both spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the private talks.

The new push from the White House put the administration at odds with GOP allies in Congress, a disconnect that threatened to upend an already difficult legislative process. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi already passed Democratsâ€™ vast $3 trillion proposal and virus cases and deaths had only increased since.

Trump raised alarms on Capitol Hill when he suggested last month at a rally in Oklahoma that he wanted to slow virus testing. Some of Trumpâ€™s GOP allies wanted new money to help test and track the virus to contain its spread. Senate Democrats were investigating why the Trump administration had not yet spent some of $25 billion previously allocated for testing in an earlier aid bill.

The payroll tax Trump wanted also divided his party. Senate Republicans in particular opposed the payroll tax break as an insufficient response to millions of out-of-work Americans, especially as they tried to keep the total price tag of the aid package at no more than $1 trillion.
Trump said Sunday in the Fox News interview that he would consider not signing any bill unless it included the payroll tax break, which many GOP senators opposed.
â€œI want to see it,â€ he said.

As McConnell prepared to roll out his $1 trillion-plus proposal, he acknowledged it would not have full support. This would be the fifth virus aid package, after the $2.2 trillion bill passed in March, the largest U.S. intervention of its kind.
The first round of virus aid is running out.
A federal $600-a-week boost to regular unemployment benefits would expire at the end of the month. So, too, would the federal ban on evictions on millions of rental units.
With 17 straight weeks of unemployment claims topping 1 million â€” usually about 200,000 â€” many households were facing a cash crunch and losing employer-backed health insurance coverage.

Despite flickers of an economic upswing as states eased stay-at-home orders in May and June, the jobless rate remained at double digits, higher than it ever was in the last decadeâ€™s Great Recession.

Pelosiâ€™s bill, approved in May, included $75 billion for testing and tracing to try to get a handle on the virus spread, funneled $100 billion to schools to safely reopen and called for $1 trillion to be sent to cash-strapped states to pay essential workers and prevent layoffs. The measure would give cash stipends to Americans, and bolster rental and mortgage and other safety net protections.
In the two months since Pelosiâ€™s bill passed, the U.S. had 50,000 more deaths and 2 million more infections.
â€œIf we donâ€™t invest the money now, it will be much worse,â€ Pelosi said.

otherData.headline: Trader Joe's Says It's Rebranding Some Products After Petition Calls Them Racist
otherData.short_description: The brand claims it decided to repackage products labeled "Trader Ming's," "Trader Giotto's," "Arabian Joe," and more "several years ago," not because of the petition.

articleContent: Trader Joeâ€™s announced that it has been working on repackaging its international food products for â€œseveral yearsâ€ after a widespread petition called out the grocery chain out for their â€œracist branding and packaging.â€
A petition created earlier this month took aim at Trader Joeâ€™s â€œethnic foodsâ€ and noted that they belie â€œa narrative of exoticism that perpetuates harmful stereotypes.â€

â€œFor example, â€˜Trader Mingâ€™sâ€™ is used to brand the chainâ€™s Chinese food, â€˜Arabian Joeâ€™ brands Middle Eastern foods, â€˜Trader JosÃ©â€™ brands Mexican foods, â€˜Trader Giottoâ€™sâ€™ is for Italian food, and â€˜Trader Joe Sanâ€™ brands their Japanese cuisine,â€ reads the petition. â€œThe Trader Joeâ€™s branding is racist because it exoticizes other cultures - it presents â€˜Joeâ€™ as the default â€˜normalâ€™ and the other characters falling outside of it - they are â€˜Arabian Joe,â€™ â€˜Trader JosÃ©,â€™ and â€˜Trader Joe San.â€™â€

The petition also took issue with the chainâ€™s founder, Joe Coulombe, taking â€œinspiration in building the Trader Joeâ€™s brand from a racist book and a controversial theme park attraction, both of which have received criticism for romanticizing Western Imperialism and fetishizing non-Western peoples.â€ The petition points to the chainâ€™s website, which claims Coulombe was inspired by the book â€œWhite Shadows in the South Seasâ€ and the Disneyland Jungle Trip ride.

Spokesperson Kenya Friend-Daniel told NPR on Monday that the brand â€œmade the decision several years ago to use only the Trader Joeâ€™s name on our products moving forwardâ€ and â€œhad hoped that the work would be complete by now but there are still a small number of products going through the packaging change and we expect to be done very soon.â€
Friend-Daniel also told the publication that repackaging had been in progress before the petition and was not in response to it.

She said the controversial approach to naming â€œmay have been rooted in a lighthearted attempt at inclusiveness.â€ However, Friend-Daniel said, â€œwe recognize that it may now have the opposite effect â€” one that is contrary to the welcoming, rewarding customer experience we strive to create every day.â€

In a statement to CBS News, the brand added: â€œWhile this approach to product naming may have been rooted in a lighthearted attempt at inclusiveness, we recognize that it may now have the opposite effect â€” one that is contrary to the welcoming, rewarding customer experience we strive to create every day.â€

While many of the offending product packaging has already been changed, according to the brand, Trader Joeâ€™s also told the publication they plan to finish changing over all packaging â€œvery soon.â€
Trader Joeâ€™s did not respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment.

The chain is one of many who has been faced with reassessing their brandâ€™s racist history and/or marketing. In the wake of the police killing of George Floyd and nationwide protests against racial inequality in America, brands like Aunt Jemima, Uncle Benâ€™s, Cream of Wheat, Mrs. Butterworth, and more have reevaluated their names, mascots and imagery to not perpetuate racism and stereotypes.

otherData.headline: Petition To Rename 'Bloody Sunday' Bridge For John Lewis Nabs Over 460,000 Signatures
otherData.short_description: The Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama, is named after a Confederate general and Ku Klux Klan leader.

articleContent: More than 460,000 signatures appeared as of Sunday on an online petition that calls for putting the name of late Rep. John Lewis on the Selma, Alabama, bridge where police beat civil rights marchers bloody in 1965.

Lewis, who died Friday after a months-long battle with pancreatic cancer, led hundreds of activists across the Edmund Pettus Bridge â€• named for a Confederate general and Ku Klux Klan leader â€• during a civil rights march on March 7, 1965. Police charged at the marchers, beating them with clubs and firing tear gas at them in an incident that became known as â€œBloody Sunday.â€
The John Lewis Bridge Project, launched last month, seeks to rename the bridge that crosses the Alabama River after the civil rights icon and to remove â€œother existing signs of the Confederacy.â€
The death of Lewis â€”a Democrat who represented Georgiaâ€™s 5th Congressional District â€• further ignited support for it.

â€œItâ€™s far past time to rename the Edmund Pettus Bridge after Rep. John Lewis, a civil rights icon that nearly gave his life on that bridge,â€ Michael Starr Hopkins, a political strategist who created the project, said in a statement.

â€œEdmund Pettus was a bitter racist, undeserving of the honor bestowed upon him,â€ Hopkins added. â€œAs we wipe away this countryâ€™s long stain of bigotry, we must also wipe away the names of men like Edmund Pettus.â€
As of Sunday afternoon, the online petition calling for the bridgeâ€™s renaming had garnered more than 460,000 signatures, which was more than 50,000 signatures higher than the previous day.

Several high-profile figures have signed the petition, including Ava DuVernay, who directed the 2014 film â€œSelma,â€ an Oscar-nominated historical drama that centered on the civil rights marches in Alabama.
Rep. Jim Clyburn (D-S.C.) echoed the call to rename the bridge in an interview with NBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Press.â€

â€œI think you ought to take a nice picture of that bridge with Pettusâ€™ name on it, put it in a museum somewhere dedicated to the Confederacy, and then rename that bridge and repaint it, redecorate it: the John R. Lewis Bridge,â€ Clyburn said.

He added: â€œTake his name off that bridge and replace it with a good man â€” John Lewis, the personification of the goodness of America â€” rather than to honor someone who disrespected individual freedoms.â€

Some Selma residents â€” including civil rights activists â€” have voiced reluctance about changing the bridgeâ€™s name. A resolution to rename the structure in 2015 was defeated in the Alabama House of Representatives, The New York Times reported.

â€œAs a daughter of Selma, I understand the complexities surrounding the renaming of the bridge,â€ Rep. Terri Sewell (D-Ala.) told the Times. â€œAnd while I personally can think of no better name than that of John Lewis, I ultimately believe the Selma community should decide who it is named after.â€
